site_title: Section 377A set for repeal has an 800-year history
summary: Singapore's Section 377A, a law criminalizing consensual sex between men, has an 800-year history that began in 1938. Although not actively enforced in recent years, amendments to repeal the law are set to be introduced in Parliament in October.

site_title: Scholz chides climate activists for targeting artworks
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz condemned climate activists for targeting famous artworks, including throwing mashed potatoes at a Claude Monet painting in Potsdam and gluing themselves to a dinosaur skeleton at Berlin's Natural History Museum. Scholz urged the activists to find alternative methods of expression and not to endanger others, citing a reported incident where activists delayed emergency workers from reaching a cyclist who had been run over. The Last Generation environmental protest group denied responsibility for the delay, but expressed hope for the cyclist's condition.

images.alt_text: In Germany, protesters last week threw mashed potatoes over a Claude Monet painting in Potsdam.

site_title: The attack at the Pelosis’ home was part of a dangerous pattern
summary: US Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi's husband, Paul Pelosi, was attacked at their San Francisco home in October 2022, with an intruder shouting "Where is Nancy?" before assaulting the 82-year-old with a hammer. Paul Pelosi required surgery on his skull and right arm. The incident was part of a pattern of partisan violence in the US, highlighting the growing threat of political loathing and its potential to harm innocent people, including politicians' families.

images.alt_text: Police and FBI personnel at the home of US Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi after her husband Paul Pelosi was attacked by a home invader, on Oct 28, 2022.

site_title: Tony Fernandes resigns as acting group CEO of AirAsia X
summary: Tony Fernandes has resigned as acting group CEO of AirAsia X (AAX) with immediate effect, citing a desire to focus on other commitments. Fernandes, who was redesignated as group CEO in July, wants to concentrate on lifting AirAsia X out of a Practice Note 17 (PN17) status, which is given to financially distressed firms. He will continue to focus on delivering value to shareholders of Capital A, the holding company of AirAsia Aviation Group, and has expressed confidence in the airline's growth under the current senior leadership team.

images.alt_text: Mr Tony Fernandes was redesignated group CEO of AAX only in July this year.

site_title: ST HeadSTart: How do I decide what to wear to work? | Full allotment of S'pore Savings Bonds for those who applied for up to $10,000
summary:
Singapore job market shows signs of 'slowing momentum' as retrenchment rises. Employment continued to rise in the third quarter, but the job market recovery is slowing down. 

Those who applied for up to $10,000 worth of the November tranche of the Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) will get their full allotment. The November tranche was 2.4 times subscribed, with a first-year interest rate of 3.08% and a 10-year average rate of 3.21%.

site_title: North Korea demands US, South Korea halt joint military drills
summary: North Korea has demanded that the US and South Korea halt their joint military exercises, calling them a provocation that may lead to "more powerful follow-up measures". The US and South Korea are conducting a large-scale military air drill, Vigilant Storm, which will run until Friday, featuring hundreds of warplanes staging mock attacks. North Korea has condemned the joint drills as a rehearsal for invasion and proof of hostile policies, and has ignored repeated US calls to resume talks over its nuclear and missile programmes.

images.alt_text: South Korean and US soldiers take part in their joint river crossing operation drill in Yeoju, South Korea, on Oct 19, 2022.

site_title: Practical ways to cut their carbon footprint: How the young are learning to play an active role in climate action
summary: Keppel Electric, a Singapore-based company, is launching a program to educate primary and secondary school students about climate change and sustainability. Through its "Powering a Brighter Future" initiative, the company aims to empower students to take action and reduce their carbon footprint. The program includes interactive exhibitions and games that teach students about renewable energy sources, energy-saving tips, and the causes of climate change. With plans to reach 20,000 students in eight schools, Keppel Electric hopes to inspire a new generation to play an active role in climate action and support Singapore's goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Digital trust tools needed amid rising cyber threats; spending on solutions to reach $765b by 2027
summary: Spending on digital trust solutions is expected to double from $385 billion in 2022 to $765 billion globally by 2027, driven by demand for cybersecurity, digital identity services, and cyber insurance. The sector is projected to grow to $4.8 billion in Singapore by 2027, with an accompanying workforce of up to 45,000 people. Rising cybercrimes, privacy violations, and misinformation have made users wary of digital platforms, making digital trust solutions crucial to mitigate these issues.

images.alt_text: Spending on digital trust solutions is expected to double from $385 billion in 2022 to $765 billion globally by 2027.

site_title: From green hydrogen to bioplastics: How investors can identify opportunities in the sustainable economy
summary: Investors can tap into the growing sustainable economy by identifying opportunities in emerging technologies such as green hydrogen, bioplastics, and renewable energy. AXA Investment Managers predicts that green hydrogen could become a key alternative energy source by 2030, with costs expected to fall by 70%. Meanwhile, wind and solar power already account for over 10% of global electricity generation, with investments likely to expand their capacity. Investors can also explore innovations like bioplastics and 3D printing, which have the potential to reduce carbon emissions in various industries.

site_title: Muhyiddin Yassin will need ‘a lot of good fortune’ to return to top job: Analyst
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has announced his intention to run for the top job again in the upcoming 15th general election in November. Analysts predict an uphill battle for him and his Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition, given the challenges they will face. Yassin, 75, has a strong reputation in his home state of Johor, where he first entered politics in 1978. His return to politics may be hindered by his past controversies and the need to regain public trust, making a successful comeback uncertain.

images.alt_text:
zumuh31 - PUTRAJAYA, 26 Okt -- Pengerusi Perikatan Nasional, Tan Sri Muhyiddin Yassin menyampaikan ucapan semasa hadir pada Program Jelajah Prihatin Parlimen Putrajaya malam ini.

--fotoBERNAMA (2022) HAK CIPTA TERPELIHARA

site_title: Elon Musk takes tech deals to another level
summary: Elon Musk's $44 billion acquisition of Twitter marks a significant shift in the tech industry, as he will have absolute control over the platform with 240 million users worldwide. Unlike traditional corporate deals, Musk's takeover was made impulsively and for personal reasons, rather than for financial gain. This move is seen as a demonstration of the growing power of billionaires in the tech industry, with some experts warning of a loss of counterbalance to their influence. Musk's control over Twitter could have far-reaching consequences, potentially leading to improvements in the platform or further erosion of democratic values.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk's photo is seen through a Twitter logo in this illustration taken October 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Redefining the future of banking as a technology company
summary: DBS, a leading technology company, is redefining the future of banking by harnessing emerging technologies such as blockchain, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. The bank has successfully transformed its technology stack to be cloud-native, enabling it to cope with massive demand for digital banking services during the pandemic. DBS has also established blockchain-enabled businesses, including the DBS Digital Exchange and Partior, to disrupt the financial sector. Additionally, the bank is leveraging AI and data analytics to provide personalized experiences for customers, with over 3.5 million customers engaging with hyperpersonalized nudges every month. DBS continues to innovate, with recent partnerships and initiatives in the metaverse and digital twin technology, solidifying its position as a global leader in technology.

site_title: Preparing medical students to lead change in healthcare
summary: Duke-NUS Medical School has developed a unique approach to medical education, focusing on "Clinician First, Clinician Plus" to prepare students for a rapidly changing healthcare landscape. By integrating basic sciences into a single intensive year and incorporating a research and scholarly development period, students develop critical thinking, leadership, and practical doctoring skills. This approach allows students to apply knowledge, conduct research, and address authentic healthcare problems, equipping them to lead change in healthcare. The curriculum is constantly evolving to stay up-to-date with current trends and crises, ensuring students are well-prepared for a dynamic and ever-evolving medical field.

site_title: Investing in staff amid a volatile economy is the best bet for these S’pore firms
summary: Two Singapore-based companies, Ocean Network Express and Vicinity Studio, are reaping benefits from investing in staff retraining and development amidst a volatile economy. Ocean Network Express has invested $1.6 million in staff training, resulting in a 7% annual staff turnover rate and an 83% global employee engagement score. Vicinity Studio, a video production agency, created a roadmap with NTUC's Company Training Committee, resulting in a 69.5% increase in sales revenue and a 45% growth in staff. Both companies attribute their success to retaining and retraining staff, which has led to better engagement, productivity, and outcomes for the businesses.

site_title: Updated road map for hotel industry to upskill workers, drive innovation by 2025
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board has launched a refreshed Hotel Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025, aiming to upskill workers and drive innovation in the hotel industry by 2025. The roadmap includes strategies to transform existing jobs into higher-value roles, increase the adoption of proven technologies, and encourage hotels to adopt sustainability standards. The industry is expected to add a 5.9% compound annual growth rate by 2025, with a focus on emerging roles such as sustainability manager and digital marketing manager.

images.alt_text: Hotels can tap support schemes to groom local staff to take on more senior roles.

site_title: Mammograms: Your best defence in fighting breast cancer
summary: Breast cancer remains the most common cancer affecting women in Singapore, with a high survival rate for stage 1 and stage 2 patients (80-90% over 5 years). Regular mammograms are the most effective way to detect breast cancer early, and women aged 40 and above can benefit from this screening method. However, younger women can monitor themselves through monthly breast self-examinations. If an abnormality is detected, a biopsy will be performed to determine if the lump is cancerous. Treatment methods vary depending on the tumour subtype and extent of spread, but surgery, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, radiation therapy, and hormonal therapy are commonly used. Breast cancer screening and treatment options are available through IHH Healthcare Singapore's Screen for Life subsidies and Integrated Shield Plan.

site_title: Elon Musk, who runs 4 other companies, to become Twitter CEO
summary: Billionaire Elon Musk, owner of Tesla, SpaceX, Neuralink, and The Boring Company, will become the CEO of Twitter after firing CEO Parag Agrawal and top company officials. Musk's takeover of Twitter concluded a months-long saga, with his advisers working on layoffs and product changes. The priorities include trimming the company's ranks and exploring changes to the mobile app. Twitter may charge users $20/month to retain verified status, and Musk has brought in engineers and product leaders from his other companies to aid in the transition.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk previously changed his Twitter bio to “Chief Twit” in a sign alluding to this move.

site_title: Good interpersonal skills and attitude: Hotel industry wants people with passion to create memorable experiences
summary: Singapore's hospitality industry is experiencing a surge in demand for tourism talents as travel rebounds from pandemic lows. Hotels are ramping up hiring efforts, prioritizing candidates with good interpersonal skills, a positive attitude, and customer-centric approach. Employers value individuals with passion to serve and help others, rather than just qualifications. To succeed, jobseekers should assess their career aspirations through identifying their career values, interests, personality, and skills, and utilize resources such as MyCareersFuture and e2i's Tourism Careers Hub to find job matching services.

site_title: BG Lee Yi-Jin appointed SAF’s first Chief of Digital and Intelligence Service
summary: Brigadier-General Lee Yi-Jin, a 42-year-old artillery officer, has been appointed the first Chief of Digital and Intelligence Service (DIS) of the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF). He previously headed contact tracing operations during the pandemic and played a key role in establishing the new service. Lee is expected to be promoted to major-general in 2023 and will concurrently serve as director of Military Intelligence. The DIS will oversee the SAF's digital and intelligence operations, with Brigadier-General Mark Tan taking on the role of Chief of Staff and Military Expert 5 Noh Kok Tiong serving as Chief Expert.

images.alt_text: Brigadier-General Lee Yi-Jin is expected to be promoted to major-general in 2023.

site_title: #PopVultures Podcast: Analysing Kylie Jenner’s ‘climate criminal’ controversy
summary: Kylie Jenner faced criticism for posting a picture of herself with Travis Scott standing between two private jets amidst a climate crisis. The hosts of #PopVultures and Green Pulse podcast discuss the impact of celebrities on the environment through their lifestyles and endorsements. The podcast touches on the debate of single-out celebrities as "climate criminals" and whether they can be helpful in the fight against climate change. The conversation highlights the environmental harm caused by private jets and the importance of greenwashing detection.

images.alt_text: Kylie Jenner recently found herself the subject of much criticism after she posted a picture of herself with her partner Travis Scott standing between two private jets amidst an ongoing climate crisis.

site_title: Premium furnishings, fixtures and high ceilings: Freehold Bukit Timah condo lets you live in luxury
summary: A freehold condominium project in Singapore's District 10, Perfect Ten, has sold out its first tower and received high praise from homebuyers. The twin-tower development features 230 units, ranging from 753 sq ft to 1,281 sq ft, and boasts luxurious finishes, including marble floors and high ceilings. Units were sold at prices ranging from $2.08m to $4.2m, with an average price of $3,000 per sq ft. The development, designed by DP Architects, offers unblocked views of Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and a 50m-long infinity pool, and is expected to be completed in 2029.

site_title: The A-Z of energy transition
summary: Singapore is tackling the climate crisis by transitioning to clean energy sources. The country aims to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 and is exploring various options, including ammonia-fired gas turbines, bioenergy, carbon capture and utilization, and hydrogen fuel. The Energy Market Authority is working with researchers and industry players to develop geothermal, solar, and wind energy, with a focus on distributed energy resources and energy storage systems. Singapore also plans to import low-carbon electricity and nuclear energy, and is investing in electric vehicles and renewable energy technologies.

site_title: How the banking industry is stepping up to keep you safe in a digital world
summary: Banks in Singapore have introduced new measures to protect customers from phishing scams, which remain the main driver of crime in the country. The Association of Banks in Singapore has worked with key players to implement measures such as no clickable links in SMSes or e-mails, lower default thresholds for transaction notifications, notification of change in contact details, cooling-off period for setting up new tokens, and a "kill switch" to freeze accounts. These measures aim to make it more difficult for scammers to dupe their victims and are part of a multi-pronged approach to educating the public on scam prevention, including a quiz and outreach initiatives on social media.

site_title: Putin says power grid strikes in Ukraine were in response to Crimea drone attack
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin said strikes on Ukraine's power grid were a response to a drone attack on Russia's fleet in Crimea. The strikes, which partially knocked out power in Kyiv, were in retaliation for the alleged drone attack, which Putin claimed used the same marine corridors as grain ships under a UN-brokered deal. The incident occurred amid ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine, with both sides exchanging attacks on infrastructure and civilians.

images.alt_text: Kyiv plunged into darkness following a military strike that partially brought down the power infrastructure on Oct 31.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Nov 1
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary:

The US Justice Department charged 42-year-old David DePape with assault and attempted kidnapping for attacking House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband Paul, who underwent surgery for a skull fracture. South Koreans mourned 155 victims of a crowd crush at Seoul's nightlife district, raising questions about poor crowd management and police deployment. US President Joe Biden threatened tax penalties for oil companies that fail to lower costs, following record profits. Taylor Swift made music history by becoming the first artist to claim the entire top 10 on the US song chart with her album "Midnights".

site_title: Morning Briefing: Top stories from The Straits Times on Oct 19
summary:
Top stories from The Straits Times on Oct 19 include: 
Singapore introduces a new URA guideline to curb shoebox units in central Singapore to ensure larger units are built for families. 
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizes the importance of upskilling for economic growth, valuing "hands-on and heart work". 
The Singapore government urges seniors and immuno-compromised individuals to wear masks in crowded indoor settings amid rising Covid-19 infections. 
A home-grown restaurant chain, Ministry of Food, has been declared bankrupt due to a $5.4 million debt. 
Singapore offers help with Australian flood relief efforts, and a charity organization fulfills the last wishes of terminally ill patients.

site_title: Keeping the peace: His clever low-cost solution allows people and snow leopards to co-exist
summary: Dr. Shafqat Hussain, a trained economist and environmental anthropologist, has implemented a low-cost insurance plan in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region to reduce conflicts between farmers and snow leopards. The risk-pooling insurance scheme compensates farmers for livestock lost to the predators, allowing them to rebuild their herds and co-exist with the big cats. Since 2006, Rolex has supported Dr. Hussain's work, expanding his scheme to 22 villages with 15,000 participants. The initiative has helped stabilize the snow leopard population, with conservation efforts now focusing on addressing local people's concerns to ensure conservation success.

site_title: Umno chief Zahid Hamidi could be PM contender if he clears legal hurdle and BN wins big
summary: Umno chief Zahid Hamidi is considered a potential prime minister candidate if he clears legal hurdles and his party wins big in the upcoming general elections. Despite criticisms and corruption charges, Zahid has managed to hold on as Umno chief for over four years, sparking interest in his potential leadership.

images.alt_text: Zahid Hamidi has managed to hold on as Umno chief for over four years despite criticisms.

site_title: Istana open house on Oct 24 to mark Deepavali
summary: The Istana in Singapore will host an open house on October 24 to celebrate Deepavali, a festival of lights. The event will feature dance performances, live band shows, and activities like candle making and balloon sculpting. Visitors can take self-guided or guided tours of the Istana's gardens and main building, with free entry for Singaporeans and permanent residents. An entrance fee of $2 applies to others, with all proceeds from merchandise booths going to charity. The event will be held from 8.30am to 6pm, with the nearest MRT station being Dhoby Ghaut.

site_title: From leadership to problem-solving skills: How e-sports can enhance learning
summary: E-sports is gaining acceptance as an educational tool, with institutions incorporating e-sports programs and clubs to enhance learning. The EDUtech Asia 2022 expo will showcase new tools and trends in teaching and education, including e-sports. Institutions like XCL World Academy have created facilities and programs to support e-sports development, teaching skills such as leadership, teamwork, and problem-solving. The e-sports industry is expected to reach 560 million viewers by the end of the year, comparable to Formula One races. The expo will feature panels, discussions, and a tournament for secondary school students, highlighting the potential of e-sports in education.

site_title: Defence diplomacy key to ending conflict: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasized the importance of state and defence diplomacy in preventing or ending conflict. He noted that the threats and risks of tactical nuclear weapons being deployed are no longer theoretical, and that the world is still grappling with the impact of the pandemic and the invasion of Ukraine. Ng urged the US and China to make progress in their diplomatic initiatives, citing the scarcity of high-level engagements between the two countries as a concern. He also highlighted the role of Singapore's annual Shangri-La Dialogue in increasing mutual understanding and trust, and the need for a strong and relevant Singapore Armed Forces.

site_title: Police report made against ex-footballer Amos Boon for forgery
summary: Former S-League goalkeeper Amos Boon, 50, is under investigation for allegedly forging documents to secure a $300,000 loan. He has filed for bankruptcy with over $759,000 in debt. Boon, a businessman and former football player, claims the Covid-19 pandemic affected his business, leading to his bankruptcy. He previously ran an events company and was director of Launch Group, which was struck off the register in 2021. Boon denies being aware of the police report and is cooperating with the investigation.

site_title: Tech’s biggest companies are sending worrying signals about the economy
summary: Tech giants like Google, Meta, and Microsoft are signaling a slowdown in the economy, with declining profits and reduced hiring. Despite their significant investments, these companies rely heavily on advertising sales, which are cooling off. The industry's growth was fueled by pandemic-era consumer spending, but now, as that spending slows, companies are adjusting. Apple's quarterly report warned of a holiday slowdown, while Microsoft forecast a 30% decline in Windows sales. The slowdown is affecting not only tech companies but also other industries, with semiconductor companies cutting spending and Bitcoin's value plummeting.

images.alt_text: Amid stubborn inflation and rising interest rates, even the biggest giants of Silicon Valley are signalling that tough days may be ahead.

site_title: Govt to invest more in training to help S'poreans excel in their fields
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for Singapore to adopt a twin strategy of attracting top talent and developing its own people to remain competitive. The government will invest more in skills training, focusing on developing Singaporean specialists and leaders across various sectors. Wong noted that while short courses may be sufficient for some, many workers need extensive skills upgrades to stay relevant in changing industries. The government will also review manpower policies and rules to ensure fair employment practices and provide support for displaced workers, nudging them towards active job search and skills development.

site_title: Teen scammed into filming herself with hands, legs bound
summary: A 19-year-old Singaporean girl was scammed into filming herself bound and gagged by a China official impersonator, then forced to transfer $170,000 to a bank account. The scam involved a series of unsolicited calls claiming she had a detained parcel and was involved in money laundering. Authorities tracked her down and arrested a 22-year-old man suspected of involvement. This case is part of a larger trend of China official impersonation scams in Singapore, with 548 cases reported in 2022 resulting in losses of at least $67.9 million.

site_title: Did Germany learn from its Russia trouble? The test may come in China
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is set to visit Beijing, where over 1 million German jobs depend on China. Germany's heavy reliance on Russian gas led to a strategic vulnerability that only became apparent after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Now, concerns arise that Germany may not have fully learned from this experience, as China's increasing tensions in the Taiwan Strait pose a threat to European economic stability. Scholz's visit may test whether Germany will adopt a more cautious approach with China.

images.alt_text: More than one million German jobs depend directly on China, and many more indirectly.

site_title: 9 workers allegedly block Ang Mo Kio building entrance
summary: Nine foreign workers blocked the entrance of NCS Hub in Ang Mo Kio, Singapore, alleging unpaid wages. The workers, aged 28-54, claimed they were owed three months of unpaid salary and used a lorry to block the main entrance. The police received a call for assistance and the workers complied, but no arrests were made. The workers are assisting with investigations into the offence of participating in a public assembly without a permit. The dispute is between the workers and a subcontractor, Zhengda Corporation, which supplied six workers for renovations to the NCS Hub lobby.

site_title: Longer waiting times for bivalent Covid-19 jab at vaccination centres
summary: Singapore sees longer waiting times for the new bivalent Covid-19 jab at vaccination centres, with some people waiting up to an hour. Amid a spike in infections, the number of hospitalised patients increased to 661, and the Ministry of Health expects the current wave to peak at 15,000 daily cases by mid-November. The bivalent vaccine, designed to protect against the original strain and Omicron variant, has seen a significant increase in demand since its launch. Some centres reported waiting times of over two hours, prompting the Health Sciences Authority to consider extending operating hours.

site_title: Sunak, Hunt say ‘inevitable’ all Britons will pay more tax
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government has pledged to restore public finances stability by making all Britons, especially the richest, pay more tax. The government aims to find £40 billion in savings to address the "eye-watering" gap in public finances. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt has agreed that "tough decisions" are needed on tax rises and spending, with experts warning that spending cuts alone are not enough to address the economic challenge.

images.alt_text: The government pledge tens of billions of pounds to help households and businesses cope with surging energy prices this winter.

site_title: Boost for manufacturing, trade sectors
summary: Industry transformation road maps (ITMs) were unveiled, creating at least 13,400 new jobs across sectors including electronics, aerospace, and logistics. The ITMs aim to make manufacturing smarter, greener, and more connected, outlining strategies for sector transformation.

site_title: Armenia and Azerbaijan agree not to use force, stick to peace deals: Report
summary: Armenia and Azerbaijan agreed to not use force and stick to peace deals, following the worst fighting since a 2020 war that killed over 200 people. The leaders of the two countries met in Sochi, Russia, with Russian President Vladimir Putin also attending, and agreed to resolve disputes based on mutual recognition of sovereignty and territorial integrity. The clashes are linked to decades-old hostilities over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region internationally recognized as part of Azerbaijan but controlled by the majority ethnic Armenian population.

images.alt_text: Firefighters work among the ruins of a house, which is said was hit by Azeri shelling during recent border clashes with Azerbaijan, in the settlement of Sotk, Armenia, on September 14, 2022.

site_title: Multi-stakeholder approach can minimise tension spillover into cyberspace: Minister
summary: Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo emphasized the need for a multi-stakeholder approach to create a safe and secure global cyberspace, minimizing tension spillover from geopolitics. US Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas agreed, stressing the importance of collaboration between governments, industry, academia, and the private sector to address evolving cyber threats. The Russia-Ukraine conflict has heightened divisions, making international consensus harder to achieve, while hackers continue to grow in sophistication and scope in their attacks, posing a threat to global security and individual freedoms.

site_title: NUS Medicine study finds five factors that increase the odds of ageing well
summary: A study by the Singaporean Chinese Health Study, involving over 14,000 Chinese Singaporeans, found that five lifestyle factors can increase the odds of ageing well. These factors include regular exercise, a plant-based diet, a healthy body mass index, not smoking, and limiting alcohol intake. The study found that individuals who adopted more of these healthy lifestyle factors by age 66 had a 18% improved odds of ageing healthily by age 74. The researchers emphasize the importance of a healthy lifestyle in maintaining quality of life for the ageing population, particularly in Singapore, where 10 years of life are often spent in poor health.

site_title: Man locked ex-girlfriend's fiance inside flat
summary: A 30-year-old man, Surenthiran Sugumaran, pleaded guilty to locking his ex-girlfriend's fiancé, Mohammad Azli Mohammad Salleh, inside their flat on their wedding day. Fueled by jealousy, Surenthiran set a fire outside the unit, causing inconvenience and potential harm. He used petrol and a bicycle lock to secure the gate, and wore a black hoodie to conceal his face. The court sentenced him to a six to nine-month jail term, citing premeditation and malicious intent to intimidate the victim.

site_title: Parents told that students can keep masks on for exams
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Education advises students to wear face masks during national examinations due to rising Covid-19 infections, primarily driven by the XBB sub-variant. Parents are encouraged to inform schools if their children test positive before or during exams. Schools will maintain good practices, including wiping down surfaces and visual screening of students' well-being. Parents are taking precautions, such as wearing masks and washing hands, to minimize cross-infection. The situation will be closely monitored and updated as needed.

site_title: ST editor Warren Fernandez to join Edelman as its Asia-Pacific CEO
summary: ST editor Warren Fernandez, 56, will join Edelman as its Asia-Pacific CEO on Oct 25, replacing Stephen Kehoe. Fernandez will oversee 1,300 employees across 21 offices in the region. He takes the role after leaving SPH Media Group, where he was editor-in-chief of The Straits Times and English/Malay/Tamil Media Group. Fernandez's experience in transforming a news outlet into an integrated multimedia platform is seen as an asset to Edelman clients and capabilities. He will be based in Singapore and report to global president and COO Matthew Harrington.

site_title: Indian community's efforts helped lighten Covid-19 gloom: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam has praised the Indian community's efforts in supporting each other during the COVID-19 pandemic. A video, "Light Of Hope," was launched to showcase the community's tenacity through real-life stories and an original song. Despite muted celebrations in the past two years, the community has continued to hold cultural and religious events, and this year's festivities promise to return to normal. Shanmugam noted the community's unity and support for organizations like the Singapore Indian Development Association, which helped more students and underprivileged families than before.

site_title: Welcome to the world of the polycrisis
summary: The world is experiencing a "polycrisis," a situation where multiple, disparate shocks interact to create a worse outcome than the sum of the individual problems. These shocks include the pandemic, drought, floods, mega storms, wildfires, and the threat of a third world war. Former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers described this situation as the most complex and cross-cutting set of challenges in his 40-year career, highlighting the need for a comprehensive approach to address the interconnected nature of these crises.

images.alt_text: A partially dried-up river bed of the Gan River during a drought in Nanchang, China's Jiangxi province, in August.

site_title: Cop's death: Driver had wine but passed breathalyser test
summary: A 54-year-old American, Andrew Charles Vasko, is on trial for causing the death of Staff Sergeant Salinah Mohamed, 40, in a car accident in Singapore in 2019. Vasko consumed two glasses of white wine before the accident, but passed a breathalyzer test. He allegedly failed to keep a lookout while driving and struck Mohamed, who died four days later from a head injury. Vasko's lawyers have made an application for him to travel overseas, which was granted, and he is now out on $10,000 bail until his trial resumes on November 16.

site_title: Overcrowded Schiphol to extend passenger compensation
summary: Schiphol Airport, one of Europe's busiest, is extending its passenger compensation scheme for travelers who missed flights due to long wait times. The scheme, which originally ran until August 11, will now apply from August 12 to October 31, covering costs for rebooking, replacement flights, or additional travel expenses. The extension comes after the airport implemented measures to address staff shortages, including reducing daily passenger numbers by over 9,000 and investing 100 million euros in staff recruitment efforts. Passengers have until November 30 to submit their claims.

images.alt_text: Passengers at Schiphol have been confronted with huge lines sometimes lasting hours.

site_title: ST Full-time Report: SNOC fines Schooling for breaching conduct rules | National Stadium unavailable for Lions
summary: The Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) fined Olympic champion Joseph Schooling, Amanda Lim, and Teong Tzen Wei $2,800 to $10,000 for breaching conduct rules. The trio also received conditional warnings after admitting to consuming illicit drugs. Meanwhile, the National Stadium will be unavailable for the Lions' game against Myanmar due to the Jay Chou concerts scheduled for the same time. World Cup rights holders in Singapore face challenges in recouping the estimated $25 million rights fee due to the late announcement and unique timing of the tournament.

site_title: Questions raised about lax crowd control as South Koreans mourn crowd crush tragedy
summary: South Korea mourns the deaths of 155 people in a crowd crush at Seoul's nightlife district Itaewon during Halloween festivities. Questions are raised about poor crowd management and insufficient police deployment, which may have contributed to the disaster. President Yoon Suk-yeol has ordered the government to develop a crowd management system for similar events, and a thorough investigation is underway. The police have formed a special investigation team and interviewed 44 eyewitnesses, but no criminal acts have been detected. The government and businesses in Itaewon are taking steps to prevent similar accidents, including cancelling events and providing support to affected merchants.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Oct 31
summary: At least 68 people were killed and dozens critically injured when a suspension bridge in India's Gujarat state collapsed, with children among the victims. In South Korea, a crowd crush in Seoul's Itaewon district killed over 150 people, described as a "perfect storm" of human congestion and unique layout. A man attacked a migrant processing centre in the UK, killing himself after throwing petrol bombs, while three men were injured in an attack on a pro-democracy vigil outside the Iranian embassy in Berlin. Manchester United secured a 1-0 win over West Ham United in the Premier League.

site_title: GIC to co-invest in Blackstone’s $19.8 billion deal to take control of US climate tech unit
summary: Emerson Electric will sell a majority stake in its climate technologies unit to Blackstone in a deal valued at $14 billion, with Blackstone and co-investors contributing $4.4 billion in equity and $5.5 billion in debt financing. Emerson will retain a 45% stake and receive an upfront payment of $9.5 billion. The deal values the unit at 12.7 times its cash flow in fiscal 2022, a premium to peers. Emerson plans to use proceeds to invest in automation-related businesses and spend $2 billion on share repurchases in 2023.

images.alt_text: Sovereign wealth fund GIC manages Singapore's foreign reserves.

site_title: FairPrice offers 15% discount on three rice products until Nov 9
summary: FairPrice is offering a 15% discount on three rice products - SongHe AAA Thai Hom Mali Rice, FairPrice Thai Brown Unpolished Rice, and Double FP Thai Hom Mali Premium Quality Fragrant Rice - until November 9. The discounted prices are $14.35 for the 5kg SongHe rice, $9.50 for the 5kg FairPrice brown rice, and $19.90 for the 10kg Double FP rice. This promotion aims to reduce the effects of inflation on daily essentials and moderate the cost of living, as stated by FairPrice Group's CEO, Vipul Chawla.

images.alt_text: Customer will be able to buy up to four bags of the rice at the discounted prices.

site_title: A Cartoonist’s View: Lee Chee Chew, Nov 1, 2022
summary: A Singaporean cartoonist, Lee Chee Chew, has been detained under the Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act for his caricatures of a Muslim leader. The caricatures were deemed insulting and offensive by the Muslim community. The cartoonist was arrested on October 31, 2022, and released on bail the same day. His case has raised concerns about freedom of expression and the limits of blasphemy laws in Singapore. The incident has sparked debate about the balance between protecting religious sentiments and preserving artistic freedom. The outcome of the case remains uncertain.

site_title: Instagram fixes bug that triggered hours-long outage
summary: Instagram has fixed a software bug that caused a 8-hour outage, affecting thousands of users worldwide. The outage led to reports of accounts being suspended, with some users being asked for email IDs and phone numbers to access their accounts. The issue was resolved after 7,500 reports were filed on outage-tracking website Downdetector, with the number of reports declining to nearly 500 by 6pm. Meta-owned Instagram did not comment on the suspension of accounts, and the outage occurred amid a wider sell-off in stock markets, with Meta's shares closing down 6.1%.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for Instagram did not comment on suspension of accounts.

site_title: Malaysia’s next PM: A race to the top
summary: Malaysia is set to hold its next general election, with three main national alliances - Barisan Nasional (BN), Pakatan Harapan (PH), and Perikatan Nasional (PN) - fielding their prime ministerial candidates. Umno president Zahid Hamidi, who chairs BN, is a dark horse contender despite facing corruption charges. Former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is also vying for the top job, but analysts say it will be an uphill battle for him and his PN coalition. Anwar Ibrahim, the opposition leader, will mark his final bid for premiership after being blocked by imprisonment and party politics.

site_title: England orders all poultry and captive birds to be kept indoors
summary: The UK government has ordered all poultry and captive birds in England to be kept indoors starting November 7 to contain a devastating outbreak of avian influenza. This measure aims to prevent the spread of the disease, which has already killed millions of wild birds and millions of birds culled across Europe. The confinement policy applies only to England, and other parts of the UK will set their own health policies. Authorities hope to protect the supply of Christmas turkeys and emphasize the importance of biosecurity measures to prevent the spread of the disease.

images.alt_text: Millions of wild birds have been killed by the current outbreak of avian flu.

site_title: S'pore and EU ink deal to work on safety rules for flying taxis, drones
summary: Singapore and the European Union have signed an agreement to collaborate on safety rules for flying taxis and drones, marking the first transnational agreement on urban air mobility for Singapore. The deal aims to establish certification standards and harmonized safety certificates for flying taxis and drones, with the goal of making widespread use a reality by 2024. The partnership also seeks to develop public outreach strategies and co-organize conferences on urban air mobility. The EU was the first to publish drone regulations in 2019 and has also completed guidance for vertiport design.

site_title: Singapore’s 4th egg farm, backed by Japan’s top egg producer, to operate from 2024
summary: Singapore's fourth egg farm, backed by Japan's top egg producer Ise Foods Holdings, is set to increase the country's egg production capacity to meet about half of the demand for eggs. The $100 million farm, expected to start operations in 2024, will produce 360 million eggs annually and contribute to Singapore's target of meeting 30% of its nutritional needs with local production by 2030. The farm will incorporate sustainable practices, including AI-powered image recognition and renewable energy sources, to improve efficiency and reduce environmental impact.

images.alt_text: The move is set to increase the capacity of Singapore’s egg industry to collectively meet about half of Singapore’s demand for eggs.

site_title: Loyang Valley condominium in Changi up for collective sale at $980m
summary: Loyang Valley, a 362-unit condominium in Changi, is up for collective sale at a reserve price of $980 million. The site, zoned for residential use, has 59 years left on its lease and can yield approximately 1.35 million sq ft of gross floor area upon redevelopment. The owners of two-bedroom units can expect an average payout of $1.86 million, while those of four-bedroom units can get up to $4.35 million each. The collective sale comes after a previous attempt in 2018 failed to garner sufficient support, with the new reserve price seen as more attractive due to the upcoming Loyang MRT station.

site_title: Anwar Ibrahim’s last bid at premiership
summary: Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's opposition leader, is set to make his final bid for the prime ministership in the upcoming general election. Ibrahim, 75, has been on track to become prime minister since 1993 but was jailed for corruption in 1999, dimming his prospects. His journey to the top has been marked by repeated setbacks, earning him the phrase "always a bridesmaid, never the bride." Ibrahim's appointment as deputy prime minister under Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad's government in 1993 was his last major opportunity, and this election may be his final chance.

images.alt_text: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's opposition leader, speaks at the Pakatan Harapan (PH) Convention at the Ipoh International Convention Centre in Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia, on Thursday, Oct. 20, 2022. Malaysia will hold elections on Nov. 19 with Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob's party looking to capitalize on a string of victories from local polls and consolidate power in the Southeast Asian country. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

site_title: Our Better Nature video series: Accelerating Singapore’s electric vehicle drive
summary: Singapore aims to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles by 2040, with a focus on electrifying vehicles to reduce emissions. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to have 60,000 EV charging points by 2030, with every Housing Board town becoming an EV-ready town. The country's comprehensive public transport network and cycling initiatives have helped reduce private vehicle ownership, but vehicles still contribute about 15% of the nation's emissions. An electric vehicle emits half the carbon dioxide of a similar internal combustion engine vehicle, making EV adoption a key part of Singapore's climate change strategy.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore and Australia signed a green economy agreement, targeting 17 joint initiatives in areas such as sustainable agriculture and green shipping corridors. Overseas Chinese students worldwide have taken up protests against China's strict Covid-19 policy, displaying posters with slogans. Karim Benzema won the Ballon d'Or award at 34, the oldest winner since 1956. A charity, Ambulance Wish Singapore, has granted over 100 wishes for terminally ill patients, including an 81-year-old woman with breast cancer.

site_title: Wall Street ends strong month on weaker note; focus on Fed meeting
summary: US stocks closed down on Monday, ending a strong month of gains, as investors focus on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week. The Dow booked its biggest monthly percentage gain since 1976, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also posted significant gains. Investors expect the Fed to raise interest rates by 75 basis points, but are looking for signals that the central bank may slow down its aggressive interest rate hike policy. Market expectations for future hikes will be shaped by comments from Fed officials and labor market data later this week.

images.alt_text: The Dow booked its biggest monthly percentage gain since January 1976.

site_title: Chinese developer Greenland says likely to default on bond
summary: Chinese developer Greenland Holding Group is likely to default on a US$362 million US dollar bond due November 13, citing financial struggles due to the Covid-19 situation in Shanghai and negative market conditions. The company's sales and operations have declined, affecting its cash flow and liquidity. Greenland is also seeking to extend the maturity of other bonds by two years. The development threatens to exacerbate China's junk dollar bond market's worst-ever month in October, with losses of about 11%.

images.alt_text: China’s junk dollar bond market has just suffered one of its worst ever months with losses of about 11 per cent in October.

site_title: Why (digital) banking should be a family affair again
summary: Visits to the bank were a regular practice for the author as a child. The family would go to a bank branch together, with bank passbooks and cash for the month. This traditional banking approach has been revived as new digital banking features emerge, highlighting the need for a more secure and family-oriented approach to banking in the face of increasing cyber threats.

images.alt_text: With more new banking features, more cyber threats appear on the horizon.

site_title: Australian PM to rein in energy prices that are soaring despite abundant supply
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is facing pressure to address soaring energy prices despite the country's abundant gas and coal supply. The Labor government had promised to cut household power bills by A$275 per year within three years, but now expects electricity prices to rise 56% over the next two years. This contradicts the government's previous commitment, and Albanese must address the issue to maintain public trust.

images.alt_text: According to Australian government data, coal exports were worth A$63.5 billion in 2021.

site_title: SSB, T-bill and fixed deposits: How to maximise your savings with low-risk tools
summary: Singaporeans are seeking low-risk investment options amid rising inflation and interest rates. The Monetary Authority of Singapore data shows record highs for Singapore Savings Bonds, with a first-year interest rate of 3.08% and a 10-year average return of 3.21%. Other low-risk investment vehicles include T-bills, SGS bonds, fixed deposits, savings plans, savings accounts, cash management accounts, and money market funds. Experts recommend diversifying portfolios to fight inflation and taking into account liquidity, risk, and return on investment when choosing a product.

images.alt_text: Low risk tools can help to maximise savings amid high inflation

site_title: Ismail Sabri Yaakob’s biggest obstacle is his own party Umno
summary: Umno vice-president Ismail Sabri Yaakob faces his biggest challenge in his bid to become prime minister again, as he navigates a power struggle with party president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi. After being sworn in as prime minister in 2021, Ismail's tenure was marked by a general election forced by Zahid, despite Ismail's efforts to delay it. The next general election, originally scheduled for mid-2023, is now uncertain due to the ongoing power struggle, which may impact Ismail's chances of returning to the post.

site_title: Singapore, Australia sign landmark pact on green economy
summary: Singapore and Australia have signed a landmark agreement to intensify cooperation in the green economy, aiming to reduce emissions, promote sustainable agriculture, and develop zero-emission sea routes. The 17 joint initiatives include reducing tariff barriers for green goods, promoting research collaboration, and fostering business engagements in green sectors. The agreement supports both countries' transition to net-zero emissions and aims to create jobs and boost growth in the green sectors.

site_title: Two new F&B outlets to open at emerging lifestyle hub
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has awarded tenders to two new tenants, Wheeler's Estate and The Blackbird, to join the emerging lifestyle hub at Gillman Barracks. Wheeler's Estate will offer cyclist-friendly activities, while The Blackbird will feature live music and events. Current tenants, including Creamier Handcrafted Ice Cream and Coffee, Hopscotch, and Handlebar, will also stay and introduce new offerings and green initiatives. The SLA plans to introduce more lifestyle concepts, including artisanal craft, fitness, and wellness spaces, through future tenders.

site_title: S'pore representative office in Ramallah inaugurated
summary: Singapore has opened a new representative office in Ramallah, a key milestone in ties with the Palestinian Authority, aiming to strengthen links and facilitate capacity-building efforts. The office's opening was inaugurated by Minister Maliki Osman, who expressed hope that the move would lead to stronger ties between Singapore and the Palestinians. The office is part of a $10 million Enhanced Technical Assistance Package (ETAP) to support the PA's capacity-building efforts, with over 600 officials participating in courses since its inception.

site_title: Football: France forward Martial back in United team training after injury
summary: Manchester United forward Anthony Martial returned to team training after missing six games due to a back injury sustained during a league win at Everton on October 9. The 26-year-old will aim to return for the final Europa League group game against Real Sociedad on Thursday, with United needing four games to complete before the World Cup begins on November 20. Martial has scored three goals and two assists this season, and his return could be timely for the team.

images.alt_text: Manchester United's Anthony Martial celebrates scoring their second goal on Oct 6, 2022.

site_title: Raffles Medical’s Q3 profit rises by over 60% to $38.3m
summary: Raffles Medical, a private healthcare provider in Singapore, reported a 60% year-on-year increase in Q3 net profit to $38.3 million, driven by the return of foreign patients and a surge in elective surgeries among locals. Revenue rose 6.5% to $199.5 million and 9.6% to $581.8 million for the year to date. The group attributes its performance to better cost control and reduced inventories. Despite expected inflationary pressures and rising interest rates, Raffles Medical expects to remain profitable for the rest of 2022.

images.alt_text: People seen queueing outside a Raffles Medical clinic along Bishan Street 22 on Feb 24, 2022.

site_title: Asean needs to take hard decisions on Myanmar
summary: ASEAN leaders are unlikely to make significant progress on Myanmar at their upcoming summit, given the ongoing violence and lack of dialogue among internal parties. A special meeting of Asean foreign ministers last week expressed concern and disappointment, but no concrete actions were agreed upon. Despite this, Asean intends to engage with opponents of the junta, as part of a unanimous agreement to strengthen its peace initiative with "concrete, practical and time-bound actions". ASEAN's efforts have been thwarted so far, but Indonesia, set to assume chairmanship, is committed to taking a more active role.

site_title: Mother gets life in jail instead of death penalty
summary: A 5-year-old boy died from scald injuries after being repeatedly splashed with hot water by his mother, Azlin Arujunah, and her husband, Ridzuan Mega Abdul Rahman. Azlin was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder, while Ridzuan received life imprisonment with no caning. The Court of Appeal rejected the death penalty, stating that Azlin did not comprehend the fatal consequences of her actions. The court emphasized that the death penalty requires a "blatant disregard for human life," which was not present in this case.

site_title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro silent on Lula election victory until Tuesday
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro has refused to publicly address his defeat in the presidential election until Tuesday, amid doubts over whether he will accept the victory of his leftist rival Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Pro-Bolsonaro truckers have set up roadblocks throughout the country, protesting Lula's return to power, with some calling for a military coup. The protests have not yet disrupted grain shipments, but agricultural lobbies warn they may affect exports. Bolsonaro's allies urge him to concede defeat, while his former minister calls congratulating Lula a part of democracy.

images.alt_text: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro has barely been seen since Oct 30, 2022.

site_title: Paul Pelosi attack suspect sought to take Speaker hostage with intention to break her kneecaps
summary: A 42-year-old suspect, David Wayne DePape, has been charged with assault and attempted kidnapping in the attack on US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband, Paul Pelosi, at their San Francisco home. DePape threatened to take Pelosi hostage and break her kneecaps if she lied under questioning. Pelosi, 82, was hospitalized with skull fractures and injuries after DePape was subdued by police. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, but online messages linked to DePape expressed support for former President Donald Trump and QAnon conspiracy theories.

images.alt_text: Police have not offered a motive for the assault.

site_title: Malaysia election: Which PM candidate can win a strong mandate?
summary: Malaysia's 15th General Election is expected to be a tight race, with no coalition likely to win an outright majority. For the first time, there are three prime ministerial candidates: Barisan Nasional (BN), Pakatan Harapan (PH), and Perikatan Nasional (PN). The election is set to take place on November 19, and the outcome will determine the country's leadership. The election's outcome is uncertain, with all three alliances vying for a strong mandate.

site_title: Football: Two sentenced over Champions League violence
summary: Two men were sentenced to jail for throwing bottles at security forces during the Champions League final in Paris on May 28. The defendants, both in their twenties, received 15 months and 12 months suspended imprisonment for aggravated violence. The incident was part of a larger security breach that marred the game, with French authorities and UEFA blamed for a lack of preparation and poorly-executed security arrangements. The investigation, aided by video surveillance, led to 240 complaints, and the incident caused a diplomatic headache for France. The sentence was handed down in November 2022.

images.alt_text: Before the game, they threw bottles at security forces.

site_title: From home and car loans to investing: How you can benefit by going green
summary: Singapore has introduced various schemes to encourage sustainable living, including reduced road tax for electric vehicles (EVs) and rebates for EV owners. UOB offers incentives for eco-friendly practices, such as the UOB EVOL credit card and sustainable home loan options. Sustainable investing is also gaining momentum, with UOB's Risk-First Approach considering environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment decisions. As the climate crisis worsens, individuals can make a difference by adopting sustainable habits and investing in eco-friendly companies.

images.alt_text: Electric vehicles

site_title: Taylor Swift makes US song charts history with Midnights
summary: Taylor Swift made music history by becoming the first artist to simultaneously occupy all 10 spots on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart with her album Midnights. The album also debuted at the top of the Billboard top albums chart, with the biggest week for a release since 2015. Swift's 13 songs tell the story of 13 sleepless nights and mark her return to pop after two pandemic albums. The album's release crashed Spotify for hours, but set a record for the most-streamed album in a day. Swift has also released two re-recorded albums so far.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 28, 2022 American singer-songwritter Taylor Swift poses at the red carpet during 2022 MTV Video Music Awards at the Prudential Center in Newark, New Jersey. - Taylor Swift made music history October 31, 2022, becoming the first artist ever to simultaneously nab all ten of the top US song chart's spots after the release of her album "Midnights." (Photo by Andres KUDACKI / AFP)

site_title: Norway raises military alert in response to Ukraine war
summary: Norway has raised its military alert level in response to the ongoing war in Ukraine, with the measure expected to last a year or possibly more. The country's chief of defence, General Eirik Kristoffersen, cited "uncertainties" and the escalation of the war, as well as recent incidents such as a gas explosion and drone activity, as factors in the decision. Norway has been training Ukrainian forces and protecting its own gas exports, which are vital to Europe's energy supplies this winter. The raised alert level will see the armed forces spend more time on operational duties.

images.alt_text: The raised level is expected to last a year, “possibly more”, said Norway's chief of defence.

site_title: Global WhatsApp outage lasted 2 hours, thousands of users in S’pore affected
summary: WhatsApp experienced a 2-hour global outage, affecting over 20,000 users in Singapore and millions worldwide. Users could not send or receive messages on the Meta-owned platform, forcing them to switch to alternatives like Telegram. The service was restored around 5pm in Singapore. Meta apologized for the inconvenience and did not explain the cause of the disruption. The outage was similar to a 2021 Facebook outage that affected 2.7 billion users, raising concerns about the reliability of messaging services, particularly for those with limited technical expertise.

images.alt_text: More than 20,000 users in Singapore reported failure to send and receive messages.

site_title: Worrying trends as Israel heads into another general election
summary: Israel is set to hold its fifth general election in four years, with polls predicting an inconclusive result. Extreme anti-Arab politicians are gaining ground, adding to the country's political instability. The centre-right camp, led by former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and the centre-left camp, led by current Prime Minister Yair Lapid, are unlikely to secure a parliamentary majority. The election's outcome is seen as a repeat of past results, with both camps struggling to form a stable government, raising concerns about the country's political future.

images.alt_text: An Israeli soldier casts their ballot for the general elections at a military base in the city of Ashdod, on Oct 30, 2022.

site_title: Singapore approves Pfizer bivalent jab for those aged 12 and above
summary: Singapore has granted interim authorisation for Pfizer-BioNTech's bivalent Covid-19 vaccine for individuals aged 12 and above. The vaccine targets both the original strain and the Omicron BA.4 and BA.5 variants. Based on a previous study showing promising results, the Health Sciences Authority approved the vaccine as a booster jab, with the Expert Committee on Covid-19 Vaccination and Ministry of Health expected to issue official recommendations. The vaccine is available now, with side effects similar to the original vaccine, and is expected to be made widely available by the end of this year.

images.alt_text: The bivalent vaccine targets both the original strain of the coronavirus and the Omicron BA.4 and BA.5 variants.

site_title: Man arrested for suspected drink driving after running red light, colliding with bike
summary: A 32-year-old BMW driver was arrested for suspected drink-driving after running a red light and colliding with a 31-year-old e-bike rider in Sembawang, Singapore. The accident occurred at 12:05am and the victim was taken to Khoo Teck Puat Hospital. The e-bike rider, who was working for an unknown food delivery company, suffered injuries. Investigations are ongoing. This incident marks a decline in drink-driving accidents, with 71 reported in the first half of the year compared to 78 last year.

images.alt_text: The scene of the accident at the junction of Sembawang Road and Canberra Road in the wee hours of Wednesday morning. Two men were conveyed to Khoo Teck Puat Hospital while conscious, with the 32-year-old driver of the BMW subsequently arrested for suspected drink driving.

site_title: Stopping Alex Jones and the lucrative industry of lies
summary: A Connecticut jury ordered Alex Jones to pay US$965 million in damages to several families for his defamation claims, stemming from his lies about the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. Jones' statements falsely suggested parents of victims were actors in a government plot. This verdict adds to a previous US$49 million award to another Sandy Hook family. The damages aim to compensate for Jones' egregious cruelty, including threats against the families and one family's need to relocate due to the harassment.

images.alt_text: A Connecticut jury has ordered Alex Jones to pay US$965 million (S$1.37 billion) in damages to several families for his egregious cruelty.

site_title: Biden threatens tax hit for oil majors that fail to lower prices
summary: US President Joe Biden threatens tax penalties for oil companies that fail to lower prices, citing record profits. The comments come as oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported bumper earnings, boosting the industry amid the Russia-Ukraine invasion. Biden says companies have a responsibility to act beyond executive shareholders' interests and help consumers by raising production and refining capacity. If they don't, they'll face higher taxes and restrictions. The issue is a sensitive one for American voters ahead of the midterm elections, with persistently high inflation squeezing families and driving concerns about negative economic issues.

images.alt_text: Higher gasoline prices are a sensitive issue for American voters as midterm elections draw close.

site_title: Ministry of Food founder declared bankrupt over $5.4 million debt
summary: The Ministry of Food founder, Lena Sim, was declared bankrupt by the Singapore High Court on October 13 over a debt of approximately US$3.8 million (S$5.4 million). The debt was incurred by her life partner Ting Choon Meng's company, Blue-link Properties Offshore Limited. Sim acted as a personal guarantor for the US$5 million loan.

site_title: Singapore stocks snap 8-day losing streak, ending 0.3% up
summary: Singapore stocks ended a 8-day losing streak, rising 0.3% to close at 3,025.88 on Tuesday, driven by positive developments in the UK's economic policy. Regional markets also rallied, with Bursa Malaysia, Hang Seng, and Nikkei indices gaining 1%, 1.8%, and 1.4% respectively. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC rose 0.3%, 0.7%, and 1% respectively. Analysts attribute the rally to improved risk environment, with Yeap Jun Rong stating that the UK's policy changes could bring a positive impact on the broader risk environment.

site_title: Initiatives skill up workers in SMEs and manufacturing sector
summary: Singapore Polytechnic's Company and Workforce Transformation programme is upskilling workers in SMEs and the manufacturing sector through digital transformation initiatives. The programme, part of the polytechnic's efforts to support SMEs in the digital age, provides guidance on process redesign, data intelligence, and human capital management. Companies like Fire Armour and GlobalFoundries have benefited from similar retraining programmes, leading to improved operations efficiency and attractive career options for Singaporeans. The initiatives aim to adapt workers to changing job scopes and create opportunities for growth and development in the industry.

site_title: Class 4 sprint shaping up to be a sizzler
summary: Shanghai Star and Street Of Dreams, two contenders in the upcoming Class 4 $50,000 sprint, are expected to face off on Saturday. Shanghai Star, trained by Shane Baertschiger, finished second in a similar race on Oct 2 and has shed his maiden status. Street Of Dreams, a four-year-old Australian-bred, won his previous start on Oct 2, and his trainer Steven Burridge is confident he will win again. The race is set to take place on the turf over 1,400m.

site_title: Team wins defence tech prize for breakthrough in shelf life of platelets which can save lives
summary: A team from Singapore's Army Medical Service and DSO National Laboratories has won the annual Defence Technology Prize for extending the shelf life of platelets from one week to two years, making it possible to freeze them for up to two years. This breakthrough could save lives in medical emergencies and military operations, particularly for soldiers with excessive bleeding. The research process took five to six years and culminated in successful clinical trials, paving the way for the usage of frozen platelets in military operations and humanitarian aid missions.

images.alt_text: From left: MAJ (Dr) Jasper Wang, DSO National Laboratories programme director Associate Prof Lu Jia (pink), HSA Blood Services Group assistant group director Dr Tan Hwee Huang (brown) and SGH Haematology Department senior consultant Dr Ang Ai Leen (black white pattern) at their exhibition booth during the Defence Tech Prize (DTP) Awards ceremony held at the DSTA Auditorium, 20 Oct 2022. The four were part of a team  that developed a method to cryogenically preserve blood platelets to increase its shelf life.

site_title: Company briefs: Microsoft Softbank Group Hybe
summary: Microsoft laid off under 1,000 employees, affecting less than 1% of its workforce, amid a global economic slowdown. Softbank Group is selling its £36 million stake in British online shopping company THG, marking the end of a disastrous investment. Meanwhile, Hybe Co, the management group of K-pop band BTS, saw its shares rise 7.8% after its seven members announced mandatory military service in South Korea, clearing uncertainty over their plans and paving the way for their potential return in 2025.

site_title: Handbook for manufacturing to help draw, retain talent
summary: Singapore has launched a handbook to help manufacturing companies, especially smaller ones, attract and retain skilled workers. The handbook, developed by the Singapore Precision Engineering and Technology Association and the Institute of Human Resource Professionals, aims to address the record number of unfilled skilled jobs in the sector. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for companies to upskill existing workers and adopt progressive human resource strategies to support business growth. The initiative is part of Singapore's plan to reinvigorate its manufacturing hub with advanced technologies.

site_title: Updated road maps for manufacturing, trade to add 13,400 jobs
summary: Singapore has unveiled refreshed industry transformation maps (ITMs) for five advanced manufacturing and trade clusters, aiming to create at least 13,400 new jobs. The ITMs support research and development, innovation, and sustainability across various sectors, including electronics, precision engineering, and energy. The move is expected to spur the creation of good jobs for Singaporeans, with a focus on Industry 4.0, tech, and sustainability skills. The ITMs are part of Singapore's goal to grow manufacturing value-added by 50% from 2020 to 2030, with the sectors contributing 80% of the country's annual manufacturing output.

site_title: Upskilling key to boosting value of hands-on, care work: Economists
summary: Singapore's economy undervalues hands-on care work, with a focus on cognitive abilities. Economists emphasize the importance of upskilling to boost the value of care workers, including those in technical, service, and community care roles. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong acknowledged the issue, stating that the country needs to better value the contributions of those engaged in "hands-on and heart work". Upskilling can help shift societal perception and increase the economic value of care work, ultimately benefiting society as a whole. This shift is crucial for a more inclusive and equitable economy.

site_title: New URA guideline to curb shoebox units in central area
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has introduced a new guideline to curb the proliferation of shoebox units in the central area, requiring a minimum of 20% of dwelling units to have a nett internal area of at least 70 sq m. This move aims to ensure a good mix of unit sizes to attract more families to live in the area. The guideline, effective from Jan 18, 2023, aims to address declining dwelling unit sizes in the central area, which conflict with the URA's planning intent.

site_title: SIA and Scoot carry 2.1m passengers in September, up 2.5% from August
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its budget arm Scoot carried 2.1 million passengers in September, a 2.5% increase from August. Demand remains strong across most routes, except East Asia, where travel restrictions persist. The group's passenger capacity dipped 0.8% month-over-month but jumped 111.8% from last year. SIA's passenger load factor improved to 87% in September, up 1.6 percentage points from August. Cargo operations expanded 33.3% but saw a 31 percentage point fall in load factor year-over-year. SIA's stock ended 1.4% higher at $5.07.

site_title: Regulators in US investigating Three Arrows Capital
summary: US regulators are investigating Three Arrows Capital, a failed hedge fund, for potential violations of rules by misleading investors and failing to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The SEC and CFTC are scrutinizing the company's balance sheet and conduct, which could lead to monetary fines and penalties. The founders, Zhu Su and Kyle Davies, remain unknown and have not cooperated with liquidators, who have seized control of tens of millions of dollars of the fund's assets.

site_title: Spotlight on nudging platform workers into retirement system
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) is ranked 9th globally for retirement systems, with room to encourage platform workers to contribute more to the national savings scheme. The CPF takes care of three main needs: retirement, housing, and medical. Currently, self-employed individuals, including platform workers, contribute only 8-10.5% to their MediSave accounts. A committee formed in 2021 to improve welfare for platform workers is set to submit recommendations before the end of 2022, considering measures such as corporate-sponsored pension plans and tax benefits for companies.

site_title: Chinese junk bonds set record low as property crisis spreads
summary: Chinese junk dollar bonds have hit a record low of 55.7 US cents due to a property crisis sparked by a government crackdown on excessive borrowing and home sales. The crisis, which began in 2020, has led to record defaults by developers, including China Evergrande Group, and unprecedented mortgage boycotts. Investors are waiting for policy changes, but recent developments suggest that even initial efforts to rescue the sector are insufficient, with Shanghai-based Cifi Holdings Group defaulting on a bond earlier this month. Chinese developers' shares have also plummeted to their lowest since 2012.

site_title: Informatics gets exit offer from Berjaya unit at 1.1 cents per share
summary: Informatics Education has received an exit offer from Berjaya Leisure Capital to buy all outstanding shares at 1.1 cents per share, representing an 8.9% premium to the benchmark price. The offer is unconditional and in connection with the company's directed delisting from the Singapore Exchange. Berjaya Leisure also offers to acquire outstanding warrants at a nominal price of 0.01 cent per warrant. The exit and warrant offers are part of the company's decision to exit the market following pre-tax losses for three consecutive years.

site_title: VAR to kick off in S'pore
summary: The Singapore Premier League (SPL) is set to adopt video assistant referee (VAR) technology, becoming only the second professional league in South-east Asia to do so, after Thailand. The implementation process is at the third stage and officials are "confident" of introducing VAR in 2023. The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) has worked closely with FIFA to train match officials and assess progress, with a two-day workshop conducted in February. VAR will be used to correct clear and obvious errors or serious missed incidents, and its implementation has been welcomed by the local football fraternity.

site_title: The Silent Foundation donates $2.5m to IPS to promote harmony
summary: The Silent Foundation (TSF) has donated $2.5 million to the Institute of Policy Studies (IPS) over five years to promote racial and religious harmony in Singapore. The donation will support two new IPS programs: the IPS Programme on Race, Religion and Intergroup Cohesion, and the IPS Thought Leadership Forum on Racial and Religious Harmony. This initiative aims to foster a more harmonious society, particularly in light of increasing diversity and cultural identities in Singapore. TSF's executive director, Matthew Teng, stated that the donation is the single largest commitment made by the organization so far.

site_title: Drops Of God ready to greet the judge again
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The Hong Kong Jockey Club provides analysis for Wednesday's Happy Valley form. Key contenders include Drops Of God, who is set to face the judge again, and Lucky Archangel, who is racing well and has a good draw. Other notable horses include Smoothies, On Excel Star, and Super Commander, who are expected to perform well in their respective races. The analysis highlights the strengths and weaknesses of each horse, providing insights for those looking to place bets. The article concludes with comments from The Hong Kong Jockey Club, offering expert opinions on the upcoming races.

site_title: President Halimah visits Vietnam-S'pore industrial park
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob visited the Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park in Bac Ninh province, showcasing the 635ha facility that has attracted 125 companies with $2.5 billion in investments and created 40,000 jobs. The industrial park, one of 11 in Vietnam, was opened in 2007 and has been a success due to Singapore's reputation as a reliable business partner. The park's CEO attributes the success to transparency, reliability, and efficiency provided by Singapore companies. The visit is part of Halimah's five-day state visit to Vietnam, where she will meet local leaders and businessmen.

site_title: PM Lee offers SAF assistance for flood relief efforts Down Under
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong offered assistance to Australia in its flood relief efforts, deploying military assets based in Oakey, Queensland. This comes after Australia experienced severe flooding in New South Wales, Victoria, and Tasmania. The Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) has previously assisted with flood and bush fire relief efforts. The offer was made during an annual meeting between PM Lee and Australian counterpart Anthony Albanese, highlighting the countries' strong defence and security cooperation.

site_title: S'pore needs to recognise value of hands-on and care work: Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for Singapore to recognize the value of hands-on and care work, citing a growing divergence in starting salaries between university and Institute of Technical Education (ITE) graduates. The median starting salary for a university graduate is now almost twice that of an ITE graduate. Wong proposed a twin strategy to support local workers, including redesigning jobs, upgrading skills, and establishing better career progression, and urged firms to recognize the value of different types of work, pay workers well, and support government initiatives.

site_title: Strawberry Light should shine brightly third-up
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:
