The article provides form analysis for upcoming horse races in South Africa, focusing on Races 1-6. Key contenders include Strawberry Light, Simply Beautiful, and Head Girl in the first race, with Strawberry Light looking promising in the second race. In the third and fourth races, Intimidator and Run For Me are expected to make a strong finish, while in the fifth and sixth races, Happy Chance and Betty Boop are favored to win, with Shantastic also expected to improve. The article advises readers to respect market support for newcomers and to look for in-form combinations.

site_title: Fifa mulls over fund to help migrant workers
summary: Fifa president Gianni Infantino announced the organization is negotiating measures to help migrant workers on Qatar's construction sites ahead of the World Cup. The talks follow pressure from rights groups, including Amnesty International, to establish a $450 million fund to compensate workers who suffered during the decade-long construction process. Qatar has already started a fund for unpaid workers, and Infantino praised the Gulf state's "groundbreaking reforms" that aim to improve working conditions. An announcement on the proposed fund is expected in the coming weeks.

site_title: No 'special treatment' for Bucs' star Brady
summary: Tampa Bay Buccaneers quarterback Tom Brady's absence from the team's final walkthrough to attend the wedding of New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft has raised scrutiny. Despite coach Todd Bowles' denial of "special treatment," Brady's extended sabbatical and other excused absences have drawn attention. Brady rejoined the team on Saturday night before the loss to Pittsburgh, which dropped the Buccaneers to 3-3. Bowles defended Brady, saying he works hard and others have similar absences, but the optics of Brady's absence are being scrutinized.

site_title: All finals from now, says Klopp after beating City
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp believes his team's 1-0 win over Manchester City was crucial, as they now face all Premier League games as "finals." The Reds, in eighth place, have struggled with injuries, with Diogo Jota ruled out for the World Cup due to a calf injury and another forward also sidelined. Klopp's team will face West Ham on Wednesday, with West Ham boss David Moyes anticipating a defensive approach from Liverpool. The match is a significant test for both teams, with the winner potentially gaining an advantage in the title race.

site_title: How businesses can bridge the skills gap with an age-diverse, inclusive workforce
summary: A Singaporean bank, UOB, has launched a flexible work programme called "Gig+U" to retain retired employees and bridge the skills gap with an age-diverse, inclusive workforce. The programme allows retirees to work part-time, with the same medical benefits and insurance coverage as full-time employees. The bank also aims to increase the employment rate of differently-abled individuals to 40% by 2030, up from 30% between 2020 and 2021. By promoting inclusive hiring, UOB hopes to alleviate manpower issues and empower differently-abled individuals to generate a source of income.

images.alt_text: Retiree Ms Quek went back to work under a flexible arrangement

site_title: Frequent outbursts, increased irritability and lack of motivation: Signs parents of teens should not ignore
summary: Parents of teens should be aware of signs of increased stress, anxiety, and depression, including irritability, lack of motivation, and increased isolation. According to a survey, about one in three youth in Singapore experienced mental health symptoms, with those aged 14-16 having more serious symptoms. To support their children, parents can practice active listening, ask open-ended questions, and create family routines. It's also essential to validate their child's need for privacy and seek professional help if concerns arise. Building trust and open communication with their child is key to helping them navigate the emotional rollercoaster of adolescence.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Key events and conclusions for the next 48 hours include: English Premier League matches, Spanish Primera Liga matches, and European football matches. Notable matches include Liverpool vs West Ham, Man United vs Tottenham, and Arsenal vs PSV in the Europa League. Additionally, tennis tournaments such as the Napoli Cup, European Open, and Guadalajara Open will take place. Viewers can catch these matches on Singtel TV and StarHub TV Plus.

site_title: Sports World: Loh wins opener in Denmark Open
summary: Singapore's Loh Kean Yew won his first match since becoming world No. 5, defeating Thailand's Sitthikom Thammasin 21-13, 22-20 in the Denmark Open. Loh will face India's Srikanth Kidambi in the round of 16. Former Japan footballer Shunsuke Nakamura will retire at 44 due to ankle injuries. Australia's Pat Cummins will captain the ODI team after Cricket Australia named him as Aaron Finch's replacement. The World Anti-Doping Agency declared the International Federation of Bodybuilding and Fitness non-compliant with doping standards.

site_title: Aussie netball's deal raises concerns
summary: Australia's national netball body, Netball Australia, has agreed to stick with a multimillion-dollar sponsorship deal with Hancock Prospecting, despite concerns raised by Aboriginal player Donnell Wallam. Wallam, who is set to represent Australia, had expressed concerns about the company's treatment of Indigenous communities due to its founder's past actions. The deal has reportedly caused tension among players, with some opting not to wear the sponsor's logo. Netball Australia has met with the players and the sponsor to address the concerns and extend their commitment to the partnership.

site_title: Policing at Euro final 'criminal', says report
summary: An independent report chaired by Professor Phil Scraton has deemed the policing at the Champions League final in Paris "criminal assault". The report found that French authorities and Uefa's security arrangements were severely inadequate, leading to delays, tear gas deployments, and violent attacks by local gangs on fans. The report cited sustained failure in crowd management, putting fans' health and well-being at risk. The experience of the Liverpool fans echoed the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, resulting in no lives lost but severe psychological and financial harm.

site_title: Neymar has no memory of taking part in Barca talks
summary: Brazilian football star Neymar testified in a Spanish court hearing a trial over alleged irregularities in his 2013 transfer to Barcelona. Neymar stated his father, his manager, handled his contract negotiations, and he signed agreements based on his father's instructions. Prosecutors seek a 2-year prison term and €10 million fine for Neymar, while his lawyers claim he is innocent and the €40 million paid was a "legal signing bonus". The trial, which started on October 17, is expected to conclude on October 31.

site_title: Plenty of drama before tip-off
summary: The National Basketball Association (NBA) is set to begin its new season under a cloud of scandals and drama. The Golden State Warriors and Boston Celtics are navigating internal crises, while the Brooklyn Nets and Los Angeles Lakers are trying to integrate their stars. The Phoenix Suns' majority owner, Robert Sarver, was fined and suspended for using racial slurs and engaging in sexist behavior, but will sell the teams due to public pressure. Other issues include the punishment for Golden State's Draymond Green for punching his teammate, the Celtics' interim coaching situation, and trade rumors surrounding Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving.

site_title: Benzema becomes ambitious with age
summary: Karim Benzema, 34, has won the Ballon d'Or, becoming the oldest winner since Stanley Matthews in 1956. The Real Madrid striker dedicated his trophy to "the people" and credited his ambition growing after turning 30. Benzema, who scored 44 goals in 46 games last season, overcame a 51.5-year national team ban due to a blackmail scandal. He now targets the World Cup with France, aiming to win the trophy. Benzema's win marks the second time a player other than Messi or Ronaldo has won the award since 2008.

site_title: S'pore, Australia set up working group to strengthen supply chains
summary: Singapore and Australia have established a working group to strengthen their mutual supply chains, particularly in times of crisis. The group aims to facilitate the flow of critical goods, including food and energy, and enhance supply chain resilience. The two countries also agreed to begin work on a bilateral food pact to increase trade and investments in both countries' food supply. Additionally, they are exploring opportunities for cooperation in the green economy, including standards, business engagements, research, and eco-labelling.

site_title: Warriors open title defence against 'underdogs' Lakers
summary: The Golden State Warriors, seeking to repeat their NBA title, face off against the Los Angeles Lakers in a nationally televised opener. The Warriors, with most of their championship cast intact, will rely on their depth to navigate the season. The Lakers, rebuilding after a 33-49 record last season, are considered the "underdogs" and are looking to relish the underdog status. The teams last met in 2021, with the Warriors winning 121-114 in Los Angeles.

site_title: We will reform, transform football in Indonesia: Fifa
summary: FIFA president Gianni Infantino pledged to help "reform and transform" Indonesian football, two weeks after a stadium crush killed 133 people, including 40 children. Infantino met with President Joko Widodo to discuss improving stadium operations and fan behavior, as well as creating programs for football in schools. He also assured that FIFA would work with the government to ensure the Under-20 World Cup, scheduled for 2023, can go ahead safely. FIFA and the Asian Football Confederation will also help Indonesia rebuild the Kanjuruhan Stadium according to international safety standards.

site_title: Be ready or be dropped
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag has made it clear that no player is guaranteed a starting spot, and those who are not performing will be dropped. Defender Luke Shaw praises ten Hag's approach, saying it keeps players on their toes and ensures everyone gives their best effort. Shaw, who has been benched this season, credits ten Hag for recognizing his hard work and giving him a second chance. The teams face off on Wednesday, with Tottenham missing Richarlison due to a calf injury, and Manchester United looking to secure a crucial win to move closer to the top of the Premier League table.

site_title: Not-so-optimist Potter downplays good start
summary: Graham Potter, Chelsea's manager, downplays the team's strong start to the season, stating it's "a long way to go" despite five consecutive wins. Potter credits Thomas Frank, Brentford's manager, for his team's success, praising their attacking clarity and defensive aggression. Chelsea look to bounce back from a 4-1 defeat at Brentford in April and close the gap to Manchester City to just a point. Potter will be without injured players N'Golo Kante, Wesley Fofana, and Reece James, and is wary of in-form Brentford striker Ivan Toney.

site_title: Asean, EU ink world's first bloc-to-bloc aviation pact
summary: A landmark aviation pact between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) and the European Union (EU) was signed, aiming to boost air connectivity between the two regions. The agreement, set to benefit over 1 billion people, allows airlines from 37 countries to operate flights between the regions, with no restrictions on frequency or cargo services. The pact also promotes cooperation in areas like safety, air traffic management, and consumer protection, and replaces over 140 bilateral air services agreements. The signing marks a significant milestone in world aviation history, with the agreement expected to accelerate economic recovery.

site_title: Ismail still BN candidate for PM
summary: Caretaker Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob remains the Barisan Nasional's (BN) prime ministerial candidate for the upcoming general election, according to BN chairman Ahmad Zahid Hamidi. The BN's stance on this issue will not change if it forms the next government, despite opposition claims that Ismail's re-appointment is a concern. The opposition is focusing on this issue, but BN's position remains unchanged.

site_title: Andreescu thrives in high altitude
summary: Canadian tennis player Bianca Andreescu won her first-round match at the Guadalajara Open, defeating Swiss Jil Teichmann 6-2, 6-4 in a high-altitude match. Andreescu attributed the altitude to her advantage, stating it "drags the ball around," which she likes. Her win sets up a first-round meeting with Petra Kvitova. Other notable winners include Victoria Azarenka, Belinda Bencic, and Rebecca Marino, who advanced to the second round in the hard-court tournament.

site_title: How a style-neutral global equities strategy can help you better navigate uncertain markets
summary: PineBridge Investments' portfolio manager Robert Hinchliffe suggests a style-neutral global equities strategy can help investors navigate uncertain markets. A balanced approach to stock selection, focusing on company fundamentals and long-running themes, can enhance potential returns. Hinchliffe recommends a diversified portfolio with a mix of growth and value stocks, minimizing exposure to unremunerated risks. By adopting a differentiated, active strategy with a focus on identifying mispriced positive company changes, investors can generate alpha consistently across all market conditions.

site_title: Evening Update: Today's headlines from The Straits Times on Oct 21
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Headlines include whether taking a third Covid-19 vaccine booster affects immunity and the ongoing race for Britain's next prime minister. Constitutional changes to protect the definition of marriage in Singapore are proposed, and Malaysians can now get discounted flight tickets for voting. Rebalancing economic rewards between "head", "heart", and "hands" work is discussed. A man is charged with jail and caning for raping a woman after a fake online encounter. A knife-wielding man allegedly resisted arrest and assaulted 4 CNB officers. New wines are trending in Singapore, with health and colorful options set to gain traction.

site_title: New faces key to 76ers, Celtics' NBA championship hopes
summary: The Philadelphia 76ers and Boston Celtics, two teams with realistic NBA championship hopes, face off in the 2022-23 season opener. The Celtics, led by new head coach Joe Mazzulla, have added Malcolm Brogdon to their roster, while the 76ers will rely on reigning scoring champion Joel Embiid. The Celtics aim to win their 18th championship, while the 76ers seek to improve after falling to the Miami Heat in the second round last season. With new faces and a new coach, both teams face a challenge in reaching championship form.

site_title: Perak assembly dissolved, paving way for state polls
summary: The Perak state legislative assembly has been dissolved by Chief Minister Saarani Mohamad following a letter from Sultan Nazrin Muizzuddin Shah. The move comes as part of the preparations for Malaysia's 15th general election, with Perak set to hold state polls concurrently with the parliamentary seat elections. This decision affects Perak, Pahang, and Perlis, which will join forces to hold the elections, while other opposition-held states have chosen not to dissolve their state assemblies.

site_title: NParks to relocate some otters from residential areas
summary: The National Parks Board (NParks) in Singapore has relocated six otters from a residential area in Seletar to a safer location with abundant food sources. The otters had wandered from waterways in Punggol and established a holt in the housing estate. NParks' integrated approach includes relocation and possibly sterilization in the long term, with the goal of preventing human-wildlife conflict. The number of otters in Singapore has increased to 170 islandwide, with 17 families, and NParks is working with residents and home owners to implement measures to prevent otters from entering residential areas.

site_title: Sharp fall in transnational marriages in past 2 years
summary: Singapore has seen a sharp decline in transnational marriages over the past two years, with the proportion of such marriages among citizens dropping from 29% in 2021 to 30% in 2020 and 37% in 2019. The main reason cited is the disruption caused by Covid-19 travel restrictions. However, the drop is partially offset by an increase in marriages between Singaporean couples, with 29% of marriages involving at least one Singapore citizen being transnational in 2021.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (Nodx) grew 3.1% in September, down from 11.4% in August, due to a weakening global growth outlook and recession risks. Transnational marriages in Singapore have declined by 7% over the past two years, mainly due to Covid-19 travel curbs. Commercial vehicles in Kolkata will be required to use non-fossil energy by 2030 to reduce carbon emissions. A housewife in Singapore is disputing a $100,000 insurance loss after early policy termination, while telcos have raised concerns over anti-SMS scam measures that may infringe on privacy.

site_title: Indian community can finally see light after darkness: Shanmugam
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam launched a video titled "Light Of Hope" by the People's Action Party, showcasing the Indian community's efforts during the Covid-19 pandemic. The video features real-life stories and an original song about kindness, meant to convey the essence of Deepavali. Despite muted celebrations in 2020 and 2021, the community came together, with organizations and community groups supporting each other. This year's festivities promise a return to form, with a focus on unity and health, as the community emerges stronger and more united.

site_title: Overseas posts, better job matches with e2i, SNEF tie-up
summary: Singapore's Employment and Employability Institute (e2i) and Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) have signed a memorandum of understanding to launch a pilot program, allowing job seekers to work overseas. The pilot aims to match workers with job openings at SNEF member firms, with the goal of improving wages, job prospects, and worker welfare. The program falls under the Job Security Council (JSC), which has already matched about 60,000 workers to new jobs since its launch in 2020.

site_title: Lifting of vaccination-differentiated measures a boon for Mice sector
summary: The lifting of vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) for events with over 500 participants has boosted the Mice sector in Singapore, with event organizers expecting more contracts and increased turnout. The easing of restrictions, which removed the need for manual vaccination checks, is expected to ease manpower constraints and reduce costs by up to 50%. The move is seen as a significant development for the sector, which had accounted for 0.8% of Singapore's GDP and supported over 34,000 jobs before the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore, Vietnam ink pacts on renewable energy, carbon credits
summary: Singapore and Vietnam signed four memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on Monday, including agreements on renewable energy and carbon credits collaboration. The agreements aim to advance energy collaborations, reduce carbon dioxide emissions, and promote green energy transition. Singapore and Vietnam aim to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 and mid-century, respectively. The MOUs cover energy cooperation, carbon credits, and other areas such as cyber security, education, and vocational training. The agreements are seen as a step towards strengthening bilateral relations and deepening regional economic integration.

site_title: Man posed as woman offering sexual services for money
summary: A 23-year-old man, Lim Sin Yi, pleaded guilty to four charges of cheating after posing as a woman on social media and scamming three victims out of $1,030. He posted nude videos on Twitter and advertised for sexual services, convincing men to pay him $500 each to meet up. Lim gave various excuses to break off appointments and was found uncontactable when victims tried to meet. He faces up to three years in jail and a fine, with restitution to be made to the victims from his seized bank account.

site_title: PM Lee meets academics and business leaders in Sydney
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met academics and business leaders in Sydney as part of his three-day visit to Australia from Oct 16 to 18. The discussions covered geostrategic developments and their impact on the region, with Australia playing an important role in regional security. Lee also welcomed Australian businesses to build partnerships with Singapore in digital and green economies. He is also scheduled to attend the 7th Singapore-Australia Leaders' Meeting in Canberra with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on Tuesday. This is PM Lee's first trip to Australia since the start of the pandemic.

site_title: Can't book a slot to view T-Rex skeleton? Join walk-in queue
summary: A Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton named Shen will be displayed at the Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall in Singapore from Oct 28-30. Due to high demand, a walk-in queue will be available for those who couldn't book a slot online. Shen, assembled from 79 excavated bones, is 12.2m long and 4.6m tall, and is estimated to be worth between US$15-25 million. This will be the first T-Rex skeleton to be auctioned in Asia and displayed in a museum in the region.

site_title: BTO flats cater to diverse groups: Desmond Lee
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee emphasized that Build-To-Order (BTO) flats cater to diverse groups, including those in lower-income segments. Flats in attractive locations have higher price points, while those in non-mature estates are more affordable. Lee cited examples of affordable BTO flats, such as those in Jurong East and Woodlands South, which can be fully financed by CPF accounts. He also acknowledged concerns about rising resale prices, but noted that the government has introduced cooling measures to moderate demand. The government aims to launch up to 100,000 new BTO flats between 2021 and 2025.

site_title: Grab driver dies, taking workplace deaths to 40 in 2022
summary: A 68-year-old Grab driver died in a crash involving a car, lorry, and bus in Ang Mo Kio, Singapore, on Sunday. The accident occurred when the driver made a discretionary right turn, colliding with the lorry. The driver was taken to hospital, where he died. The incident is the 40th workplace fatality in 2022, surpassing the 37 recorded in 2021. A 33-year-old woman in the car and the lorry driver were also taken to hospital, while the bus driver is assisting with the investigation.

site_title: Global energy crisis a wake-up call for businesses to go green, says SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean urges businesses to go green amid the global energy crisis, warning those that delay action will lose out to competitors. He emphasizes the need for decarbonization, sustainable supply chain management, and investment in research and development of sustainable innovation to thrive in a low-carbon world. Singapore aims to become a carbon services and trading hub, while also advancing global climate action and decarbonization goals through partnerships like its discussions with Ghana and Colombia. The country plans to progressively raise its carbon tax to $50 to $80 per tonne by 2030.

site_title: Director Ken Kwek's film barred from being shown in S'pore
summary: A Singaporean film, #LookAtMe, directed by Ken Kwek, has been barred from being screened in the country due to its potential to cause enmity and social division. The film, set in Singapore, denigrates a religious community and portrays a pastor engaging in behavior against his faith. The Infocomm Media Development Authority, Ministry of Home Affairs, and Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth agreed that the film should be refused classification, citing the Film Classification Guidelines. The decision effectively bans the film from being sold, rented, or made public in Singapore.

site_title: Small, mid-sized states well placed to tackle global problems, says Zaqy
summary: Small and mid-sized states are well-positioned to tackle global challenges, according to Senior Minister of State for Defence Zaqy Mohamad. He highlighted the Asean Defence Ministers' Meeting (ADMM-Plus) as a platform where countries can pool resources to solve transnational problems. Zaqy emphasized the importance of multilateral platforms for small and middle-sized countries, citing examples such as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, which brought together 11 countries, including Singapore. He noted that these countries have historically played a key role in the international system, serving as convenors, mediators, and reformists.

site_title: ST video series looks at push to electrify vehicles
summary: Singapore is working to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the land transport sector, which is the third-largest contributor to emissions after power and industrial sectors. The country's public transport network and cycling/walking initiatives have reduced the need for private vehicles. Efforts to electrify vehicles are underway, aiming to mitigate climate change.

site_title: Social enterprise sector continues to thrive amid pandemic
summary: The social enterprise sector continued to thrive during the pandemic, with many innovating and digitalizing services to reach a wider audience. The Singapore Centre for Social Enterprise (raiSE) provided support, waiving fees and developing self-help toolkits to help its members sustain themselves. As a result, the sector grew from $179 million in 2020 to $210 million in 2021, with 27% of raiSE members joining in 2021. Social enterprises like Amazing Speech Therapy and Tictag expanded their reach and social impact, with raiSE's efforts complementing the Government's grants and supports.

site_title: Woman in dispute with bank over $100k in losses for ending policy early
summary: A 69-year-old housewife is disputing a $100,000 loss from early termination of an insurance policy purchased from DBS Bank in 2019. The bank claims she was aware of the high costs involved and made the decision voluntarily. The woman alleges she was tricked into making an unwise investment, sparking a dispute over whether she was justified in ending the policy early due to buyer's remorse. The outcome of the case is yet to be determined.

site_title: Malaysian PM urges end to Umno-PAS friction, culture of sabotage in BN
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob urged an end to friction between Umno and Parti Islam SeMalasiam (PAS) and a culture of sabotage within the Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition. He emphasized that both parties should avoid insults and attacks, as ties may still continue in the future. Ismail also stressed the importance of unity and cooperation among BN candidates to win the 15th General Election and form a stable government. He warned that sabotage would harm the public and party members, and referenced the 2018 election as a lesson to work harder and avoid instability.

site_title: Sembcorp gets licence to develop Viet industrial park
summary: Sembcorp Industries has obtained an investment licence to develop a 293.7ha industrial park in Can Tho City, Vietnam, through its subsidiary Sembcorp Development. The project, operated by Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park (VSIP) Group, is part of the central government's master plan to establish Can Tho as a trade and services hub by 2023. Sembcorp expects minimal impact on its earnings and shares closed unchanged at $2.88 following the announcement.

site_title: Ismail remains coalition's candidate for PM: BN chief
summary: Barisan Nasional (BN) chairman Ahmad Zahid Hamidi has reaffirmed Datuk Seri Ismail Sabri Yaakob as the coalition's candidate for prime minister, despite opposition claims that Zahid would be the candidate. Zahid stated that BN's decision is final and not influenced by the opposition's attempts to create friction. The coalition plans to contest 191 parliamentary seats, with at least 70% of candidates being new faces, and will also give opportunities to Friends of Barisan parties to contest on the coalition's ticket.

site_title: Pound rallies as traders eye shift in fiscal stance under new finance chief
summary: The British pound rose 0.77% to US$1.1258 in early Asia trading, boosted by expectations that Prime Minister Liz Truss' package of unfunded tax cuts may be reversed. New finance minister Jeremy Hunt indicated a move towards fiscal probity, potentially stabilizing the currency before the end of the month. The pound has whipsawed in recent weeks, but remains vulnerable to further market volatility, with some analysts predicting a decline to US$1.05 in three months.

site_title: More protection needed for vulnerable customers, say experts
summary: Singapore's rapidly ageing population poses financial planning risks for elderly customers, particularly those new to the process. Experts emphasize the need for more protection to help these customers manage their retirement savings. With an average life expectancy of nearly 85 years, it is crucial for individuals to plan ahead to avoid outliving their savings. Industry experts recommend targeted measures to support vulnerable customers in navigating financial planning.

site_title: BTO flats priced for various budgets
summary: The National Development Minister Desmond Lee stated that Build-To-Order (BTO) flats cater to various budgets, offering different attributes, price points, and grant amounts to cater to median- and lower-income households. This approach allows for more affordable options, even in desirable locations, where prices may be higher due to their desirability.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports grow at slower pace amid headwinds
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports grew 3.1% year-over-year in September, missing the 6.9% median forecast, due to a decline in electronics exports. Electronics shipments fell 10.6% year-over-year, with disk media products and personal computer parts declining 42.7% and 22.3%, respectively. Economists expect Nodx growth to turn negative in the coming months due to a technology downturn. The slowdown in electronics is attributed to falling global shipments of semiconductors and a manufacturing slowdown.

site_title: S'pore start-up Endowus buys HK's Carret Private
summary: Endowus, a Singapore-based digital wealth adviser, has acquired a controlling stake in Carret Private Investments, a leading Hong Kong-based wealth manager. The acquisition will combine Endowus' digital wealth technology with Carret's platform of ultra-high-net-worth individuals, families, trusts, and charitable organizations across Asia. The deal expands Endowus' reach and scales up its services, serving tens of thousands of clients with assets exceeding US$4 billion. The partnership also includes a strategic alliance with Singapore-based Lumen Capital Investors, allowing Endowus to grow faster and become one of Asia's largest independent wealth advisers.

site_title: Japan keeps up warnings of firm response to rapid yen moves
summary: Japan's authorities have reiterated their warning of a firm response to rapid yen declines, after the currency fell to a 32-year low. Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki stated that the government would take decisive steps against excess currency moves driven by speculation. The warnings come after the Group of Seven acknowledged currency volatility and Japan's Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda reaffirmed the central bank's easing policy, citing core consumer inflation. The yen remains near 149 against the US dollar, sparking concerns over import costs and business uncertainty.

site_title: SIA likely to redeem convertible bonds sooner than expected: Citi
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is likely to redeem its outstanding mandatory convertible bonds sooner than expected, according to Citigroup Global Markets. The airline's strengthened balance sheet and improved cash position, driven by faster-than-expected air travel recovery, have made early redemption possible. Additionally, delays in Boeing 777X plane deliveries are also contributing to the decision. This move aims to limit share dilution, as SIA seeks to redeem all outstanding MCBs.

site_title: Egonu takes break after furore but gets support
summary: Italy's outgoing Prime Minister Mario Draghi offered full support to volleyball player Paola Egonu after she took a break from the national team following comments questioning her nationality. Egonu, born to Nigerian parents, had said she was tired of being asked about her Italian citizenship, leading to an outpouring of support from across Italy. Draghi praised Egonu as a "pride to Italian sport" and assured her of future opportunities. The incident highlights a sensitive issue in Italy regarding restrictive citizenship laws.

site_title: Starlets ace Asian test
summary: Singapore's teenage silat exponent Dhani Andika Razali won the gold medal in the men's under-45kg weight class at the Asian Pencak Silat Championships in Srinagar, Kashmir. This achievement contributed to the country's nine-gold medal haul, placing them second overall behind Vietnam. Dhani, 17, credited his training and support from his family, friends, and coaches for his victory, aiming to win a gold medal at the world championships and SEA Games in the next two years.

site_title: Nunes to miss Oct 29 meeting
summary: Jockey Manoel Nunes has been suspended for one Singapore race day for careless riding. He was found guilty of allowing his mount to shift near the 100m mark, which caused him to lose track of another horse, Last Samurai. As a result, Nunes will miss the October 29 Kranji meeting, which he had been scheduled to ride.

site_title: So much is riding on Fed's moves, it's hard to know what to invest in
summary: The US Federal Reserve's aggressive campaign to combat inflation has sent markets into turmoil, with investors uncertain about the central bank's next moves. Despite a recent two-day rally, markets have been volatile, and investors are bracing for potential further damage before a possible pivot. Experts differ on whether the Fed will relax its stance, with some predicting a dovish turn and others warning of more pain ahead. The Fed's plan to slow inflation by slowing economic growth is working, but inflation remains stubbornly high, with consumer prices rising 8.2% in the year through September.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Key football matches in the next 48 hours include English Premier League matches between Liverpool and West Ham, Man United and Tottenham, Brentford and Chelsea, and Newcastle and Everton, all airing on Singtel TV and StarHub TV Plus. Additionally, Spanish Primera Liga matches between Cadiz and Betis, and Elche and Real, will take place on the same channels. Tennis tournaments, including the ATP Tour's European Open, will also air on Singtel TV and StarHub TV Plus.

site_title: New private home sales in Sept soar with 987 units sold
summary: New private home sales in Singapore soared to 987 units sold in September, the second highest monthly tally this year, driven by strong take-up at two suburban projects, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok. The two projects accounted for 84% of units launched, with median prices above $2,100 psf. Despite rising interest rates and economic uncertainty, developers cited pent-up demand from HDB upgraders. Experts predict private home sales will slow in the fourth quarter, but EC sales are expected to remain robust due to affordability and limited supply.

site_title: Lakers' success banks on fixing leaky defence
summary: The Los Angeles Lakers are focusing on rebuilding their leaky defense after a dismal 2021-2022 season, which saw them finish with a 33-49 record and miss the playoffs. The team has made personnel changes, including the arrival of veteran Patrick Beverley, and new coach Darvin Ham emphasizes a holistic 360-degree approach that prioritizes defense. LeBron James and Anthony Davis must also maintain their fitness levels throughout the season, a challenge after Davis played only 40 times last season. A strong defense is seen as key to the Lakers' success.

site_title: Albirex appeal on Tanaka's 'goal' rendered invalid
summary: Albirex Niigata's appeal to credit Kodai Tanaka with their final goal in a 5-3 loss to Tampines Rovers was rendered invalid due to an incomplete submission. The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) stated that the club failed to pay a $2,000 deposit and submit a complete appeal within 48 hours. As a result, Tanaka will not be credited with the goal, trailing Stags striker Boris Kopitovic by one goal in the Golden Boot race. Tanaka remains determined to help his team win the match and make up for the deficit in the season's final game.

site_title: S'poreans' inflation expectations hit 11-year high amid global uncertainty: Poll
summary: Singaporeans' inflation expectations have reached an 11-year high, rising to 4.6% in September, according to a poll from the Singapore Index of Inflation Expectations (Sindex). This is the highest recorded since December 2011. Consumers attribute the increase to global uncertainty, the Russia-Ukraine conflict, and supply chain disruptions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) forecasts a median of 3.5% for the consumer price index (CPI) in 2023. The survey also showed that inflation expectations for food and transportation increased, while core inflation expectations rose to 4.5% and 4.6% respectively.

site_title: Keppel O&M to begin charters for 4 rig assets in Saudi Arabia
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) has completed modification works on four KFELS B Class jack-up rigs, which will be deployed on bareboat charters in Saudi Arabia starting in October. The rigs will be chartered to Arabian Drilling Company and ADES Saudi Limited Company, generating a total charter revenue of about $250 million over three to five years. The rigs, capable of operating in 122m water depth and drilling to 9,140m, will be deployed to Saudi Aramco for 3-5 years. The move is part of Keppel O&M's efforts to capitalize on rising demand for modern, high-specification jackup rigs.

site_title: Having partner as coach works out well for Evans
summary: Britain's Neah Evans won her first world title in the women's points race at the track world championships, securing gold with 60 points. Evans, 32, finished ahead of Denmark's Julie Leth and the US's Jennifer Valente. Her success is attributed to a change in coaching, with partner Jonathan Wale, who took on the role earlier this year. Meanwhile, Dutch rider Harrie Lavreysen secured his fourth consecutive sprint gold, becoming the first rider to win four straight titles since Japanese legend Koichi Nakano in 1986.

site_title: Saturday's Singapore Stipendiary Stewards' report highlights
summary: Singapore's Saturday Stipendiary Stewards report highlighted several incidents. Pacific Star was withdrawn after suffering a leg laceration, while Easylights returned lame off-fore in Race 3. City Gate bled in Race 5 after being taken back to obtain cover, and Atlanteran failed to stride out freely. Dixit Dominus' jockey was noted for his frequent looks over his shoulder, possibly to check for interference. Hard Too Think was disappointing after being bumped in Race 10, and Rocketship returned lame off-fore in Race 11. Several horses were penalized for their performances, including Griffin, who settled back in the field.

site_title: Qatar to stage next Asian Cup
summary: Qatar will host the next Asian Cup in place of China, which withdrew due to its zero-Covid-19 policy. The tournament is likely to be held in early 2024, rather than mid-2023, to avoid the Gulf summer heat. Qatar, which hosted the 2022 World Cup, was preferred over South Korea and Indonesia due to its existing infrastructure and hosting capabilities. The 24-team tournament will run from January 24, 2024, and will use all eight venues built for the World Cup.

site_title: Celtics' new interim coach is no ordinary Joe
summary: The Boston Celtics have named 34-year-old Joe Mazzulla as their new interim coach after Ime Udoka's season-long suspension due to a team rule violation. Mazzulla, a Boston assistant for three seasons, will lead the team that reached the NBA Finals last season. The Celtics are considered title contenders and have a roster that includes Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown, and Marcus Smart. Mazzulla aims to maintain strong communication with players and build on last season's success, which ended with a loss to the Golden State Warriors in the NBA Finals.

site_title: Burridge revival in the works
summary: Veteran Australian trainer Steven Burridge is gaining momentum in the 2022 Singapore racing season after a quiet start. He has picked up two wins in the past month, bringing his total to 16 winners, nearly doubling his score from the halfway mark. Burridge is rebuilding his stable, which had been reduced to 25 horses, and is looking to increase his chances by investing in new horses and adjusting his racing strategy. He plans to attend the Magic Millions Gold Coast 2YO In Training sale to find new talent and is considering increasing the stakes for open maidens.

site_title: Mr Black back the dark horse: Nunes
summary: Mr. Black Back, a 5-year-old Snitzel trained by Tim Fitzsimmons, won the $70,000 Wild Geese 2014 Stakes Class 3 race at Kranji, Singapore, with a dominant performance from off the pace. The win has boosted his chances of competing in the $1 million Singapore Gold Cup on November 19, with trainer Fitzsimmons calling him a "live chance" at a low weight. Stand-in jockey Manoel Nunes praised the horse's natural front-running style, which could give him an edge in the Gold Cup, despite the field being capped at 16 runners.

site_title: City claim coin-throwing, attack on bus by fans
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola was targeted with coins thrown during the team's 1-0 loss to Liverpool, with the FA launching a wide-ranging probe into the incident. The City bench also celebrated vigorously after a disallowed goal, prompting a retaliation from Liverpool supporters. The FA will review the referee's report to determine if action can be taken, while Liverpool has condemned vile chants from City fans and vowed to work with authorities to eradicate them.

site_title: Bucks need to limit rivals' Trey chances
summary: The Milwaukee Bucks face a crucial season with a focus on improving their team defense and limiting opponents' three-point chances. After a disappointing pre-season, coach Mike Budenholzer's team is looking to change their approach, which has been criticized for protecting the paint at the expense of allowing open looks from beyond the arc. Giannis Antetokounmpo emphasizes the importance of building good habits and being hungry, with the team needing to come together and defend better to make a deep playoff run.

site_title: I never asked to leave PSG: Mbappe
summary: Kylian Mbappe has denied reports that he wants to leave Paris Saint-Germain, saying he has "never asked to leave" the Qatar-owned club. The 23-year-old France superstar signed a new three-year contract in May, but has expressed dissatisfaction with his position in the PSG attack this season. Mbappe attributed the recent rumors to his entourage and insisted he is "very happy" with his current situation, saying "it is completely false" that he wants to leave Paris. PSG remain three points clear at the top of Ligue 1.

site_title: Swiatek's eighth title of the season
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek captured her 11th career WTA title and 8th of the year by defeating 47th-ranked Donna Vekic 6-3, 3-6, 6-0 in the San Diego Open final. This victory marks Swiatek's WTA-best 64th match win of 2022. The 21-year-old Polish champion bounced back from a previous loss to seal her 11th career title.

site_title: From automated assembly lines to digital factory simulators, the future of manufacturing is taking shape in Jurong
summary: Singapore's Jurong Innovation District (JID) is a hub for advanced manufacturing, featuring state-of-the-art facilities and partnerships with top companies like Hyundai Motor Group. The district aims to support Singapore's ambitions in advanced manufacturing, aiming for a 50% growth in the sector by 2030. JID offers resources for companies to adopt Industry 4.0 technologies, including digitalization solutions, robotics, and artificial intelligence. The district also provides training and talent development programs, as well as test-beds for companies to test their innovations. With a focus on sustainability, JID features an underground logistics network and green spaces, aiming to reduce its carbon footprint.

site_title: Warriors to battle 'biggest crisis'
summary: The Golden State Warriors face uncertainty as they begin their defense of the NBA championship due to a practice-court assault by Draymond Green on teammate Jordan Poole. Green escaped suspension and is expected to start the season opener, but the incident has raised questions about the team's locker room dynamics. Coach Steve Kerr hopes Green can rebuild "trust" with teammates and coaches, while the team has backed Poole with a contract extension. Green believes rebuilding team camaraderie is key, and he plans to use the incident as motivation to prove others wrong.

site_title: Blinkered Vida Futura gets right course and trip
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Trainer Alan Greeff has a strong hand in Tuesday's South Africa form analysis, with Emily's Spirit and Divine Design favored to fight out the finish in RACE 1. Nairobi is improving and could be third-time lucky, while Tipsey Tina may play a minor role. Vida Futura is set to beat the competition in RACE 4 with the blinkers, and Mhlabeni is in good form for RACE 5. Track Commander is in good heart for RACE 6, and Ekoria is a class act in RACE 7, with Peach Daiquiri and Stolen Kiss also deserving respect.

site_title: ST Full-time Report: Singapore ref heads to Qatar 2022 | Who will win Sportsman & Sportswoman of the year award?
summary: Singaporean referee Taqi Jahari is set to officiate at the Qatar 2022 World Cup, marking his first major tournament as a video assistant referee. The Saudi-backed LIV golf tour continues to feud with the PGA Tour, causing a rift in the golf world. The Singapore Sports Awards nominees have been announced, with Loh Kean Yew and Aloysius Yapp vying for Sportsman of the Year and Shayna Ng, Amita Berthier, and Yu Mengyu competing for Sportswoman of the Year. The top goalscorer in the Singapore Premier League remains up for grabs, with Kodai Tanaka and Boris Kopitovic in the running.

site_title: Premier League talking points
summary: Arsenal secured a 1-0 win over Leeds United, staying four points above second-placed Manchester City with a performance marked by grit and resilience. The young Arsenal side withstood pressure for 96 minutes, aided by VAR, to make their best start to a top-flight season with nine wins from 10. Meanwhile, Tottenham Hotspur's 2-0 victory over Everton kept them third, showcasing their depth, and Leicester City's reliance on James Maddison was highlighted as they drew with Crystal Palace, with Maddison set to miss Thursday's game against Leeds due to a yellow card.

site_title: Sports World
summary: Neymar and eight others, including former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell, went on trial in Barcelona for alleged fraud and corruption related to Neymar's 2013 transfer from Santos. Spanish prosecutors seek a two-year prison term and €10 million fine for Neymar, while Rosell faces a five-year jail term and €8.4 million fine. Meanwhile, two Brazilian football matches were abandoned due to fan incursions, and West Indies suffered a stunning 42-run defeat to Scotland in the T20 Cricket World Cup opener.

site_title: Football: SPL Team of the Week (Matchweek 27)
summary: Syazwan Buhari (Tampines Rovers) is named SPL Team of the Week for Matchweek 27, following his impressive goalkeeping performances, including a notable late save against Nicky Melvin Singh. Tajeli Salamat (Geylang International) and Ilhan Noor (Geylang) also shine, with Ilhan scoring his first goal of the season. Meanwhile, Maxime Lestienne (Lion City Sailors) reaches 23 assists for the season, and Gabriel Quak (Sailors) scores a match-winning brace. The top scorer, Boris Kopitovic (Tampines), leads the list with 33 goals.

site_title: Dealing with transitory and structural economic shocks
summary: A 238 basis-point rise in US Treasury yields as of Sept 30 is one of the largest climbs in history. This significant economic shock is a concern, but the author emphasizes the importance of humility in navigating such transitory and structural economic shifts. By remaining open to diverse perspectives and ideas, investors can make informed decisions and adapt to changing market conditions, ultimately mitigating potential losses.

site_title: BT Money Hacks Podcast: Critical illness coverage - Insurance for your income
summary: A critical illness coverage podcast discusses how to insure against 'lost earnings' due to illness, in an inflation-riddled environment. Managing director Colin Chan from Great Eastern explains that critical illness plans can help protect income, and debunks common misconceptions about the gap in coverage. The conversation also touches on the evolving nature of C.I. plans and affordability. Great Eastern offers C.I. coverage as a solution to ensure financial stability during illness recovery.

site_title: S'pore non-oil exports disappoint with 3.1% rise in Sept, electronics shrink again
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 3.1% in September, but fell short of forecasts, with electronics exports shrinking 10.6% year-over-year, marking a two-month decline. Real non-oil domestic exports (Nodx) contracted 3.5% to a seven-month low, driven by higher prices rather than trade volumes. The decline was led by a sharp drop in electronics exports, and the outlook for regional manufacturing remains bleak due to US-China tensions and a weakening global growth outlook.

site_title: Keppel O&M to begin charters for four rig assets in Saudi Arabia
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) has completed modification works on four KFELS B Class jackup rigs, set to be deployed on bareboat charters in Saudi Arabia starting October. The rigs, capable of operating in 122m water depths and drilling to 9,140m, will be chartered to Arabian Drilling Company and ADES Saudi Limited Company for 3-5 years, yielding $250 million in charter revenue. The rigs will work for Saudi Aramco, the country's national oil company, with options for extension. The four rigs will be transferred to Asset Co after a proposed merger between Keppel O&M and Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: S’pore digital wealth adviser Endowus acquires Hong Kong’s Carret Private
summary: Endowus, a Singaporean digital wealth adviser, has acquired a controlling stake in Carret Private Investments, a leading Hong Kong-based wealth manager. The acquisition will combine Endowus's digital wealth technology with Carret's platform serving ultra-high-net-worth individuals, families, trusts, and charitable organizations across Asia. The combined entity will serve tens of thousands of clients with assets of over $4 billion, expanding Endowus's presence beyond Singapore and solidifying its position as one of Asia's largest independent wealth advisers.

site_title: Pound rallies as traders eye shift in UK fiscal stance under new finance minister
summary: The pound rose 0.6% to US$1.1243 in early Asia trading, boosted by expectations that UK Prime Minister Liz Truss' package of unfunded tax cuts may be partially reversed. New finance minister Jeremy Hunt stated that nothing is "off the table" for abandoning measures, signaling a shift towards fiscal probity. The pound has whipsawed in recent days, but analysts expect it to recover to pre-fiscal plan levels, with Goldman Sachs predicting a fall to US$1.05 in three months.

site_title: Quick-acting hotel executive stops guest from hurting himself, gets award for vigilance
summary: A hotel executive, Ms Marie Joyce Agustin, received a Special Mention Award for her quick action in stopping a guest from harming himself with scissors at The Clan Hotel Singapore in October 2022. The guest, in his 20s, had started slashing his wrist, but Agustin intervened, applying pressure to stem the blood loss and taking him to a quiet area. The guest suffered only superficial scratches and received medical attention. Agustin's actions were recognized at the annual Hotel Security Awards ceremony, alongside other hotel employees who were also honored for their bravery and vigilance.

images.alt_text: Ms Marie Joyce Agustin, a guest service executive at The Clan Hotel Singapore, who saved a suicidal guest last October.
Mr Gary Sim (right) and Mr Muhammad Zulhimi Suhardi are lifeguards at Shangri-La Rasa Sentosa. The pair saved two people who were drowning at sea after their kayaks capsized in August last year.

site_title: ST readers get creative with 'makeover' of Merlion
summary: The Straits Times invited readers to reimagine the iconic Merlion on its 50th birthday, and received over 300 submissions. Fifteen-year-old Yap Yuan Yuan and 12-year-old Nicole Chia, among 50 chosen artists, showcased their creative interpretations of the Merlion, incorporating local mascots, landmarks, and Singlish phrases. The artwork, which included drawings and paintings, aimed to capture the spirit of Singapore and its evolution. The selected artists will receive goodie bags containing Merlion memorabilia.

site_title: Invest Talk Podcast: How young investors can navigate inflation, higher interest rates and recession
summary: Invest Talk Podcast discusses how young investors can navigate inflation, higher interest rates, and recession. Associate editors Lee Su Shyan and Ven Sreenivasan offer tips on saving, investing, and earning a return in the current environment. They advise young adults to budget and spend smartly, save wisely, and invest in themselves. The hosts also address whether to invest in the stock market during a recession. The podcast aims to provide practical advice for young investors to manage their money effectively in uncertain economic times.

site_title: askST Jobs: I just got my first remote job. What should I look out for?
summary: Workers with remote or hybrid jobs should be aware of the software and technology used by their company, including how they are utilized. Experts recommend understanding the tools and systems to ensure seamless communication and productivity. This knowledge can also help remote workers identify potential technical issues and troubleshoot problems. By being informed, remote workers can better navigate their work environment and achieve success in their new role.

site_title: Sharp drop in transnational marriages in past 2 years due to Covid-19 travel curbs
summary: A sharp decline in transnational marriages in Singapore has been observed over the past two years, primarily due to Covid-19 travel restrictions. In 2019, approximately 8,100 transnational marriages were registered, but this number dropped to around 6,800 in 2021, a decrease of 15%. The proportion of transnational marriages among all citizen marriages also fell from 37% in 2019 to 29% in 2021, down from 30% in 2020. The decline is attributed to the disruptions caused by travel restrictions during the pandemic.

site_title: Workers can soon file unpaid salary claims online with help of chatbot
summary: Workers in Singapore can soon file unpaid salary claims online with the help of a chatbot called "Ask TADM" by March 2023. The Online Dispute Resolution portal, launched in 2020, will be integrated with the chatbot to simplify the process. This move aims to provide a more efficient and accessible way for employees to resolve disputes with their employers. The integration is part of the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management's efforts to improve dispute resolution in the country.

site_title: Over 3,000 devotees take part in Hindu fire-walking festival
summary: Over 3,000 devotees participated in the Hindu fire-walking festival, Theemithi, at Sri Mariamman Temple in Singapore. The event, held without restrictions for the first time in two years, was attended by Minister Josephine Teo and saw the return of a 4km walk and a sacred vessel procession. The ceremony, which symbolizes gratitude for blessings granted, was delayed by an hour due to rain and accommodated up to 1,000 people at a time, down from pre-pandemic numbers of 5,000-6,000.

site_title: 370,000 women have benefited from subsidised mammogram screenings
summary: About 370,000 women in Singapore have benefited from subsidized mammogram screenings since 2002, with nearly 90% being diagnosed at an earlier stage of breast cancer. The Health Promotion Board's Screen For Life initiative has detected over 4,800 cancers. The program encourages women aged 50 and above to undergo screenings every two years. Additionally, the Ministry of Health is promoting healthier lifestyles through the Healthier SG program, which includes osteoporosis prevention and cervical cancer vaccination.

site_title: Some S'pore owners fit emission-cheating devices in their vehicles to save thousands of dollars each year
summary: Some diesel trucks and buses in Singapore have been fitted with "defeat devices" that override emission cleaning systems, allowing vehicles to bypass standards and emit high levels of nitrogen oxide, a poisonous greenhouse gas. These devices, sold online, save owners thousands of dollars each year by reducing the cost of AdBlue, a solution meant to clean exhaust emissions. The use of such devices is a concern, as it can harm the environment and public health, and is likely to be illegal under Singapore's emission regulations.

site_title: Icons, everyday sights and Singlish phrases: ST readers get creative with Merlion's 'makeover'
summary: Singaporeans, aged 5-60, submitted 50 reimagined Merlion artworks for its 50th birthday, showcasing creativity and nostalgia. The artworks incorporated Singlish phrases, everyday sights, and mascots of public campaigns. A 15-year-old student, a 12-year-old Primary 6 pupil, and a 60-year-old senior consultant were among the 50 chosen, with their pieces displayed in an interactive graphic. The selected artists will receive a goodie bag containing Merlion memorabilia, while the public can view the artworks online. The event aims to celebrate the Merlion's enduring significance in Singapore's identity.

site_title: Football: Mbappe insists he 'never asked to leave' PSG
summary: Kylian Mbappe, Paris Saint-Germain star, denied ever asking to leave the club in January, despite reports he intended to seek a move. In a statement, Mbappe insisted he was "happy" and "never asked to leave," contradicting rumors fueled by his entourage. The France superstar attributed the reports to a misunderstanding, stating he was shocked by the news. Mbappe recently signed a three-year contract with PSG in May.

site_title: Call for S'poreans to compile family history: Man spends 17 years on research to write book
summary: A 71-year-old retired florist, Bernard Chiang, spent 17 years researching and writing a book about his family's history, which spans three countries and cultures. The book, "The Chiang Family History - A Tale Of Three Cultures And Chia Keng Village," was launched by the Genealogy Society Singapore on October 7, 2022. Chiang's research involved compiling family records and tracing their ancestry, ultimately resulting in a unique and detailed account of his family's history.

site_title: Use new dedicated cycling lane in Seletar properly or face penalties
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has launched a new dedicated cycling lane in Seletar, Singapore, with exclusive access to cyclists from 5am to 11am on Sundays. The 4.6km lane, marked with solid blue lines, aims to promote safe cycling. Motorists and cyclists found to be reckless will face penalties. The trial will run for six months to gather feedback and assess its impact on traffic, with plans to expand similar lanes to other areas, including the Central Business District, if successful.

site_title: T-Rex skeleton to go on display in Singapore before auction in Hong Kong
summary: A nearly complete T-Rex skeleton named Shen, assembled from 79 excavated bones, will be displayed in Singapore before auctioning off in Hong Kong on November 30. Estimated value: US$15-25 million. The 1,400kg skeleton, named Shen meaning "god-like" in Chinese, will be displayed from October 28-30 at the Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall. Critics worry private collectors may outbid museums, limiting public access to the fossil. Experts express concern that private ownership may hinder scientific research and preservation.

site_title: Cost and revenue in public transport will never meet
summary: The Singapore Government emphasizes that the cost of public transport will never meet revenue levels, acknowledging it's an unideal situation. However, the alternative is unthinkable, as it would require significant subsidies funded by taxpayers. The government reminds the public that all goods and services come with a cost, and the fare revision in October is a necessary reminder of this reality.

site_title: Workers can soon file unpaid salary claims online with help of chatbot
summary: Workers in Singapore can file unpaid salary claims online by March 2023, thanks to an integrated Online Dispute Resolution portal and a chatbot. The portal, launched in 2020, will now be trialed and ready for use by then, providing a convenient and accessible way for employees to compute and submit claims against their employers. The move aims to streamline the dispute resolution process, making it easier for workers to seek redress for unpaid salaries.

site_title: Emission-cheating devices installed in some trucks and buses in S'pore
summary: Singapore has discovered diesel trucks and buses fitted with "defeat devices" that override emission-cleaning systems, allowing vehicles to bypass standards and emit high levels of nitrogen oxide, a poisonous greenhouse gas. These devices are sold online and can be found on some vehicles in the country. The discovery highlights a significant environmental concern, as nitrogen oxide emissions can have severe health and environmental impacts. Authorities are likely to take action against vehicle owners and sellers of these devices to address the issue.

site_title: Funds still flowing into private markets, but investors more selective
summary: Global venture funding plummeted to US$74.5 billion in the third quarter, down 30% from the previous quarter, marking the lowest level in nine quarters. Slower growth and rising interest rates have led to a pullback in business valuations and reduced investor appetite for risk.

site_title: More foreigners here falling prey to scams
summary: Foreigners in Malaysia are increasingly falling victim to scams, with losses more than doubling to $88 million in 2021. The most common scams include phishing and job-related ones. A recent case involved a 34-year-old Malaysian nurse who was scammed out of $77,000 in just a week after meeting a man on an online dating app. The scammer pressured her to invest in a platform, leaving her with significant financial loss and regret. Authorities are urging caution and warning of the dangers of online scams.

site_title: Book on family's history the fruit of 17 years of research
summary: Retired florist Bernard Chiang spent 17 years researching his family's history, spanning three countries and cultures, and has published a book, "The Chiang Family History - A Tale Of Three Cultures And Chia Keng Village". The book was launched by the Genealogy Society Singapore on October 7. Chiang's story is seen as an inspiration for Singaporeans to record their own ancestors' stories to enrich the nation's social history.

site_title: 17-year-old tricked into being 'undercover agent' for scammers
summary: A 17-year-old Chinese student was tricked into becoming an "undercover agent" for scammers posing as Chinese officials, who demanded he pay a $60,000 fine for money laundering. The student, a Secondary 4 student, was promised forgiveness for his crimes and potential membership in the Communist Party of China if he cooperated. He was deceived into taking on this role, highlighting the vulnerability of young people to online scams. Authorities have not commented on the incident.

site_title: Q3 earnings to feature in coming weeks amid strong US dollar, high inflation
summary: Global markets experienced significant fluctuations last week, with investors reacting to various news flows and expectations. The US dollar remained strong, and high inflation persisted, affecting market performance. Sats, a Singapore-based company, closed at $2.73 on Friday, its lowest since 2021, amid market volatility. The upcoming Q3 earnings season is expected to feature in the coming weeks, with investors closely monitoring developments amidst ongoing market uncertainty.

site_title: Get tips on choosing a secondary school at ST webinar
summary: The new Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE) scoring system has made little difference to postings for popular secondary schools. Only two schools saw a fluctuation by one achievement level, with Temasek Junior College having a cut-off point of eight and Methodist Girls' School having a cut-off point of seven. A webinar on November 12 will discuss school postings under the new system and full subject-based banding, which will be implemented in about 90 schools by 2023. The event will feature an MOE official and six secondary school principals, offering tips and insights for parents choosing a secondary school.

site_title: China auto sector raises $8.5b as EV start-ups defy funding slump
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) start-ups have defied the global venture capital funding slump, raising $8.5 billion in funding this year, with EVs accounting for the majority of deals. Despite a contraction in VC investment globally, China's auto sector has led the way, with provincial and municipal governments taking minority stakes in EV companies through city-financed investment funds. State support, including tax breaks, cheap loans, and capital investment, has contributed to the sector's buoyancy, with local governments backing major EV-related IPOs and seeking to replicate the success of Hefei, a city that made a return of 5½ times its investment in Nio.

site_title: Insects like crickets may be coming to your dinner plate soon
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) is seeking feedback on allowing insects for human consumption and as livestock feed. Insects like crickets, beetles, and moths could be consumed directly or made into products such as snacks or protein bars. The agency is considering regulations similar to those in the European Union and other countries that have already allowed the consumption of certain insect species. Companies are expressing interest in importing or farming insects for food and animal feed, citing their high nutrient content and potential to support sustainable food production.

site_title: T-Rex skeleton to go on display in S'pore before auction in HK
summary: A Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton, named Shen, will be displayed at Singapore's Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall before auctioning off in Hong Kong on November 30. The 1,400kg skeleton, assembled from 79 bones and additional casts, is estimated to be worth between US$15 million and US$25 million. The auction, hosted by Christie's Hong Kong, is the first Asian auction of a T-Rex skeleton, sparking concerns among palaeontologists that private collectors may outbid museums, limiting public access to the fossil.

site_title: What you should pay attention to when you get a remote job
summary: A new remote worker should actively participate in the on-boarding process to understand the employer's mission, culture, and internal workings. This is crucial for a smooth transition and success in the role. Experts recommend engaging with the company to gain a deeper understanding of its policies and expectations.

site_title: Q3 earnings to feature in coming weeks amid strong US dollar, high inflation
summary: Global markets experienced volatility last week due to various news flows and expectations. Despite a strong US dollar and high inflation, Wall Street rallied on Thursday after falling earlier in the week, driven by a rebound in stocks. The strong greenback is expected to be a significant headwind for Q3 earnings, which are set to be released in the coming weeks.

site_title: 2022 a difficult year for IPOs as recession looms, growth prospects fade
summary: IPOs worldwide fell 44% in 2022 compared to the previous year, with the Singapore IPO scene remaining muted. The decline is attributed to a looming recession, high inflation, and rising interest rates, which have led to slower economic growth and reduced fundraising opportunities for companies. Experts warn that the global economy may be entering a recession next year, making it an even more challenging time for companies seeking to raise funds through IPOs.

site_title: Spurs players are growing in many aspects: Conte
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte praised his team's ability to "find solutions" after a 2-0 win over Everton in the English Premier League. The victory, sealed by Harry Kane's late penalty, took Spurs to 23 points from their first 10 league games, their best tally at this point of the season. Conte credited his players for growing in various aspects, particularly after making a tactical change that led to a dominant second half. The win came despite Richarlison's injury, which could keep him out of the upcoming match against Manchester United.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: The article provides schedules for sports events, including tennis and football, across the next two days. On Monday, the ATP Tour's Napoli Cup and European Open, as well as the WTA Tour's Guadalajara Open, will begin. On Tuesday, English Premier League and Spanish Primera Liga matches will take place, including Brighton vs. Forest and Sevilla vs. Valencia. The schedules are available on various TV channels, including Singtel TV and StarHub.

site_title: 2022 a difficult year for IPOs as recession looms and growth prospects fade
summary: The year 2022 has been challenging for companies raising funds through initial public offerings (IPOs) and private markets, due to the looming recession and fading growth prospects. The International Monetary Fund warned of a potential global recession in 2023, citing high inflation and rising interest rates. As a result, companies are struggling to raise the funds needed to grow, with slower economic growth across many economies. This trend is expected to continue into 2023, making it a difficult year for companies seeking to raise capital.

site_title: Dealing with transitory and structural economic shocks
summary: Economic shocks are becoming increasingly complex, with some being transitory and others reflecting fundamental structural changes. The recent rise in US Treasury yields and decline in the S&P 500 are among the largest in history. Factors such as deglobalization, a shrinking working-age population, and geopolitical tensions are driving the need for structurally higher inflation and interest rates. The US dollar is expected to remain resilient despite potential capital outflows, as the US economy's fundamentals remain strong. The writer urges investors to adapt to a new era of inflation and higher interest rates, citing the importance of humility and openness to different perspectives.

site_title: Funds still flowing into private markets, but investors more selective
summary: Global venture funding fell to $74.5 billion in Q3, a 30% decline from Q2, the lowest level in nine quarters, according to CB Insights. The funding pullback is attributed to slower growth and rising interest rates, particularly affecting riskier sectors such as cryptocurrencies. Investors have become more selective, indicating a shift in market sentiment.

site_title: NBA great Mutombo has brain tumour
summary: NBA Hall of Famer Dikembe Mutombo, 56, is undergoing treatment for a brain tumor, according to the league. A global ambassador for the NBA, Mutombo played for several teams, including the Denver Nuggets and Philadelphia 76ers, and was a two-time NBA Finals participant. He is receiving the best care possible and asks for privacy during this time, with the NBA and commissioner Adam Silver offering support. Mutombo's legacy as one of the world's great humanitarians will be remembered, following his time as a standout player and founder of the Dikembe Mutombo Foundation.

site_title: S'pore to host fencing league in 2023
summary: Singapore will host a leg of the Fencing Professionals Assembly (FPA), a private fencing league, in the first quarter of 2023. The league, which also includes legs in Doha and Milan, aims to raise the profile of fencing by giving athletes a chance to shine beyond major Games. Olympic medallists and world champions are expected to compete, with a prize pool and pilot event held in Singapore in 2022. Fencing Singapore hopes to capitalize on Singapore's reputation for hosting sports events, with a strong team targetting medals at the 2023 Asian Games.

site_title: 'United should have won'
summary: Manchester United and Cristiano Ronaldo drew 0-0 against Newcastle United at Old Trafford, with the visitors' Joelinton having the best chance of the game. Ronaldo had two goals disallowed due to offside, while Newcastle goalkeeper Nick Pope kept a clean sheet for the fourth time in 10 league games. The draw keeps both teams in the top six, with United fifth on 16 points and Newcastle sixth. United boss Erik ten Hag praised his team's effort but expressed frustration over their lack of cutting edge, saying they "could, we should have scored the winning goal."

site_title: Koepka outlasts Uihlein in play-off
summary: Brooks Koepka won the US$25 million Jeddah Invitational on the LIV Golf tour, outlasting Peter Uihlein in a three-hole playoff. Koepka closed with a 69 to Uihlein's 70, and Koepka won after Uihlein's wayward drive into a bunker resulted in a missed putt. This was Koepka's first LIV Golf victory, coming after a tough period marked by injuries. Sergio Garcia and Joaquin Niemann finished one stroke back.

site_title: Max stays on Olympic course
summary: Maximilian Maeder, a 16-year-old kitefoiler, secured a silver medal at the Formula Kite World Championships in Cagliari, Italy, on Sunday. The achievement marks his best result at the senior level and cements his spot in the 2023 Sailing World Championships, a key Olympic qualification event. Maeder's performance is seen as a promising start to his Olympic aspirations, with the Sailing Federation's general manager stating he has the potential to qualify for the 2024 Paris Games.

site_title: Hard work pays off as Bradley ends four-year drought
summary: Keegan Bradley won his first PGA Tour victory in four years at the Zozo Championship in Japan, edging out Rickie Fowler and Andrew Putnam. Bradley closed with a 2-under 68 to finish 15-under 265, earning $1.98 million. The 36-year-old world No. 44 expressed his emotional relief and pride after his clutch birdie putt on the 17th hole, his first win since the 2018 BMW Championship. Bradley credits his hard work and hopes this win will be a springboard for greater recognition and Ryder Cup contention.

site_title: Elite runners teach drills ahead of GEWR
summary: Elite runners Jenny Huang, Jasmine Goh, and Choo Ling Er led a run clinic and exercise drills for over 50 women and their families from charity group Daughters Of Tomorrow at the Singapore Sports Hub. The event aimed to support Daughters Of Tomorrow, one of Great Eastern's adopted charities for the 2022 Great Eastern Women's Run. Participants, including 57-year-old grandmother Asmah, praised the elite runners for sharing their fitness tips and inspiring others to participate in the upcoming run. The event encouraged public support for the causes via a fund-raising initiative.

site_title: Third time's the charm for Brausse; Kouame wins rare title for France
summary: Franziska Brausse won the women's individual pursuit at the track cycling world championships, her third podium finish in as many years. Brausse edged out New Zealand's Bryony Botha, while Britain's Josie Knight claimed bronze. Meanwhile, Marie-Divine Kouame made history by becoming the first Frenchwoman since 1999 to win the women's 500m gold. The event marked a successful day for France, with the women's madison and men's omnium crowns also up for grabs on Sunday.

site_title: California Spangle sends warning to Golden Sixty
summary: California Spangle, trained by Tony Cruz, won the HK$5 million Oriental Watch Sha Tin Trophy Handicap over 1,600m with a 45.63-second surge to the finish, beating second-place Tourbillon Diamond and third-place Savvy Nine. The 8-1 winner is now set to face Golden Sixty and Romantic Warrior in the BOCHK Private Wealth Jockey Club Mile on Nov 20. Champion jockey Zac Purton believes California Spangle needs to improve to beat Golden Sixty in the Group 1 Longines Hong Kong Mile on Dec 11, calling Golden Sixty "the champ" and saying he's still the favorite to win.

site_title: 50 ways to reimagine the Merlion as it hits the big five-o | The Straits Times
summary: The Straits Times invited readers to reimagine the Merlion, Singapore's iconic lion-fish hybrid, to celebrate its 50th birthday. Over 300 entries were received, and 50 winning creations showcased the statue in new and creative ways. The Merlion was first built in 1972 by local sculptor Lim Nang Seng, based on a blueprint by the University of Singapore's vice-chancellor. Since then, it has become a popular tourist spot and has undergone several transformations, including being struck by lightning and turned into a pop-up hotel.

site_title: Sports World: Swiatek on cusp of eighth title this year
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek advanced to the San Diego Open final, beating Jessica Pegula 4-6, 6-2, 6-2. She will face Danielle Collins or Donna Vekic in the final. Meanwhile, Elina Svitolina welcomed her first child, a daughter named Skai, after stepping back from tennis due to the mental toll of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. In the UFC, Alexa Grasso won her fourth straight fight, defeating Viviane Araujo by unanimous decision.

site_title: Clements has an exciting 3yo for 2023
summary: Trainer Michael Clements' three-year-old Ejaz, owned by Al-Arabiya Stable, has secured his second win in just three starts in the $75,000 Laughing Gravy 2016 Stakes Novice race.
