Ejaz, a chestnut son of Street Boss, won by 13/4 lengths, ahead of stablemates Montana Flash and Deception. Clements praised Ejaz's performance, saying he's shown speed and ability to finish strong. With this win, Clements is considered a top contender for the 2023 Singapore Three-Year-Old series, and his stable is also building up for the 2024 crop.

site_title: Football: Guardiola says coins were thrown at him in Liverpool loss
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola claimed coins were thrown at him during their 1-0 loss to Liverpool, a heated encounter in which Liverpool coach Juergen Klopp was sent to the stands. Guardiola expressed frustration with the disallowed goal by Phil Foden and the referee's decision, stating that Liverpool fans retaliated after he remonstrated with them. The incident sparked a statement from Liverpool condemning vile chants from City supporters, who vandalized the concourse with graffiti.

site_title: Football: Super Salah ignites Liverpool season, as Man City lose for first time
summary: Liverpool earned a 1-0 victory over Manchester City, with Mohamed Salah scoring the winning goal in the 86th minute. The win marked Liverpool's first defeat in their previous 27 home league matches and gave them a much-needed boost in their season. The match saw Liverpool's coach Juergen Klopp red-carded for protesting a foul, while City's Pep Guardiola was furious at the referee's decision. The win moved Liverpool up to eighth in the standings, 10 points behind second-placed City.

site_title: Worth investing in Global Dollar again
summary: Key South African horse racing analysis for Monday's Greyville races includes potential investments and strong contenders. RACE 1: (7) McCartney, (4) Word for Word, and (9) King's Spear show promising form. RACE 2: (1) Johnny's Hope, (3) Imaginable, and (6) Corsican are top contenders. site_title: Gunners win amid chaos
summary: Arsenal secured their best start to a Premier League season with a 1-0 win over Leeds, despite chaos and controversy. Bukayo Saka scored the only goal in the 35th minute, and the Gunners benefited from two VAR calls that overturned a penalty and a goal. Leeds missed several chances, including a penalty, and Arsenal's goalkeeper was also saved by a spectacular stop. The win keeps Arsenal at the top of the table and leaves Leeds frustrated, with manager Jesse Marsch praising his team's discipline and concentration.

site_title: Benzema sends Real top of La Liga
summary: Karim Benzema led Real Madrid to a 3-1 win over Barcelona, moving his team to the top of La Liga with 25 points. Benzema scored in the 12th minute and added a penalty in added time, as Real Madrid defeated the lifeless Barcelona. The win marks a significant statement by Real Madrid, who had lost to Barcelona 4-0 in the corresponding fixture last season. Benzema's performance has strengthened his case for the Ballon d'Or, with the French striker now joint-eighth on the all-time El Clasico goal list.

site_title: Disruptive civil war bad for golf
summary: The PGA Tour and LIV Golf Series are further apart due to their rivalry, with events held on the same continent. The divide was evident at the Zozo Championship in Japan, where American Keegan Bradley won on the PGA Tour. Meanwhile, LIV Golfers Dustin Johnson, Cameron Smith, and Eugenio Chacarra competed for a $25 million prize in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. The ongoing feud threatens to disrupt the sport, with the PGA Tour and LIV Golf continuing to drive each other further apart. The rivalry is causing tension among the golf fraternity.

site_title: Football: Newcastle frustrate Man United and misfiring Ronaldo
summary: Manchester United and Newcastle United drew 0-0 at Old Trafford, with Cristiano Ronaldo's goal attempts thwarted by offside calls and disallowed by the referee. Newcastle, led by Eddie Howe, showed solidity and passion, with Joelinton's double header the closest they came to scoring. The result keeps both teams in the top six, with Manchester United fifth on 16 points and Newcastle sixth on 15 points. Ronaldo has now scored only twice this season, sparking concerns about his career.

site_title: Football: Chelsea maintain run as Mount scores twice in win at Villa
summary: Mason Mount scored a double to lead Chelsea to a 2-0 Premier League win over Aston Villa, maintaining the team's unbeaten run in six games under Graham Potter. The victory lifted Chelsea to fourth place with 19 points from nine games. Villa, meanwhile, remain 16th with pressure mounting on manager Steven Gerrard. Mount's goals were assisted by a defensive error from Tyrone Mings, who has lost his place in the England squad.

site_title: Football: Unbeaten Real Madrid defeat Barcelona in Clasico to top La Liga
summary: Real Madrid defeated Barcelona 3-1 in the Clasico, overtaking their rivals at the top of La Liga. Karim Benzema scored in the 12th minute, with Fede Valverde adding a second before Ferran Torres pulled one back for Barcelona. Rodrygo converted a late penalty to seal the win, ending Barcelona's seven-game winning streak in the league and leaving them three points behind Madrid. The victory marks Real Madrid's 15th consecutive La Liga win and their 100th at the Santiago Bernabeu.

site_title: Golf: Koepka grabs biggest payday with LIV play-off win
summary: US golfer Brooks Koepka won the LIV Golf Invitational-Jeddah play-off with a birdie on the third hole, securing a US$4 million payday. This victory denied Peter Uihlein, his close friend, a potential US$12.75 million win. Koepka's win also earned him an additional US$750,000 for team victory. The tournament marked the first LIV stop in Saudi Arabia and the last individual event of the debut season, which has sparked controversy over LIV's funding and its impact on the golf world.

site_title: Football: Arsenal hold off hungry Leeds to stay top of Premier League
summary: Arsenal secured a 1-0 victory over Leeds United, staying top of the Premier League with their best ever start to a season. Bukayo Saka scored the winning goal in the 35th minute, and the result gave Arsenal 27 points from 10 games, four ahead of Manchester City. Leeds had several scoring opportunities but were unable to capitalize, and the loss marked their first home loss of the season. The win solidified Arsenal's position as the league leaders, while Leeds fell to 15th in the table with nine points from nine games.

site_title: 370,000 women benefited from subsidised mammogram screenings since 2002
summary: About 370,000 women in Singapore have benefited from nearly a million subsidized mammogram screenings since 2002, with 90% of cases detected at an earlier stage of breast cancer. The Health Promotion Board's Screen For Life initiative has led to the detection of over 4,800 cancers. The program aims to promote early detection and treatment, with subsidized screenings available for eligible women. The Women's Health Committee also addresses other key health concerns, including cervical cancer prevention and osteoporosis prevention through improved bone health.

site_title: Fencing: Top athletes to compete in S'pore, which will host one leg of new pro league
summary: Singapore will host one leg of the Fencing Professionals Assembly (FPA), a new three-stop private league, in the first quarter of 2023. The league aims to professionalize the sport, featuring Olympic medallists and world champions, with a prize pool and a strong base to raise the sport's profile. The FPA will be held in Singapore, Doha, and Milan, with plans for a fourth leg. The league's CEO, Francesco Rossi, compares it to the International Swimming League (ISL) and golf's PGA Tour, seeking to change the sport's perception and give athletes a chance to shine beyond major Games.

site_title: More than 3,000 Hindu devotees take part in biggest fire-walking festival in S'pore since Covid-19
summary: More than 3,000 Hindu devotees participated in the biggest fire-walking festival in Singapore since the Covid-19 pandemic. The ceremony, known as Theemithi, was held without restrictions and featured a 4km walk led by Sri Mariamman Temple's chief priest. The event, which symbolizes 18 days of war, saw devotees walk barefoot on burning embers, with some participants taking part for the 28th time. The ceremony was delayed due to rain but returned to its pre-pandemic scale, with about 5,000 to 6,000 participants before the pandemic.

site_title: With so much riding on the Fed's moves, it's hard to know how to invest
summary: The US Federal Reserve's efforts to slow inflation by slowing economic growth are starting to show results, with the Conference Board's index of 10 forward-looking indicators falling for the sixth consecutive month. However, inflation remains stubbornly high, and markets are uncertain about the Fed's next moves. Analysts predict a possible "credit event" could prompt a pivot, but others warn of more pain ahead. The Fed's aggressive campaign has sent stock and bond prices tumbling, with the S&P 500 plummeting 5.3% in the third quarter. Investors are advised to remain cautious, with some recommending a barbell approach to stocks and others favoring bonds, pending a potential pivot by the Fed.

site_title: Forex traders eye Japan response as yen approaches 150 per US dollar
summary: The Japanese yen reached a 32-year low, closing at 148.70 per US dollar last Friday, after nine consecutive weeks of losses. Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki expressed concern over market volatility, and chief currency official Masato Kanda stated the authorities are prepared to take "bold action" to support the currency. The yen has fallen 23% against the US dollar in 2022 due to the monetary policy differential between the US and Japan. Analysts expect the yen to continue to decline, with some speculating that 150 per US dollar is a key psychological level that could prompt government intervention.

site_title: MMA: Alexa Grasso wins by unanimous decision at Fight Night
summary: Alexa Grasso won by unanimous decision against Viviane Araujo at UFC Fight Night in Las Vegas. Grasso took all three judges' scorecards with scores of 49-46, 49-46, and 50-45. This victory marks her fourth consecutive win, improving her record to 15-3. Grasso landed 193 strikes, while Araujo had 148 and 126. The win solidifies Grasso's position in the flyweight division.

site_title: Golf: Outside the ropes, the battle heats up between LIV Golf and PGA Tour
summary: The rivalry between the PGA Tour and LIV Golf continues to escalate, with lawsuits flying between the two rival circuits. Recent events saw PGA Tour winner Keegan Bradley and LIV Golfers Dustin Johnson, Cameron Smith, and Eugenio Chacarra compete in separate tournaments. The divide between the two tours has driven them further apart, with the PGA Tour focusing on its own wins and LIV Golf pushing for its own success, including a $25 million prize. The ongoing feud raises questions about the future of golf's two main tours.

site_title: Kitefoiling: Maximilian Maeder wins silver at Formula Kite World Championships
summary: Maximilian Maeder, a 16-year-old kitefoiler, won a silver medal at the 2022 Formula Kite World Championships in Cagliari, Italy. This marks his best-ever result at the senior level, following multiple youth world championships and Asian titles. Despite falling short of a world title, Maeder's second-place finish is an improvement from last year's fifth-place finish. His performance secures a spot at the 2023 Sailing World Championships, a key Olympic qualification event, and puts him in good stead to qualify for the 2024 Paris Olympics.

site_title: Motorcycling: Rins wins Australian MotoGP as Quartararo crashes out
summary: Alex Rins won the Australian MotoGP, claiming his 100th premier class podium and securing a surprise victory. Rins, starting 10th, outpaced Marc Marquez by 0.186 seconds. Francesco Bagnaia took third, moving to the top of the championship standings. Fabio Quartararo crashed out, dealing a significant blow to his title hopes. Bagnaia now leads the championship with a 14-point advantage heading into the penultimate grand prix in Malaysia.

site_title: Cyclists, motorists could face penalties for reckless use of Seletar dedicated cycling lane
summary: Singapore's new dedicated cycling lane in Seletar, which opened for a six-month trial, may impose penalties on reckless cyclists and motorists. The 4.6km lane, open from 5am to 11am on Sundays, has solid blue lines and signboards indicating operating hours. Enforcement by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and a new handbook will guide safe sharing of space. The trial aims to gather feedback and assess impact on traffic before finalizing plans for future dedicated lanes.

site_title: Cycling: Third time lucky for Germany's Brausse at track worlds
summary: Germany's Franziska Brausse won the women's individual pursuit at the UCI Track Cycling World Championships, her first gold medal in three years. Brausse, 23, edged New Zealand's Bryony Botha by a narrow margin after "suffering" in the grueling 3km race. Brausse's victory marks her first gold in a major championship, following podium finishes in 2020 and 2022. Britain's Josie Knight took bronze, while France's Marie-Divine Kouame won the women's 500m event.

site_title: China's auto sector defies funding slump, with EV start-ups leading the way
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) start-ups have defied the global venture capital funding slump, with over 147 deals amounting to $5.95 billion in funding so far this year. The sector's growth is attributed to ample state support, including tax breaks, cheap loans, and capital investment. Provincial and municipal governments have taken minority stakes in EV companies, offsetting the decline in foreign venture dollars. Despite a slight decline in overall deal value, EV-related deals have logged more deals than last year, with top EV start-ups collectively selling 465,300 cars from January to September 2022.

site_title: Golf: Bradley staves off Fowler, Putnam to win Zozo Championship
summary: Keegan Bradley won the Zozo Championship in Japan with a one-stroke victory over Rickie Fowler and Andrew Putnam. Bradley finished 15-under overall with a two-under 68 in the final round, securing his first PGA Tour win in four years. The 36-year-old American held off a late surge from Putnam and Fowler to claim his fifth tournament victory, praising his practice and clutch putting on the 17th hole. Bradley earned $1.98 million, the largest prize in the $11 million tournament.

site_title: Consumption of insects like crickets, beetles may soon be approved in S'pore
summary: Singapore's Singapore Food Agency (SFA) is seeking feedback on allowing the consumption of insects like crickets and beetles as food and livestock feed. The agency has assessed specific species with a history of human consumption and will subject imported or locally farmed insects to food safety requirements. The move aims to promote sustainable food production and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Companies are welcoming the change, citing the high nutrient content and potential for insect farming to support food security. A public consultation is ongoing until Dec 4, with the goal of introducing a regulatory framework for insect products.

site_title: Lifting of VDS for Mice events reduces manpower cost, brings in foreign attendees
summary: Singapore's lifting of vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) for events with over 500 participants has reduced manpower costs and attracted foreign attendees. The move, effective October 10, has eased restrictions and allowed for more planning visits and site inspections, potentially increasing contracts and pipeline for Mice events. Organizers expect a higher turnout, with some citing a 40-50% increase in labor costs due to VDS procedures. The industry is now in a strong position to rebound to pre-pandemic levels, with the safety of attendees remaining a top priority.

site_title: Boxing: Wilder knocks out Helenius in triumphant heavyweight return
summary: Former world heavyweight champion Deontay Wilder made a triumphant return, knocking out Finland's Robert Helenius in the first round of their bout. Wilder, 38, improved his record to 43-2 with 42 KOs, after a year-long lay-off. The victory likely sets up a 2023 fight against Andy Ruiz, with Wilder also open to a bout against Oleksandr Usyk. Wilder stated he wanted to "make boxing fun again" and expressed his excitement to be back in the heavyweight division, which he believes is "back on track."

site_title: 4 things to know about Healthier SG
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG is a preventive care strategy aimed at empowering individuals to take charge of their health. The program pairs residents with a single family doctor, providing free consultations and health plans. Residents can access free annual check-ups, vaccinations, and screenings for diseases such as diabetes and cancer. Cheaper medicines and a new subsidy tier for chronic disease drugs will also be introduced. The program includes healthy activities, enhanced public infrastructure, and a revamped Healthy 365 app to encourage active lifestyles, with a budget of $1 billion over three to four years.

site_title: Have your say to help shape Healthier SG
summary: Singapore's new preventive care strategy, Healthier SG, aims to have patients stick with one family doctor to take charge of their health. The strategy is designed to improve healthcare by reducing fragmentation and costs. However, some critics have expressed skepticism about the approach, questioning its effectiveness and potential impact on existing healthcare systems. Healthier SG is part of a larger healthcare transformation strategy, but its benefits and challenges remain to be fully realized. The strategy's success will depend on its ability to address these concerns and deliver tangible results for the country's residents.

site_title: Get tips on secondary school selection and postings at Straits Times webinar
summary: The new PSLE scoring system introduced in 2021 has made little difference in the posting patterns of popular secondary schools in Singapore. Only two schools, Temasek Junior College and Methodist Girls' School, saw a fluctuation of one achievement level compared to indicative figures. Despite this, student diversity was maintained, and principals reported no significant changes in intake numbers. A post-PSLE webinar on Nov 12 will provide more information and tips on secondary school selection and posting patterns, including full subject-based banding, which will be implemented in about 90 schools by 2023.

site_title: Bilingual book on long-lost Qixi Festival launched, authors hope to bring celebration back
summary: A bilingual book titled "Reviving Qixi: Singapore's Forgotten Seven Sisters Festival" was launched in Chinatown, documenting the rise and fall of the Qixi Festival in Singapore. Authors Lynn Wong and Lee Kok Leong hope to revive the festival, which was once celebrated until the 1970s, with the book's release. The festival is associated with the legend of the cowherd and weaver girl and was an important traditional Chinese festival for women in Singapore. The book is partially funded by the National Heritage Board and aims to revive the festival through community involvement and collaborations.

site_title: Scammers tricked 17-year-old foreign student into becoming their ‘undercover agent’
summary: A 17-year-old Chinese foreign student, Peter, was tricked by scammers into becoming their "undercover agent" after being threatened with a $60,000 fine for money laundering offences. To avoid trouble and bring honour to his family, Peter agreed to the role, which involved combating fraud. The scammers promised him forgiveness and potential membership in the Chinese Communist Party if he performed well, but the true intentions remain unclear.

site_title: GPs air concerns about annual service fee, medication subsidies under Healthier SG
summary: Singaporean GPs express concerns about the effectiveness of Healthier SG, a preventive care strategy aimed at encouraging patients to switch to family doctors. The strategy includes medication subsidies, but GPs question whether these subsidies will be enough to persuade patients to make the switch. GPs emphasize the need for regular checks and tests for diabetic patients, particularly for eye and foot complications, highlighting the need for more comprehensive support under Healthier SG.

site_title: Tennis: Swiatek rallies past Pegula to reach San Diego final
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek rallied past American Jessica Pegula 4-6, 6-2, 6-2 to reach the San Diego Open final. The match was suspended due to rain after Pegula took a 4-6, 6-4, 4-2 lead over Donna Vekic in the semi-finals. Swiatek overcame a first-set loss and regained focus to secure her 4-1 lifetime advantage against Pegula. She will face either Danielle Collins or Donna Vekic in the final on Sunday.

site_title: Demand for ferries between S'pore and Malaysia, Indonesia increases, 1.1m passengers from Jan to Sept
summary: Ferry travel between Singapore and Malaysia/Indonesia has seen a significant surge, with 1.1 million passengers passing through Singapore's international ferry terminals from January to September 2022. Following the reopening of borders in June, long queues were observed at Tanah Merah Ferry Terminal in October. The increased demand suggests that Singaporeans are opting for ferry rides as a convenient and hassle-free way to travel to nearby destinations.

site_title: Quest for a healthier Singapore: What's needed to get Healthier SG off the ground?
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG, a preventive care strategy, aims to empower individuals to take charge of their health. Primary care physicians will play a larger role, with fees based on health risk profiles and care scopes. GPs have expressed concerns about annual service fees and medication subsidies. The strategy, set to roll out in 2023, will focus on managing chronic conditions, particularly diabetes, with regular checks and tests. Critics have questioned the strategy's effectiveness, citing previous efforts to encourage patient ownership of health.

site_title: More foreigners scammed in S'pore, with $88m lost in 2021
summary: A significant increase in foreigner scams was reported in Singapore in 2021, with $88 million lost. The number of cases involving foreign victims rose from 3,431 in 2020 to 5,210 in 2021. One notable incident involved Malaysian nurse Pan Han Ni, who was scammed of $77,000 by a man she met on an online dating app. The scam involved pressure to invest in a platform, leaving her with significant financial losses. This highlights the growing concern of online scams targeting foreigners in Singapore.

site_title: Primary care physicians to play larger role under Healthier SG
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG strategy aims to have primary care physicians play a larger role in preventive care, starting in the second half of 2023. Under this plan, family doctors will help individuals take charge of their health. The goal is to improve health outcomes and reduce hospital readmissions. However, some questions remain unanswered, such as how the strategy will address existing healthcare systems and ensure seamless transitions. The shift is expected to transform Singapore's healthcare landscape, but details on implementation and potential challenges have yet to be fully addressed.

site_title: Buoyant demand for ferry services to Malaysia, Indonesia
summary: Singapore's international ferry terminals saw 1.1 million passengers from January to September, reaching 45% of pre-Covid-19 levels. The number of passengers increased after the reopening of borders in June, with ferry services to nearby destinations in Indonesia and Malaysia experiencing steady demand. Popular destinations include Batam and Bintan, known for their good seafood and beach resorts, as well as Desaru, which offers cycling routes and golf courses. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore is assessing a new ferry route application between Tanah Merah and Johor's Tanjung Pengelih.

site_title: Cruise lines to offer longer voyages from Singapore, more regional port calls
summary: Cruise lines are expanding their itineraries from Singapore, offering longer voyages and more regional port calls. Royal Caribbean International and Resorts World Cruises are introducing new sailings to destinations such as Phuket and Bali. The Singapore Tourism Board expects more operators to include the region in their itineraries as countries recover from the pandemic. Longer cruises, such as those offered by TUI Cruises, will also be available, with some departing from Singapore in 2022 and 2023. The industry is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by 2023-2024.

site_title: XBB-driven Covid-19 wave may peak here by mid-Nov
summary: Singapore's current XBB-driven Covid-19 wave is expected to peak at 15,000 daily cases by mid-November, with healthcare capacity deemed adequate to cope with the rise in cases. However, authorities are prepared to bring back stricter safety rules, such as mask mandates and vaccination-differentiated safe management measures, if needed. Public hospitals have increased bed capacity to over 1,000 beds, and the government urges Singaporeans to take personal responsibility and stay vaccinated to avoid a return to curbs.

site_title: XBB sub-variant more transmissible, but no severe cases linked to it so far
summary: Singapore has seen a rise in COVID-19 cases driven by the XBB sub-variant, which accounts for 54% of local cases. Despite concerns over transmissibility, no severe cases have been linked to the strain, with test samples from intensive care units showing no signs of XBB. The sub-variant may be less virulent than prior waves, with a 30% lower risk of hospitalization compared to the BA.5 variant. Vaccinated individuals can still get infected, and booster jabs are recommended for eligible individuals, with mild symptoms reported in most cases.

site_title: Guidelines to follow amid XBB wave of infections
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung has issued four guidelines amid the XBB wave of infections: (1) those aged 50+ to receive bivalent Moderna vaccine for severe illness prevention, (2) possibility of resuming safe management measures like mask-wearing and vaccination-differentiated measures if the situation worsens, (3) restrictions on hospital visitors due to increased pressure, and (4) personal responsibility to mask up, test, and isolate if unwell. The government will monitor the situation closely and adjust measures as needed.

site_title: Authors hope book launch will help revive forgotten Qixi Festival
summary: A book titled "Reviving Qixi: Singapore's Forgotten Seven Sisters Festival" was launched in Chinatown, Singapore, to revive the long-lost Qixi Festival. The book, written by heritage researchers Lynn Wong and Lee Kok Leong, documents the festival's rise and fall and provides a roadmap for its revival. The authors aim to revive the festival, which was celebrated until the 1970s, through community partnerships and events. The book is partially funded by the National Heritage Board and can be purchased online. The authors plan to organize a series of activities, including a documentary film and handicraft workshops.

site_title: The quest for a healthier Singapore
summary: Singapore introduces "Healthier SG", a preventive care strategy aiming to encourage people to enroll with a general practitioner (GP) for health management. The program, launched by a family after their mother's hospital readmission, highlights the importance of a familiar GP in managing chronic conditions. The initiative seeks to improve healthcare outcomes and address unanswered questions about its effectiveness.

site_title: Do it online from mid-Nov
summary: A new online portal, the Office of the Public Guardian Online system, allows individuals to create lasting power of attorney (LPA) documents starting from November 14. This shift aims to speed up the process, reducing the average time from three weeks to 1½ weeks. The new system replaces the current hard copy form method, and the Ministry of Social and Family Development has implemented security measures to protect sensitive data and prevent unauthorized disclosure.

site_title: Over 800 hospital beds to be set aside in next 2 weeks
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has announced plans to set aside over 800 hospital beds for Covid-19 patients amid the rise in cases caused by the XBB strain of the Omicron variant. Non-critical operations will be postponed, and public hospitals will prioritize resources for Covid-19 patients. The government is also introducing stricter visitor curbs to protect healthcare capacity, allowing up to two visitors per patient and limiting visit times to 30 minutes. This move aims to ensure timely care for those with medical conditions that require immediate treatment.

site_title: PM Lee to hold talks with Albanese at annual leaders' meet in Australia
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is set to hold a three-day visit to Australia, where he will meet with counterpart Anthony Albanese at the 7th Singapore-Australia Annual Leaders' Meeting. The key agenda includes a first-of-its-kind green economy agreement, expected to remove non-tariff barriers to trade in green goods and services. The two leaders will also discuss bilateral cooperation, regional and global developments. PM Lee will be accompanied by a delegation, including Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, and Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will act as Acting Prime Minister during his absence.

site_title: Gan Kim Yong visits Batam, Bintan to boost ties
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong visited Indonesian islands of Batam and Bintan to strengthen ties between the two nations. He met with local officials and business representatives, discussing the impact of Covid-19 on the Indonesian economy and Singaporean businesses. Gan noted that Singaporean companies continue to thrive despite challenges, with bilateral trade reaching $59.1 billion in 2021. Singapore remains Indonesia's top source of foreign direct investment, and Gan emphasized the importance of economic cooperation between the two nations, citing their geographical proximity and strong connectivity.

site_title: In a crowded place or visiting vulnerable people? Better to mask up
summary: Singapore is considering reinstating mask mandates amid a new wave of Covid-19 infections driven by the XBB Omicron subvariant, which could reach 15,000 daily new cases by mid-November. Masks are currently only required on public transport and in healthcare settings, but Health Minister Ong Ye Kung advises the public to wear masks in crowded places or when interacting with vulnerable individuals. Experts emphasize that wearing masks reduces the risk of infection and encourages long-term awareness and precautions to protect oneself and others.

site_title: What it should have been
summary: A Singaporean article incorrectly stated that children aged 5-11 can receive specific Covid-19 vaccine combinations for minimum protection. However, the Novavax/Nuvaxovid and Sinovac-CoronaVac vaccines have not been approved for this age group, contradicting the initial claim.

site_title: Lasting power of attorney can be made online from Nov 14
summary: Singapore to launch online lasting power of attorney (LPA) portal on Nov 14, replacing the current hard-copy form system. The digital method aims to speed up the process, cutting it from 3 weeks to 1.5 weeks. Donors will use the Office of the Public Guardian Online system, while donees will receive notifications via SMS or email and accept the LPA through the portal. Data protection measures have been put in place to prevent unauthorized access. The move is part of amendments to the Mental Capacity Act passed in 2021, which also enabled LPAs to be made electronically.

site_title: Dialogue on coastal protection draws different perspectives
summary: Singapore's first coastal protection dialogue brought together 80 participants, including environmentalists, oceanographers, and everyday citizens, to discuss the best way to protect the country's shoreline from rising sea levels. The event, organized by PUB, highlighted the need to balance environmental concerns with recreational and personal property interests. Participants expressed hope for nature-based coastal protection measures and safeguarding key areas, while also acknowledging the need for policy trade-offs and embracing change. The dialogue's findings will contribute to PUB's study on protecting Singapore's south-eastern shoreline from sea-level rise.

site_title: President Halimah to meet Viet leaders during state visit
summary: President Halimah Yacob is on a five-day state visit to Vietnam, starting today, at the invitation of Vietnamese President Nguyen Xuan Phuc. She will visit Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, meeting key leaders and attending various events, including a state banquet and a business roundtable. The visit aims to reaffirm Singapore and Vietnam's warm relations and promote bilateral cooperation, with a focus on economic development and investments. This is Madam Halimah's first state visit to Vietnam as President, reciprocating President Phuc's visit to Singapore in February.

site_title: Have your say to help shape Healthier SG
summary: The Healthier SG initiative has sparked debate, with some expressing skepticism about its effectiveness. Salma Khalik, a commentator, initially reacted with skepticism, questioning whether the program will bring significant changes. The Healthier SG initiative aims to promote healthier lifestyles, but its impact is yet to be determined. The article invites readers to share their thoughts and opinions on how to shape the program to achieve better health outcomes.

site_title: WWF-Singapore takes down illegal wildlife listings on e-platforms
summary: WWF-Singapore has taken down over 14,000 illegal wildlife listings on e-commerce platforms since 2020 through its Cyber Spotter Programme, involving 342 Singaporean volunteers. The organization plans to train another 300 people to remove more than 20,000 listings. The initiative aims to stop the buying of wildlife products and combat the illegal wildlife trade. Meanwhile, a WWF-Singapore study found that Singaporeans prioritize circular economy, food security, and renewable energy, with most willing to take personal environmental actions such as conserving energy and reducing food waste.

site_title: Malay/Muslim professionals can be mentors for next gen: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of mobilizing Malay/Muslim professionals as mentors and role models to the next generation, citing their rising post-secondary qualifications and increased presence in PMET roles. Wong urged self-help groups like AMP Singapore to collaborate with the government and one another to address complex social issues, promoting a "family-centric approach" to uplift families and create a more inclusive society.

site_title: Eggs from Malaysian farm recalled after salmonella detected
summary: A batch of eggs imported from Malaysia's Teo Seng Layer Farm 1 is being recalled due to salmonella enteritidis contamination. The affected eggs, identified by the code CEJ027, pose a risk of food poisoning if consumed raw or undercooked. The Singapore Food Agency has directed six companies to recall or withhold the eggs, and the farm has been suspended pending rectification. The eggs are safe to eat if cooked thoroughly, and the recall is ongoing.

site_title: SPCA's dogs and cats set to be workplace stress busters
summary: The Singapore SPCA plans to launch a corporate wellness programme by the second quarter of 2023, where adopted animals will visit workplaces to alleviate stress among employees. This initiative follows a 2021 survey that found pets positively impacted their owners' mental well-being. Two companies have expressed interest in participating, and the programme aims to socialise stray and abandoned animals, while enhancing employee mental well-being. The goal is to provide a mutually beneficial experience, with the potential for employees to adopt the animals they connect with, while ensuring animal and worker safety.

site_title: Higher risk of XBB infection for those who've not had Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health data shows that people who have never caught Covid-19 (Covid-naive patients) have a higher incidence rate of the new XBB strain, with 162.5 infections per 100,000 person-days between Oct 8 and Oct 14. Those previously infected before the Delta wave in 2021 had a lower incidence rate of 147.4 infections per 100,000 person-days. The risk of reinfection decreases with time since the last infection, with a 0.7 infection rate for those infected a month ago and significantly lower rates for those infected 4-10 months ago.

site_title: GPs air concerns about annual service fee, medication subsidies
summary: Singaporean GPs have expressed concerns about the annual service fee structure for chronic condition management. While diabetes is a common condition, doctors feel that more effort is needed to help diabetic patients manage their condition compared to high blood sugar, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. GPs, such as Dr. Lim Kim Show, emphasize the importance of regular eye and feet checks, as well as regular tests to detect complications. The Health Ministry must consider these issues when determining the annual fee for GPs caring for different patient groups under Healthier SG.

site_title: 3 things to note about bond investments
summary: Bond investors are experiencing relief as interest rates may soon stop rising, alleviating the financial strain from the past year. Historically, bonds have performed worse than stocks, with 2022 being the most devastating period for bonds since at least 1926. According to a bond maven, 2022 is potentially the worst year for bonds since record-keeping began in the late 18th century, contrasting with the current bear market in stocks.

site_title: Infants, pregnant women can recover at home under Protocol 2 from Oct 25
summary: Singapore to allow infants and pregnant women to recover at home under Protocol 2 starting Oct 25, as the risk of severe Covid-19 is low for these groups. They will be required to self-isolate for 72 hours and take antigen rapid tests, with close monitoring for signs of worsening symptoms. This change aims to reduce hospital admissions and allow patients to recover in a more pleasant environment with their families.

site_title: Longer sailings, more regional port calls on the way as cruise lines return
summary: Cruise lines are expanding their itineraries to include more regional destinations in Southeast Asia, with longer sailings and more port calls. Royal Caribbean International and Resorts World Cruises have announced new sailings to Phuket, Thailand, and Bali. The Singapore Tourism Board expects more operators to include the region in their itineraries, with a goal to return to pre-pandemic levels between 2023 and 2024. Several cruise lines, including TUI Cruises and French luxury vessel Le Laperouse, have also announced sailings to Singapore, with some offering flights from Europe.

site_title: Bivalent vaccine offers stronger, broader protection
summary: Singapore has started offering the Moderna bivalent vaccine as a second booster shot to people aged 50 and older. The vaccine protects against the original wildtype virus, BA.1/2 strains, and the XBB strain, providing stronger and broader protection. Director of medical services Kenneth Mak said the bivalent vaccine offers a 75% better antibody response against Omicron compared to the original mRNA vaccine, and protection against severe illness remains strong. The vaccine is available at nine Joint Testing and Vaccination Centres, with potential weekend openings if demand is high.

site_title: Arts facility for people with disabilities
summary: A new arts facility for people with disabilities has opened in Bukit Merah Community Hub, marking the third centre run by non-profit ART:DIS. The facility features a recording studio and a 32-seater black box, offering arts programs and workshops. Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong attended the opening event, which showcased works and performances. This initiative aims to provide more opportunities for people with disabilities to pursue the arts.

site_title: Franklin Templeton’s Jenny Johnson can play soccer and steer $2 trillion
summary: Franklin Templeton CEO Jenny Johnson expressed confidence in the global economy, stating there's no need to panic despite uncertainty. She praised Singapore's approach to blockchain, citing its potential to address future crises. Johnson's comments came on a day when Wall Street closed following a poor overnight trading session, with the yuan and yen experiencing a sharp decline. Johnson's remarks suggest she is optimistic about the company's ability to navigate the economic landscape, with its $2 trillion in assets under management.

site_title: Low-income families get mini-library to encourage kids to read
summary: Low-income families in Singapore, numbering over 1,800, have received mini-libraries as part of the KidStart Stories initiative, aiming to encourage early childhood development through reading. The program, launched by Minister of State Sun Xueling, provides age-appropriate books and videos on storytelling techniques to support parents in fostering a love for reading in their children. The initiative is sponsored by KidStart Singapore, SP Group, and EtonHouse Community Fund, and has already seen positive results, with families reporting increased engagement and imagination in their children.

site_title: 12,100 crypto tokens in zombie trading limbo
summary: Over 12,100 cryptocurrency tokens have become "zombies" this year, defined as tokens that have not traded for a month, according to recent data. This marks a significant number of tokens stuck in limbo due to the ongoing crypto bear market. The total digital-asset market value that evaporated in 2022 was estimated to be around US$2 trillion.

site_title: What qualifies as 'emotional distress' when personal data is misused
summary: Singapore residents who experience emotional distress due to personal data misuse may have legal recourse. However, mere annoyance or unhappiness resulting from data misuse does not qualify as "emotional distress" under the law, as these emotions are seen as normal life experiences. To qualify, the distress must be severe and significantly impact daily life, such as sleepless nights. Those experiencing emotional distress due to data misuse can now seek legal action against the perpetrators.

site_title: Should you take advantage of attractive FX rates?
summary: A strong US dollar is attracting interest in foreign currencies, particularly the Japanese yen and British pound, as well as other Asian currencies like the US, Australian, and Hong Kong dollars. Some investors are taking advantage of attractive exchange rates to diversify their portfolios. However, it's essential to consider various factors, including market fluctuations and personal financial goals, before making any investment decisions. Potential forex investors should weigh the risks and benefits of investing in foreign currencies, especially if they don't closely monitor the foreign exchange market.

site_title: Investing in clean water for the future
summary: BlackRock is fine-tuning an investment strategy based on the increasing concern of global water scarcity, particularly in the rich world, due to extreme weather events. Historically, water scarcity was viewed as a developing country issue, but Mr. Omar Moufti, product strategist at BlackRock, notes that it's a global problem.

site_title: Investing in clean water for the future
summary: Scientists predict more frequent and intense extreme weather events will disrupt global water supplies, exacerbating concerns over water scarcity. Investment manager BlackRock is fine-tuning an investment strategy based on this bet, recognizing that clean water is no longer just a developing country issue. As weather events intensify, the rich world is likely to face increasing shortages, making clean water a critical investment opportunity. BlackRock's product strategist Omar Moufti notes that historically, water scarcity was seen as a developing country problem, but its impact now extends globally.

site_title: Data misuse: Why a manager who mailed a client from his former firm landed in hot water
summary: A former employee who mailed a client's information from his former firm to his new company has landed in hot water. The move may not have been a breach of confidence if the information was not downloaded illegally, but using it in the new company is still questionable. The incident highlights the importance of not using confidential customer data from a previous employer in a new role, even if it's accessible to everyone. This can lead to a world of pain and potential consequences.

site_title: 3 things to note about bond investments
summary: Stocks are in a bear market, but bonds have been worse, with 2022 being the most devastating period since at least 1926. This year may be the worst for bonds since reliable record-keeping began in the late 18th century, according to one bond expert. The historical record shows that bonds have underperformed stocks in 2022, making it a difficult time for investors to diversify their portfolios.

site_title: Photojournalists talk about capturing big moments
summary: Photojournalists Louie Palu and Mathias Heng shared their experiences capturing significant moments in their careers. Palu's project "Political Year Zero" documented events in the US capital from 2019 to 2021, including the January 6, 2021, insurrection, and won the World Press Photo Long-Term Project Award. Heng presented his work covering the war in Ukraine, highlighting the resilience and unity of the Ukrainian people. The exhibitions aim to advocate for eye-opening journalism and showcase the power of photographs in conveying complex stories.

site_title: Beware, customer data is off-limits to ex-staff
summary: A former employee can be sued for using a former employer's customer database without permission, even if they have access to it. To prove a breach of confidence, customers must demonstrate losses under the data protection Act. Former employees are advised not to contact customers using the database, as doing so could lead to legal consequences.

site_title: Should you take advantage of attractive FX rates?
summary: Forex investors are considering taking advantage of attractive exchange rates in Japan and Britain, where $1 can go further due to the strong US dollar. Adeline Tan, a subscriber, recently converted some Singapore dollars to Japanese yen and British pounds for future travel. However, she does not closely monitor the foreign exchange market, which typically involves frequent currency swaps. The article suggests that investors must weigh various factors to maximize their chances of benefiting from a strong Singdollar, rather than simply reacting to headlines.

site_title: Me & My Money: Investing long-term, with liquid funds for protection
summary: Finance sector executive Wildon Goh, who grew up in a low-income household, now prioritizes long-term investing and insurance to secure his family's future. His tough childhood, marked by financial struggles, instilled in him a determination to provide for his loved ones. Goh now uses liquid funds to protect his investments, ensuring his family's well-being. By sharing his story, Goh aims to inspire others to take control of their finances and create a stable future for their families.

site_title: 12,100 crypto tokens in zombie trading limbo
summary: A total of 12,100 cryptocurrency tokens are currently stuck in a trading limbo, unable to be traded due to a lack of liquidity. This phenomenon is a result of the massive bear market that occurred in 2022, where the digital-asset market value plummeted to US$2 trillion. The exact number of tokens affected is not specified, but it is estimated to be around 12,100.

site_title: Ganna secures his fifth title in world-record time
summary: Italian cyclist Filippo Ganna secured his fifth world title in the men's individual pursuit, breaking the world record with a time of 3min 59.636sec at the Track Cycling World Championships in France. Ganna, 26, outperformed Ashton Lambie's mark set at the 2021 world championships by nearly 0.3 seconds. Ganna also won the team pursuit gold at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, and celebrated his victory with champagne.

site_title: Jenny Johnson can play soccer and steer $2 trillion
summary: Franklin Templeton CEO Jenny Johnson expressed confidence in the global economy, stating she doesn't foresee another crisis on the horizon. Johnson praised Singapore's approach to blockchain, citing its potential benefits. The meeting took place on a day when the S&P 500 had closed after a poor overnight trading session, with currencies such as the yuan and yen experiencing significant decline. Johnson's comments suggest a cautiously optimistic outlook, despite the current economic uncertainty.

site_title: Shaken Barcelona in dire need of Clasico fillip
summary: Barcelona, despite spending over €1.3 billion on new players, is on the brink of a second straight group-stage elimination in the Champions League. The club has not won the Champions League since 2015 and is currently top of La Liga only on goal difference. A loss to Real Madrid in the upcoming Clasico match at the Santiago Bernabeu could be a devastating blow to the team and its president Joan Laporta, who is hoping for a fillip in Madrid to boost morale and signal the project's resilience.

site_title: Investing long-term, with liquid funds for protection
summary: Finance sector executive Wildon Goh, who grew up in financially tight times, now prioritizes investing in insurance to protect his family's well-being. Despite struggling to afford textbooks in school, Goh's experiences instilled a desire to ensure his family's financial security. He now allocates a significant portion of his portfolio to insurance, recognizing its importance in safeguarding his loved ones. This approach reflects his personal values and financial goals, shaped by his challenging upbringing.

site_title: What qualifies as 'emotional distress' when information is misused?
summary: A person may be eligible for legal recourse if their personal data was misused and it caused them significant emotional distress, including anxiety, fear, or severe emotional pain. However, minor annoyance or unhappiness, considered normal life experiences, does not qualify as emotional distress under the law. To seek compensation, individuals must demonstrate that their emotions were severe and directly related to the misuse of their data. Those who have experienced significant emotional distress due to data misuse may be able to take legal action against the perpetrators.

site_title: Self-belief fires Fowler chase
summary: Rickie Fowler took a one-shot lead into the final day of the Zozo Championship in Japan, ending a three-year PGA Tour title drought. Fowler scored a 66 at the Narashino Country Club, moving to 14 under. Fellow American Keegan Bradley is one shot behind, while Hideki Matsuyama's chances of retaining his title have dimmed after a round of 66 left him 10 shots off the lead. Fowler remains confident, saying he believes he can win but knows it will be tough, and will look to build momentum in Sunday's final round.

site_title: Golden Boot duel goes down to the wire
summary: SPL top scorers Boris Kopitovic and Kodai Tanaka are locked in a tight battle for the Golden Boot award. Kopitovic scored what he believes to be an 'own goal' in a 5-3 win over Albirex, giving him 33 goals, while Tanaka scored 32 goals. The outcome of an appeal by Albirex against the goal's classification could influence the award, with both players set to finish the season on Thursday. If the score remains tied, the award will be shared.

site_title: Sports World: Brentford hit out at racist abuse of Toney
summary: Brentford Football Club has condemned racist abuse directed at England striker Ivan Toney via social media. The club described the incident as a "despicable hate crime" and reported it to the police and Meta. Meanwhile, the French Football Federation will send a delegation to Qatar to investigate working conditions for migrant workers, following a documentary revealing poor living conditions at the World Cup base. Argentina captain Lionel Messi expressed concern over injuries to teammates Angel di Maria and Paulo Dybala, hoping they will recover in time for the World Cup.

site_title: Key injuries for Chelsea but Potter thankful to the team
summary: Chelsea manager Graham Potter expressed concern over the team's injury situation ahead of the World Cup. Defender Reece James, England's first-choice right-back, may miss the tournament due to a knee injury, while midfielder N'Golo Kante, a key player for France, is also uncertain due to a hamstring injury. Potter will consult specialists to determine their availability. Defender Wesley Fofana's knee injury also raises doubts about his chances of making the France squad. Despite injuries, Potter remains optimistic about the team's chances, citing the players' receptiveness to his ideas and recent unbeaten start.

site_title: City 'world's best team'
summary: Jurgen Klopp acknowledges Manchester City, led by striker Erling Haaland, as the best team in the world, citing their impressive 13-point lead in the Premier League. Despite Liverpool's strong attacking potential, Guardiola remains wary of their rivals, saying the title is not going to be won "at a canter." With City's 22-game away league unbeaten streak and Liverpool's 27-home league unbeaten run, the Anfield clash is expected to be a closely contested match.

site_title: Koepka stays in hunt for first LIV title after his 67
summary: Brooks Koepka is in contention to win his first LIV title after firing a second-round 3-under 67, finishing 11-under 129 and one shot behind leader Peter Uihlein. Koepka's strong round, combined with a solid first round, has him tied for third place on 131. The tight leaderboard is set to continue into Sunday's final round, where Koepka hopes to capitalize on his momentum and nearly 20 months of on-and-off fitness problems behind him.

site_title: Swiatek praised for her 'high level'
summary: Iga Swiatek advanced to the San Diego Open semi-finals with a 6-0, 6-3 win over Coco Gauff, reaching her eighth WTA Tour title of the year. The 21-year-old Pole will face sixth-ranked Jessica Pegula on Sunday. Swiatek has dominated the season, holding the world No. 1 spot with 5,600 points separating her from second-ranked Ons Jabeur. Many consider her the favourite to win the season-ending WTA Finals, citing her exceptional skill and lack of worthy competitors.

site_title: Timely return to the top in QEII Cup
summary: Prosperous Return, ridden by Jake Bayliss, won the $300,000 Group 1 Queen Elizabeth II Cup at Kranji in Singapore with a surprise move at the 200m mark, circling the field and overtaking leaders Hongkong Great and Senor Don. Trainer Michael Clements, who was in Australia, praised Bayliss's tactics and the horse's ability to overcome the wide barrier and slow start. The win marked Clements' first G1 victory since 2020 and Bayliss' first Kranji Group 1 win.

site_title: From baby-faced teen referee to the World Cup
summary: Singaporean football referee Taqi Jahari is set to make his World Cup debut in less than three weeks. A Fifa international referee for over a decade, Jahari has officiated numerous international matches, including abroad. He will take the familiar journey from his Bukit Batok home to Changi Airport, marking another milestone in his career.

site_title: Financial support and income replacement: How cancer patients can have better peace of mind
summary: Cancer patients in Singapore can experience significant financial burdens due to high medical expenses. However, critical illness insurance can provide relief, offering income replacement and covering ongoing expenses. Two cancer patients, Joel Lim and Eddie Low, share their experiences with the financial support they received from their insurance plans, which helped alleviate their worries and focus on recovery. With advances in cancer treatments, patients like Lim have managed to defy initial poor prognoses, but these treatments come with high costs. Insurance coverage, including hospitalization and critical illness plans, has been instrumental in supporting patients and their families during their recovery.

site_title: Football: Leicester held by Palace, Forest sink to bottom of the Premier League
summary: Leicester City drew 0-0 with Crystal Palace, holding off the bottom spot in the Premier League. Nottingham Forest fell to the bottom after losing 1-0 at Wolves. Fulham and Bournemouth maintained top-half positions with a 2-2 draw. Leicester signed defender Wout Faes to bolster their defense, but a record 23 new arrivals have yet to yield results.

site_title: Rashford gets backing
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag believes striker Marcus Rashford needs to be more clinical in front of goal, despite the England forward showing improved form. Rashford has already matched his previous season's goal tally in 10 games and has started all eight of United's league games. Ten Hag praises Rashford's efforts but notes that he must improve his finishing. United face Newcastle on Sunday, a game that could extend their winning run to four matches and boost their confidence ahead of big clashes.

site_title: Banking on talent: How this firm is equipping its people with in-demand skills
summary: UOB's Talent & Development arm has launched several programs to equip its employees with in-demand skills in a digital banking landscape. The Technology Development Programme (TDP) and Career Conversion Programme (CCP) provide on-the-job training and guidance, allowing employees to pick up new skills quickly. Since its launch in 2017, CCP has supported nearly 1,400 employees, while TDP has trained over 75 participants in cyber-security. The bank also offers the Career Pivot Programme to support employees exploring new career paths, and the "Better U" learning and development program, which has been taken by over 17,000 employees. UOB believes that lifelong learning is key to developing talent and providing sustainable careers.

images.alt_text: Team of professionals with mentors at work

site_title: NBA: Hall of Famer Mutombo being treated for brain tumour
summary: Basketball Hall of Famer Dikembe Mutombo, a 56-year-old former NBA centre, is undergoing treatment for a brain tumour in Atlanta. Mutombo played 18 seasons with six teams, earning four Defensive Player of the Year awards and being inducted into the Hall of Fame. He is receiving the best care possible and his family is asking for privacy during this time. Mutombo's iconic finger wag and humanitarian work, particularly through his foundation, are also being remembered.

site_title: Football: Kane helps Tottenham close gap on leaders Arsenal
summary: Tottenham Hotspur moved to within a point of Premier League leaders Arsenal after defeating Everton 2-0 at home. Goals from Harry Kane and Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg helped Spurs secure the win, with Kane scoring from the penalty spot and providing an assist for Hojbjerg's second goal. The victory keeps Tottenham in third place, but they now trail Manchester City on goal difference ahead of their match against Liverpool on Sunday. Kane's 10th goal of the season contributed to the win, showcasing his continued form for the team.

site_title: Klopp's swat at City's cash raises the heat for Anfield tie
summary: Manchester City and Liverpool, who dominated the Premier League together for four seasons, are now set to face off in a crucial tie. The rivalry has intensified after Manchester City's large spending raised eyebrows, prompting Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp to "swat at" the club's financial advantage. This development raises the stakes for the upcoming match between the two teams, with the outcome potentially influenced by the financial disparity between them. The intense rivalry and differing financial strengths are expected to make the Anfield tie highly competitive.

site_title: Two more Kenyans fail dope tests
summary: Kenyans Diana Kipyokei and Betty Wilson Lempus have been provisionally disqualified and suspended for doping after testing positive for triamcinolone acetonide, a steroid, in 2021 Boston Marathon and Paris half-marathon respectively. Kipyokei's 2021 Boston win was annulled, while Lempus' 2021 Paris half-marathon victory is also at risk. The Athletics Integrity Unit (AIU) also accused them of obstructing the investigation with false information. This is the 10th Kenyan athlete to test positive for the substance between 2021 and 2022.

site_title: Polo: Space-Executive capture Singapore Urban Polo crown
summary: Singapore Urban Polo event returned after a three-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Space-Executive, comprising Ang Roon Kai, JJ Humbert, and Daniel Chua, emerged victorious in the four-team competition, defeating FWD 3-2 in the final. The event, held at the Singapore Polo Club, marked the first time it was held since 2019. This year's event was a comeback for the Singapore Urban Polo, which was initially put on ice due to the pandemic.

site_title: Tennis: Baby joy for Ukrainian tennis star Elina Svitolina
summary: Ukrainian tennis star Elina Svitolina has given birth to a baby girl, Skai Monfils, with her husband Gael Monfils. The announcement was made on social media, with Svitolina expressing gratitude to her husband and God for the special moment. The birth comes after a traumatic year for Svitolina due to the war in her native Ukraine, which she stepped back from in March. Svitolina's husband, Gael Monfils, also shared his excitement on social media, describing the birth as the "most incredible gift."

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary:
Key events and sports schedules for the next 24 hours include:
- Cycling: Track World Championships on StarHub Ch 201 at 6pm.
- Football: English Premier League matches Manchester United v Newcastle (8.50pm) and Liverpool v Man City (11.20pm) on Singtel TV Ch102 & StarHub Ch221.
- Golf: DP World Tour's Andalucia Masters on StarHub Ch203 at 7.30pm.
- Mixed Martial Arts: UFC Fight Night featuring Grasso v Araujo on StarHub Ch202 & Singtel Ch112 at 7am.
- Motorcycling: MotoGP's Australian Grand Prix at 11am on Singtel TV Ch114 & StarHub Ch209.
- Rugby: Women's World Cup matches Italy v Canada and Wales v New Zealand on Singtel TV Ch126 & StarHub Ch213 at 7.30am and 10am respectively.
- Tennis: ATP Tour's Gijon Open and WTA Tour's Translyvania Open and San Diego Open finals on Singtel TV Ch127 & StarHub Ch211 and StarHub Ch201 at 7.30pm and 11.10pm respectively.

site_title: Golf: LIV's Sergio Garcia says European career could be over after fine
summary: Sergio Garcia, a 2017 Masters champion and Ryder Cup stalwart, has hinted that his European Tour career may be over after being fined for withdrawing from the BMW PGA Championship without explanation. Garcia, who has been recruited by LIV Golf, said he feels "more welcomed and loved" on the Saudi-funded circuit, where he has performed well with three top-10 finishes in six events. Garcia's fine and potential departure from the European Tour come amid criticism of LIV Golf for its impact on the established tours and its association with Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Athletics: Boston Marathon winner Kipyokei provisionally suspended for doping
summary: Kenya's 2021 Boston Marathon winner Diana Kipyokei and compatriot Betty Wilson Lempus have been provisionally suspended for using the banned substance triamcinolone acetonide. The Athletics Integrity Unit (AIU) has also charged them with obstructing the investigation by providing false information. Kipyokei's sample was taken after her Boston victory, and if charges are proven, she would be stripped of her title. This is the 10th Kenyan athlete to test positive for the substance, with only two global cases during the same period.

site_title: Rough day at work? Get some playtime with dogs or cats at the office, come mid-2023
summary: The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SPCA) plans to launch a corporate wellness programme that brings dogs and cats to workplaces in mid-2023. The initiative aims to alleviate stress in workers and was inspired by a 2021 survey showing that 89% of respondents found pets to have a positive impact on mental well-being. Two companies have expressed interest in participating, and the programme also seeks to socialize stray animals and facilitate adoptions. The SPCA will ensure the safety of both animals and workers before launching the programme.

site_title: Great Eastern Women's Run host run clinic for Daughters of Tomorrow
summary: The Great Eastern Women's Run hosted a run clinic and sharing session for over 50 women and their families from charity group Daughters Of Tomorrow at the Singapore Sports Hub on October 15, 2022. Elite runners Jenny Huang, Jasmine Goh, and Choo Ling Er shared their stories and fitness tips, conducting exercise drills for the participants. The event aimed to inspire and empower the women, who will be participating in the GEWR for the first time on November 20. The clinic was part of a larger fund-raising initiative to support Daughters Of Tomorrow and the Singapore Cancer Society.

site_title: 'It's still an unbelievable appointment': S'porean referee Taqi recounts 20-year journey to World Cup
summary: Singaporean referee Taqi Jahari will head to the World Cup 2022 in Qatar as a video assistant referee. This marks a milestone in his 20-year journey to the tournament. A Fifa international referee for a decade, Jahari has officiated in various countries, including Iran, India, and the Middle East. With the World Cup just weeks away, Jahari is set to make his debut in the tournament, showcasing his expertise in VAR technology.

site_title: Football: Man United's Mason Greenwood charged with attempted rape
summary: Manchester United forward Mason Greenwood, 21, has been charged with attempted rape, controlling and coercive behaviour, and assault. He was first held in January 2022 over allegations from a young woman, after images and videos were posted online. Greenwood had been on bail but was arrested for allegedly breaching his conditions. The charges relate to the same woman, and he is due to appear in court on Monday. Nike and Electronic Arts have previously suspended or terminated their sponsorship deals with Greenwood over the allegations.

site_title: Lasting power of attorney can be made online from Nov 14
summary: Singapore will launch an online portal for making lasting power of attorney (LPA) on Nov 14, allowing donors to create and submit digital forms. The new system aims to speed up the process, reducing processing time from three weeks to 1.5 weeks. The portal uses the MyInfo service to automatically fill up most fields, and donees will be notified via SMS or email to accept the LPA. Donors will then need to visit a certificate issuer to digitally sign the LPA via Singpass. The move aims to make the process faster, easier, and more secure, with data protection measures in place to prevent unauthorized access.

site_title: Football: Golden Boot battle to go on as Albirex appeal against decision for 3rd goal in 5-3 loss to Tampines
summary: Albirex Niigata striker Kodai Tanaka is appealing against a decision that credited Tampines Rovers' Ryaan Sanizal with a goal in a 5-3 loss, potentially affecting the Golden Boot award. Tanaka scored the White Swans' second and third goals, but was not credited with the third. The Football Association of Singapore will review the decision, which could impact the top scorer award between Tanaka and Tampines' Boris Kopitovic.

site_title: S'pore, Indonesia strengthen defence ties with 34th edition of military exercise
summary: Singapore and Indonesia strengthened their defense ties with the 34th edition of military exercise, Exercise Safkar Indopura, held in Bekasi, West Java, from Oct 8 to 17. Over 130 Singaporean and 140 Indonesian troops participated, fostering mutual understanding and deepening interpersonal bonds through exchanges and training exercises. The exercise concluded with a combined brigade planning exercise and a battalion-level field training exercise, solidifying friendship and professional cooperation between the two armies, according to Singapore's Chief of Army Major-General David Neo.

site_title: President Halimah Yacob to meet Vietnam leaders during state visit
summary: President Halimah Yacob is set to make a five-day state visit to Vietnam from Sunday, at the invitation of Vietnamese President Nguyen Xuan Phuc. During her visit, she will meet key Vietnamese leaders, including Communist Party of Vietnam Central Committee General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong and Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh. The visit aims to reaffirm Singapore and Vietnam's warm relations and deepen bilateral cooperation in areas such as the digital economy, green economy, and innovation.

site_title: Tennis: World No. 1 Swiatek rips Gauff to reach San Diego semis
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek defeated eighth-ranked Coco Gauff 6-0, 6-3 in 65 minutes, advancing to the San Diego Open semi-finals. Swiatek will face sixth-ranked Jessica Pegula, whom she has a 3-1 head-to-head record against. Swiatek praised Pegula's athleticism and defensive skills, while Pegula described Swiatek as "super athletic and aggressive." Other semi-final matches feature Donna Vekic vs. Danielle Collins and the winner of the Gauff vs. Pegula match.

site_title: Cycling: Ganna storms to fifth men's pursuit title in world record
summary: Filippo Ganna broke the men's individual pursuit world record with a 3min 59.636sec time, surpassing Ashton Lambie's mark by nearly 0.3sec. The 26-year-old Italian clinched his fifth world title in the event, ahead of compatriot Jonathan Milan. Ganna also celebrated a world record in the hour event last week.

site_title: PM Lee to meet Australian PM Anthony Albanese in Canberra
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit Australia from Sunday for a three-day trip, where he will meet with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese for the 7th Singapore-Australia Annual Leaders' Meeting. The two leaders will discuss bilateral cooperation, regional and global developments, and a proposed green economy agreement, which is currently under negotiation. Lee will also visit Sydney, where he will meet with senior business leaders and academics, and be accompanied by his wife, Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, and other government officials.

site_title: ST Sports Talk Podcast: Taqi Jahari’s 20-year journey from teen S-League ref to Qatar World Cup
summary: Singaporean referee Muhammad Taqi Jahari shares his 20-year journey from being a teenage S-League referee to the Qatar World Cup. He discusses milestones, sacrifices, and his experience officiating international matches, including the World Cup. Taqi reflects on his preparation for the tournament, including VAR duties, and emphasizes the physical demands of being a referee. He is looking forward to officiating at the World Cup and shares his passion for the sport.

site_title: First national dialogue on how to protect Singapore's coastline from rising sea levels
summary: Singapore held its first national dialogue on protecting its coastline from rising sea levels, involving 80 participants from diverse backgrounds. The dialogue, organized by PUB, aimed to incorporate environmental and everyday concerns in finding solutions. Participants, including environmentalists and oceanographers, discussed the importance of nature-based coastal protection measures and the need to balance heritage and nature preservation with the reality of climate change. The event's findings will contribute to PUB's study on protecting Singapore's south-eastern shoreline from sea-level rise, and participants expressed hope for safeguarding key recreational and personal properties.

site_title: Malay/Muslim groups need to collaborate strongly to tackle social issues: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for Malay/Muslim professionals to collaborate and contribute to their community, particularly as role models and mentors. The number of Malay residents with post-secondary qualifications has increased, with 40% holding PMET roles. Wong urged Malay/Muslim organizations and the government to work together to address complex social issues, and proposed a family-centric approach to provide holistic support. The government will continue to invest in citizens' capabilities and skills, while self-help groups like AMP Singapore will play a key role in this effort.

site_title: Football: Xavi and Laporta all-in on Clasico after summer gamble
summary: Barcelona head into Sunday's Clasico against Real Madrid seeking a victory that will vindicate their high summer expenditure, despite struggling in the Champions League. The club spent big, bringing in Robert Lewandowski, Jules Kounde, and others, but are on the verge of a second consecutive group stage elimination. Barcelona currently top La Liga but only on goal difference, and defeat would be another blow. President Joan Laporta hopes to bring back the good times, but questions are being asked of coach Xavi, who urged his team to "insist, persist, believe" in their ability to succeed.

site_title: Photojournalists are critical witnesses to historical events, say speakers at ST's Through The Lens exhibition
summary: Photojournalists play a crucial role in documenting historical events, as evident in the ST's Through The Lens exhibition. Louie Palu's project "Political Year Zero" showcases his photographs of events in Washington DC from 2019 to 2021, including the Jan 6, 2021 insurrection at the US Capitol. Meanwhile, Singapore-born photojournalist Mathias Heng presented his work covering the war in Ukraine, highlighting the unity and resilience of the Ukrainian people. The exhibition aims to advocate for eye-opening journalism and provide a platform for photojournalists to share their work, emphasizing the importance of their role in shaping public perception of historical events.

site_title: Golf: Fowler confident of ending title drought at Zozo Championship
summary: Rickie Fowler holds a one-shot lead into the final day of the Zozo Championship, moving to 14 under after a 66. The 33-year-old golfer, seeking his first US PGA Tour title in three years, credited his self-belief for staying strong despite poor form. Fowler faces a challenge from Keegan Bradley and Andrew Putnam, with Hideki Matsuyama's title defense seemingly lost after a round of 66. Fowler is confident of ending his drought but acknowledges the difficulty of the final round.

site_title: Football: Chelsea's Potter says 'glow up' down to more expensive haircut
summary: Chelsea manager Graham Potter credits a more expensive haircut as the reason behind his "glow up" after taking over as manager, stating it made him look "like a fine wine." The 47-year-old former Brighton and Hove Albion manager has also gained attention for his new style, including a roll neck black jumper, drawing comparisons to James Bond on social media. Potter expressed a desire for more sophisticated discussions about his career, rather than his appearance.

site_title: Mercedes cabby arrested for drink driving after crashing into Zion Road shophouse
summary: A 49-year-old Mercedes cab driver was arrested for suspected drink driving after crashing into a shophouse at Zion Road in Singapore at 1.40am on Saturday. The driver sustained minor injuries but was not hospitalized. Eyewitnesses reported seeing the airbag inflate in the vehicle. The incident occurred during a time when drink driving arrests rose to 793 in the first half of 2022, up from 741 in the same period in 2021, but accidents decreased by 9%. The driver was taken into custody.

site_title: On The Ball: Klopp's strike at City's cash raises the heat for Anfield tie
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has criticized Manchester City's financial advantage, stating that state-run clubs do not compete fairly. This comes after Manchester City's recent spending spree, which has raised concerns about the competitiveness of the Premier League. Klopp's comments echo his long-held sentiment that City and other state-funded clubs have an unfair edge. The tension is likely to be heightened when the two teams face off in an upcoming Anfield tie. Klopp's statement has sparked debate about the future of English football and the balance of power between state-funded and privately owned clubs.

site_title: Infants, pregnant women with Covid-19 can recover at home by themselves or under primary doctor's care
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that infants and pregnant women with Covid-19 can recover at home under Protocol 2, starting Oct 25. The risk of severe Covid-19 in these groups is low, based on trends from Omicron subvariants. Patients should self-isolate for at least 72 hours, take an antigen rapid test, and monitor themselves for signs of concern. This change aims to reduce hospital admissions and allows patients to recover in a more pleasant environment with their families. MOH will continue to monitor patients closely and provide telehealth services and oral antiviral medications as needed.

site_title: $550k raised to drive road safety against backdrop of higher number of accidents
summary: Singapore's Road Safety Council raised $550,000 to improve road safety amid a 6% increase in accidents in the first half of 2022, compared to the same period in 2021. Despite a 21% decline in fatalities, speeding-related violations and drink driving arrests rose. Vulnerable road users, such as the elderly and motorcyclists, account for a disproportionate number of accidents. The council presented awards to companies and individuals who implemented road safety systems and practices, including installing speed limiters and blind spot mirrors in vehicles.

site_title: Bivalent vaccine gives stronger and broader protection against all Covid-19 strains
summary: Singapore has started offering the Moderna bivalent vaccine to people aged 50 and older as a second booster shot to provide stronger and broader protection against all Covid-19 strains. The vaccine protects against the original virus and BA.1/2 strains, including the XBB strain currently fuelling the current wave of infections. Director of medical services Kenneth Mak noted that protection against infection is stronger after the bivalent vaccine, and it expands the range of antibodies against all variants, giving better protection. The vaccine is available at Joint Testing and Vaccination Centres, and priority is given to those at higher risk, such as those with underlying medical conditions.

site_title: Football: French football chiefs promise checks after workers' conditions in Qatar exposed
