summary: French football authorities announced plans to send an on-site verification delegation to Qatar to check the working conditions of migrant workers ahead of the World Cup. The move follows a TV documentary revealing crowded and unsanitary living conditions, including dirty toilets and infested bedrooms, at migrant worker accommodations. The French Football Federation (FFF) had previously conducted checks on contractors but found unacceptable irregularities, leading to the termination of one contract. The FFF president, Noel Le Graet, was criticized for downplaying the issue, prompting a response from France's sports minister, Amelie Oudea-Castera, who described his reaction as "lacking humanity and coherence".

site_title: XBB sub-variant more transmissible but no severe cases linked to it in S'pore so far
summary: Singapore has reported a surge in cases of the XBB sub-variant of the Omicron variant, accounting for 54% of local cases from Oct 3-9. Despite its high transmissibility, no severe cases or deaths linked to the XBB strain have been reported in Singapore so far. The sub-variant may be less virulent than previous waves, with a 30% lower risk of hospitalization compared to the BA.5 variant, according to Ministry of Health data. Vaccinated individuals are still at risk of infection, with booster jabs recommended. The situation will be closely monitored by the authorities.

site_title: With Covid-19 cases rising due to XBB strain, do people need to mask up again?
summary: Singapore may need to mask up again due to the rising XBB Omicron subvariant, which could lead to an average of 15,000 daily new cases by mid-November. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung urged those not feeling well or living with the elderly to wear masks, citing personal responsibility and the risk of infection from Covid-19 and other respiratory diseases. Experts emphasize the importance of voluntary mask-wearing in crowded spaces and avoiding crowds when sick, as the country continues to make data-driven decisions to mitigate the spread of the virus.

site_title: Over 1,800 low-income families to receive mini-library to encourage kids to read
summary: The KidStart Stories initiative, launched in Singapore, aims to encourage low-income families to read with their children through the provision of mini-libraries. Over 1,800 families will receive a mini-library, including a bookshelf and age-appropriate books, along with access to storytelling videos and resources. The initiative, run by KidStart Singapore, aims to promote early childhood development and a lifelong love for reading, with the goal of sparking language skills and imagination in young children. Minister of State Sun Xueling launched the initiative at a community club in Choa Chu Kang.

site_title: Over 800 hospital beds to be set aside in Covid-19 fight, non-critical operations postponed
summary: Singapore's public hospitals to set aside over 800 beds for Covid-19 patients amid rising cases, with non-critical operations postponed. The Ministry of Health prioritizes resources to cater to the needs of Covid-19 patients, while hospitals activate contingency measures, including redeploying doctors and nurses, and preparing more beds. The move aims to preserve capacity and ensure timely care for seriously ill patients. Bed occupancy is currently at 93%, with additional beds activated to cope with the increase.

site_title: Higher risk of infection during XBB wave for those who've never caught Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health found that individuals who have never caught Covid-19 (Covid-naive) have a higher risk of infection with the new XBB strain compared to those who were infected before the Delta wave in 2021. The incidence rate for Covid-naive patients was 162.5 infections per 100,000 person-days, while those previously infected had a rate of 147.4. Those who caught Covid-19 4-6 months ago had a significantly lower rate, and those infected 7-10 months ago had a higher rate, but still lower than Covid-naive individuals.

site_title: Felicia Teo's death: Man who dumped, burned corpse jailed
summary: A 37-year-old man, Ahmad Danial Mohamed Rafa'ee, was sentenced to 26 months in jail for his role in Felicia Teo's 2007 death. Ahmad and his accomplice, Indonesian Ragil Putra Setia Sukmarahjana, stuffed Felicia's body in a carton box, burned it, and covered it up. Ahmad's sentence was backdated to his arrest in 2020, and he is expected to be released soon. The accomplice remains at large, and the case had been classified as a missing persons case for over 13 years.

site_title: Beyond career-related posts: How to avoid oversharing on LinkedIn
summary: LinkedIn, a professional networking platform, has become a space where users often blur the lines between personal and career-related discussions. Users share their personal lives, beliefs, and opinions, which can be perceived as oversharing. This trend has created a unique culture on the platform, with over three million users in Singapore. The article highlights the importance of maintaining a professional boundary on LinkedIn, suggesting users avoid sharing personal details to maintain a professional image and avoid potential misinterpretations.

site_title: 4 guidelines on living with Covid-19 amid XBB wave
summary: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung has issued four guidelines to help Singaporeans live with Covid-19 amid the XBB wave. These guidelines include: (1) receiving the bivalent Moderna vaccine for those aged 50+, (2) potential resumption of safe management measures if the situation worsens, (3) hospital visitor restrictions in place during waves, and (4) emphasizing personal responsibility to mask up, test, and isolate when necessary, especially for vulnerable groups like pregnant women and infants.

site_title: Users build connections on LinkedIn, but risk oversharing
summary: LinkedIn, a popular networking site, has created a culture where users share personal aspects of their lives and beliefs alongside professional information. With around three million users in Singapore, the platform allows workers to host resumes, connect with peers, apply for jobs, and learn new skills. However, this trend raises concerns about oversharing, blurring the lines between personal and professional lives. The site's unique culture has become a niche, but users must consider the potential risks of sharing too much of themselves.

site_title: S’pore’s XBB Covid-19 wave to peak in mid-Nov with 15,000 average daily cases, mask rules not ruled out
summary: Singapore's current Covid-19 wave, driven by the XBB sub-variant, is expected to peak at 15,000 daily cases by mid-November. Despite projections indicating adequate healthcare capacity, the government does not rule out reintroducing stricter mask rules or vaccination-differentiated safe management measures if needed. Public hospitals have increased bed capacity to over 800 beds, and the government urges the public to take personal responsibility, stay vaccinated, and minimize non-essential hospital visits.

site_title: Take part in NLB book exchanges at parks till Feb next year
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) has launched the "Nodes at Parks" initiative, bringing sustainability education to green spaces through book exchanges and pop-up sustainable product displays. From October to February, book exchanges will be held at various parks, allowing visitors to exchange up to three used library books, while stocks last. The program also features exhibits on sustainable products, such as exercise mats made from shoe waste, and sustainable benches painted by secondary school students.

site_title: Zam Zam restaurant ex-director granted discharge over rash act, criminal intimidation charges
summary: Former Zam Zam restaurant director Zackeer Abbass Khan, 52, has been granted a discharge not amounting to an acquittal for two pending charges of criminal intimidation and committing a rash act. The charges stem from a 2020 attack on a supervisor of rival eatery Victory, where Khan allegedly threatened and swerved a car at a man. Khan can still be prosecuted again if new evidence surfaces, as the prosecution had applied for the discharge after the victim failed to attend court.

site_title: Businesses will continue to get help to transform: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that businesses in Singapore will continue to receive support to transform their operations and become more energy efficient. The Government has already provided a $1.5 billion support package for households to deal with rising prices, and previously offered up to 70% funding support for energy-efficient equipment adoption. Wong emphasized the importance of restructuring and transformation for businesses to cope with the current economic situation and sustain their operations in the long term, with the Government planning to study additional help measures for businesses in the upcoming Budget.

site_title: About 10,500 more students to get financial help after eligibility changes
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has raised the income eligibility cap for financial assistance schemes, increasing the gross household monthly income ceiling from $2,750 to $3,000 and the per capita income ceiling from $690 to $750. This change is expected to benefit around 10,500 more students, bringing the total number of students receiving financial assistance to about 135,500. The revised criteria will take effect from January 2023 for primary, secondary, and pre-university students, as well as those in special education schools and independent schools.

site_title: Engaging the community helps reduce smoking rate: NZ minister
summary: New Zealand Associate Minister of Health Ayesha Verrall emphasized the importance of community engagement in reducing smoking rates, particularly among Maori, Pacific, and low-income communities. The country aims to become smoke-free by 2025, with a goal of reducing the smoking rate to below 5%. To achieve this, Verrall introduced a Smokefree 2025 Action Plan, which includes initiatives such as waka-ama, a traditional canoeing sport, and low-nicotine cigarettes. Despite increased excise taxes, progress has been slow, with poor and minority groups less likely to quit smoking, highlighting the need for more targeted interventions.

site_title: People of Asia must stand against conflict: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of Asian nations standing together against conflict and focusing on building stronger ties to achieve the 21st century as the "Asian century". He stressed the need for investing in education and technology to remain globally competitive, and highlighted the potential for regional cooperation on shared interests such as climate change. Wong called for closer collaboration between organizations to fund green projects and urged ASEAN to become an effective grouping to press on with regional plans, including cross-border real-time retail payments.

site_title: Pre-schoolers from struggling families get help from support programme
summary: A support programme by My First Skool, a pre-school operator, helps 5,000 pre-school pupils from lower-income families each year. The programme includes speech and therapy support, small group lessons, and financial assistance, narrowing the gap between disadvantaged children and their peers. A three-year study found children who participated showed improvement in language and cognitive skills, moving from below-average scores to national averages. Since 2016, 30,000 children have benefited from the programme, which aims to support 7,000 children annually by 2025.

site_title: Fresh chickens from Malaysia selling fast despite higher prices
summary: Malaysia has lifted its export ban on fresh broiler chickens to Singapore, allowing for the import of over 1.8 million chickens per month. Despite a 15-35% price increase, demand remains healthy, with crowds seen at wet markets. Poultry hawkers are expected to sell out, with some anticipating reduced profit margins. To celebrate the return of fresh chicken, some businesses, like OK Chicken Rice, are offering free plates to elderly or needy customers, while others, like poultry sellers, worry about the impact on their supply and profit margins.

site_title: How fate of missing teen was uncovered after 13 years
summary: Felicia Teo, a 19-year-old fine arts student, disappeared in June 2007 after attending a party with two friends. Despite a massive search effort involving over 200 people and thousands of missing-person fliers, she was never found. Her mother was convinced she had settled abroad and continued to hold onto hope. However, in 2020, a breakthrough came when a fresh screening of her MacBook laptop revealed that one of her friends, Ahmad Danial Mohamed Rafa'ee, had possessed her laptop, leading to his arrest and conviction. It has been over 13 years since her disappearance.

site_title: $1.5b package to help Singaporeans cope with inflation
summary: Singapore's government has announced a $1.5 billion support package to help households cope with rising inflation. 2.5 million eligible adult Singaporeans will receive up to $500 in cash, while every household will get an additional $100 Community Development Council (CDC) voucher. The package aims to support lower-income and elderly Singaporeans, with the goal of fully covering the increase in cost of living for lower-income households on average. The package will also provide more support for middle-income households and help with rising transport costs.

site_title: Health screening to get more convenient for needy kids
summary: A new programme, Heads-Up, will be launched in the next year to provide health screenings to underprivileged children in pre-schools. The programme, a partnership between the Khoo Teck Puat - National University Children's Medical Institute and social service agency Care Corner Singapore, aims to identify potential health issues early and support children from families in the bottom 20% of household income. The programme will leverage childcare teachers and social workers to help children achieve better health outcomes, including oral health assessments via teledentistry. Up to 300 children will benefit from the programme over the next two to three years.

site_title: Couple tried to lift tree off victim but failed, court told
summary: A woman, 38-year-old Loke Xiao Li, died after a 20m-tall tree fell on her while jogging in Marsiling Park in February 2021. A couple who rushed to her aid attempted to lift the tree but were unsuccessful. The coroner's inquiry revealed termites were the primary cause of the tree failure, which had entered the tree from beneath the ground. The National Parks Board had not detected the termite infestation during a visual assessment in 2020. The inquiry is expected to continue on November 11.

site_title: S'pore will defend sovereignty over Pedra Branca, MFA says in response to KL reports
summary: Singapore is prepared to defend its sovereignty over Pedra Branca, a disputed island in the Singapore Strait, after Malaysia announced plans to pursue legal action at the International Court of Justice. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that Singapore will robustly defend its sovereignty and deal with any action taken by Malaysia. The ICJ previously awarded sovereignty over Pedra Branca to Singapore in 2008, with Malaysia retaining sovereignty over Middle Rocks and South Ledge. The 10-year statute of limitations for a revision application has expired, and Malaysia's plans to pursue further action are unlikely to change the outcome.

site_title: Pofma correction orders issued over misinformation on XBB sub-variant
summary: The Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) Office ordered corrections on false statements about the XBB Covid-19 sub-variant. The statements, made by Thailand Medical News, opposition politician Goh Meng Seng, and others, claimed severe Covid-19 cases were rising and mortuaries were facing a "pile-up" in cases. However, the Ministry of Health (MOH) stated that XBB cases have a 30% lower risk of hospitalization compared to Omicron BA.5 cases and that Covid-19 deaths have not increased. Corrections were issued to rectify the misinformation and prevent public concern.

site_title: Vaccination centres busy on first day of bivalent Covid-19 jabs
summary: Vaccination centres in Singapore saw a surge in activity on the first day of offering the Moderna bivalent Covid-19 jab, with seniors and those planning to travel making up the majority of recipients. Long queues were reported at several centres, with some waiting times stretching to 30 minutes. The vaccine targets two variants, providing better protection, and was approved by the Health Sciences Authority in September. The Ministry of Health stated that clinical trials showed greater antibody response and better protection against newer variants, with similar side effects to the original vaccine.

site_title: DSO's mission to tap tech to defend S'pore must continue: PM
summary: Singapore's Defence Science Organisation (DSO) has been instrumental in developing secret-edge technologies to safeguard the country's security and sovereignty over the past 50 years. Founded in 1972, DSO's mission remains unchanged, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasizing the importance of maintaining a technological edge in the face of increasing competition and cyber threats. DSO's contributions, including its bio-defence capabilities during the Covid-19 pandemic, have been invaluable, and the organization must continue to innovate and adapt to stay relevant.

site_title: COE supply for Nov-Jan to fall 13.8%, with commercial vehicles hardest hit
summary: Singapore's COE supply for November to January will decrease by 13.8%, with commercial vehicles hardest hit. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will have 3,040 COEs available each month, down from 3,526 previously. This is the second revised method to calculate COE supply, aiming to reduce volatility and return deregistered vehicles to the bidding pool. COE premiums are expected to rise, particularly for motorcycles, with only 137 commercial vehicle COEs available each month.

site_title: ComLink in touch with over 11,000 families with kids in rental flats
summary: The Community Link (ComLink) programme has reached out to approximately 11,200 families living in public rental housing in Singapore, with 80% of the projected 14,000 families contacted as of October 2022. The programme has secured $2.7 million in donations and engages over 218 partners and companies to support low-income families. Minister-in-charge Desmond Lee emphasized the need for holistic support, addressing basic needs, self-reliance, and social mobility, as single agencies often struggle to provide comprehensive assistance.

site_title: Measures this year to fully cover inflation impact for bottom 40% of households
summary: The Singapore Government's cost-of-living support measures, announced in 2022, will fully cover the impact of rising prices for the bottom 40% of households and more than half of their average expenditure increase for the middle 20%. The measures reduce inflation by over half, with the bottom 20% experiencing more than 1.5 times of their average expenditure increase covered. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation is expected to be around 6% for 2022, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore core inflation averaging 4%.

site_title: GST Assurance Package to be updated to factor in higher inflation: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that the GST Assurance Package will be updated to account for higher-than-expected inflation. The $6.6 billion support package will offset the impact of the GST hike, which will increase from 7% to 8% in 2023 and 9% in 2024. The Government is committed to cushioning the impact on lower- and middle-income households for at least 5 and 10 years, respectively. The package will be reviewed to ensure it meets its commitments, and the GST increase will proceed to secure revenue for growing expenditure.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore has announced a $1.5 billion support package to help households cope with rising prices, with up to $500 in special cost-of-living payments for 2.5 million eligible residents. Meanwhile, a Malaysian man has been jailed for 26 months for dumping the body of Felicia Teo in 2007. Fresh Malaysian chickens are back on shelves after a 4.5-month absence, despite a 15-35% price hike. Additionally, LinkedIn users may risk revealing too much about themselves online, while regional badminton stars will compete in the Brave Sword International Team Challenge 2022 in December.

site_title: Asia ex-China spends $71b to shore up currencies
summary: Asian governments spent approximately $71 billion in September to shore up their currencies against the US dollar, the highest level since March 2020. This includes $30 billion from emerging Asian nations excluding China, and $20 billion from Japan. The surge in US dollar sales is driven by the interest rate hike and Bloomberg's Dollar Spot Index at an all-time high. The move aims to reduce the value of other currencies in central banks' portfolios, with the pace of intervention potentially not over, especially for Japan.

site_title: Pofma orders issued to TOC, economist over claims on past reserves and HDB loss
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) Office has ordered former GIC chief economist Yeoh Lam Keong and alternative news site The Online Citizen (TOC) to correct false claims about the loss made by the Housing Board in a BTO project and the nation's past reserves. The claims, made on Facebook and TOC, alleged an "accounting sleight of hand" and claimed the Government would profit from $500 million in land sales. However, the Ministry of National Development (MND) disputed these claims, stating that losses are real and covered by the annual Budget, and that selling land at fair market value does not increase past reserves.

site_title: Company Briefs : Garuda Indonesia PropertyGuru Pinterest
summary: Flag carrier Garuda Indonesia secured shareholder approval to launch a rights issue in December to raise up to 14.3 trillion rupiah, or S$1.3 billion, to strengthen its capital. The government plans to invest 7.5 trillion rupiah, following a debt restructuring program agreed in June. Meanwhile, Singapore-based PropertyGuru acquired home-service technology start-up Sendhelper for an undisclosed sum, entering the home-services industry. Pinterest shares rose 34% from a two-year low, driven by improving user growth and search-driven advertising, as the platform works to help advertisers sell products directly on the site.

site_title: Bail denied for man accused of illegally obtaining girl's details
summary: A 46-year-old man, Fong Poh Kuen, has had his bail denied due to being deemed at "extremely high risk of re-offending" for illegally obtaining a schoolgirl's personal information in January 2020. Further police investigations have uncovered new victims, potentially adding 10 more charges to his case. Fong, a former insurance agent, has been in remand since September 2 and is expected to appear in court on November 11. He faces fines or imprisonment of up to 10 years for the offense.

site_title: MAS tightens Sing$ policy again to fight inflation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) tightened its monetary policy to fight inflation, boosting the Singdollar's midpoint to its prevailing level, but no change was made to the slope and width of the band. The move aims to reduce imported inflation and curb domestic cost pressures. MAS forecasts core inflation to average 4% and headline inflation to reach 6% in 2022. The decision follows five previous tightening moves since October 2021, and the next policy statement is due in April 2023.

site_title: Singapore's economy beats forecast to grow 4.4% in Q3
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4.4% year on year in Q3 2022, beating forecasts and avoiding a technical recession. The services sector led the growth, expanding 9.2% year on year, while the manufacturing sector saw slower growth. Economists warn that the road ahead is bumpy, expecting below trend growth in 2023 due to high global inflation, tighter monetary policies, and geopolitical uncertainties. Full-year growth could easily reach the higher end of the 3-4% forecast.

site_title: Infineon partners LG Group to mentor S'pore, S. Korean start-ups
summary: Infineon Technologies has partnered with LG Group to mentor start-ups in Singapore and South Korea, focusing on decarbonisation and digitalisation. Five Singaporean start-ups and one from South Korea will participate in Infineon's Co-Innovation Space programme, gaining access to business partners, office space, and mentorship. The collaboration aims to accelerate joint development of solutions for smart mobility and sustainability, with Infineon also partnering with Vietnamese smart electric car maker VinFast. The initiative highlights the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises in driving innovation and growth in the region.

site_title: Musk under federal probe over deal, Twitter says in court filing
summary: Billionaire Elon Musk is under a federal probe over his conduct in the US$44 billion takeover deal for Twitter, according to a court filing by the social media company. Twitter claims Musk's attorneys are withholding documents, including drafts of emails to the SEC and FTC, citing "investigative privilege." The filing accuses Musk of a "game of 'hide the ball'" and requests the judge to order his attorneys to provide the documents. The SEC has questioned Musk's comments about the acquisition, and the FTC is scrutinizing whether Musk failed to comply with antitrust reporting requirements.

site_title: China inflation stays subdued, stifled by lockdowns
summary: China's consumer inflation rose 2.8% in September, the highest since April 2020, driven by pork prices. Core inflation slowed to 0.6%, the weakest pace since March 2021, while factory-gate inflation decreased to 0.9%. Economists attribute the subdued inflation to lockdowns and a property crisis, which have stifled consumption and demand. The nation's adherence to Covid-19-Zero policy and ongoing economic challenges suggest China may be heading towards an era of deflation, with some experts warning of increasing risks from deflation and weak economic recovery.

site_title: Yen falls to 32-year low against greenback
summary: The Japanese yen hit a 32-year low against the US dollar, falling to 147.785 yen on Friday. The US dollar rose 0.34% to that level, its highest since 1990. Despite US inflation accelerating, a rally in global stock markets and a reversal of short-seller positions drove the dollar's gain. Japan's Finance Minister reiterated the government's readiness to intervene in currency markets, while analysts predict the yen could fall to 150 per dollar in the near future.

site_title: S'pore stocks continue losing streak to hit new 19-month low
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.03% to a 19-month low, marking the seventh straight day of losses. Losers outpaced gainers 255 to 251, with Reits among the worst hit. Despite Singapore's economy beating expectations with 4.4% year-on-year growth, the Monetary Authority of Singapore tightened policy to fight inflation with a less aggressive move. Markets in Hong Kong, South Korea, Australia, and Japan rallied after Wall Street's 2.6% rebound from a hotter-than-expected inflation report.

site_title: An uphill task for reigning champion
summary: Defending champion Hideki Matsuyama struggled in the second round of the PGA Tour's Zozo Championship in Japan, carding a 69 and falling 10 shots behind joint leaders Rickie Fowler and Andrew Putnam. Matsuyama, seeking to retain his title, described the two rounds as "stressful" and warned that a poor score on the final day would make winning the title difficult. Fowler and Putnam share the lead at 10-under 130, with Matsuyama tied 49th. The tournament continues over the weekend.

site_title: MAS tightens policy again to fight inflation
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has tightened monetary policy again to combat inflation, despite not being as aggressive as expected. The MAS forecasts core inflation at 3.5-4.5% and headline inflation at 5.5-6.5% for 2023, considering the 1% GST increase. This is the fifth policy tightening since October 2021, as the MAS aims to control inflation and maintain economic stability.

site_title: Ginobili jersey goes up, up and away
summary: The NBA sent Manu Ginobili's autographed jersey into space with a zero-pressure balloon in recognition of his induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame. The jersey reached over 30km in height and remained for about four hours. The tribute was organized by B2Space, a firm specializing in near space testing, to celebrate Ginobili's legacy in basketball and Latin America. Ginobili, a four-time NBA champion and Olympic gold medalist, was inducted into the Hall of Fame in September 2022, becoming one of the most decorated international players in basketball history.

site_title: Private banking industry sets green standards
summary: The Private Banking Industry Group has released guidelines for integrating sustainability practices into private banking business models. Developed by an industry task force, the framework covers financial activities such as wealth planning and investments. The guidelines aim to increase transparency and clarity for clients on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing. A training benchmark has also been rolled out to upskill private banking relationship managers in sustainability, prioritizing technical competencies such as sustainable investment management and climate change management. The move follows growing demand for sustainable investments among high-net-worth individuals and family offices.

site_title: Tough for LIV players to get ranking points: Cho
summary: The LIV Golf Invitational Series faces significant challenges in winning world ranking points, according to Asian Tour CEO Cho Minn Thant. The tour's application to the Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) board is hindered by the board's composition, which includes senior figures from American and European golf. LIV players are struggling to climb the rankings, with some, like Patrick Reed, complaining about the impact on their qualification for the four Majors. Cho hopes for a compromise, but the process is expected to take over a year, leaving LIV players' futures uncertain.

site_title: TSMC capital spending falls 10% - a red flag for tech sector
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) has slashed its 2022 capital spending target by 10% to $36 billion, a sign of trouble for the technology industry amid US restrictions on doing business with China. The move suggests a broader-than-anticipated downturn in sectors such as smartphones and servers. Analysts estimate TSMC could lose 10% of its annual sales due to the restrictions, which will impact about 5-8% of its revenue. Despite this, TSMC is betting on its size and technology to navigate challenges, reaffirming its long-term targets for revenue and growth.

site_title: Fifa open to World Cup labour fund
summary: Fifa is exploring the creation of a compensation fund for migrant workers injured while working on World Cup projects in Qatar, following human rights organizations' calls for such a fund. The idea was suggested by Amnesty International, which demanded a US$440 million fund for "abused" workers in Qatar. Qatar has faced criticism over under-reporting deaths and injuries among workers, as well as unpaid wages. A decision on the fund's implementation is pending, with Fifa considering the need for "structure, rules, and governance."

site_title: Pace of price rises expected to ease in 2nd half of 2023
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has revised its inflation forecast for 2023, predicting a slower pace of price increases in the second half of the year. Core inflation is expected to range from 3.5-4.5% and headline inflation from 5.5-6.5%, with the impact of a goods and services tax (GST) increase considered "transitory". The MAS also noted upside risks, including shocks to global commodity prices and second-round effects, and warned of considerable uncertainty around the inflation and growth outlook.

site_title: Lavreysen buries sprint loss with keirin hat-trick
summary: Harrie Lavreysen of the Netherlands won his 10th world track cycling championship gold medal, claiming his third consecutive men's keirin title. Lavreysen's compatriot Jeffrey Hoogland finished second, with Colombia's Kevin Quintero taking bronze. Meanwhile, Belgian Lotte Kopecky won the women's elimination race, edging out Italy's Rachele Barbieri and securing a third world title. Britain won the men's team pursuit title, upsetting Olympic champions Italy, while the Italian women's team took gold in the women's team pursuit.

site_title: Arteta hopes busy Gunners keep a clean bill of health
summary: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta will closely monitor his players ahead of Sunday's Premier League trip to Leeds United due to their recent Europa League exertions on an artificial pitch. The Gunners maintained their perfect start in Europe with a 1-0 win over Bodo/Glimt, with Bukayo Saka's goal securing the victory. Arteta aims to keep his 11 players fresh for the next two days, considering the artificial pitch may lead to injuries. Arsenal will be without Emile Smith Rowe and Mohamed Elneny, and Oleksandr Zinchenko will miss his third straight game.

site_title: Singaporeans face another year of paying more for goods and services
summary: Singaporeans can expect to pay more for goods and services in 2023, with headline inflation forecast to be around 5.5-6.5%. This is a continuation of pre-pandemic levels, indicating that the country's economy is not yet recovering from the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic. The central bank's assessment suggests that inflation will remain a concern for consumers in the coming year.

site_title: Back Master Of Destiny over trip
summary: Greyville's Sunday racing analysis focuses on the prospects of various horses, including Master Of Destiny, who is favored to win the 7th race. Other notable contenders include Ellis Island, Ellis Island's stablemate Winter Air, and Teichman, all of whom have strong form. Master Of Destiny's consistent performance over shorter distances suggests he could excel in the longer 1900m trip.

site_title: Salute to California Spangle
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Hong Kong racing scene is set to kick off with a packed Sunday schedule at Sha Tin. Favorites include California Spangle in the Oriental Watch Sha Tin Trophy, and Baebae Tsoi in the 1,400M race. Other standout horses include 5 Inspiring City, 9 Mister Monte, and Lucky With You, who are expected to dominate their respective races. The day's events will also feature horses returning from injury, such as Cobhfield and Captain Win, and newcomers like Generous Friend and Sweet Diamond. With many talented horses competing, it's shaping up to be an exciting day of racing.

site_title: Battle of the star strikers: Looks like no contest
summary: Manchester City's Erling Haaland has dominated Liverpool's Darwin Nunez since the close season, with Haaland scoring 15 goals in just nine Premier League games and holding the record for most goals and goal involvements in a player's first 10 appearances. Nunez, who was signed for £75 million, has struggled to replicate his impressive form at Benfica, scoring just three goals in the Premier League. City's focus on a central striker has paid off, with Haaland continuing to raise the bar for his team.

site_title: Conte not taking any 'stupid risks'
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte is prioritizing patience and caution in nursing midfielder Dejan Kulusevski back from injury ahead of a hectic schedule. The 22-year-old, who has missed four games since sustaining an injury in September, is not ready to return to the fold, with Conte emphasizing the need to avoid "stupid risks" and burnout. Spurs face a nine-game stretch before the World Cup, with Conte confident that his team can maintain their good form despite the congested schedule.

site_title: S'pore venue for Masters event
summary: Singapore will host the Brave Sword International Team Challenge 2022 from Dec 2-4, featuring Olympic and world champions like Liliyana Natsir and Eddy Hartono. The Masters series, which includes teams from Indonesia and Malaysia, aims to promote the sport among players aged 35 and above. The event, organized by Brave Sword Badminton Academy, is significant as it highlights the importance of older players in the sport. The tournament is expected to grow interest in badminton, with the Singapore Badminton Association already having over 200,000 active players.

site_title: Neymar faces jail term in fraud trial
summary: Brazilian forward Neymar is set to stand trial on fraud and corruption charges related to his transfer from Santos to Barcelona in 2013. The case, led by Spanish prosecutors, involves Neymar, his parents, and former club officials, with the complainant, DIS, seeking a five-year jail term for Neymar. The trial begins in Barcelona on Monday, with Neymar's lawyers arguing that competition rules do not apply to the transfer market and that the player's free will should be respected. Neymar faces a two-year prison term and a €10 million fine.

site_title: Second QEII Cup win is not unthinkable
summary: Hard Too Think, a six-year-old stayer, will defend his title in the $300,000 Group 1 Queen Elizabeth II Cup after a year of struggling in unsuitable races. He has dropped only four points since the Singapore Gold Cup and will carry 58kg, the same weight as his competitors. Trainer Stephen Gray believes Hard Too Think has regained his form and is well weighted in the Gold Cup, citing jockey Danny Beasley's decision to switch to him. A win would be Hard Too Think's second QEII Cup victory, after his 2021 win.

site_title: Lionesses coach Ng to leave on Oct 31
summary: Stephen Ng, the head coach of Singapore's women's football team, will step down on October 31 after almost 20 months in charge. Ng's assistant, Ratna Suffian, will take over as interim coach. During Ng's tenure, the Lionesses achieved historic results, including a 6-2 win over Seychelles and a 95th-minute winner against Laos. Ng leaves with a record of three wins, one draw, and 11 defeats, and expressed his pride in the team's development under his leadership. A search for a new coach has begun.

site_title: Sports World
summary: Singapore pool player Aloysius Yapp lost 9-1 to Bosnia's Sanjin Pehlivanovic in the US Open round of 64. Yapp, ranked world No. 5, had previously won the Michigan Open and Sandcastle 9-Ball Open. Cricket fans can watch the T20 World Cup on StarHub's Channel 204 with a Sports+ subscription. England rugby coach Eddie Jones stated the 2023 Rugby World Cup will not be his last, and sprinter C.J. Ujah will be considered for selection after his 22-month doping ban ends.

site_title: Gan Kim Yong visits Batam and Bintan to strengthen bilateral relations
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong visited Batam and Bintan to strengthen bilateral relations between Singapore and Indonesia. During his trip, he met with local officials and business representatives from various sectors, discussing the impact of COVID-19 on the Indonesian economy and Singaporean businesses. Singapore companies, including Sembcorp Marine and Esco, have operations in the islands and continue to show interest in exploring opportunities. Bilateral trade reached $59.1 billion in 2021, with Singapore being Indonesia's top source of foreign direct investment since 2014.

site_title: United belief bears fruit
summary: Manchester United secured a 1-0 win over Cypriot side Omonia Nicosia at Old Trafford, thanks to a late goal from Scott McTominay in the 93rd minute. The victory gave the Red Devils hope of finishing top of Group E in the Europa League, despite being behind Real Sociedad by three points. Manager Erik ten Hag praised his team's self-belief and creativity, despite poor finishing, and expressed confidence in their ability to win matches. The win sets United up for a crucial final group game against Sociedad in November.

site_title: Football: Liverpool are City's biggest title challengers, says Pep ahead of Sunday's game
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola has stated that Liverpool are his team's biggest title challengers, despite being 13 points behind in the league table. City have been consistent this season, unbeaten in 13 competitive matches, while Liverpool have struggled, winning only two of their eight league games. Guardiola believes Liverpool's quality and the World Cup break will make them a threat, and City will need to be at their best to beat them. The match between the two teams is set to take place at Anfield on Sunday.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary:
Key events and sports schedules for the next 24 hours include: 
- Track World Championships (Saturday, 11:55pm)
- English Premier League matches: Leicester v Palace (7:25pm), Wolves v Forest (9:50pm), Tottenham v Everton (Sunday, 12:30am)
- Singapore Premier League matches: Tampines v Albirex (5pm), Young Lions v Hougang (5:20pm)
- Andalucia Masters (golf): Day 3 (7:30pm)
- US Open pool s-finals (10pm) and final (Sunday, 4am)
- UFC Fight Night: Grasso v Araujo (Sunday, 4am)
- MotoGP Australian Grand Prix practice 3 (6:55am), 4 (10:30am), and qualifying (11:10am)
- Women's World Cup rugby matches: Scotland v Australia (9:45am), USA v Japan (12:15pm), France v England (2:45pm)
- ATP Tour Gijon Open s-finals (8pm), WTA Tour San Diego Open s-finals (Sunday, 5am), and Transylvania Open s-finals (8pm).

site_title: Coll eyes grip on No. 1
summary: New Zealand's Paul Coll will face Egyptian Ali Farag in the men's draw at the Nov 15-20 Marigold Singapore Squash Open, a $220,000 PSA World Tour Gold event. Coll, the world's No. 1, has received a first-round bye and will play Malaysian Ng Eain Yow or Indian Saurav Ghosal. Egyptian Farag, the world No. 2, will face compatriot Omar Mosaad or Englishman Patrick Rooney. The women's draw features top seed Amanda Sobhy, with Singapore's Au Yeong Wai Yhann and Samuel Kang also competing.

site_title: Swiatek renews bid for eighth title of season
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek defeated China's Zheng Qinwen 6-4, 4-6, 6-1 in the San Diego Open, advancing to the quarter-finals. This win marks her 13th quarter-final of the year and sets her up for a match against American Coco Gauff on Saturday. Swiatek credited adjusting to Zheng's topspin forehand for her victory, which came after a second-set comeback from a break down. With a final tournament before the season-ending WTA Finals, Swiatek aims to secure her eighth title of the season.

site_title: Pofma correction orders issued to ex-GIC economist, TOC over false claims on past reserves and HDB loss
summary: Former GIC chief economist Yeoh Lam Keong and alternative news site The Online Citizen (TOC) have been ordered under the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) to correct false statements about the loss made by the Housing Board in the Central Weave @ AMK BTO project. Yeoh made claims of "accounting sleight of hand" and alleged the government acquired land at minimal cost, while TOC published articles echoing these claims. The Ministry of National Development (MND) clarified that losses incurred by HDB are accurate and real, and are covered by funding from the annual Budget.

site_title: 13-year search for Felicia Teo: How fate of missing teen was uncovered
summary: A 13-year search for missing 19-year-old Felicia Teo in Singapore has ended with the arrest and conviction of her former friend Ahmad Danial Mohamed Rafa'ee. Teo disappeared in June 2007 after leaving a party with two friends, and her family and friends had been searching for her in vain. A breakthrough came in 2020 when a security camera image was matched to a MacBook found by Rafa'ee, leading to his arrest and conviction for possessing Teo's belongings. The case has finally brought closure to Teo's family, who had held onto the hope that she would be found alive.

site_title: Eggs from Malaysian farm recalled after salmonella detected
summary: A batch of eggs imported from a Malaysian farm, Teo Seng Layer Farm 1, has been recalled in Singapore due to salmonella enteritidis contamination. The eggs can be identified by the code CEJ027 and may cause diarrhoea, fever, and vomiting if consumed raw or undercooked. All six companies that imported the affected eggs have been directed to withhold or recall them, and the farm has been suspended pending rectification of the contamination. The eggs are safe to eat if cooked thoroughly, and the recall is ongoing.

site_title: ComLink in touch with over 11,000 families with children living in rental flats
summary: The Community Link (ComLink) programme has reached 80% of its target 14,000 families with children living in public rental housing, connecting with over 11,200 families as of October 2022. Minister-in-charge of Social Services Integration Desmond Lee announced $2.7 million in donations and secured partnerships with over 218 organizations. Lee emphasized the need for a holistic approach to social services, addressing stability, self-reliance, and social mobility, and criticized piecemeal services that can exacerbate family issues.

site_title: Health screening to get more convenient for needy kids
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced a new programme, Heads-Upp, to provide health screenings to underprivileged children in pre-schools. The programme, in partnership with Care Corner Singapore and pre-schools, aims to identify potential health issues early and support better health outcomes for children from families in the bottom 20% of household income. The initiative, launching next year, will leverage childcare teachers and social workers, and includes teledentistry to assess oral health. Up to 300 children will benefit from the programme over the next two to three years.

site_title: Yen pushed to 32-year low against US dollar amid accelerating inflation
summary: The Japanese yen reached a 32-year low against the US dollar, trading at 147.785 yen per dollar, amid accelerating inflation. Despite a brighter global mood, investors remain concerned about the yen's value, with Japan's Finance Minister reiterating the government's readiness to intervene if necessary. The US dollar rose 0.34% to its highest level since 1990, while the British pound slipped 0.77% after the government's U-turn on tax cuts. The focus shifts to the upcoming Fed meeting, where a fourth consecutive 75-basis-point rate increase is expected.

site_title: COE supply for Nov to Jan to fall by 13.8% to about 3,040 per month
summary: The supply of certificates of entitlement (COEs) for vehicles in Singapore will decrease by 13.8% from November to January, with an average of 3,040 COEs available each month. This is down from 3,526 COEs available for the period between August and October. The reduction affects commercial vehicles the most, with a 17.5% decrease in available COEs, while motorcycle COEs will also shrink by 12.7%. Experts predict that COE prices may rise due to the low supply, but demand from commercial fleet owners and retail customers remains uncertain.

site_title: Singapore will defend sovereignty over Pedra Branca, MFA says in response to Malaysian reports
summary: Singapore has stated its intention to defend its sovereignty over Pedra Branca, following reports from Malaysia that it plans to pursue legal action in the International Court of Justice (ICJ). The Malaysian Cabinet had agreed to proceed with ICJ action, citing possible negligence on the part of former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. Singapore exercised continuous sovereignty over Pedra Branca since the British colonial government took possession of the island in 1847. The ICJ had previously awarded sovereignty to Singapore in 2008, which both countries accepted and abide by.

site_title: DSO has come long way in 50 years of tapping technology to help defend S'pore
summary: Singapore's Defence Science and Organisation (DSO) has come a long way in 50 years of developing secret-edge technologies to help defend the country. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised DSO's contributions, including its development of diagnostic kits for the Covid-19 pandemic and its work in chem-bio-defence and satellite technology. As warfare becomes more tech-intensive, DSO's mission to develop and deliver cutting-edge technologies remains unchanged and more relevant than ever. The organization's 2,000-strong workforce, including 1,600 research scientists and engineers, is expected to play a crucial role in maintaining Singapore's technological edge in the face of intensifying competition for science and technology talent.

site_title: Football: Stephen Ng steps down as Singapore women's coach
summary: Stephen Ng, the former head coach of Singapore's women's national football team, is stepping down on October 31 after almost 20 months at the helm. Ng's two-year contract will expire, and his assistant Ratna Suffian will take over as interim coach for the Olympic qualifiers in April 2023. Ng's tenure saw the team achieve historic results, including a 95th-minute winner against Laos at the SEA Games. The 51-year-old coach expressed his pride in the team's development and wished the new coach success in raising the level of women's football in Singapore.

site_title: Asia's people will be key to enhancing prosperity in the region: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of Asian people in enhancing regional prosperity, stating that their focus on building stronger ties and exchanging ideas will drive the region's success. He highlighted the need for education and technology investments to remain globally competitive, particularly in addressing climate change through pooled resources and collaboration. Wong also stressed the importance of regional integration, citing Asean's cross-border retail payments as a key example, and encouraged countries to work together to shape the regional and international order.

site_title: Singapore's private banking industry sets green standards, upskills workforce
summary: Singapore's private banking industry has released a new framework to integrate sustainability practices into their business models. Developed by an industry task force, the guidelines cover financial activities such as wealth planning, investments, and financing. The framework aims to provide transparency and clarity on ESG investing, which is increasingly expected by clients. To upskill their workforce, the Private Banking Industry Group has developed a training benchmark focusing on four technical competencies, including sustainable investment management and climate change management. The move is in response to growing demand for sustainable investments among high-net-worth individuals and family offices.

site_title: Businesses will continue to get help to restructure, Govt to study further help for them in Budget 2023
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced a new $1.5 billion support package for Singaporean households to cope with rising prices, including a special cost-of-living payment of up to $500. However, businesses will continue to receive help with restructuring and transforming their operations to become more energy efficient, with the Government studying additional support measures in the upcoming Budget. The Government has already provided schemes to help businesses adopt energy-efficient equipment and has been working with businesses to make full use of earlier announced schemes.

site_title: Woman killed by falling tree in Marsiling: Couple tried to lift tree off her but failed
summary: A 38-year-old woman, Ms Loke Xiao Li, died after a 20m-tall Araucaria excelsa tree fell on her at Marsiling Park in February 2021. A couple attempted to lift the tree off her but were unsuccessful. Termites were found to be the primary cause of the tree failure, which had entered the tree from beneath the ground and degraded the wood. The National Parks Board had not detected the termite infestation during a visual tree assessment in April 2020. The coroner's inquiry into her death is ongoing.

site_title: Singaporeans face another year of paying more for goods and services
summary: Singaporeans can expect to pay more for goods and services in 2023, with the central bank predicting headline inflation to be around 5.5% to 6.5%. This marks a continuation of increased prices post-pandemic, with no indication of a significant decrease in inflation for the upcoming year.

site_title: GST Assurance Package to be updated amid higher inflation, details in Budget 2023: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore's GST Assurance Package will be updated to account for higher-than-expected inflation, with details to be provided in Budget 2023. The GST will increase by one percentage point to 8% on Jan 1, 2023, and another point to 9% on Jan 1, 2024. The Government aims to cushion the impact on lower- and middle-income households, with the package set to last for at least five years and 10 years for lower-income households. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for revenue to fund growing expenditure despite concerns about inflation.

site_title: Book exchange corners coming to parks near you
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) has launched the "Nodes at Parks" initiative, a book exchange program where visitors can exchange second-hand library books at designated locations in parks across Singapore. The program began at Gardens by the Bay on October 14 and will run until November 22, with subsequent locations including Jurong Lake Gardens, East Coast Park, and Pasir Ris Park. The program aims to promote sustainability education and provide accessible resources, with books replenished weekly and a selection of sustainable products available for purchase.

site_title: NUS student who rode e-scooter on road given 12 months' probation
summary: A 25-year-old NUS undergraduate, Chuang Fu Yuan, was given 12 months' supervised probation for riding an e-scooter on the road, causing his female pillion, Ms Dai Yi Ting, to be flung off and suffer injuries. Initially charged with grievous hurt, the charge was withdrawn after the prosecution applied to drop it. Chuang was also ordered to perform 40 hours of community service and has parents bonded $5,000 to ensure his good behavior during the probation period.

site_title: Golf: Fowler grabs share of Japan lead but 'stressful' for Matsuyama
summary: Rickie Fowler grabbed a share of the lead at the US PGA Tour's Zozo Championship in Japan, carding a bogey-free 7-under 63 in the second round. Fowler is tied with Andrew Putnam at 10-under, while defending champion Hideki Matsuyama struggled with a 69 and is 10 shots off the leaders. Matsuyama described the two rounds as "stressful," saying he must get a big score on the weekend to retain the title. Fowler and Putnam have a mountain to climb, but the American contingent remains prominent at the top of the leaderboard.

site_title: Pool: Aloysius Yapp knocked out of US Open round of 64
summary: Aloysius Yapp, the world No. 5 pool player from Singapore, lost 9-1 to Bosnia's Sanjin Pehlivanovic in the round of 64 of the US Open. Yapp had a strong run, beating Barry West Jr., Marc Vidal Claramunt, and Mickey Krause in earlier rounds. The Singaporean team will remain in the US until November to compete in several tournaments, including the Ohio Open and US International 9-Ball Open. Yapp had previously finished second in the 2021 US Open and retained his title at the Michigan Open and Sandcastle 9-Ball Open.

site_title: Measures rolled out in 2022 fully covers inflation impact for households in bottom 40%: MOF report
summary: The Singapore Government's 2022 cost-of-living support measures have fully covered the impact of inflation on households in the bottom 40% and more than half of households in the middle 20%. The measures, including a $1.5 billion package, reduced the effect of inflation by over half, with the bottom 20% having more than 1.5 times of their average expenditure increase covered. The measures, which include price subsidies and cash support, were found to effectively buffer cost-of-living pressures, with simulated inflation rates showing a 0.3 percentage point reduction in the effective inflation faced by households.

site_title: Football: Anderlecht apologise for fans' behaviour in West Ham defeat
summary: Anderlecht issued an apology for their fans' unruly behavior during their 2-1 Europa Conference League defeat to West Ham United. Fans lit flares, threw seats, and one fan ran onto the pitch, prompting police intervention to separate the two sets of supporters. The Belgian club condemned the behavior and apologized to West Ham, promising to address the issue with fans and UEFA. West Ham manager David Moyes praised Anderlecht's response, stating that crowd trouble should not detract from the players' performance.

site_title: Squash: World No. 1 Paul Coll to compete at Nov 15-20 Marigold Singapore Squash Open
summary: World No. 1 squash player Paul Coll will compete at the Nov 15-20 Marigold Singapore Squash Open, a PSA World Tour Gold event. Coll, 30, will face Malaysian Ng Eain Yow or Indian Saurav Ghosal in the first round. Egypt's Ali Farag, world No. 2, will also participate, with a first-round bye. The tournament, valued at US$220,000, marks the first major international squash competition in Singapore in 10 years, with top seeds including Amanda Sobhy, Joelle King, and Nour El Tayeb.

site_title: $1.5b package to help S'poreans cope with inflation; 2.5m people to get up to $500 in cash
summary: Singapore's government has announced a $1.5 billion support package to help citizens cope with inflation, with 2.5 million eligible households receiving up to $500 in cash. The package aims to support lower- and middle-income households, including elderly retirees, and will also provide additional vouchers for transportation costs and increased financial assistance for students. The measures are expected to fully cover the increase in cost of living for lower-income households and more than half for middle-income households.

site_title: 'High risk of re-offending': Man charged with illegally obtaining details of schoolgirl denied bail
summary: A 46-year-old man, Fong Poh Kuen, was denied bail after being charged with illegally obtaining the personal details of a schoolgirl in January 2020. He allegedly obtained her name, date of birth, and cellphone number. Further investigations have uncovered new victims, potentially leading to 10 additional charges. Fong, a former insurance agent, has been in remand since September 2 and faces up to 3 years in jail or a fine of up to $10,000 for the offense. He is expected to appear in court on November 11.

site_title: Cash payouts, CDC vouchers: Key measures in $1.5b support package for S'poreans
summary: Singapore has announced a $1.5 billion support package to combat the rising cost of living, including cash payouts, Community Development Council (CDC) vouchers, and public transport subsidies. Eligible adult Singaporeans aged 21 or above with assessable income of up to $100,000 will receive a cash payout of up to $500. An additional $100 CDC vouchers will be distributed to every household in January 2023, and public transport subsidies will cover a 10.6% fare increase. The government will also enhance education financial assistance schemes and bursaries for more students, increasing the income eligibility threshold and providing more support for lower-income households.

site_title: Badminton: Olympic medallists Liliyana Natsir, Eddy Hartono to feature in Masters event
summary: Indonesian badminton stars Liliyana Natsir and Eddy Hartono will headline the Brave Sword International Team Challenge 2022, a Masters series event in Singapore from Dec 2-4. The tournament, featuring 19 teams from Indonesia and Malaysia, aims to promote badminton for players aged 35 and above. The event is significant for its inclusion of veterans, with 2016 Olympic gold medallist Natsir and 1992 Barcelona Olympics silver medallist Hartono set to compete. The event is part of Brave Sword's efforts to grow interest in the sport beyond elite players.

site_title: Singtel's Optus says no passport replacement needed for those affected by cyber attack
summary: Optus, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has stated that customers affected by a recent massive cyberattack won't need to replace their passports due to exposure of their passport numbers. The company is now communicating this information to affected customers after discussions with the Australian government. 2.1 million of Optus' customers had their government identification numbers compromised, while 9.8 million customers had other personal information exposed, including email addresses and phone numbers. The Australian government will provide advice to impacted customers to safeguard them from potential identity crime.

site_title: Ikea posts record sales as price hikes offset weakening consumer confidence
summary: Ikea reported record high annual sales of €44.6 billion (S$62 billion), a 6.5% growth in the 12 months to August, driven by price hikes and easing supply shortages despite weakening consumer confidence. The company attributed sales growth to increased demand, with sales improving towards the end of the year and remaining strong in the new fiscal year. Ingka Group, the owner of most Ikea stores, also reported a 5.6% sales growth, with product prices adjusted depending on availability.

site_title: About 10,500 more students to benefit from financial support, bringing total to 135,500
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) in Singapore is raising the income eligibility cap for financial assistance schemes, making about 10,500 more students eligible for help. The gross household monthly income ceiling will increase from $2,750 to $3,000 and per capita income from $690 to $750. The changes will take effect from January 2023, bringing the total number of students receiving financial assistance to approximately 135,500. The revised criteria will also apply to students in special education schools and independent schools, and will include increased support for Institute of Technical Education (ITE) students.

site_title: Pofma correction orders issued over false claims on Covid-19 XBB variant
summary: The Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) has issued correction orders to HardwareZone Forum, Thailand Medical News, and opposition politician Goh Meng Seng for spreading false claims about the Covid-19 XBB variant. The Ministry of Health (MOH) stated that there is no evidence of the XBB strain causing more severe illness than previous variants, despite claims of rising severe cases and hospitalizations. The correction directions require recipients to insert a notice with a link to the Government's clarification, and the article has since been amended by Thailand Medical News.

site_title: Fresh Malaysia chickens fly off shelves in S'pore despite higher prices
summary: Malaysia has lifted its 4½-month export ban on fresh chickens to Singapore, allowing the country to import live broiler chickens again. Despite a 15-35% price increase, customers flocked to wet markets and minimarts to buy fresh chickens, with many retailers selling out their stock. Poultry hawkers reported higher demand for fresh chickens, with some expecting to give away free plates of chicken rice to elderly or needy customers. However, the return of higher-priced fresh chicken has resulted in lower demand for other types of chicken, potentially impacting profit margins for some hawkers.

site_title: Vaccination centres busy on first day of bivalent vaccine roll-out
summary: Singapore's vaccination centres were busy on the first day of the bivalent vaccine roll-out, with seniors and travel-planning individuals making up the majority of those vaccinated. Over 50 people, mostly seniors, waited in line at the Kaki Bukit joint testing and vaccination centre, with the queue moving briskly. The vaccine targets two variants, offering better protection and giving individuals greater peace of mind amidst rising infection numbers. The Ministry of Health has confirmed the vaccine generates a greater antibody response and provides better protection against newer Covid-19 variants.

site_title: China inflation stays subdued as Covid-19 lockdowns continue to impact spending
summary: China's consumer inflation rose 2.8% in September, the highest since April 2020, driven by pork prices. Core inflation slowed to 0.6%, and factory-gate inflation decreased to 0.9%. Economists attribute the subdued inflation to ongoing Covid-19 lockdowns and a property crisis, which have stifled consumption and demand. The nation's adherence to its Covid-19-zero policy and pessimistic household savings also contribute to the deflationary pressures. China is heading towards an era of deflation, with recovery in effective demand being weak.

site_title: Asian markets surge after sharp Wall Street swing, pound holds gains
summary: Asian markets surged on Friday, extending gains on Wall Street after a forecast-beating inflation report led to expectations of more Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Nikkei rose 3.4%, the Hang Seng Index jumped 3.2%, and the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.4%. Sterling maintained gains, while the yen remained near 32-year lows. Analysts attribute the market reversal to traders accepting the data was not as bad as recent reports and anticipation of restrictive monetary policy, but warn that this trend won't last long.

site_title: Asia spent $71 billion in September to defend currencies from strong US dollar
summary: Asian governments spent approximately US$71 billion in September to defend their currencies from a strong US dollar, the highest level since March 2020. This brings total dollar sales in the region to around US$89 billion over the first nine months of the year. The surge in the US dollar has reduced the value of other currencies, prompting Asian nations to intervene in foreign exchange markets to slow down volatility and weaken their currencies. The pace of intervention may not be over, with Japan's yen at its lowest level in over 30 years.

site_title: IMF urges most Asian central banks to tighten policy further
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged most Asian central banks to tighten monetary policy further due to rising commodity prices, currency depreciations, and inflation above targets. Large currency depreciations, particularly in countries with high debt, could trigger financial stress. Exceptions include China and Japan, where economic recovery has been weaker and inflation has not risen as sharply. The IMF warns that faster monetary policy tightening is required to mitigate the risks of higher inflation and debt distress, particularly if global interest rates rise more forcefully.

site_title: 339 people investigated in 1,002 scam cases involving over $14.9m
summary: The Singapore police have launched an investigation into 339 people suspected of involvement in over 1,002 scam cases, resulting in losses of over $14.9 million. The suspects, aged 15-73, are being investigated for cheating, money laundering, or providing payment services without a license. Scams include job scams, loan scams, and government impersonation scams. The police have reported a significant increase in scam cases, with 14,349 reported this year, and a total loss of $346.5 million in the first half of the year.

site_title: NBA: Argentine great Manu Ginobili's San Antonio Spurs jersey sent into space
summary: The San Antonio Spurs jersey of Argentine basketball legend Manu Ginobili was sent into space with a zero-pressure balloon, reaching over 30km in height for about four hours. The gesture, organized by the NBA's Latin America division, recognizes Ginobili's induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame. A pioneer in international basketball, Ginobili won four NBA titles, an Olympic gold medal, and was a key figure in Argentina's historic 2004 Olympic victory over Team USA. The tribute marks a unique celebration of his remarkable career and legacy.

site_title: Singapore avoids technical recession, economy beats forecast to grow 4.4% in Q3
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4.4% year-on-year in the third quarter of 2022, avoiding a technical recession, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, the economy expanded 1.5%, a turnaround from the 0.2% contraction in the second quarter. Despite this, economists warn of "bumpy" road ahead due to high global inflation, tighter monetary policies, and geopolitical uncertainties, predicting below-trend growth in 2023. The services sector drove growth, while manufacturing slowed.

site_title: Felicia Teo's death: Man who dumped her corpse jailed for 26 months but expected to be released soon
summary: A Singaporean man, Ahmad Danial Mohamed Rafa'ee, 37, was sentenced to 26 months in jail for his role in dumping the body of his friend, 19-year-old Felicia Teo, who died after consuming Ecstasy in 2007. The duo had dismembered and burned her body, but a partial skull was later found at Punggol Track 24, identified as Teo's through DNA testing. Ahmad's accomplice, Indonesian Ragil Putra Setia Sukmarahjana, remains at large. The sentence was backdated to 2020, when Ahmad was arrested, and he is expected to be released soon due to serving less than two-thirds of his sentence.

site_title: Football: CAS to hear Chile's appeal over Ecuador World Cup player - source
summary: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) will hear Chile's appeal against FIFA's decision allowing Ecuador's Byron Castillo to play in the World Cup on November 4-5. Castillo, born in Colombia, played in eight qualifying games for Ecuador, including twice against Chile. Chile alleged he was ineligible, but Ecuador denied it. If CAS rules in favor of Chile, Ecuador could forfeit games and Chile could potentially leapfrog Colombia and Peru into the fourth automatic spot, affecting World Cup qualification. A decision is expected by November 10, just days before the tournament begins on November 20.

site_title: Tennis: Iga Swiatek downs China's Zheng Qinwen to reach San Diego quarter-finals
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek defeated China's Zheng Qinwen 6-4, 4-6, 6-1 to reach the quarter-finals of the San Diego Open. This marks Swiatek's 12th quarter-final of the year, as she closes in on an eighth title this season. Swiatek adjusted to Zheng's topspin forehand and took control in the third set, winning the final six games to secure the win.

site_title: Lower COE supply expected in next three months, quota may increase only from 2024
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply is expected to decrease by 11.4% from November to January, with only a possible quota increase from 2024. The decrease is attributed to lower vehicle deregistrations from April to August, resulting in fewer COEs available for tender each month. This could lead to higher vehicle prices in the coming months.

site_title: Football: Fifa open to compensation fund for World Cup workers
summary: Fifa is exploring setting up a compensation fund for migrant workers injured while working on World Cup projects in Qatar, following suggestions from human rights organizations. The idea, which was initially called for by Amnesty, aims to redress injuries suffered by workers in the country, where there have been accusations of under-reporting deaths and unpaid wages. Fifa deputy general secretary Alasdair Bell stated that the organization is interested in progressing the initiative, but acknowledged it requires structure, rules, and governance. The move comes as Qatar prepares to host the World Cup on November 20.

site_title: MAS sees inflation easing in second half of 2023; effect of GST hike 'transitory'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has revised its inflation projections for 2023, predicting a slowdown in the second half of the year. Core inflation is expected to range from 3.5% to 4.5%, while headline inflation is forecast at 5.5% to 6.5%. The MAS attributes the easing inflation to a "transitory" effect of the upcoming goods and services tax (GST) hike, which will be introduced in two stages. Despite this, upside risks remain due to global commodity price shocks and second-round effects.

site_title: Lower COE supply expected in next three months
summary: The supply of certificates of entitlement (COEs) is expected to decrease by 11.4% in the next three months (Nov-Jan) compared to the current quota, resulting in higher vehicle prices. This decrease is attributed to lower vehicle deregistrations from April to August. Industry observers predict that the COE quota will only increase significantly from 2024.

site_title: Vistara, Air India merger would enable SIA to retain critical foothold in market
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) confirmed talks with Tata Group over a potential merger of its 49% owned Indian entity Vistara with Air India. The two airlines were set up in 2013, with Vistara beginning operations in 2015. A merger would enable SIA to retain a critical foothold in the Indian market, where Tata's influence is significant. Details of the proposed merger remain unclear, but the move would likely impact the aviation industry in India and Asia.

site_title: Elon Musk under US investigation over Twitter deal: Court filing
summary: Billionaire Elon Musk is under a US federal investigation related to his $44 billion takeover deal for Twitter. The investigation's focus and authorities are unclear. Twitter claims Musk's attorneys are withholding documents, citing "investigative privilege." The SEC has questioned Musk's comments about the deal, including his disclosure of a 9% stake. The FTC is also scrutinizing Musk's compliance with antitrust reporting requirements. A court filing has been made, asking for the documents to be handed over, and a trial date is set for November if the deal is not closed by October 28.

site_title: Football: Neymar faces five-year jail-term request in corruption and fraud trial
summary: Brazilian soccer star Neymar is set to stand trial in Barcelona on Monday on charges of corruption and fraud related to his 2013 transfer from Santos to Barcelona. The trial, which could last two weeks, involves Neymar, his parents, former Barcelona presidents Josep Maria Bartomeu and Sandro Rosell, and ex-Santos president Odilio Rodrigues. The case stems from a complaint by DIS, which owned 40% of Neymar's rights at the time of the transfer, claiming the deal was undervalued. Neymar denies the allegations and his lawyers argue that competition rules do not apply to the transfer market.

site_title: Futuristic tunnels and dealing with trolls: What politicians are up to this week
summary: Singaporean politicians are focusing on various issues this week. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing revealed his location in a social media post, sparking a Star Wars-themed guessing game among followers. Chan was visiting the worksite of the Cantonment MRT station, part of the Circle Line 6 extension. Meanwhile, MPs shared their interactions with constituents, including MP Louis Chua, who addressed lift breakdowns in a Sengkang estate and Minister of State Sun Xueling, who clarified that she does not receive free meals or preferential treatment at coffee shops.

site_title: MAS tightens Singdollar policy again but not as aggressively as expected
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has tightened monetary policy again to combat inflation, but not as aggressively as expected. The central bank re-centred the midpoint of the trade-weighted Singdollar policy band, which led to the Singdollar appreciating 0.6% to $1.4220. MAS forecasts core inflation to average around 4% and headline inflation around 6% in 2022, with no change to the slope and width of the policy band. This move aims to reduce imported inflation and curb domestic cost pressures, providing a basis for sustainable economic growth.

site_title: Fewer ships call at S'pore port to refuel, bunker sales down 4% in September
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales dropped 4% in September, with 3.97 million tonnes sold, the first decline since June. Fewer vessels called to refuel, with 3,155 ships opting for bunkering in the city-state, down 2% from August. Lower prices in China, where refiners produce cleaner shipping fuel, are attracting shipowners to refuel there, with prices being at least US$10 per tonne lower than in Singapore. This trend is expected to continue as the year ends, with China's low-sulphur marine fuel prices becoming increasingly competitive.

site_title: Chip giant TSMC cuts capital spending 10% in warning for tech sector
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) has cut its 2022 capital spending target by 10% to approximately US$36 billion, citing a broader-than-anticipated downturn in the tech sector. The move is attributed to US restrictions on doing business with China, which are sending shockwaves through the global semiconductor industry. Despite this, TSMC expects to maintain its revenue growth projections, with a projected 43% year-over-year sales growth, and is betting on its massive size and industry-leading technology to navigate the challenges.

site_title: Bail denied for American who made false bomb threat on SIA flight
summary: A 37-year-old American man, La Andy Hien Duc, was denied bail after making a false bomb threat on a Singapore Airlines flight from San Francisco to Singapore. He allegedly claimed there was a bomb on board, grabbed a passenger's luggage, and assaulted a cabin crew member. Duc has schizophrenia and a history of substance abuse, and the prosecution argued that releasing him on bail would pose a danger to the public and himself. Duc will remain at the Institute of Mental Health for psychiatric observation until his court appearance on October 27.

site_title: Two in three SIT students secure jobs ahead of graduation
summary: About two-thirds of Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) graduates secured full-time jobs ahead of graduation, with over 90% in certain fields such as pharmaceutical engineering, infocomm technology, and allied health. The Class of 2022 is SIT's largest cohort, with over 2,200 graduates. The university has introduced a new pathway, Term-In/Term-Out, allowing students to gain work experience in their first year.

site_title: Tree that fell and killed woman in park was infested with termites
summary: A tree in Marsiling Park that fell and killed a woman in 2021 was infested with termites, according to the National Parks Board. Despite no visible signs of poor health, the termites had entered the 20m-tall Araucaria excelsa tree from beneath the ground.
