Regular visual assessments were conducted, but a more advanced assessment was not deemed necessary due to cost constraints. The inquiry, led by State Coroner Adam Nakhoda, will continue to investigate the incident, which is considered a rare case of a tree failure attributed to termite infestation.

site_title: 3,000 BTO flats to be built in Dover Forest in Ulu Pandan
summary: Around 3,000 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats will be built in Ulu Pandan, Singapore, with the first project launching in November. The project features staggered housing blocks with varying heights to maximize views of the Ulu Pandan Canal and Holland Grove landed estate. The development will incorporate nature and greenery, including a 1.2ha park and four trails for residents to lead an active lifestyle. The project is part of a larger car-lite precinct, with reduced carparks to prioritize public facilities and greenery.

site_title: Shell buys 45% stake in S'pore fuel card partner, Best Petrol & Diesel Supply
summary: Shell has acquired a 45% stake in Best Petrol & Diesel Supply, a Singapore-based fuel fleet card operator, for $21.3 million. This marks Shell's first overseas venture into the fuel card business, aiming to expand its operations globally. The investment represents a significant move by the oil giant to diversify its business interests.

site_title: Teen accused of father's murder remanded for another week
summary: A 19-year-old teen, Sylesnar Seah Jie Kai, accused of murdering his 47-year-old father Eddie Seah Wee Teck, will be remanded for another week. The teen appeared in court via video link, where the prosecution applied for further remand citing ongoing police investigations. The judge agreed, ordering the Law Society's pamphlet of rights to be provided to the accused. Seah Jie Kai, the youngest child of the couple, has been scheduled to appear in court again on October 20. The case involves a family with two sons and a daughter, who live in a unit on the fifth floor where the murder occurred.

site_title: FairPrice schemes to help consumers deal with rising prices
summary: FairPrice has launched the "Greater Value Every Day" initiative to help consumers cope with rising prices. The supermarket chain will offer weekly discounts on popular items, freeze prices of 50 essential items each month, and provide discounts for certain groups, such as NTUC union and Link members. The initiative aims to moderate costs and empower customers to save more on groceries and daily necessities. The first price freeze will be announced on the last Thursday of each month, with discounts available through various channels, including print, online, and social media advertisements.

site_title: Vogue S'pore gets stern warning; permit shortened
summary: Vogue Singapore's one-year permit has been revoked and shortened to six months after breaching content guidelines on four occasions, including nudity and promoting non-traditional families, within the past two years. The Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) issued a stern warning and stated that the magazine must comply with guidelines not undermining prevailing social norms. This decision follows similar actions taken against magazines Art Republik, Cleo, and FHM Singapore, which also had their permits shortened due to repeated breaches of content guidelines. Vogue Singapore has reapplied for a permit.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore to build 3,000 Build-To-Order flats in Dover Forest. Vehicle prices are expected to remain high due to a lower COE supply from November to January. US tech curbs on China are likely to impact Singapore's semiconductor industry, which supplies 11% of the world's semiconductors. Asean is facing an existential crisis due to internal splits, and a new model may follow an "Asean 5+X" formula. Singapore Premier League's top strikers, Boris Kopitovic and Kodai Tanaka, will battle for the top scorer award in a match on Saturday.

site_title: Move would enable SIA to retain critical foothold in India
summary: Singapore Airlines has confirmed talks with Tata Group about merging Vistara, its 49%-owned Indian entity, with Air India. Vistara, owned 51% by Tata, would be combined with Air India, giving SIA a critical foothold in India. This potential merger would mark a significant development in the Indian aviation industry, potentially leading to increased competition and changes in market dynamics. Details of the merger remain unclear, but the move is seen as a strategic step by SIA to expand its presence in the Indian market. A formal agreement is expected to be announced soon.

site_title: Reservoir of trust among S'poreans a key asset: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore must prepare for global tensions, Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen said, highlighting the country's reservoir of trust among Singaporeans as a key asset. This stands in contrast to growing distrust between Europe and Russia. Ng praised Singaporeans' support for national service, with 96% of respondents in 2021 deeming it critical for the country's defence and security. He warned of increased militarisation in Europe and Asia due to worsening US-China relations, which could lead to heightened security risks and physical confrontation. Ng also emphasized the importance of solidarity among Singaporeans in defending their home.

site_title: Prestigious Singapore military award for chief of staff of Indonesian Air Force
summary: Air Chief Marshal Fadjar Prasetyo, Chief of Staff of the Indonesian Air Force, received the prestigious Pingat Jasa Gemilang (Meritorious Service Medal) from Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen. The award recognized his significant contributions to strengthening defence ties between the Indonesian and Singapore air forces, including a joint 40-year celebration in 2021. The award reaffirmed the mutual commitment to cooperation and deepened people-to-people ties. ACM Fadjar expressed hope for continued friendship and cooperation between the two air forces.

site_title: Long wait over as bigger centre opens for students with dyslexia
summary: A new, larger learning centre for students with dyslexia has opened in Yishun, Singapore, offering reduced waiting times for enrolment. The centre, run by the Dyslexia Association of Singapore, has twice the capacity of its predecessor, serving about 300 students. The facility provides a conducive learning environment with wireless projectors and dimmable lights. The centre's opening is expected to benefit families in the Yishun area, with 17% more enrolments since classes began in March, and will also provide more support to needy students through the DAS Bursary Fund.

site_title: Keppel's solar-powered building generates double the energy it uses
summary: Keppel Infrastructure @ Changi, a revamped building in Singapore, has launched with 4,000 sq m of solar panels, producing over double the energy it consumes annually. This marks a milestone in the country's push towards a low-carbon built environment, with the building's energy harvesting equivalent to 600,000 kilowatt hours of renewable energy per year. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions and support Singapore's net-zero target by 2050, with the building's features avoiding 7,000 new trees' worth of carbon emissions.

site_title: Man in bribery case gets longer jail term after he appeals
summary: A Singapore court has increased the jail term of a man, Goh Ngak Eng, who conspired with others to obtain bribes from a shipbuilding company, Keppel Fels. The original sentence of one year, five months, and three weeks was more than doubled to three years, one month, and three weeks. The court found that Keppel Fels suffered an economic detriment of 45% due to the bribes, and the increased sentence reflects the severity of the offenses. Goh pleaded guilty to 15 charges in 2021, with the total amount of bribes paid being $879,853.63.

site_title: Fresh broiler chicken from Malaysia back on shelves here
summary: Malaysian fresh broiler chicken has returned to Singapore's supermarkets after a 4.5-month ban due to domestic shortages. The limited supply was evident, with only 10 people browsing the fresh-chicken shelves within an hour of restocking at FairPrice outlets. Prices are higher than before, with whole birds costing $14.80 each, and sales were slow. Wet markets are expected to have stock from Friday. The return of fresh chicken is expected to meet about half of Singapore's pre-ban chicken imports from Malaysia, with 1.8 million birds per month anticipated.

site_title: US scrambles to prevent export curbs on China chips from disrupting supply chain
summary: The US is scrambling to mitigate the impact of new export curbs on China's chip industry, which could disrupt the global semiconductor supply chain. SK Hynix, Samsung Electronics, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company received temporary exemptions or authorizations to continue receiving goods for chip production facilities in China. The US had initially planned to spare foreign companies from the new restrictions, but the rules did not exempt them. The China Semiconductor Industry Association warned that the US export controls could put more stress on supply chains and called for the US government to adjust its course of action.

site_title: SIA in talks over potential Vistara, Air India merger
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is in talks with Tata Group over a potential merger of Vistara airline and Air India, following media reports that Tata is considering the move. SIA holds a 49% stake in Vistara, while Tata has a 51% stake. The talks aim to deepen the existing partnership and may include integrating Vistara and Air India, with no definitive terms agreed upon. Any deal would require approval from Singapore's competition watchdog and Indian authorities, and it's unclear what stake SIA would hold in the merged entity.

site_title: OCBC scouting for acquisitions in Indonesia to speed up growth: CEO
summary: OCBC Bank is seeking acquisitions in Indonesia to accelerate growth, leveraging its strong capital buffer of $2.84 billion. The bank's CEO, Helen Wong, believes its financial strength makes it an attractive suitor for Indonesian banks. Indonesia, the world's fourth-most populous country, remains underserved by a fragmented banking network, and the government is pushing for consolidation. OCBC has a 85% stake in an Indonesian bank and is eyeing opportunities to expand its presence in the country. The bank's rivals, UOB and DBS, have also made acquisitions in the region this year.

site_title: Company Briefs: Toshiba
summary: Toshiba shares surged 7.4% after a domestic-led consortium, led by Japan Industrial Partners, made a 2.8 trillion yen ($27.3 billion) bid for the Japanese conglomerate. The group, which includes Chubu Electric Power, received the right of first refusal. Meanwhile, UBS' Asia-Pacific investment bank head David Chin resigned after five years, and will be replaced by Taichi Takahashi on November 1. Additionally, ByteDance is in talks with music labels to expand its music-streaming service globally, potentially integrating music streaming within its short-video service.

site_title: S'pore firms keen on opportunities in emerging areas: Tan See Leng
summary: Singaporean businesses, including small and medium-sized enterprises, are keen to explore opportunities in emerging areas such as the digital economy and green economy. Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng emphasized the need for businesses to develop pilot projects and test use-cases to demonstrate the value of emerging technologies. Singapore and Britain have started discussions on a green economy framework to tackle climate change. The 23rd Annual Business Awards recognized companies in sustainability, technology, and customer service, with notable winners including Muuse and Rolls-Royce Singapore.

site_title: Freehold Meyer Park relaunches collective sale tender at $420m
summary: Freehold seafront condo Meyer Park in Marine Parade has relaunched its collective sale tender at a reserve price of $420 million. The site, located near the upcoming Katong Park MRT station, can be redeveloped into a mid-sized luxury high-rise condominium with up to 251 residences. The sale tender will close on Nov 2, with the successful bidder having until June 1, 2023, to submit a development application. This follows a previous attempt that closed without a buyer in September. The site's proximity to amenities and growing demand for residential investments support the tender's relaunch.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losing streak to close at 19-month low
summary: Singapore stocks closed at a 19-month low, falling 1.4% to 3,040.45 on the Straits Times Index. The decline was attributed to impending US inflation data and fears of a global recession. Local tech manufacturers were among the biggest losers, with AEM and UMS plummeting 11.4% and 6.8%, respectively. Only two STI stocks, Emperador and Wilmar, ended in the black. The decline mirrored losses across key regional indices, including Japan, Shanghai, and Hong Kong.

site_title: S'pore will feel the pain as US tech curbs on China squeeze chip industry
summary: The US has imposed new export controls on technology firms doing business with China, threatening the global semiconductor industry. Weaker global demand for electronics will further exacerbate the issue. Singapore, a significant supplier of semiconductors and chip-making gear, is expected to feel the impact, with its industry already struggling. The curbs are likely to darken the outlook for the industry, which already faces challenges due to reduced demand.

site_title: No time for regrets as clasico beckons
summary: Barcelona coach Xavi Hernandez expressed disappointment over the team's 3-3 draw with Inter Milan, citing defensive errors as the primary cause. The result leaves Barca third in Group C with four points, while Inter is second with seven points. With the head-to-head record separating teams level on points, Barca risks elimination if Inter beats Viktoria Plzen on October 26. Xavi emphasized the need to focus on the upcoming El Clasico against Real Madrid, stating that the team must improve their defensive mistakes and continue believing in their abilities.

site_title: Opec+ oil supply cuts could tip world into recession, says IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that Opec+ oil supply cuts could push the global economy into recession due to high oil prices. The agency slashed its global oil demand growth forecast by 20% and attributed the decline to the supply cuts, which have driven up prices above $90 a barrel. The IEA also predicts that global oil consumption will increase by 1.7 million barrels a day in 2023, down from a previous forecast. The agency's report comes as the global economy faces unrelenting inflationary pressures and interest rate hikes.

site_title: US inflation rises to 40-year high, ushering in another big Fed hike
summary: US inflation rose to a 40-year high in September, with the core consumer price index (CPI) increasing 6.6% from a year ago and the overall CPI rising 8.2%. Food, shelter, and medical care were the largest contributors to the increase. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates further, with traders pricing in a higher peak rate for next year. The report also highlights the ongoing impact of geopolitical events, such as the Russia-Ukraine war, on commodity prices.

site_title: Tougher consumer safeguards weigh on S'pore crypto firms
summary: Singapore's cryptocurrency firms face challenges as tougher consumer safeguards are implemented. Local exchanges that cater to retail users may lose customers to overseas-based operations due to stricter regulations. Industry players express concerns about hindering business and innovation, while high licensing costs are also a worry. The stricter rules aim to protect consumers, but may impact the local industry's competitiveness.

site_title: UK pension funds selling stokes fear across bond markets
summary: British pension funds are selling assets to meet margin calls, contributing to a decline in US investment-grade corporate bonds and European leveraged loans. The selling pressure is linked to the Bank of England's planned end of its emergency bond-buying programme on Friday, sparking concerns about market stability. Yields on British government securities and sterling-denominated corporate bonds have surged, with the latter reaching over 7% for the first time since 2009. The market fears a return of the "LDI crisis" and is awaiting the central bank's response to the programme's end.

site_title: Rocky brings the smiles back
summary: Leading trainer Donna Logan is optimistic after Rocky's barrier trial win, which boosted her team's morale after a week of ups and downs. Logan has two new horses, a Charm Spirit colt and a Santos gelding, and has secured a solitary win with Luxury Brand. However, her top apprentice jockey Yusoff Fadzli was not riding due to injury and illness, forcing Logan to reshuffle rides. Despite the setback, Logan remains focused on upcoming races, including the Singapore Gold Cup, and is confident in her team's abilities.

site_title: Spurs top group with Son's brace, eye last-16 spot
summary: Tottenham Hotspur topped Group D in the Champions League with a 3-2 win over Eintracht Frankfurt, thanks to Son Heung-min's brace. Despite falling behind early, Son equalized and then scored a blistering volley to put Spurs in control. Harry Kane converted a penalty for his first Champions League goal this season, and Tottenham held on despite Frankfurt's late efforts. With two matches remaining, Spurs are top of the group with seven points, one clear of Marseille and Sporting Lisbon. The win avoids a "disaster" for Spurs, according to coach Antonio Conte.

site_title: Steele leads after solid round
summary: Brendan Steele leads the Zozo Championship after a 6-under 64, four strokes ahead of Adam Schenk. Steele's strong round, which included four consecutive birdies on the back nine, gave him the top spot. Hideki Matsuyama struggled to a 71, despite having a strong field and thousands of fans cheering him on. The tournament, which is the only PGA Tour event in Japan, features a strong US presence, including Steele, Schenk, and Xander Schauffele.

site_title: Local governments in China buying houses to boost property sector
summary: Chinese local governments are purchasing homes in bulk from developers to boost the struggling real estate market. Cities such as Suzhou, Jinan, and Huzhou are buying thousands of units, while a prefecture in Xinjiang is encouraging state-owned enterprises to buy homes and convert them into subsidized housing. The central government's latest property policy package has failed to stimulate demand, with residential transactions plummeting 38% in major cities. The purchases are part of efforts to prop up the real estate sector, which has been weakened by high mortgage rates and the Covid-19-zero policy.

site_title: 'Gloomy future' for Hanoi grand prix
summary: Hanoi's Formula One grand prix circuit lies largely abandoned after the 2020 cancellation due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The city was set to debut in 2020 but hopes for a future event are fading. The spectator stands have been removed, and the track remains largely empty, with only a few cyclists using the space. Vietnam's largest private conglomerate, VinGroup, paid US$60 million annually to host the event, but the race was dropped from the 2021 calendar after city mayor Nguyen Duc Chung's arrest. The future of the race in Hanoi appears gloomy, with city authorities ruling out hosting the event between 2022 and 2029.

site_title: 600th win for Tsui, first for Richards
summary: Veteran jockey Me Tsui achieved his 600th win at Happy Valley, while trainer Jamie Richards secured his first victory with horse Handsome Rebel. Tsui rode Star Of Wuyi to the win in the Class 5 Pottinger Handicap over 1,000m, while Richards' first win came in the same race with Handsome Rebel. The two trainers, who have worked together since 2021, celebrated significant milestones in their careers.

site_title: Inoue and Butler to fight for 'history'
summary: Japanese boxer Naoya Inoue, nicknamed "Monster", announced a fight against Britain's Paul Butler on December 13 in Tokyo to capture the WBO title and become undisputed world champion. Inoue, 29, holds three belts and aims to unify the four organizations, while Butler, 33, is determined to write his name into boxing history. A victory would make Inoue the first Asian undisputed world champion and only the ninth since the four-belt era began in 2004.

site_title: Brugge second Belgian side to qualify
summary: Club Brugge became the second Belgian team to qualify for the Champions League's last 16 with a 0-0 draw against Atletico Madrid, securing 10 points in Group B. The Belgian side, led by goalkeeper Simon Mignolet, kept Diego Simeone's side at bay despite finishing the game with 10 men after a red card. Brugge's qualification marks their first since 1990-91 and only the second for a Belgian team, following Gent's run in 2015-16.

site_title: Salah sizzles with 7-min treble
summary: Mohamed Salah scored a record-breaking 7-minute hat-trick in Liverpool's 7-1 win over Rangers, helping his team rediscover their spark ahead of a crucial clash with Manchester City. The Egyptian's swift treble beat the previous record held by Bafetimbi Gomis in 2011. Liverpool, who have struggled in the Premier League, hope the boost in form will carry over to Sunday's match against City, who are on an unbeaten start to the season.

site_title: Nebraas to lead a Tarry 1-2 in Race 5
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

The article provides form analysis for Saturday's South Africa (Turffontein) horse racing events. Notable predictions include Nebraas leading a Tarry 1-2 in Race 5, Solo Diva looking to beat the field in Race 2, and Terra Time aiming for a hat-trick in Race 4. Other notable contenders include Strike A Match and MoonshiningThrough in Race 3, Vanderbilt seeking his sixth win on the trot in Race 8, and Vivacious Spirit trying to make amends in Race 9. The article provides insights into the strengths and weaknesses of each horse, helping readers make informed betting decisions.

site_title: Duel for golden boot
summary: Top scorers in the Singapore Premier League, Boris Kopitovic of Tampines Rovers and Kodai Tanaka of Albirex Niigata, are set to face off in a crucial match as they vie for the league's top scorer award. Both players have 31 goals, and a draw would result in a shared prize. The match between Tampines and Albirex on Saturday could determine the winner, with Kopitovic's evolution into a team player and Tanaka's exceptional positional sense making them unpredictable opponents.

site_title: Relentless all set for QEII Cup
summary: Relentless, trained by Tim Fitzsimmons, is poised to win the $300,000 Group 1 Queen Elizabeth II Cup over 1,800m. The Australian-bred, who finished fifth in his first-up run over 1,600m, showed improvement after a well-deserved rest. Relentless has strong form in Group company, beating Lim's Kosciuszko in the Group 2 Stewards' Cup and finishing close to Senor Don in his previous start. Fitzsimmons is concerned about the wide draw but is optimistic about Relentless' chances, citing the need for luck and cover to win the race.

site_title: Quality of life, not records for Verstappen
summary: Max Verstappen, 2022 F1 champion, considers retirement after his contract with Red Bull ends in 2028 due to a desire for 'quality of life' and to pursue other interests. Verstappen, 25, has already signed a new deal worth £40 million annually until 2028, but plans to retire at 40, citing the grueling nature of F1. He will focus on helping Red Bull secure the constructors' championship in the remaining four races, with the US Grand Prix next on October 23.

site_title: Indian Olympic medallist to face murder trial
summary: Two-time Indian Olympic medallist Sushil Kumar will stand trial for allegedly murdering junior grappler Sagar Dhankar in a stadium brawl last year. Kumar, 39, was charged with murder, kidnapping, rioting, and using deadly weapons. Prosecutors claim he was a "kingpin" in the case, while Kumar maintains his innocence. The trial begins after a week-long manhunt following the deadly brawl fueled by personal and professional rivalry. Kumar, a former Olympic champion, is being held in a separate cell at Delhi's Tihar prison for security reasons.

site_title: Saudi focuses on growing and promoting golf at home
summary: Saudi Arabia is investing heavily in golf, aiming to transform the Gulf state into a golf powerhouse. The country's golf federation is promoting the sport through programs like "Ladies First" and "Let It Fly," offering free lessons and course access to female golfers and Saudi youth. At least 10 new courses are planned, bringing the total to 24. Professional golfers are focused on growing the sport at home, with many Saudis now playing regularly, rather than being drawn to LIV Golf, a Saudi-funded breakaway circuit.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary: The article provides a schedule for upcoming sports events, including the Track World Championships, English Premier League and Singapore Premier League matches, MotoGP Australian Grand Prix, DP World Tour Andalucia Masters, ATP Tour Gijon Open, WTA Tour San Diego Open, and WTA Tour Transylvania Open. The events will take place over the next 24 hours, with various start times listed for each match. Viewers can access the schedule and updates on the Singtel and StarHub websites or check the on-screen TV guide.

site_title: Football: Haaland and Nunez were tipped to be rivals, but so far it has been no contest
summary: Manchester City striker Erling Haaland has silenced doubters with his impressive performance, scoring 15 goals in 9 Premier League games, the most in the competition's history for a player's first 10 appearances. In contrast, Liverpool's Darwin Nunez has struggled to match Haaland's output, scoring 3 goals in 5 starts, despite showing signs of improvement. Haaland's incredible form has raised the bar for Nunez, who is looking to prove himself against his former rival in Sunday's match between the two teams.

site_title: Reservoir of trust among Singaporeans a key defence asset: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasized the importance of trust among Singaporeans as a key defence asset, contrasting it with the loss of trust between Europe and Russia. As global tensions rise, Singapore must prepare its defences, with 96% of Singaporeans supporting National Service. Ng highlighted the challenges of emerging uncertainties, including heightened security risks, US-China relations at an all-time low, and potential militarization in Europe and Asia. He urged solidarity among Singaporeans to ensure the country's survival in the face of conflict, drawing lessons from the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Sports World: Alvarez to have wrist surgery, out till Sept
summary:
Sports World: 

Saul "Canelo" Alvarez will undergo wrist surgery in the US, potentially keeping him out of the ring until September. Alvarez's surgery follows a recent victory over Gennadiy Golovkin. After recovery, he may seek a rematch with Dmitry Bivol. 

Brady and Clijsters invest in Major League Pickleball, joining investors LeBron James and Draymond Green. The MLP expansion will feature 16 teams, increased events, and prize money exceeding $2 million. 

A football from Diego Maradona's infamous 'Hand of God' match is expected to sell for at least £2.5 million at auction.

site_title: La Liga's Tebas takes feud with PSG boss to court
summary: La Liga president Javier Tebas has taken his long-standing feud with Paris Saint-Germain president Nasser al-Khelaifi to court, securing a court order to freeze tens of millions of dollars of beIN Media Group assets over unpaid broadcast-rights payments. The outstanding debt of €50 million represents a fraction of the total amount contracted to be paid, with industry estimates suggesting up to US$1.5 billion. The dispute highlights Qatar's influence in football and the influence of al-Khelaifi, who holds multiple roles in European football.

site_title: S'pore companies keen to grab opportunities in emerging areas: Tan See Leng
summary: Singaporean companies are keen to explore emerging areas such as the digital economy and green economy, according to Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng. He encouraged businesses to develop and implement use-cases and pilot projects to demonstrate the value of these technologies. Notable examples include Singapore-based start-up Muuse, which has reduced single-use items in landfills, and British companies with significant investments in Singapore, such as Rolls-Royce and GSK. Tan emphasized the importance of remaining open and building a talent pipeline to achieve innovation, but warned that the Covid-19 pandemic has affected talent mobility.

site_title: Defying cultural norms: Meet Singapore’s first female chef-owner of a Japanese restaurant
summary: Singapore's 28-year-old Aeron Choo has made history as the first female chef-owner of a Japanese restaurant, Kappou. Choo, who overcame rejection and sexism in the male-dominated culinary scene, credits her stubbornness for achieving her dream. After completing her training in Japan and learning the language, she returned to Singapore in 2014 and started her first venture, a donburi stall. Today, Kappou has evolved into a stylish omakase restaurant, with Choo's inspiring story featured in Porsche's global "Dreamers. On." campaign, which aims to encourage the next generation of dreamers to pursue their passions.

site_title: Golf: LIV series is 'trending upwards', says Mickelson
summary: Phil Mickelson says the LIV Golf Series is "trending upwards" while the PGA Tour will be "trending downwards". The six-time major winner, who joined the Saudi-backed breakaway series, believes he's on the winning side of golf's evolution. Mickelson criticized the PGA Tour for using antitrust laws against LIV Golf, stating that both sides need to have a conversation to work out their differences. He praised LIV Golf for its inclusive and fluid approach, saying it's "leading the way" in golf.

site_title: MCI shortens permit for Vogue Singapore, issues warning for breaching content guidelines
summary: Vogue Singapore's permit has been shortened from one year to six months after breaching content guidelines four times over two years, including issues with nudity and non-traditional families. The Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) issued a stern warning after the magazine failed to comply with guidelines that include not undermining prevailing social norms. This marks the latest action taken by MCI against a magazine, following similar cases in 2008 and 1998, and a 2014 case against Art Republik for religiously insensitive content. Vogue Singapore has reapplied for a new permit.

site_title: WWF-Singapore's citizen sleuths take down over 14,000 illegal wildlife listings
summary: WWF-Singapore's citizen sleuths have removed over 14,000 illegal wildlife listings from e-commerce platforms since 2020, with plans to train another 300 people to potentially take down 20,000 listings. The initiative aims to combat the illegal wildlife trade, which sees more than 7,000 species of plants and animals being illegally traded worldwide. The organization's conservation efforts are part of its broader focus on sustainability, with a study revealing Singaporeans prioritize circular economy, food security, and renewable energy.

site_title: New veterinary hospital officially opens in Whitley Road to cater to complex conditions
summary: The Veterinary Emergency and Specialty (VES) Hospital Singapore has officially opened its second facility in Whitley Road, providing 24-hour treatment for complex conditions, emergency and critical care, surgery, and imaging services. The hospital has upgraded its MRI machines for higher resolution and now has 23 vets, including specialists, with plans to grow the number by 30% in 2023. VES aims to transform the veterinary industry in Singapore by supporting professionals and students, and will host the largest number of specialists in Singapore, including 12 board-certified specialists.

site_title: Football: United, Arsenal scrape Europa wins as Sociedad claim top-two spot
summary: Manchester United and Arsenal secured crucial Europa League wins, while Real Sociedad clinched a top-two spot in Group E. Manchester United's Scott McTominay scored a last-minute winner against Omonia Nicosia, while Arsenal's Bukayo Saka netted the only goal against Bodo/Glimt. Real Sociedad's 3-0 victory over Sheriff secured a top-two finish, guaranteeing a knockout round playoff spot.

site_title: Tougher consumer safeguards weigh on S'pore crypto firms
summary: Singapore's cryptocurrency firms face tougher consumer safeguards, raising concerns about hindering businesses and curtailing innovation. Industry players worry about the costs of obtaining a license and the potential impact on the market. Despite supporting greater protection, "serious concerns" have grown among market observers, highlighting the challenges of balancing consumer safety with business regulations.

site_title: US inflation rises to 40-year high, paving way for another big Fed hike
summary: US inflation has reached a 40-year high, increasing 6.6% from a year ago, according to the Labor Department's core consumer price index. This is the highest level since 1982, pressuring the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further to combat inflation. The Fed is expected to hike interest rates by 75 basis points at its November meeting, with some speculating for a fifth consecutive increase. The report highlights broad-based inflation, with shelter, food, and medical care indexes contributing to the increase, while used car prices dropped.

site_title: Cycling: Dutch sprint star Lavreysen clinches 10th world track title
summary: Netherlands' Harrie Lavreysen won his 10th world track cycling championship gold medal, claiming his third consecutive men's keirin title. Lavreysen beat compatriot Jeffrey Hoogland and Colombia's Kevin Quintero to secure the win. Belgian rider Lotte Kopecky took gold in the women's elimination race, while Jennifer Valente secured bronze. Britain won the men's team pursuit title, upsetting Italy and securing the bronze medal. The UCI Track Cycling World Championships continue with finals scheduled for Sunday.

site_title: Dow gains 2.8% as US stocks end roller-coaster day higher
summary: US stocks ended a roller-coaster day higher on Thursday, reversing early losses and rallying after disappointing inflation data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.8%, while the S&P 500 jumped 2.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 2.2%. The consumer price index (CPI) report showed inflation rose 0.4% in September, twice the expected level. Stocks initially tumbled after the report, but reversed course as they refused to drop below a key trading level, with some companies like Delta Air Lines and Netflix gaining ground.

site_title: Man staged road accident, roped in whole family to commit insurance fraud
summary: Tan Lek Keong, 28, was jailed for 8 months and 12 weeks and fined $4,400 for staging a road accident and committing insurance fraud with his family. He and two colleagues agreed to stage an accident using his car to lodge false insurance claims, with Tan's family members lying about injuries to receive medical leave and compensation. The scheme resulted in over $70,000 in false claims, but none were paid out. Tan was also disqualified from driving for 10 months.

site_title: Two-thirds of SIT's Class of 2022 secured full-time jobs ahead of graduation
summary: The Singapore Institute of Technology's Class of 2022 achieved a high employment rate, with two-thirds securing full-time jobs ahead of graduation. More than 9 in 10 graduates from certain fields like pharmaceutical engineering, infocomm technology, and allied health secured employment. The Class of 2022 is the largest cohort to date, with over 2,200 graduates. SIT has introduced a new pathway allowing students to gain work experience early, with some programs alternating between university and workplace every year.

site_title: Football: Indonesian FA, Fifa form taskforce to improve safety measures after fatal stampede
summary: The Indonesian Football Association (PSSI) and FIFA have formed a joint taskforce to improve crowd control and safety measures following a deadly stampede at a football match in October that killed over 130 people. The taskforce will include government officials, FIFA representatives, and experts in soccer and security. Indonesian police will synchronize their standard operating procedures with FIFA regulations to prevent similar incidents. FIFA President Gianni Infantino is expected to visit Jakarta to discuss Indonesia's readiness to host the FIFA Under-20 World Cup next year.

site_title: Fewer ships call at Singapore port to refuel, bunker sales down nearly 4% in Sept
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales declined in September, with 3.97 million tonnes sold, a 4% drop from August. Fewer vessels (3,155) called to bunker in Singapore, a 2% decrease from August. Lower prices in China, driven by record refiner production, are attracting shipowners to refuel there, with prices 10-15 US dollars per tonne lower than in Singapore. This trend is expected to continue, potentially pulling volume away from Singapore, especially for low-sulphur fuel.

site_title: High Court dismisses man's $800k negligence suit against TTSH over mum's death
summary: A High Court in Singapore has dismissed a $800,000 negligence lawsuit filed by a man against Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) over the death of his 74-year-old mother. The lawsuit alleged that doctors were negligent in not diagnosing his mother correctly, leading to her death in 2018. The court found the allegations "woefully short of evidence" and accepted the defendants' expert witnesses' testimony that another possible cause of her death was a blood clot in the lung, rather than a heart attack.

site_title: Fallen tree that killed woman at Marsiling Park had termite infestation but showed no signs of poor health
summary: A tree in Marsiling Park that killed a woman in February 2021 was found to have a termite infestation, but no visible signs of poor health. The National Parks Board (NParks) said the termites entered the tree from beneath the ground, and the tree's foliage showed no symptoms of decay or cavities. The tree, a 20m-tall Araucaria excelsa, was previously inspected every 24 months and was recorded as being in healthy condition. The inquiry will continue on Friday, with NParks officials explaining that such a rare situation is "extremely rare" and that there have been only three cases in the past 12 years where tree failure was attributed to termite infestations.

site_title: Golf: Matsuyama struggles to 71 in soggy defence of Zozo Championship
summary: Defending champion Hideki Matsuyama struggled to a one-over 71 in the first round of the Zozo Championship in Japan, seven shots behind leader Brendan Steele. Matsuyama started poorly, bogeying the second hole, and finished with only two birdies against three bogeys. Xander Schauffele carded a 67 to lie just three shots off the lead, while Steele shot a 64 to take the clubhouse lead. The tournament is set to improve with clear skies forecast for the rest of the week.

site_title: Pre-schoolers from struggling families get leg up with therapy, financial and social support
summary: Singapore's My First Skool programme provides therapy, financial, and social support to pre-schoolers from struggling families. The 3-year study, conducted with National Institute of Education, showed 58 children improved in language and cognitive skills, moving to a national average score. Since 2016, 30,000 children from low-income families participated. The programme offers small group lessons, social-emotional lessons, and financial assistance to parents, aiming to narrow the gap between disadvantaged children and their peers, with plans to support 7,000 children annually by 2025.

site_title: Vivian Balakrishnan meets WHO's director-general, discusses global health
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan met with WHO Director-General Tedros Ghebreyesus in Geneva on Oct 13, discussing global health issues. They agreed on strengthening pandemic surveillance, countering misinformation, and preparing for future pandemics. Balakrishnan commended the WHO's handling of Covid-19 and expressed support for the organization's role in global health. Tedros acknowledged Singapore's active Covid-19 surveillance, including rigorous testing and genomic sequencing. Both sides reaffirmed their commitment to vaccine multilateralism and global pandemic preparedness.

site_title: Football: SPL goal machines Kopitovic and Tanaka cross paths as race for Golden Boot nears end
summary: SPL goal machines Boris Kopitovic (Tampines Rovers) and Kodai Tanaka (Albirex Niigata) are set to clash in a crucial match as the league's top scorer award nears its end. Both players are tied with 31 goals each, with the winner sharing the prize. Their teams, Tampines and Albirex, meet on Saturday with no pressure to win the league title. The match is expected to be intense, with both teams looking to secure the Golden Boot award for their respective strikers.

site_title: SIA in talks over potential Vistara, Air India merger
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) confirmed it's in talks with Tata Group over a potential merger of Vistara and Air India, amid reports of Tata's plans to merge the two. SIA holds a 49% stake in Vistara, while Tata has a 51% stake. The discussions aim to deepen the partnership and integrate Vistara and Air India, but no definitive terms have been agreed upon. The deal would need approval from Singapore's competition watchdog and Indian authorities, and it's unclear what SIA's stake would be if Vistara merges into Air India.

site_title: No long wait as new bigger learning centre for students with dyslexia opens in Yishun
summary: A new, larger learning centre for students with dyslexia has opened in Yishun, Singapore. The centre, run by the Dyslexia Association of Singapore, has twice the capacity of the previous facility, serving around 300 students. The new centre provides a comfortable environment with modern amenities and is closer to the Yishun MRT station, reducing wait times for parents. The centre's opening comes after a 17% increase in enrolment since March, with 72% of students from the former Yishun centre benefiting from the DAS Bursary Fund.

site_title: Infineon partners with LG Group to mentor Singaporean, South Korean start-ups
summary: Infineon Technologies has partnered with LG Group to mentor Singaporean and South Korean start-ups in decarbonisation and digitalization. The collaboration includes five Singaporean start-ups and one from South Korea, Deep-In-Sight, participating in Infineon's Co-Innovation Space programme. The initiative aims to accelerate the development of innovative solutions and fast-track product commercialization. Infineon and LG Sciencepark will continue to identify and support promising start-ups in South Korea and Southeast Asia, with a focus on sustainability, smart-homes, and smart-mobility.

site_title: Fresh Malaysian chickens back on sale in S'pore after more than four months
summary: Fresh Malaysian broiler chickens have returned to Singapore's retailers after a four-and-a-half-month ban due to a domestic shortage in Malaysia. The chickens, typically exported at 40 days old, were sold at $14.80 each, with a limited supply evident at several outlets. Sales were slow, with only a few customers purchasing the fresh chicken, and some opting for frozen or kampung chicken instead due to the higher price. The return of fresh Malaysian chickens is expected to meet about half of Singapore's pre-ban chicken imports from Malaysia, with about 1.8 million chickens arriving each month.

site_title: Indian Olympic medallist Kumar to stand trial for murdering fellow wrestler
summary: Indian Olympic medallist Sushil Kumar will stand trial for allegedly murdering a fellow wrestler, Sagar Dhankar, during a stadium brawl in May 2021. Kumar, 39, was charged with murder, kidnapping, and other crimes after investigators produced enough evidence. He has denied the allegations, claiming police framed him. Kumar, a two-time Olympic medalist, faces up to life imprisonment if convicted. The trial is expected to proceed despite protests from his lawyer that the charges are trumped-up. Two of the accused remain on the run.

site_title: Man claiming to be sovereign citizen remanded at IMH after saying he was dead
summary: A 57-year-old man, Abdul Rashid Abdul Rahman, claimed to be a sovereign citizen and said he was dead, prompting a court to order his psychiatric evaluation for two weeks. He was remanded for flouting Covid-19 rules by not wearing a mask at two locations in 2021. Abdul's mental state was questioned after he appeared incoherent and refused to cooperate with authorities. His previous claims of being an ambassador and lawyer for a non-existent kingdom were also highlighted, raising concerns about his credibility.

site_title: Keppel launches solar-powered building which generates double the energy it uses
summary: Singapore's Keppel Infrastructure @ Changi, a solar-powered building, has been launched, producing over double the energy it consumes annually. The 4,000 sq m building generates 600,000 kilowatt hours of renewable energy per year, powering district cooling plants and reducing carbon emissions equivalent to 7,000 new trees. The move aligns with Singapore's goal to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 and its push towards a low-carbon built environment. The building's retrofitting features include smart sensors and district cooling systems, setting an example for existing buildings to adopt renewable energy and energy-efficient technologies.

site_title: Opec+ oil supply cuts could tip world into recession, says IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that Opec+ oil supply cuts could tip the global economy into recession, citing actual losses of around 1 million barrels per day, not the announced 2 million. The cuts have driven up prices, slowing world oil demand, and the agency slashed forecasts for global oil demand growth for 2023 by 20%. The IEA also predicts a further hit to global supplies as the European Union enacts a ban on Russian oil imports, exacerbating unrelenting inflationary pressures and interest rate hikes.

site_title: S'pore to feel pinch as US tech curbs on China further hit chipmakers' outlook
summary: The US' latest curbs on tech companies' business with China are expected to negatively impact the global semiconductor industry, particularly Singapore. As a major supplier of semiconductors (11% of world production) and chip-making equipment (20% of global supply), Singapore is likely to feel the effects. Weakening global demand for electronics and production cuts due to US curbs will darken the outlook for the industry, with potential consequences for Singapore's economy.

site_title: FairPrice launches initiative to help customers cope with rising costs
summary: FairPrice, a popular Singaporean supermarket chain, has launched an initiative called Greater Value Every Day to help customers cope with rising costs. The initiative features four schemes, including a monthly price freeze for 50 essential items, weekly discounts of up to 50% on selected items, existing discounts for seniors and NTUC members, and a curated range of exclusive products offering good value. The goal is to moderate costs and empower customers to save more on groceries and daily necessities amidst the uncertain economic climate.

site_title: Indonesian air force chief of staff receives prestigious S'pore military award
summary: Indonesian Air Force Chief of Staff, Air Chief Marshal Fadjar Prasetyo, received the prestigious Pingat Jasa Gemilang (Meritorious Service Medal) from Singapore President Halimah Yacob for strengthening defence ties between the two air forces. The award recognizes his efforts in celebrating 40 years of defence relations in 2021 through joint exercises and professional interactions. ACM Fadjar expressed hope that the friendship between the air forces will continue to thrive, citing the award as a testament to their commitment to maintaining peace and security in the region.

site_title: Freehold Meyer Park relaunches collective sale tender at $420 million
summary: Freehold seafront condo Meyer Park in Singapore has been relaunched for collective sale at a reserve price of $420 million. The site, which spans 8,981 sq m, can be redeveloped into a mid-sized luxury high-rise condominium with up to 251 residences. The sale tender will close on Nov 2, and the successful bidder will have ample time to submit a development application to the authorities before June 1, 2023. This relaunch follows the site's previous attempt in July 2022, which closed without a buyer.

site_title: 3,000 BTO flats to be built in Dover Forest in Ulu Pandan; first of 3 projects will launch in November
summary: The Housing Board plans to launch its first of three Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Dover Forest, Ulu Pandan, in November. The project will comprise 1,330 three-room and four-room flats across two blocks, with staggered heights to maximize views of the Ulu Pandan Canal and surrounding nature. The development will incorporate green and blue elements, including a natural stream, sky terraces, and roof gardens. The project is expected to have a strong demand, similar to previous mature estates, with features such as walking distance to Dover MRT station, a jogging track, and a community plaza.

site_title: Shell buys 45% stake in S'pore fuel card partner, Best Petrol & Diesel Supply
summary: Shell has acquired a 45% stake in Best Petrol & Diesel Supply, a Singapore-based fuel fleet card operator, for $21.3 million. This marks Shell's first overseas venture in the business. The investment aims to expand Shell's presence in the region.

site_title: Cost and revenue in public transport will never meet
summary: The cost of public transport in Singapore and globally is inherently mismatched between expenses and revenue. The government uses the term "cost" liberally, highlighting the gap between expenses and revenue in the public transport sector. This disparity is a universal issue, not unique to Singapore, and is a fact of life in the industry, where all goods and services require funding.

site_title: Road accident involving multiple vehicles at Causeway causes delays
summary: An accident at the Causeway involving at least two cars and several lorries caused delays on Thursday morning, blocking two out of three lanes. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) reported the incident at around 9:45am, advising travellers to expect slow traffic from Johor Bahru. The accident was cleared in two hours, with the tailback of departure traffic from Malaysia subsiding. No one was injured in the incident, which was attributed to technical issues with the brakes.

site_title: Man in bribery case linked to Keppel Fels has jail term more than doubled after his appeal
summary: A Singapore court has increased the jail term of Goh Ngak Eng, 55, from 1 year, 5 months, and 3 weeks to 3 years, 1 month, and 3 weeks after he appealed against his sentence for conspiring with others to obtain bribes from Keppel Fels. The court found that Keppel Fels suffered an economic detriment of 45% due to the bribes, and Goh's appeal was deemed "plainly unmeritorious". The increased sentence reflects the severity of the offences, with a total of $879,853.63 paid in bribes.

site_title: Getting people to quit smoking involves not just tough laws but also community: NZ minister
summary: New Zealand aims to be smoke-free by 2025, with a goal of reducing the smoking rate to below 5%. Associate Minister of Health Ayesha Verrall emphasizes the importance of community engagement in quitting smoking, citing the success of a traditional canoeing sport, waka-ama, as a way to promote smoking cessation. The government plans to cut tobacco retail outlets and nicotine levels in cigarettes, while introducing legislation to ban sales of tobacco to those born after 2009.

site_title: US scrambles to prevent export curbs on China chips from disrupting supply chain
summary: The US is scrambling to prevent disruptions to the global semiconductor supply chain due to new export curbs on China's chip industry. The Biden administration had planned to spare foreign companies operating in China, but the rules did not exempt them. However, SK Hynix, Samsung Electronics, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) have received temporary authorizations to continue operations, including receiving non-Chinese goods and equipment. The US plans to review licenses on a case-by-case basis, but the restrictions could still impact the supply chain and force companies to shut down.

site_title: As Qantas surprises with bullish update, Asian airlines face uneven recovery
summary: Qantas surprised the market with a stronger-than-expected profit forecast, forecasting underlying pre-tax profit of up to A$1.3 billion for the first half of the year. This contrasts with Asian airlines, which are recovering at varying paces due to factors such as government support, quarantine rules, and balance sheets. International rivals, including Singapore Airlines, have benefited from stronger demand, while carriers in North Asia, such as Korean Air and Taiwan's China Airlines, are showing signs of improvement. However, airline profits are expected to decline next year as demand weakens and capacity rebounds.

site_title: Football: Could Kylian Mbappe really be set to leave Paris Saint-Germain?
summary: Kylian Mbappe, a Paris Saint-Germain star, is reportedly unhappy with the club due to unfulfilled promises, particularly the failure to sign a new center-forward. Despite signing a new contract in May, Mbappe feels "betrayed" and is considering leaving the club as soon as possible. PSG has denied the rumors, with coach Christophe Galtier claiming he's unaware of Mbappe's intentions, while Luis Campos insists Mbappe has never discussed leaving. If the rumors persist, PSG may reevaluate Mbappe's value and consider selling him in the future.

site_title: Chinese local governments buying houses to aid property sector
summary: Chinese local governments are buying homes in bulk to aid the struggling real estate sector. The city government of Suzhou plans to purchase 10,000 units, while Jinan city proposes to buy 3,000 units to rent out. Other cities, including Huzhou and Tonghua, have asked state-owned companies to buy homes from struggling developers. The purchases are part of a broader effort to stimulate the sector, but it's unclear if they are endorsed by the central government. The recent property policy package and Covid-19-zero policy have also dampened the outlook for the sector.

site_title: Crypto hackers set for record year after looting over $4.3 billion
summary: Cryptocurrency hackers have stolen over $4.3 billion this year, with at least $1.03 billion stolen in October alone. Most targets are decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols, which have become vulnerable to security exploits. Hackers have manipulated token prices and created new coins to steal funds, with state-sponsored groups also involved. Chainalysis estimates 2022 may be a record year for total value hacked, with DeFi platforms bearing the brunt of the attacks.

site_title: American who allegedly made false bomb threat on SIA flight ‘a danger to the public’, denied bail
summary: A 37-year-old American man, La Andy Hien Duc, has been denied bail for allegedly making a false bomb threat on a Singapore Airlines flight from San Francisco to Singapore. Duc claimed there was a bomb on board, grabbed a passenger's luggage, and assaulted a cabin crew member. He is diagnosed with schizophrenia and has a history of cannabis use. The court ruled that he poses a danger to the public and is a flight risk, citing his lack of roots in Singapore and no fixed place to stay.

site_title: UK pension funds selling stokes fear across global bond markets
summary: British pension funds are selling assets to meet margin calls, contributing to selling pressure in global bond markets. The move is linked to the UK's end of an emergency bond-buying program, which has sparked fears of market instability. Investment-grade corporate bonds in the US and Europe are falling, and Asian dollar notes are seeing a two-month high yield premium. Investors are nervous about the potential for further leverage issues, and market volatility is expected to persist until stability returns in the rates market.

site_title: Actor Edwin Goh fined $6,500 for drink driving
summary: Actor Edwin Goh, 28, was fined $6,500 and disqualified from driving for three years for drink driving after exceeding the prescribed limit of 35mcg of alcohol in 100ml of breath. Goh pleaded guilty to the charge, which occurred on September 7 after he was stopped at 2:30am along Aljunied Road. In mitigation, he expressed remorse and asked for leniency. This conviction is part of a trend of local celebrities being convicted of drink driving, with others including Shane Pow, Terence Cao, and Christopher Lee.

site_title: Yishun teen accused of father's murder to be remanded for one more week
summary: A 19-year-old Singaporean teen, Sylesnar Seah Jie Kai, will be remanded for another week in connection with the murder of his 47-year-old father, Eddie Seah Wee Teck, found dead outside their Yishun home on October 10. The teen appeared in court via video link, where the prosecution requested an additional week of remand citing ongoing police investigations. Seah Jie Kai's lawyer requested one hour of access to his client, but the request was denied. The teen is scheduled to appear in court again on October 20.

site_title: Football: Julian Nagelsmann happy as Bayern see off Plzen to reach Champions League last 16
summary: Bayern Munich advanced to the Champions League last 16 with a 4-2 win over Viktoria Plzen. Julian Nagelsmann's side secured 12 points from four games in Group C, leading the group. Leon Goretzka scored twice, including a penalty, to help Bayern overcome the Czech underdogs. The win sets up a matchup against Barcelona in the next round. Bayern coach Nagelsmann expressed happiness about reaching the last 16, acknowledging the challenges of being the favorites in each match.

site_title: Toshiba shares surge after report of $27.4 billion buyout bid
summary: Toshiba shares surged 8.5% to 5,566 yen after a domestic-led consortium, led by Japan Industrial Partners, made a $27.4 billion buyout bid, a 26% premium from Wednesday's closing price. The group, which includes Chubu Electric Power, received a right of first refusal and is expected to borrow the rest from financial institutions. Toshiba's spokesman declined to comment on the report, citing the need to maintain a fair process.

site_title: China's bursting housing bubble will rock the economy for years
summary: China's housing market is experiencing a severe downturn, with home sales and prices remaining sluggish amid an economic slowdown and zero-Covid-19 restraints. The government has implemented stimulus measures, including lower mortgage rates and tax breaks, but none have restored confidence in the sector. Experts warn that the housing market may drag on for years, with potential spillover effects on the economy, including a record increase in savings and a decline in consumer confidence. The IMF has estimated that 45% of developers may struggle to cover their debt obligations, and 20% could become insolvent, highlighting the need for a credible commitment from the government to ensure housing construction is completed.

site_title: Airfares up to 78% higher this December school holidays than before pandemic
summary: Airfares from Singapore have increased by up to 78% this December school holidays compared to pre-pandemic rates. This surge is expected to be temporary, according to travel players. Meanwhile, prices to destinations like Japan and Taiwan have decreased. The price fluctuations are attributed to various factors, but the exact causes are not specified.

site_title: Fed official says more big rate hikes on table if inflation will not cool
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman stated that if inflation does not decrease, she will continue to support aggressive interest rate hikes to combat high inflation. Bowman emphasized the importance of bringing inflation back to the target, citing a necessary condition for achieving price stability and maximum employment. The Fed's aggressive rate hikes, which have been unprecedented in recent campaigns, will remain on the table if inflation does not cool, but a slower pace of increases may be considered if inflation starts to decrease.

site_title: OCBC scouting for Indonesian acquisitions to speed up growth: CEO
summary: OCBC Bank is scouting for acquisitions in Indonesia to boost growth, leveraging its strong capital buffer. CEO Helen Wong sees Indonesia as a promising market, given its potential for growth and OCBC's financial strength, which makes it an attractive suitor to potential targets. With a record $2.84 billion capital buffer, OCBC is poised to enter a phase of growth, and analysts expect it to use its capital for acquisitions, potentially targeting consumer banks.

site_title: The rise and fall of Wall Street's pandemic darlings
summary: Wall Street's pandemic darlings, including Peloton, Zoom, Nautilus, DoorDash, and Robinhood, are facing significant declines due to soaring inflation and an economic slowdown. Companies like Peloton have seen their stocks plummet 95% from their peak, while others, such as Zoom and DoorDash, have also experienced significant drops. Experts attribute the downturn to the companies' inability to sustain growth once the pandemic wave subsided, with investors losing interest in their products and services. The economic uncertainty and inflation are further exacerbating the decline.

site_title: Hong Kong court orders return of $99,500 to Singaporean scam victim
summary: A Hong Kong court has ordered the return of $99,500 to a Singaporean victim, Ms. Roberta Teh, who lost funds to a phone scam in April 2021. The scammer had phoned her claiming to be from her phone service provider, and the money was initially deposited into a Citibank (Hong Kong) account. The funds were later converted to Hong Kong dollars and transferred to the account. The court's decision marks a resolution for the victim, who can now recover her lost funds.

site_title: Football: Stay focused, Antonio Conte urges Spurs after they beat Frankfurt
summary: Tottenham Hotspur edged past Eintracht Frankfurt 3-2 in a Champions League match, with Son Heung-min scoring twice, including a stunning volley. The win bolsters Spurs' bid to reach the last 16, as they sit top of Group D with seven points. Manager Antonio Conte praised his team's performance, saying they "avoided a disaster" after a slow start. With two matches remaining, Spurs aim to secure a spot in the knockout phase, with a one-point lead over Marseille and Sporting Lisbon.

site_title: Chip equipment maker Applied Materials slashes sales forecast on China export curbs
summary: Applied Materials, the largest chip equipment maker, has slashed its sales forecast for the fourth quarter due to new US export regulations that will reduce sales to China by around $400 million. The company now expects revenue of $6.4 billion, down from a previous forecast of $6.65 billion. The regulations, announced on October 7, will affect sales of advanced chip equipment and related parts and services to Chinese customers unless they obtain a license. The company also trimmed its profit forecast, citing reduced sales and increased inventory costs.

site_title: Football: Salah scores fastest Champions League hat-trick in Liverpool's 7-1 win at Rangers
summary: Liverpool scored the fastest Champions League hat-trick in history, with Mohamed Salah netting a treble in a 7-1 win over Rangers. The Egyptian's six-minute goal surpassed the previous record held by Bafetimbi Gomis. Roberto Firmino and Darwin Nunez also scored, while Harvey Elliott rounded off the scoring. The win boosts Liverpool's confidence ahead of their Premier League match against Manchester City, and puts them within a point of qualifying for the Champions League knockout stages.

site_title: Subcontractor not liable for stopping work in condo project, rules court
summary: A Singapore High Court ruled that subcontractor Triumph Electrical System Engineering was not liable for stopping work on a condo project after eight months of unpaid fees. The court found DSL Integrated Solution, the main electrical contractor, was justified in terminating the agreement. DSL claimed Triumph had subcontracted work without agreeing on terms, but the court deemed this not a breach of contract. The ruling found Triumph's actions reasonable given the circumstances of non-payment.

site_title: Aussie tribunal rejects couple's bid for citizenship for S'porean son, 5
summary: A Melbourne-based tribunal rejected the appeal of a couple seeking citizenship for their 5-year-old Singaporean son, citing general submissions about comparative lifestyles in Singapore and Australia. The couple claimed the boy would suffer less stress and receive better medical treatment for his kidney condition in Australia. The son has a non-functional right kidney and has received treatment since birth. The tribunal's decision was based on the couple's general submissions, which were deemed insufficient to support their claim. The couple's appeal was denied.

site_title: Football: 'It is my fault', admits Xavi as drowning Barcelona are held 3-3 by Inter
summary: Barcelona were held to a 3-3 draw with Inter Milan in the Champions League, securing a spot in the competition but putting their fate in another team's hands. Coach Xavi Hernandez blamed his team's errors for the loss, saying "it's my fault" and acknowledging that Barcelona's Champions League fate is no longer in their own hands. Robert Lewandowski scored two late goals, including a stoppage-time header, to save Barcelona from elimination, but they still face a second consecutive group-stage elimination if Inter Milan wins their next match.

site_title: Qantas sees return to first-half profit of up to $1.17b on travel demand
summary: Qantas has reported a remarkable turnaround to first-half profitability, with underlying profit before tax estimated at $1.17 billion, ending a streak of five consecutive half-yearly losses. The airline's rapid return to profitability and improvement in on-time performance are attributed to booming travel demand following the easing of pandemic-era curbs. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce's position has been bolstered, and shares have rallied the most in almost two years, gaining 11.8% in early trading. The airline will spend $200 million to maintain service levels and reward workers with increased wages.

site_title: Train and bus fares to increase by up to 5 cents from Dec 26
summary: Singapore's public transport fares will rise by 2.9% starting December 26, with adult commuters paying by card facing an additional 4-5 cents for journeys up to 8.2km and 5 cents for longer trips. Concessionary fares for seniors, students, and low-wage workers will increase by 1 cent per trip. The hike is attributed to higher energy costs, but the Public Transport Council (PTC) limited the increase to avoid a 13.5% rise, citing government subsidies and affordability indicators showing public transport remains affordable for most households.

site_title: From taxi driver to software engineer in 9 months
summary: A 53-year-old Singaporean taxi driver, Gazali Ahmad, completed a 9-month software engineering course in March 2021 and now works as a full-stack developer for a global technology firm, earning three times his taxi driving salary. He credits the course for giving him the skills and confidence to adapt to the changing job market, addressing the "labour market puzzle" for older workers with outdated skills. The course, run by Generation Singapore, a non-profit organization, provided intensive training and a six-month apprenticeship, helping Gazali land an engaging and rewarding job.

site_title: Migrant worker death in Geylang fire: Court finds flat owners not liable in lawsuit
summary: A district judge in Singapore ruled that four flat owners are not liable for the death of a migrant worker in a 2015 fire at an apartment used as an improvised dormitory. The fire occurred on April 3, 2015, at 86A Lorong 6 Geylang. The deceased, Mamun Abdullah All, a 20-year-old Bangladesh national, was a migrant worker. The court found that the owners were not negligent in the incident, and the case will now proceed to determine dependency claims. The ruling was made on October 13, 2022.

site_title: Healthier SG a decisive shift to improve people's health: Ong
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasizes the need to shift towards greater preventive care to address rising healthcare costs and chronic illnesses. Despite efforts, high blood pressure and cholesterol levels continue to rise among adults. Ong highlights the success of the Healthier SG initiative, which includes encouraging people to take charge of their health, promoting healthier drinks, and subsidizing doctor visits for older adults. By focusing on preventive care, Singapore aims to improve population health, reduce disease burden, and put its healthcare system on a more sustainable financial footing.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Bus and train fares in Singapore will rise by 2.9% from Dec 26, with adult fares increasing by 4-5 cents and concessionary fares rising by 1 cent per trip. Outgoing Jakarta Governor Anies Baswedan is seeking a running mate for the presidential election, while a 19-year-old in Singapore has been charged with the murder of his father. The US has limited influence over oil production, as seen in the Saudi-led Opec Plus decision to cut production despite US pressure.

site_title: HK court orders return of $99,500 to S'porean scam victim
summary: A Hong Kong judge has ordered the return of $99,500 to a Singaporean woman, Ms Roberta Teh, who was scammed out of the amount by a phone fraudster in April 2021. The victim, 52, was contacted by the scammer claiming to be her phone service provider staff member. Authorities traced the lost funds to a Hong Kong bank account deposit, leading to the court's decision to return the money to the victim. This is the first known case of a scammer's ill-gotten gains being recovered in Hong Kong.

site_title: He went from taxi driver to software engineer in 9 months
summary: Mr. Gazali Ahmad, 53, transformed from a taxi driver to a full-stack developer in 9 months after enrolling in a program by Generation Singapore. He previously had a diploma in mechanical engineering but felt unsatisfied in his career. Through intensive lessons and a six-month apprenticeship, Gazali gained skills in programming languages and became a global technology firm employee, earning three times his taxi driving salary. His story highlights the potential for older workers to upskill and adapt, addressing the labor market puzzle of mismatched skills and age.

site_title: Apartment owners not liable for worker's death in Geylang fire
summary: A district judge ruled that four landlord-owners are not liable for the death of a migrant worker in a Geylang apartment fire. The fire occurred in an improvised dormitory used by the worker, Mamun Abdullah All, 20, from Bangladesh. The landlord-owners were sued for negligence, but the judge found they were not involved in running the illegal dormitory. The father of the deceased worker is seeking damages and dependency claims.

site_title: Delivery of healthcare must change as population ages: NHG chief
summary: Professor Philip Choo, group chief executive of the National Healthcare Group, emphasizes the need for a change in healthcare delivery to maintain quality care as the population ages. NHG has identified key shifts, including single care plans, preventive health programs, and integrated care. The group is working closely with partners to promote health-seeking behaviors and using data to create targeted interventions. The use of technology in healthcare should serve a real purpose, with examples including telemonitoring and telemedicine, and "hospital at home" models that reduce costs and hospital bed utilization.

site_title: Aussie tribunal rejects couple's bid for citizenship for S'porean son, 5
summary: A Melbourne tribunal rejected an appeal from a couple seeking citizenship for their 5-year-old Singaporean son, K.C. Vijayan. The couple claimed their son would suffer less stress and receive better medical treatment for his kidney condition in Australia. The boy, born with a non-functional right kidney, has received treatment since birth. The tribunal's decision was made despite the couple's arguments, which were based on their son's experiences during previous visits to Australia.

site_title: Content creator gets jail and fine over obscene material on OnlyFans platform
summary: A 22-year-old content creator, Titus Low Kaide, was sentenced to three weeks' jail and fined $3,000 for transmitting obscene material on the online platform OnlyFans. He pleaded guilty to two charges of transmitting obscene material and breaching a police order. Low had been investigated after a 12-year-old girl found explicit videos of him on her phone. Despite being warned not to access his account, he continued to upload content and was the first content creator in Singapore to be convicted of transmitting obscene materials on the platform.

site_title: Unpaid subcontractor found not liable for contract breach
summary: A High Court ruled that an unpaid subcontractor, Triumph Electrical System Engineering, was not liable for breach of contract. The subcontractor stopped work after not being paid for eight months. DSL Integrated Solution, the main electrical contractor, claimed Triumph had subcontracted work on agreed terms. The court found that the circumstances of the case justified Triumph's actions, leading to the subcontractor's acquittal.

site_title: Yishun murder: Teen charged with killing father
summary: A 19-year-old, Sylesnar Seah Jie Kai, has been charged with the murder of his 47-year-old father, Eddie Seah Wee Teck, at their home in Yishun, Singapore. The teenager appeared in court via video link, where he was remanded for further investigations by the police. The case is set to be heard on Thursday, with the defence counsel seeking unlimited access to the teenager to assist with his applications and explain his rights under the law. If convicted, Sylesnar faces the death penalty.

site_title: Man who slashed Certis officer with sickle convicted of 7 charges
summary: A 32-year-old man, Vickneswaran Sivan, was convicted of seven charges for slashing a Certis enforcement officer with a sickle on November 9, 2020, after being issued a summons for smoking at a void deck. He caused grievous hurt to the officer, resulting in 141 days of hospitalization leave. Vickneswaran was also convicted of various other offenses, including attacking his wife. The court sentenced him to at least 13 years and eight months' jail and nine strokes of the cane, citing the severity of the victim's injuries and the inordinate violence exhibited during the attack.

site_title: Ex-MD of bankrupt luxury jet firm charged with embezzling $11m
summary: A former managing director of Zetta Jet, Geoffery Owen Cassidy, has been charged with embezzling over $11 million from the luxury jet operator between 2016 and 2017. Cassidy faces 34 charges, including cheating and criminal breach of trust, and is out on $300,000 bail. Former director June Tang Kim Choo has also been charged in relation to the case, accused of failing to use reasonable diligence in authorizing payments over $5 million. Zetta Jet, which operated from 2015 to 2017, went bankrupt amid corruption and mismanagement charges.

site_title: Man jailed 19 weeks over fraudulent Covid-19 claims for family members
summary: A 38-year-old man, Huang Weiming, was sentenced to 19 weeks in jail for submitting fraudulent Covid-19 Support Grant applications on behalf of his family members. He lied about their employment status and income to deceive the Ministry of Social and Family Development, receiving a total of $4,800. Huang falsely claimed his mother was employed and his wife had lost her job due to Covid-19, when in fact his wife had resigned and his mother was a housewife. The court found him guilty of three charges of cheating and attempted cheating.

site_title: Airfares for year-end school holiday period up to 78% more than before pandemic
summary: Airfares from Singapore have surged by up to 78% for the December school holidays, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. This significant increase comes despite some destinations like Japan and Taiwan seeing a drop in ticket prices compared to September. The rise in airfare costs is attributed to the post-pandemic travel demand and limited air capacity.

site_title: Fresh chicken from Malaysia likely to hit shelves here from today
summary: Fresh chicken from Malaysia is expected to hit shelves in limited quantities starting Thursday, with major retailers such as Sheng Siong and online stores offering the product. The imports were banned from June 1 due to a local supply shortage, but will resume with a reduced volume of 1.8 million chickens per month. Prices have increased by 10-16% compared to pre-ban levels. Other chicken importers, such as Hup Heng Poultry Industries, expect a fraction of their usual volume to arrive this week, and the return to pre-ban levels is uncertain due to the dissolution of Malaysia's Parliament.

site_title: Transition to living with Covid-19 helped by Omicron
summary: A study by Duke-NUS Medical School and the National Centre for Infectious Diseases found that the contagious nature of the Covid-19 Omicron variant helped highly vaccinated populations transition to living with the disease. Omicron conferred "mucosal immunity" and milder infections in vaccinated individuals, with lower rates of lung infections and oxygen support needs. The study suggests that Omicron evolved to escape immunity from past infection or vaccination, and that booster shots can alleviate weak immune responses in older adults. This information guides future responses to the pandemic, including vaccine development.

site_title: Curbs on visits to hospitals, care homes as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Singapore will tighten visitor restrictions at hospitals and residential care homes for four weeks due to rising Covid-19 cases. Patients will be limited to two pre-designated visitors, with one allowed at the bedside at a time. Critically ill patients can have up to five visitors, with two at the bedside. The measures aim to protect healthcare capacity and vulnerable people.
