Visitors must schedule ahead, take an antigen rapid test, and adhere to safe management measures, which may include stricter limits or testing requirements for vulnerable patients.

site_title: Proposed changes to Healthcare Services Act to boost patient care
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has proposed amendments to the Healthcare Services Act (HCSA) to regulate healthcare services and provide greater transparency in advertising. The changes, set to be completed by end-2023, include requiring unregistered healthcare professionals to disclose their credentials, restricting businesses from advertising medical conditions or diseases, and introducing an approval regime for specified services. The amendments aim to strengthen regulations, enhance patient safety, and promote clarity in healthcare services advertising. The public can provide feedback on the proposed changes until November 11.

site_title: NUS hits top 20 unis in world ranking, NTU up 10 spots to 36
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has reached the top 20 universities globally in the Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2023, up from 21st the previous year. Nanyang Technological University (NTU) jumped 10 spots to 36th place. Oxford University topped the rankings for the seventh consecutive year, while Harvard University ranked second. The rankings, which consider research, academic reputation, and industry income, highlight Singapore's growing strength in higher education and its universities' commitment to research and innovation.

site_title: SingPost to offer parcel service in MRT stations by January
summary: SingPost will launch POPStop, a parcel service facility, in MRT stations by January 2023. The first facility will be located in the Central Business District. POPStop will allow individuals and businesses to send and track parcels via the SingPost mobile app. The service will also offer POPDrop, an automated machine for dropping off parcels. The initiative aims to reduce the carbon footprint of parcel deliveries and provide a convenient option for consumers and sellers in the e-commerce sector. This move is expected to complement SingPost's existing POPStation automated delivery locker system.

site_title: 600,000 transport vouchers to help cope with fare hike
summary: The Singapore government will distribute 600,000 public transport vouchers worth $30 each to lower-income households starting Dec 28 to help them cope with the 2.9% fare increase. Households with monthly income of $1,600 or less qualify. The vouchers can be used to top up fare cards or buy monthly passes. Rail operators will contribute to the Public Transport Fund, with SMRT Trains and SBS Transit expected to increase their revenue by $15.4 million and $7.4 million, respectively.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand to boost cooperation in trade, digital economy
summary: Singapore and Thailand have agreed to boost cooperation in trade, digital economy, innovation, and sustainability. The two countries signed several agreements, including a Cruise Tourism Task Force, an Implementation Agreement, and memorandums of understanding in areas like intellectual property, meat trading, and carbon credit projects. The agreements aim to deepen engagement and drive bilateral initiatives, particularly in the tourism sector. The partnership is expected to benefit Singaporean businesses looking to explore the Thai market, and vice versa, with bilateral trade reaching $34.1 billion in 2021.

site_title: Maliki calls on Kazakh President, both countries reaffirm warm ties
summary: Kazakhstan and Singapore reaffirmed their warm ties ahead of their 30th anniversary of diplomatic relations in 2023. Singapore's Minister in the Prime Minister's Office, Maliki Osman, called on President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, and both countries discussed strengthening economic and people-to-people ties. They also explored opportunities in the transport and logistics sector, as well as digitalization and skills training. The two countries agreed to boost connectivity and welcomed progress in negotiations on a Services and Investment Agreement under the Eurasian Economic Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: What is the new XBB Covid-19 variant, and how dangerous is it?
summary: Singapore is facing a surge in cases driven by the XBB Covid-19 variant, a mutated Omicron sub-variant detected in several countries since August. As of now, XBB makes up 55% of local infections, but authorities say it is not more serious than other Omicron sub-variants. The number of severe cases remains low, largely due to vaccination and previous waves of infection. A booster jab is recommended for eligible individuals, and Singapore is introducing a bivalent Moderna vaccine to target the Omicron BA.1 and BA.4/BA.5 variants.

site_title: S'pore stocks fall for fifth straight day amid mixed regional trading
summary: Singapore stocks fell for a fifth consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.7% to 3,083.19, amid mixed regional trading. The benchmark index declined 22 points, with 333 losing stocks outweighing 203 gainers. Key US data releases this week may trigger volatility, with investors keeping an eye on Federal Reserve meeting minutes and inflation data. DBS Bank and UOB were among the three index stocks that ended higher, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage led the decliners.

site_title: $22m boost for deeper research into greener marine ops
summary: Singapore has allocated $22 million over five years to fund research into greener marine operations, including the use of ammonia as a marine fuel and alternative energy sources for ports. The Singapore Maritime Institute (SMI) will collaborate with two local universities, the Nanyang Technological University and National University of Singapore, on the projects. The research will focus on decarbonisation, emissions management, and operational efficiency, aligning with Singapore's energy strategy to switch to low-carbon alternatives. The funding is a continuation of initiatives started in 2017 and 2018, and will support 30 research and development projects.

site_title: Tech start-ups focus on survival, conserving cash as funding dries up
summary: Tech start-ups in South-east Asia are shifting focus from rapid growth to survival, with venture funding drying up and companies conserving cash to stay afloat. The region's start-up ecosystem is facing headwinds, with global venture funding slumping 34% in the past quarter. Companies are prioritizing cash runway discussions and adopting more realistic growth expectations. Founders are also emphasizing efficiency, with many cutting jobs and shutting operations to shore up balance sheets ahead of a potential recession.

site_title: SIAEC inks deal with MYAirline, extends Hawaiian Airlines pact
summary: SIA Engineering Co (SIAEC) signed a 10-year agreement with Hawaiian Airlines to provide airframe maintenance services for its A330-200 aircraft. The deal also includes checks on 11 aircraft until 2027. Separately, SIAEC inked a 10-year agreement with MYAirline, a Malaysian low-cost carrier, to provide component support and repair services for its A320 aircraft fleet. The deals are expected to have minimal impact on SIAEC's earnings.

site_title: Up to 700 new vans gathering dust here after failing to get tax incentive
summary: Up to 700 brand-new parallel-imported Nissan NV200 petrol vans are stranded in Singapore due to their importers failing to secure a tax incentive. The vans passed emission tests in Japan but not in Singapore, making them eligible for a higher polluting vehicle band. This results in significant financial losses for the importers, with the vans worth at least $70 million if registered. The vans have been gathering dust in various carparks, representing three to four months' worth of sales.

site_title: MAS expected to further tighten Singdollar policy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to tighten its Singapore dollar policy to combat rising imported inflation. Analysts anticipate the MAS to steepen the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$Neer) and reposition the policy band higher, taking a more aggressive "double-barrelled" approach to mitigate the impact of inflation.

site_title: Intel said to be planning 'thousands' of job cuts in the face of PC slowdown
summary: Intel plans to cut thousands of jobs as part of a cost-cutting measure to cope with a slowing personal computer market. The layoffs, which could affect around 20% of staff in some divisions, are expected to be announced in October alongside the company's third-quarter earnings report. Intel's sales and marketing group, as well as its PC, data centre, and artificial intelligence groups are likely to be impacted. The move comes as the company faces a decline in demand for PC processors and struggles to regain market share lost to rivals.

site_title: Bank of Korea raises rates again to quell inflation
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised interest rates by half a percentage point to 3% for a second time since July, as the surging dollar fueled imported inflation. The rate hike aims to quell inflation, which surged to a near 24-year high in July. The move contrasts with the Reserve Bank of Australia's smaller-than-expected increase, and economists expect borrowing rates to rise further to combat inflation, which stands at 5.6%.

site_title: London's most expensive home, sold 3 years ago, up for sale again
summary: London's most expensive home, a 45-bedroom mansion overlooking Hyde Park, is up for sale again after being previously sold in April 2020 for £210 million. The property is owned by the family of Mr. Hui Ka Yan, chairman of embattled real estate giant China Evergrande Group. The sale comes as Mr. Hui sells assets following a collapse in the real estate market, reducing his net worth from $30 billion to approximately $6 billion. The sale process is private, and representatives for Beauchamp Estates and Evergrande declined to comment.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces US tax evasion probe over accounts
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating Credit Suisse over allegations the bank aided American clients in hiding assets from authorities, eight years after a $2.6 billion tax evasion settlement. Investigators are examining whether the bank helped US account holders with South American passports conceal assets totaling hundreds of millions of dollars. Credit Suisse denies improper conduct and claims to have implemented measures to root out tax evasion. The investigation adds pressure on the bank as it seeks to revamp its risk culture and return to profitability, potentially leading to further downsizing and exits of unprofitable businesses.

site_title: HDB, condo rents continue upward trend in September
summary: HDB and condo rents continued their upward trend in September, with HDB rents rising 3.2% and condo rents increasing 3.3% from the previous month. This marks the 27th consecutive month of growth for HDB rents and the 21st for condo rents. Condo rents in the city fringe grew at the fastest pace, while demand remains strong despite cooling measures. Analysts expect rents to rise further due to rising interest rates, property taxes, and a shortage of housing options.

site_title: MAS likely to fight inflation with aggressive 'double-barrelled' move: Analysts
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to implement an aggressive "double-barrelled" move to combat rising imported inflation. Analysts predict the MAS will steepen the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate and recentre the policy band higher to mitigate inflationary pressures. This move aims to reduce the attractiveness of the Singapore dollar and curb inflation, which is expected to impact the country's economy.

site_title: Iran using 80% of its vessels to store oil, says official
summary: Iran is utilizing 80% of its tankers to store around 60 million barrels of sanctioned oil, according to a National Iranian Tanker Company (NITC) official. The remaining 20% of tankers transport crude from Malaysia to China. This comes as the West imposes severe sanctions on Iran, crippling its economy, and the country reverts to covert oil sales. The US and other countries have targeted Iranian brokers and front companies in China, leading to lower prices and increased competition for market share.

site_title: S'pore firms eye Mexico as production base for US market
summary: Singaporean firms are exploring Mexico as a production base for the US market due to its proximity and lower costs. Establishing operations in Mexico would provide easier access to North American customers and reduced duties and logistics costs. However, the country's government policies have raised concerns among investors. This shift is driven by persistent geopolitical tensions and supply chain uncertainties, particularly after the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Chess needs uniform rules
summary: The chess community is divided over whether cheaters should be banned and ostracized from the game, with top sleuth Kenneth Regan highlighting the importance of consensus. The debate comes after a cheating saga, emphasizing the need for uniform rules in online matches. Regan believes a consensus is crucial for the community, but the issue remains unresolved.

site_title: Young Jin Yee to be Asia-Pac wealth chief at Deutsche
summary: Deutsche Bank is set to appoint Young Jin Yee, Credit Suisse Group's No. 2 wealth executive in Asia-Pacific, as head of private banking in the region. Yee, a veteran with 20 years at Credit Suisse, will start at Deutsche Bank next year and remain based in Singapore. She will replace Lok Yim and becomes the highest-ranking wealth departure in Asia at Credit Suisse. Yee's promotion was announced in November, and she will oversee wealth management services globally as part of Deutsche Bank's ambitions to become the euro area's largest private bank.

site_title: Company Briefs: Uniqlo
summary: Fast Retailing, owner of Uniqlo, is expected to report a record annual profit of 291 billion yen (S$2.9 billion) due to the yen's slump boosting overseas sales, particularly in North America and Europe. The company has posted strong performances in these regions. In contrast, LVMH, a French luxury goods giant, beat market forecasts with a sharp rise in sales driven by improved business in China. Toyota Motor has started assembling cars at a new plant in Myanmar after a 19-month delay, with production beginning at a rate of one or two vehicles per day.

site_title: Holly's View has victory right in her sights
summary: South Africa's Fairview racing scene is analyzed, focusing on each of the seven races. Key predictions include Holly's View being in contention for victory in the final race, GIMME MORE TIME being a strong contender in Race 3, WAITING FOR SUMMER being the favorite to win Race 4, and CHRONICLESOFNANIA and DOUBLE CHECK being top picks in their respective races. Overall, the article provides a detailed analysis of the horses' past performances and their chances of winning in the upcoming races.

site_title: Sports World: Indian cricket set to get new chief
summary: Indian cricket is set to get a new chief as Sourav Ganguly is reportedly being forced out for refusing to join the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party. Ganguly's replacement, Roger Binny, is expected to be elected unopposed. Meanwhile, Rugby World Cup boss Claude Atcher has been removed and replaced by Julien Collette after being sanctioned for "alarming managerial practices." The Football Association of Ireland has also apologized for players singing a pro-IRA chant after qualifying for the women's World Cup for the first time.

site_title: Hongkong Great looks the real deal
summary: Hongkong Great, a 7-year-old Chilean-bred, is favored to win the Group 1 Queen Elizabeth II Cup on Saturday, with his recent training performance indicating he may have the race at his mercy. Trained by Ricardo Le Grange, Hongkong Great has won eight of his nine starts, including three Group 1 wins on turf in Chile. His impressive 35.8-second gallop over 600m has raised expectations, and Le Grange feels his charge is in top form, making him a strong contender for the Cup.

site_title: Could be a sweet hat-trick for What A Honey
summary: Thursday's S. A. (Vaal) form analysis focuses on the potential winners of nine horse races. The top contenders include What A Honey, who could complete a hat-trick in the 7th race, and AGA HEAT, eyeing a hat-trick in the 8th. Other notable horses include MIRREN, FLAG BEARER, OTTO LUYKEN, and HIGH MOON, with some horses showing improvement after rest or recent performances.

site_title: Battle of wits: The hottest game in the NFL is chess
summary: The NFL has seen a rise in players participating in online chess tournaments, including the BlitzChamps competition, which features current and former NFL players. Players such as Amari Cooper, Kyler Murray, and Larry Fitzgerald have showcased their strategic minds and competitive zeal on the chessboard. While the game is distinct from football, some players believe it helps with focus and decision-making on the field. The tournament aims to dispel the misconception that football players are not intelligent or critical thinkers, with participants like Fitzgerald and analyst John Urschel promoting chess as a valuable skill.

site_title: Raducanu to find her fifth coach in 16 months
summary: British tennis star Emma Raducanu has parted ways with coach Dmitry Tursunov, her fifth coach in 16 months. Raducanu, 20, had been working with Tursunov since July after Wimbledon, showing improvement with a 8-7 win record. However, injuries have plagued her season, and she has added fitness trainer Jez Green to her team. Raducanu's immediate priority is improving her physical condition, following a series of injuries, including wrist and hip issues, that forced her to retire from the Transylvania Open.

site_title: 'Djokovic would love to play at Aus Open'
summary: Novak Djokovic, a 21-time Major champion, is eager to play at the Australian Open but must "work out the situation" with the government, according to tournament chief Craig Tiley. Djokovic, serving a three-year ban from entering Australia, has expressed desire to return for the 2023 tournament. The government has not indicated whether they will overturn the ban, with opposition politician Karen Andrews stating Djokovic should not receive special treatment. Russian and Belarusian players will be allowed to compete as neutrals at the event.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary:
Key events and sports scheduled over the next 48 hours include: 
- Track World Championships (Day 1 & 2 on StarHub Ch204) 
- Uefa Conference League, Europa League, and English Premier League matches (Friday & Saturday on various channels) 
- Australian Grand Prix MotoGP practice sessions (Friday & Saturday on various channels) 
- Golf tournaments, including the Andalucia Masters (Day 1 & 2 on StarHub Ch204) 
- Tennis tournaments, including the Gijon Open and San Diego Open (various channels) 
- US Open pool matches (Singtel TV Ch112)

site_title: Wealth Elite can add to his six pack
summary: Wealth Elite won his second trial in slow time, showcasing his potential for future wins. Despite a slow start, his rider Simon Kok gradually increased the tempo, allowing him to catch up and win by a 1/2-length. Wealth Elite's fighting spirit and past performances suggest he may add to his six-pack of wins. Meanwhile, Sure Will Do dominated his trial, leading from start to finish with a fast 62.61-second time. Takhi also impressed with a nose win in his trial, while newcomer Ahorsewithnoname took third.

site_title: Green fined, will be available for season opener
summary: Draymond Green was fined but not suspended by the Golden State Warriors for punching teammate Jordan Poole in practice. Green apologized to Poole and the team after the incident on Oct 5, and the Warriors will move forward with him for the season opener on Oct 18. Coach Steve Kerr emphasized that the team will "lean on the experience" of their nine-year history together to overcome the crisis and make it a successful season. Green is expected to play in the pre-season finale against the Denver Nuggets on Friday.

site_title: Team-first attitude led Chelsea to win: Potter
summary: Chelsea manager Graham Potter attributed the team's recent winning run to their strong team-first mentality, which he has developed a good understanding with during his tenure. The side secured a 2-0 victory over AC Milan in the Champions League, with goals from Jorginho and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang. Despite being down a man after Fikayo Tomori's red card, Chelsea dominated possession and limited Milan's chances, ultimately leading to a fourth straight win in all competitions.

site_title: Fitter Ronaldo in good shape to contribute
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag is focused on getting the best out of Cristiano Ronaldo, who has been in better shape after scoring his 700th career goal against Everton. Ten Hag aims to support Ronaldo and get him to contribute more to the squad, despite a lackluster start to the season. The team will face Cypriot side Omonia in the Europa League, with a full-strength lineup expected. Meanwhile, billionaire Jim Ratcliffe has expressed interest in buying the club, but the Glazer family has stated they are not for sale.

site_title: Pep satisfied as 10-man City advance
summary: Manchester City advanced to the Champions League's last 16 with a 0-0 draw against FC Copenhagen, despite being a 10-man team after Sergio Gomez's red card. The draw, City's first goalless result in 24 games, was a result Pep Guardiola was "so satisfied" with, despite his team's lack of cutting edge without top scorer Erling Haaland. The draw, coupled with Borussia Dortmund's 1-1 draw with Sevilla, secures City's spot in the knockout stages with two games to spare.

site_title: Third time's the charm for Ong
summary: National floorballer Tiffany Ong has secured a stint with Swedish club Storvreta Innebandyklubb (IBK) after two overseas offers by hockey teams fell through. Ong, 25, will play in the Allsvenskan, Sweden's second-tier league, from October to April 2023. She had initially been approached by a Malaysian club and an Australian team, but opportunities did not materialize due to schooling commitments and a thumb fracture. Ong's decision to play overseas was motivated by her desire to excel and gain a higher level of experience, and she hopes to bring back lessons to Singapore to develop the local floorball scene.

site_title: $300m World Cup windfall for clubs
summary: Fifa will distribute $209 million to clubs that release their international players for the Qatar World Cup, the same amount as four years ago. Each club will receive approximately $10,000 per day the player remains with their national team during the tournament. This compensation is paid to clubs that have had players participate in international competitions over the past two years. The Nordic countries, along with the Faroe Islands and Iceland, are submitting a joint bid to host the 2025 Women's European Championship.

site_title: Beuzelin's shot at making it great again
summary: French jockey Louis-Philippe Beuzelin is hopeful that riding Hongkong Great in Saturday's QEII Cup will salvage his under-par season. Beuzelin, who recently left trainer Michael Clements, was chosen for the ride after Clements opted for Hard Too Think instead. This opportunity comes after a disappointing start to the season, with Beuzelin not visiting the winner's circle in nearly three months. He believes that a Group 1 win would be a crucial turning point for his season, and that he has a good understanding of the horse, having ridden him in a barrier trial.

site_title: Thomas unsure of 2023 Tour de France return
summary: Geraint Thomas, a 36-year-old Welsh cyclist, is undecided about competing in the 2023 Tour de France, citing a desire to "make the most of it" and potentially marking his last year of racing. Thomas finished third in the 2022 Tour de France, his third podium finish in the Grand Tour, and has nothing left to prove. He will discuss his future with his wife before making a decision, considering alternatives like the Giro d'Italia, and aims to start the season at the Tour Down Under.

site_title: US stocks edge down ahead of consumer price data
summary: US stocks edged down on Wednesday ahead of the release of the September consumer price index (CPI) report, despite a 0.4% rise in wholesale inflation. Markets largely shrugged off the data, indicating investors are no longer surprised by elevated inflation and expect tougher actions from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 declined 0.3% for its sixth straight loss. A strong earnings report from PepsiCo and a cancer vaccine announcement from Moderna also boosted stocks.

site_title: 'Ashamed' Allegri has Juve president's backing
summary: Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri expressed shame over the team's 2-0 loss to Maccabi Haifa, citing a lack of heart and passion. Despite the loss, Allegri stated he won't resign, and Juventus president Andrea Agnelli reiterated his support for the coach. The defeat leaves Juventus on the brink of elimination in the Champions League, while Maccabi Haifa secured their first victory in four matches. Real Madrid secured a 1-1 draw with Shakhtar Donetsk, ensuring their spot in the knockout stage.

site_title: Positive response from Mbappe: Coach
summary: Paris Saint-Germain coach Christophe Galtier has dismissed reports of Kylian Mbappe's unrest, saying rumors about the star's future did not disrupt the team's preparations for a 1-1 draw against Benfica. Despite signing a lucrative contract, Mbappe is reportedly unhappy with the club, feeling betrayed by their failure to sign a top-class forward. Galtier found Mbappe's preparation for the game normal and praised his performance, while former French striker Thierry Henry emphasized the importance of the team over individual desires. PSG are now in a strong position to retain Mbappe, but his future remains uncertain.

site_title: Football: Clubs to receive over US$200 million World Cup compensation
summary: FIFA will distribute $209 million to clubs releasing international players for the 2022 Qatar World Cup. Each club will receive approximately $10,000 per day a player remains with the national team. This compensation is the same amount as four years ago in Russia. Meanwhile, the Nordic countries of Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden have submitted a joint bid to host the 2025 Women's European Championship.

site_title: Cycling: Thomas unsure of 2023 Tour de France return, says he has nothing to prove
summary: Geraint Thomas, 36, is undecided about competing in the 2023 Tour de France, having finished third in the 2022 edition. Thomas, who won the Tour in 2018, has nothing to prove and wants to make the most of his remaining years. His contract with Ineos Grenadiers expires in 2023. Thomas is considering alternatives, such as the Giro d'Italia, and will discuss his future with his wife before making a decision. He aims to start the 2023 season at the Tour Down Under, looking to improve his performance and enjoy the racing experience.

site_title: Proposed changes to Healthcare Services Act aimed at enhancing safe patient care
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has proposed amendments to the Healthcare Services Act to enhance safe patient care. Unregistered healthcare professionals using the title "doctor" may need to clearly state their credentials. The proposed changes include stricter advertising regulations, introduction of an approval regime for specified services, and enhanced employee background screening. The amendments aim to provide greater transparency and protect patients from misleading advertising. The public can provide feedback on the proposed changes until November 11, with the aim of implementing the changes by June 2023.

site_title: Fresh chickens from Malaysia expected back on shelves from Thursday afternoon
summary: Fresh broiler chickens from Malaysia are expected to return to Singapore's shelves from Thursday afternoon, with limited quantities available at major retailers. The chicken export ban in Malaysia, which started on June 1, has been lifted, allowing for the resumption of exports. However, the volume of chickens expected to be imported is significantly lower than pre-ban levels, with some companies only receiving 30% of their usual volume. Prices have also increased by 10-16% due to the shortage.

site_title: Chess: Community has to unite and chart way forward after cheating scandal, says top investigator
summary: A cheating scandal has rocked the chess community, with top investigator Kenneth Regan stating that Hans Niemann benefited from "illegal assistance" in over 100 online games. Hans Niemann, a 19-year-old American, lost to world champion Magnus Carlsen, who accused Niemann of cheating after withdrawing from the Sinquefield Cup. Niemann later admitted to cheating in a Twitter letter. The community is now divided on whether to ban and ostracize cheaters from the game, with Regan emphasizing the need for a consensus on this issue.

site_title: Football: Napoli see off Ajax and stroll into Champions League knockouts
summary: Napoli secured a 4-2 victory over Ajax, advancing to the Champions League knockout stages with two games to spare. The Italian team, led by coach Luciano Spalletti, have a perfect 12 points at the top of Group A, with Hirving Lozano, Giacomo Raspadori, Khvicha Kvaratskhelia, and Victor Osimhen scoring the goals. Ajax, despite a spirited performance, remain nine points behind Napoli and need two wins from their final two matches to advance. Napoli have now won four games from four in the competition.

site_title: Floorball: Tiffany Ong finally achieves dream of playing overseas after joining Sweden's Storvreta
summary: SINGAPORE national floorballer Tiffany Ong has achieved her dream of playing overseas after joining Sweden's Storvreta IBK. The 25-year-old defender, who had previously been offered opportunities to play in Malaysia and Australia, accepted the offer after a surprise interest from the Swedish club. Ong will play in the Allsvenskan, Sweden's second-tier league, from October 2022 to April 2023. She hopes to develop as a player and bring back lessons to improve the sport in Singapore, following in the footsteps of former national floorballer Jill Quek, who was the first Singaporean to play overseas in 2000.

site_title: Golf: World rankings inaccurate if LIV events snubbed, says McDowell
summary: Former US Open champion Graeme McDowell stated that the world rankings system will become inaccurate if LIV Golf events are not awarded individual title winner points. McDowell criticized the Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) for dragging its feet in awarding points, saying it would affect the legitimacy of the system. Two-time Major winner Dustin Johnson, who clinched the individual title in Bangkok, also expressed his concerns, stating that if his ranking is inaccurate, the whole system is inaccurate. McDowell called for the removal of "Official" from OWGR if they don't award points to LIV players.

site_title: Man who slashed Certis officer with sickle and chased another officer convicted
summary: Vickneswaran Sivan, 32, was convicted of seven charges, including voluntarily causing grievous hurt and causing hurt to a public servant, for attacking a Certis enforcement officer with a sickle on November 9, 2020. He slashed the officer's hands and legs at least four times, resulting in the victim's hospitalization for 141 days. Vickneswaran was sentenced to at least 13 years and eight months' jail and nine strokes of the cane, with the court noting the seriousness of the victim's injuries and the inordinate violence exhibited by the accused.

site_title: Football: Club should be bigger than any player, Henry tells Mbappe
summary: Former France and Arsenal forward Thierry Henry criticized Kylian Mbappe for reportedly wanting to leave Paris Saint-Germain due to his positioning as a lone forward. Henry believes the club should be bigger than any player and questions whether Mbappe feels valued by the team. Henry drew parallels to his own experiences at Barcelona and France, where he also had to adapt to different roles. PSG has denied Mbappe's departure rumors, but Henry's comments suggest he may be concerned about the forward's loyalty to the club.

site_title: New SingPost facility to be set up at MRT stations for users to send parcels
summary: SingPost is launching a facility called POPStop at MRT stations in Singapore, where users can send parcels, starting by January 2023. The first facility will be at a central business district MRT station, with more locations to be announced. POPStop will be manned by SingPost staff and offer packing materials, while also providing a service for consumers to pick up deliveries. The facility will also feature an automated POPDrop machine for dropping off parcels at any time, with tracking available through the SingPost mobile app. This move aims to reduce carbon footprint and improve convenience.

site_title: Football: United's Ten Hag determined to get the best out of a fitter Ronaldo
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag stated that Cristiano Ronaldo, now finding his feet, lacked sharpness early in the campaign due to missing pre-season. Ronaldo has played a part-time role so far, scoring twice in four starts. Ten Hag aims to get the best out of Ronaldo, who has 700 career goals, and is focused on securing a top spot in Group E of the Europa League. United trail group leaders Real Sociedad by three points and will field a full-strength team against Cypriot side Omonia Nicosia.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand set to deepen cooperation in trade, tourism and digital economy
summary: Singapore and Thailand agreed to deepen cooperation in trade, tourism, and the digital economy. The sixth Singapore-Thailand Enhanced Economic Relationship ministerial meeting led to agreements on cruise tourism, carbon credit projects, and intellectual property protection. Memorandums of cooperation and understanding were signed between entities, including a program to support entrepreneurs in both countries. Bilateral trade between Singapore and Thailand reached $34.1 billion in 2021, with Singapore being Thailand's largest foreign investor at $1.8 billion in 2020.

site_title: Kazakhstan and Singapore reaffirm ties ahead of 30th anniversary of diplomatic relations
summary: Kazakhstan and Singapore reaffirmed their strong ties ahead of the 30th anniversary of diplomatic relations in 2023. Minister Maliki Osman met with President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, discussing opportunities for economic cooperation, particularly in the transport and logistics sector. The two countries also welcomed progress in negotiations for a Services and Investment Agreement under the Eurasian Economic Union - Singapore Free Trade Agreement. They also exchanged views on education and skills training, with Singapore offering to learn from Kazakhstan's experience. A state visit is expected in the near future.

site_title: askST: What is the XBB strain and how will it affect me?
summary: Singapore is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases driven by the XBB strain, a mutated Omicron sub-variant. The strain has been detected in several countries since August 2022 and currently accounts for 55% of local infections. While it's not considered more serious than other Omicron sub-variants, vaccination and previous waves of infection have built resilience, resulting in mostly mild symptoms. The government recommends getting a booster jab and has introduced the bivalent Moderna vaccine, effective against the Omicron BA.1 variant and others, to protect against the strain.

site_title: Cricket: Emirates-based player gets 14-year ban for attempted match-fixing
summary: Mehar Chhayakar, an Indian cricketer based in the UAE, has been banned from all cricket for 14 years for seven breaches of the International Cricket Council's anti-corruption code. Chhayakar was found guilty of attempting to influence aspects of international matches in 2019 and obstructing the work of the Anti-Corruption Unit. He denied the charges, but the ICC stated it will "relentless" pursue those who try to corrupt the sport, sending a clear message with the lengthy ban.

site_title: Delivery of healthcare must change to maintain quality care as S'pore population ages: NHG chief
summary: Singapore's National Healthcare Group (NHG) must adapt its healthcare delivery to maintain quality care as the population ages, said NHG chief Philip Choo. The group aims to achieve this through accountable care, single care plans, and integrated care programs. NHG has set up committees to establish preventive health and integrated care programs, and is using data to target interventions. The group also explored the use of technology, telemonitoring, and telemedicine to improve care, with potential cost savings and reduced hospital bed utilization.

site_title: Curbs on number of visitors at hospitals, residential care homes as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Singapore has tightened visitor restrictions at hospitals and residential care homes due to a rise in Covid-19 cases. Patients will be allowed only two pre-designated visitors for the entire admission period, with limited time slots of 30 minutes. Critically ill patients can have up to five visitors, but with stricter rules. Visitors must adhere to safe management measures, including antigen testing and avoiding eating, drinking, and sitting on patients' beds. The measures aim to protect healthcare capacity and vulnerable individuals during the rising case period.

site_title: NBA: Warriors fine Green for punching teammate, but won't suspend him
summary: Draymond Green was fined by the Golden State Warriors for punching teammate Jordan Poole during practice, but will not be suspended. Green apologized to Poole and the team after the incident on October 5, and the Warriors will continue to work on the situation. Coach Steve Kerr emphasized the team's commitment to moving forward and relying on their experience and continuity to succeed in the upcoming season. Green is expected to return to action for the Warriors' pre-season finale against the Denver Nuggets on Friday.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic has to 'work out situation' with government, says Australian Open boss
summary: Novak Djokovic, the nine-time Australian Open champion, is eager to return to the tournament but must "work out the situation" with the Australian government, according to tournament chief Craig Tiley. Djokovic is currently serving a three-year ban from entering Australia due to his unvaccinated status, which was a major controversy at the 2022 championships. The government has not indicated whether they will overturn the ban, but Tiley confirmed that Russians and Belarusians can compete as neutrals at the 2023 tournament.

site_title: 600,000 public transport vouchers available from Dec 28 to help with fare hike
summary: Singapore to offer 600,000 public transport vouchers worth $30 each to lower- to lower-middle-income households to help cope with the 2.9% fare increase starting Dec 26. Households with monthly income per person of $1,600 or less are eligible. Vouchers can be used to top up fare cards or buy monthly concession passes. The vouchers are part of a $50.3 million fare increase, with rail operators contributing to the Public Transport Fund.

site_title: Former managing director of bankrupt luxury jet firm charged with embezzling over $11 million
summary: A former managing director of bankrupt luxury jet firm Zetta Jet, Geoffrey Owen Cassidy, has been charged with embezzling over $11 million. Cassidy faces 34 charges, including cheating and misappropriation, and was out on $300,000 bail. He allegedly siphoned funds from 2016 to 2017, using $1.4 million for personal expenditures and duping another company of $400,000. Former director June Tang Kim Choo was also charged for failing to use reasonable diligence in her duties, authorizing payments of over $5 million without verification.

site_title: Football: Conmebol backs Infantino for new term as Fifa president
summary: Conmebol, the South American Football Confederation, has unanimously supported Gianni Infantino's bid for a third term as FIFA president. Infantino, who previously served from 2016, will face re-election at the 73rd FIFA congress in March 2023. This backing comes after similar expressions of support from the Asian Football Confederation and the Confederation of African Football. Additionally, Conmebol has announced the implementation of video assistant referees (VAR) in its two major club competitions, starting from 2023, to increase transparency from the beginning of the tournaments.

site_title: Up to 700 new vans gathering dust in S'pore after failing to get tax incentive
summary: Up to 700 new Nissan NV200 petrol vans, worth at least $70 million, are gathering dust in Singapore after their importers failed to secure a tax incentive. The vans, among the best-selling models, were expected to be registered but their importers lost the incentive, leaving them stranded in carparks across the island. This represents three to four months' worth of sales, highlighting the significant financial loss for the importers.

site_title: 12 scholarships and over 260 training awards given to early childhood educators and students
summary: The Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) in Singapore has awarded 12 scholarships and over 260 training awards to early childhood educators and students. The scholarships will fund bachelor's and master's degrees in early childhood education, while the training awards support courses currently being taken by students. Minister Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the importance of early childhood educators, citing their role in supporting families and uplifting disadvantaged backgrounds. The Government has also committed to reviewing and increasing salaries for pre-school educators, with the pay review expected to be completed by the end of this year.

site_title: Content creator Titus Low gets 3 weeks' jail, fine for breaching police order, transmitting obscene material
summary: Content creator Titus Low Kaide was sentenced to 3 weeks' jail and fined $3,000 for transmitting obscene materials on OnlyFans, despite a police order to stop. Low, 22, pleaded guilty to two charges, breaching the order and transmitting obscene material. He had previously uploaded 8 photos and videos, earning $240,979, and continued to access his account despite warnings, breaching the order multiple times. The court heard Low's actions were premeditated, intended to undermine police investigations for financial gain.

site_title: Train, bus fares to rise by 4 to 5 cents for adults from Dec 26
summary: Singapore's public transport fares will rise by 2.9% starting December 26 for adults paying by card, with bus and train rides costing 4-5 cents more. Concessionary fares for seniors, students, and low-wage workers will increase by 1 cent per trip. The fare hike is lower than the maximum 13.5% increase allowed under the current fare formula, which was influenced by high energy costs and global inflation. The remaining 10.6% increase will be rolled over to future fare reviews, with the government providing $200 million in subsidies to cover the shortfall.

site_title: Football: Nordic nations make joint bid for women's Euro 2025; Spain beat US for the first time
summary: Nordic countries Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden have submitted a joint bid to host the 2025 Women's European Championship, with eight venues planned in Copenhagen, Stockholm, Oslo, and more. This is supported by the Faroe Islands and Iceland. Bidding closes on October 12, with France, Poland, and Switzerland also competing. Meanwhile, Spain's women's team beat the US 2-0 in a friendly, marking their first win over the world champions despite controversy surrounding the team's management. The UEFA executive committee will decide on the winning bid on January 25.

site_title: Singapore companies look to Mexico as nearshoring gains ground
summary: Singapore companies are increasingly looking to Mexico as a nearshoring alternative due to geopolitical tensions and supply chain uncertainties. A business mission led by Racer Technology Medica's founder and CEO Willy Koh explored opportunities in Mexico earlier this month. Setting up operations in Mexico would provide easier access to the US market, reduced duties, and lower logistics costs, particularly in shipping, which have increased since the Covid-19 pandemic. This shift aims to mitigate risks and capitalize on the region's proximity to North America.

site_title: Credit Suisse's Young Jin Yee to join Deutsche Bank as Asia wealth head
summary: Deutsche Bank is set to appoint Young Jin Yee, a veteran executive from Credit Suisse, as head of private banking in Asia-Pacific. Yee, who will start next year, will replace Lok Yim and continue to be based in Singapore. This is the highest-ranking wealth departure in Asia so far at Credit Suisse, following Yee's promotion last year. Yee's appointment is part of Deutsche Bank's efforts to build up its wealth management services globally.

site_title: Iran storing around 60 million barrels of oil on state-owned ships: Official
summary: Iran is storing around 60 million barrels of sanctioned oil on state-owned tankers operated by the National Iranian Tanker Company (NITC), according to a senior official. The oil is primarily being stored off Kharg Island, a key Iranian crude export terminal, while the rest of the tankers transport crude to China. This move comes as the West imposes severe sanctions on Iran in an attempt to slow down its nuclear programme, and as indirect talks on an accord have broken down, forcing Teheran to revert to covert oil sales.

site_title: ECs fetch strong resale profits as price gap with new units narrows: OrangeTee
summary: Executive condominiums (ECs) in Singapore are generating significant resale profits, with nearly 300 units yielding $500,000 or more. A study by OrangeTee found that nearly all 4,266 sampled ECs netted around $300,000 in gross profits, driven by high demand and limited supply. The price gap between new and resale ECs has narrowed to 14.4%, with resale prices climbing 30.3% to $1,115 per square foot. Larger units tend to fetch better prices, with 170 ECs of 1,600 sq ft or more yielding an average gross profit of $455,207.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents up in September; strong demand ensures landlord's market
summary: Rents for Housing Board flats and private apartments rose 3.2% and 3.3% in September, respectively, marking the 21st straight month of growth for condo rents and the 27th for HDB rents. Strong demand and limited housing options have driven up rents, with condo rents up 30.9% and HDB rents up 24.7% year on year. Analysts predict further rent increases due to rising interest rates, property taxes, and the impending GST increase, with potential rent hikes of up to 10% in the fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: Man gets 19 weeks' jail over fraudulent Covid-19 grant claims for family members
summary: A Singaporean man, Huang Weiming, 38, was sentenced to 19 weeks' jail for cheating the Ministry of Social and Family Development out of $4,800 from the Covid-19 Support Grant. He falsely claimed his mother and wife were employed and received $2,400 each, while his father's application was rejected due to lack of eligible loss. Huang lied about employment status and income, despite his wife resigning from her job and mother being a housewife. The court found him guilty of three charges of cheating and attempted cheating.

site_title: Cabby arrested for allegedly rolling up cab window on traffic police's arm, dragging him on the road
summary: A 69-year-old Singaporean taxi driver was arrested for allegedly trapping a traffic police officer's arm in his taxi window and dragging him down the road. The incident occurred when the officer tried to stop the driver for using his phone while driving. The driver was uncooperative and rolled up his window, dragging the officer for a few meters before stopping. He faces charges of voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant, which carries a jail term of up to seven years. The taxi company has condemned the driver's behavior, emphasizing the importance of road safety and cooperation with authorities.

site_title: NUS and NTU rise in world university rankings, taking 19th and 36th places
summary: National University of Singapore (NUS) has climbed to 19th place and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) jumped to 36th in the latest Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2023. NUS has been in the top 50 list since 2011, and NTU since 2020. The rankings are based on research publications, citations, and academic reputation, highlighting Singapore's progress in higher education and the growing strength of NUS and NTU in research and innovation.

site_title: Healthier SG a decisive shift to get population healthier, keep costs sustainable: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasizes the need for a shift towards preventive care in the country's healthcare strategy, dubbed "Healthier SG". The initiative aims to empower individuals to take charge of their health, with measures such as mandatory nutrition labeling, gamification, and subsidized family doctor services. The goal is to reduce healthcare costs, improve population health, and increase the proportion of people dying at home, from 60% to 50% within five years.

site_title: SIA Engineering extends contract with Hawaiian Airlines, inks deal with MYAirline
summary: SIA Engineering Co has extended its partnership with Hawaiian Airlines to provide airframe maintenance services for the airline's A330-200 aircraft until 2027. The company has also signed a 10-year agreement with Malaysian low-cost carrier MYAirline to provide support services for its Airbus A320 fleet. The deals are not expected to impact the group's earnings, with maintenance services to be performed at SIAEC's Singapore facility. The agreements aim to strengthen the airlines' operations and support their growth plans.

site_title: Crypto start-up funding plunges to lowest level in over a year
summary: Crypto start-ups saw a 37% decline in venture capital investment to $4.44 billion in the third quarter, the lowest level in over a year. This drop mirrors broader tech investing declines and is attributed to high risk and plunging cryptocurrency prices, with Bitcoin's value dropping to under $20,000. However, dedicated crypto funds continue to back start-ups, and some founders remain committed to their decentralised visions. Gaming platforms, particularly those using NFTs, have seen interest from investors, with companies like Improbable and LootMogul raising over $100 million each in September.

site_title: Asia stocks slump, US dollar wallops pound and yen
summary: Asian stocks fell to two-year lows amid a strengthening US dollar, British bond market instability, and upcoming US inflation data. The US dollar broke 146 yen for the first time since 1998, prompting Japan's pledge to intervene in the foreign exchange market. The pound hit a two-week low after the Bank of England ended its emergency bond buying program, while the International Monetary Fund cut its global growth forecast to 2.7%. Stocks on Wall Street fell, and oil prices dropped due to concerns over falling fuel demand and tightening Covid-19 curbs in China.

site_title: South Korea delivers another big rate hike as Fed moves sink local currency
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised interest rates by 50 basis points to 3% for the second time since July, amid a surge in the US dollar and imported inflation. The move aims to combat inflation, which reached a 24-year high in July. The won has slumped 17% this year, making imports more expensive and fueling consumer price gains. The decision contrasts with the Reserve Bank of Australia's smaller-than-expected hike last week, and analysts expect borrowing rates to rise further, with some predicting a 3.75% base rate by the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Japan's machinery orders post biggest fall in 6 months in blow to corporate spending
summary: Japan's machinery orders fell 5.8% in August, the largest single-month decline in six months, due to a global economic slowdown and a weaker yen. Business confidence at big manufacturers hit a five-month low, according to the Reuters Tankan survey. Core orders, a measure of capital expenditure, rose 9.7% year-over-year, but the decline in machinery orders signals a potential blow to corporate spending. The economy, which has grown 3.5% this year, faces risks from an economic slowdown in Asia and the US, affecting consumer and business confidence.

site_title: 19-year-old charged with murder of father in Yishun
summary: A 19-year-old, Sylesnar Seah Jie Kai, has been charged with the murder of his 47-year-old father, Eddie Seah Wee Teck, at their Yishun residence. The incident occurred between the 4th and 5th floors of Block 653 Yishun Avenue 4. Seah Jie Kai appeared in court via video link, wearing a mask, and was remanded for two days. The case is set to be adjourned to Thursday to hear arguments on the defense council's access to the teenager. The victim, a partner in a property business, was pronounced dead by paramedics at the scene.

site_title: Football: Allegri 'ashamed' as Juve fall in Israel to edge closer to Champions League exit
summary: Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri expressed shame after his team's 2-0 loss to Maccabi Haifa in the Champions League, falling on the brink of elimination. The Israeli side, led by Omer Atzili's two goals, dominated the first half and took control after Juventus midfielder Angel di Maria limped off with a thigh problem. Despite Juventus' late pressure, Maccabi held on comfortably. Allegri ruled out talk of resignation, citing a lack of "heart and passion" from his team, while Juventus president Andrea Agnelli expressed dismay but reiterated his support for the coach.

site_title: S&P 500, Nasdaq end lower; BoE comments add to market jitters late
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq ended lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.12% due to Amgen Inc's 5.7% jump. The Bank of England announced it will end its emergency support program for the UK bond market in three days, adding to market jitters. Investors are cautious ahead of key US inflation data and third-quarter earnings, with the International Monetary Fund predicting a 1.6% US economic growth this year.

site_title: Football: PSG's Galtier insists Mbappe exit rumours had no impact on Benfica build-up
summary: Paris Saint-Germain coach Christophe Galtier said rumors about Kylian Mbappe's potential departure had no impact on his team's preparations for the Champions League match against Benfica. Despite reports suggesting Mbappe might leave in January, he played with intensity and scored a penalty in a 1-1 draw. The result preserves PSG's unbeaten record this season, but the club's failure to sign a new center-forward has raised concerns about Mbappe's unhappiness. PSG denied any suggestion that Mbappe could depart during the transfer window.

site_title: Survival tips for tech start-ups as funding dries up
summary: Tech start-ups worldwide are facing a severe funding crisis amid surging inflation and interest rate hikes, with global venture funding slumping to $74.5 billion in the past three months. Experts warn that companies must prioritize cash conservation and efficiency to survive, with many advising portfolio companies to maintain a 36-month cash runway. As a result, some start-ups are being forced to cut costs, reduce subsidies, and refocus on proven business models, with founders emphasizing the need for sustainability and efficiency in a challenging economic environment.

site_title: Football: Chelsea beat 10-man Milan to top Champions League Group E
summary: Chelsea secured a 2-0 win over 10-man AC Milan, moving to the top of Champions League Group E. Fikayo Tomori was sent off in the 18th minute after pulling back Mason Mount, and Jorginho scored the resulting penalty. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang sealed the win with a calm finish 11 minutes before halftime. The defeat leaves Milan third, but still in contention for the knockout stages. Chelsea will now face Dinamo Zagreb and Salzburg in the remaining group matches to determine their fate.

site_title: Evergrande billionaire founder puts London's most expensive mansion up for sale
summary: A London mansion, previously London's most expensive home, is up for sale through Beauchamp Estates. The 45-bedroom property, located in Knightsbridge and overlooking Hyde Park, was bought by Vision Perfect Global Limited in 2020 for £210 million. The ultimate owner is the family of Hui Ka Yan, chairman of embattled real estate giant China Evergrande Group, who has been selling assets following a real estate market collapse. The sale comes less than three years after the property was last sold, and Hui's net worth has significantly decreased to around US$6 billion.

site_title: Intel plans thousands of job cuts in face of PC slowdown
summary: Intel plans to announce thousands of job cuts, likely affecting around 20% of its staff, as the company struggles with a decline in demand for personal computer processors. The layoffs, which could be as early as this month, come as Intel faces a steep drop in revenue and profit, with analysts predicting a 20% decline in third-quarter revenue. The company had previously warned of a $11 billion sales shortfall and has made smaller cuts since its last major layoff in 2016. Intel's shares have fallen over 50% in 2022, putting pressure on the company to improve profits.

site_title: MRT station will affect heritage of former Bukit Timah Turf Club but area's value can be retained: Report
summary: A heritage impact assessment report for the Cross Island Line MRT station in Singapore's former Bukit Timah Turf Club site concludes that sufficient heritage value can be retained by preserving several historic sites, including the grandstands and secretaries' bungalows. While parts of the racetrack, stables, and hay barn will be demolished, the report recommends protecting these areas to minimize damage to the site's history. The report's findings aim to balance the need for MRT development with the preservation of Singapore's heritage.

site_title: Worker fined $500 for having illegal cigarettes - amount close to his salary for a month
summary: A 33-year-old Bangladeshi migrant worker was fined $500 for smoking duty-unpaid cigarettes, a penalty close to his monthly salary. The worker hid the cigarettes within an empty duty-paid pack. During a recent operation by Singapore Customs, 33 men, including nine Singaporeans, were caught smoking duty-unpaid cigarettes. The offenders faced fines ranging from $500 to $1,300, and six are currently being investigated. Customs officers seized 380 sticks of contraband cigarettes, with penalties including fines up to 40 times the evaded duty and GST, and jail terms of up to six years.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces US tax evasion probe, Senate inquiry over accounts
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating Credit Suisse for allegedly aiding US account holders in hiding assets worth hundreds of millions of dollars from the IRS. The probe comes eight years after the bank paid a $2.6 billion settlement and pledged to tackle the issue. Credit Suisse denies improper conduct and claims to have implemented measures to root out tax evasion. The Senate Finance Committee is also preparing a report on the bank's vetting process for dual citizens and potential systemic failures to crack down on undeclared US accounts.

site_title: What you need to know about S'pore's new Covid-19 vaccination strategy
summary: Singapore has transitioned to a new Covid-19 vaccination strategy, focusing on being up to date rather than the total number of shots received. The new strategy requires individuals to be up to date with at least three doses of an mRNA vaccine, or four shots of Sinovac-CoronaVac or Sinopharm vaccines, with their last vaccine dose administered within the past year. Booster shots will be recommended for those aged 50 and above, and specific guidance will be provided for children and those with certain medical conditions.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: The Moderna/Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine, targeting the Omicron variant, will be available from Friday, three days ahead of schedule. Japan reopened its borders to vaccinated visitors from 68 countries, and a doctor in Singapore was charged over a woman's death due to alleged negligence during an aesthetic treatment. The US government introduced new restrictions on semiconductor exports to China, which may impact the country's chip industry. Oil prices rose after Opec+ announced a production cut, and experts warned of potential injuries from sudden changes in exercise routines.

site_title: Cross Island Line phase 2 could have major impact on nearby forests: Study
summary: A new study by Aecom reveals that the Cross Island Line's phase 2 construction could have a major environmental impact on nearby forests, including Clementi Forest, Windsor Forest, and Eng Neo Avenue Forest. Initial plans to build a station within Clementi Forest were scrapped, and mitigation strategies such as relocating worksites and reducing land consumption have been implemented. However, the study found that even with these measures, the CRL could still cause irreversible habitat loss and fragmentation of ecologically connected areas, with potential impacts on critically endangered species.

site_title: Cross Island Line could have 'major' impact on nearby forests: Study
summary: The Cross Island Line's (CRL) construction plans have been revised to minimize its environmental impact on nearby forests. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has implemented measures such as relocating worksites, reducing the size of the Maju station, and installing water-filled barriers to minimize roadkill. Although the study still predicts "major" environmental impacts on several forested areas, the LTA claims these measures can adequately manage these effects. The CRL's phase two, set to open by 2032, will provide greater public transport access to western areas, despite potential irreversible habitat loss for critically endangered wildlife.

site_title: Proposals to boost gig worker protections ready in 1 to 2 months
summary: Singapore's Advisory Committee on Platform Workers is set to finalize recommendations on improving gig worker protections in the next 1-2 months. The committee, established in 2021, aims to enhance retirement and housing adequacy, work injury compensation, and bargaining power for cabbies, private-hire car drivers, and freelance deliverymen. The proposals include making platform companies contribute to the Central Provident Fund accounts of gig workers and adapting the Work Injury Compensation Act. Once finalized, the recommendations will be released, followed by further engagements with workers and platform companies to implement the changes.

site_title: Bivalent Covid-19 jab available from Friday
summary: Singapore will make the Moderna/Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 jab available three days ahead of schedule, starting Friday, to better protect against the Omicron strain. The vaccine, which targets both the original and Omicron variants, showed a 75% greater antibody response against Omicron in clinical trials. The Health Minister encouraged those 50 and older, as well as those medically vulnerable, to take the jab. Nine vaccination centres will offer the bivalent vaccine daily, with no appointment required for those 50 and above. The vaccine's safety and effectiveness have been confirmed, with rare serious adverse events reported.

site_title: MOH refutes rumours of surge in severe coronavirus cases, deaths
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has refuted rumors of a surge in severe Covid-19 cases and deaths due to the XBB strain of the Omicron variant. Despite a recent spike in local cases, the number of severe cases remains relatively low, with 11 ICU cases and 50 requiring oxygen supplementation as of Tuesday. The MOH attributes this to the resilience built up through vaccination and previous waves of infection, with most patients reporting mild symptoms. There is no evidence that XBB causes more severe illness, and hospitalised cases are increasing in line with overall case numbers.

site_title: Leadership changes in Oct
summary: SPH Media Group announced leadership changes effective October 26. Editor-in-chief Warren Fernandez is leaving to pursue other opportunities. Fernandez will be succeeded by Wong Wei Kong as editor-in-chief of the English/Malay/Tamil Media Group (EMTM), Jaime Ho as editor of The Straits Times, and Chen Huifen as editor of The Business Times. The appointments mark significant changes to key leadership positions within the company.

site_title: Surprise treats for travellers as T2 departure hall reopens
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 2 departure hall has reopened after a two-year suspension, marking the final piece of Singapore's reopening strategy. The revamped terminal offers surprise treats for travellers, including free snacks and coffee, and is expected to handle around 70 million passengers per year. The reopening coincides with the resumption of flights to South-east Asia destinations, including Singapore Airlines, Air India, and Air India Express. The terminal's handling capacity is expected to boost the airport's overall capacity, and its renovation is scheduled to be completed by 2024.

site_title: $25m research programme to boost detection, treatment of glaucoma
summary: Singapore launches a $25 million research programme, Target, to reduce the rate of blindness caused by glaucoma over the next 10 years. The programme aims to improve diagnosis and treatment through AI-assisted screening, genetic testing, and innovative treatments. Glaucoma affects approximately 10% of Singapore's population, with up to 50% of patients undiagnosed due to lack of symptoms and screening models. The project will fund projects using AI to diagnose undiagnosed glaucoma, genetic risk factors, and new treatments, with the goal of significantly reducing blindness rates worldwide by 2040.

site_title: 'I opened the door and saw the man's face covered with blood'
summary: A 47-year-old man, identified as Eddie Seah Wee Teck, was found dead in his Yishun flat after a neighbor reported a suspicious person at the door. The victim had asked to be let into the building, then collapsed. His 19-year-old son was arrested and charged with murder, with police saying the crime occurred around 7:05pm on Monday. The motive behind the murder is not yet clear, and police investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Lauded for training youth to support their peers in distress
summary: The founder of Campus PSY, Mr Cho Ming Xiu, received a Leader of Good Award for training up to 150 young people every two years to identify and respond to mental health issues in their peers. Social enterprises Empact and Agape Connecting People also received awards for their cross-sector partnerships with corporations to develop training programs for social sector staff and job placement centers for former offenders and single mothers. The initiatives aim to address mental health concerns, skills gaps, and job opportunities in the social sector, with notable success in job placements and training sessions.

site_title: Key leadership changes on Oct 26 at The Straits Times, The Business Times
summary: Key leadership changes occurred at The Straits Times and The Business Times on October 26. Warren Fernandez, editor-in-chief of The Straits Times, is leaving the company to pursue other opportunities. He will be succeeded by Wong Wei Kong, who is taking over as EMTM editor-in-chief. Jaime Ho will become the new editor of The Straits Times, while Chen Huifen will become the editor of The Business Times. The changes aim to further transform the newsrooms into multimedia operations, meeting changing audience needs.

site_title: Doctor charged over death of patient after aesthetic treatment
summary: A Singaporean doctor, Chan Bingyi, has been charged with negligence after a 31-year-old woman, Ms Lau Li Ting, died in 2019 from EDTA toxicity following an aesthetic treatment. Chan allegedly administered EDTA at too high a concentration and too quickly, causing her cardiac arrest. The Ministry of Health's database shows Chan is still registered as a medical practitioner. He faces up to two years in jail if convicted of a negligent act not amounting to homicide. Additional charges are pending.

site_title: Phishing e-mails sent to over 5,000 consumers after hackers target Case
summary: Cyber attackers hacked the mail server of Singapore's Consumers Association of Singapore (Case), impersonating its officers and sending over 5,000 phishing e-mails to consumers. The e-mails asked recipients to participate in live chats and make payment transactions to receive monetary compensation. Case confirmed the hacking, but stated that only email addresses were compromised and personal info remained secure. The organization suspended affected mailboxes, reconfigured email accounts, and strengthened cyber security systems. Consumers are advised not to click on links or disclose personal details, and to report any suspicious transactions to the authorities.

site_title: Ex-security supervisor jailed after molesting girl, 16, in guardhouse
summary: A 58-year-old security supervisor was sentenced to 12 months' jail for molesting a 16-year-old girl while working at a condominium in Singapore. The incident occurred in February 2022, when the girl was temporarily employed as a security guard along with her stepfather. The supervisor molested her for 30 minutes despite her protests, and also offered her $100 to perform a sex act. The court considered the severe exploitation and lack of remorse from the accused, stating it was reasonable for the victim to trust her supervisor.

site_title: Tengah BTO flats to feature beamless design as part of trial
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) will trial a beamless design in two Build-To-Order (BTO) projects in Tengah, starting in November. The hybrid system uses 2D and 3D precast components, allowing for greater flexibility in flat layout design. This move aims to raise building productivity by 25% and adopt sustainable construction methods as part of its Construction Transformation Project. HDB will also pilot virtual models, artificial intelligence in crane operations, and fibre-glass reinforced concrete materials in the Tengah BTO projects.

site_title: Five-power defence nations to hold more exercises, exchanges
summary: Military chiefs from the Five Power Defence Arrangements (FPDA) nations, including Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore, and the UK, have agreed to resume exercises and exchanges, with activities gradually increasing as the global health situation improves. The decision comes after the pandemic scaled down activities over the past two years. The 21st FPDA Defence Chiefs' Conference, held in Singapore, also emphasized the need to update exercises to address emerging security challenges. The FPDA aims to maintain an open, inclusive, and resilient region, with its activities complementary to other regional partnerships.

site_title: New spanner in works for election at biggest motor trade body here
summary: A new candidate, Mr Arthur Ong, has emerged in the election for Singapore's biggest motor trade body, the Singapore Vehicle Traders Association (SVTA). Ong, an assistant project development officer, claims the inclusion of Mr Neo Tiam Ting as a candidate is unconstitutional. Ong has threatened to take legal action against the association for including Neo as a candidate, adding a new twist to the election saga. The election is set to take place, with Ong and Neo among the contenders for the SVTA presidency.

site_title: Report lists ways to lessen impact of Turf City station
summary: A heritage impact assessment report for Turf City station in Singapore's Cross Island Line (CRL) has found it possible to retain "sufficient heritage value" by preserving several historical sites, including the grandstands and secretaries' bungalows. The report recommended demolishing parts of the racetrack, stables, and hay barn to make way for the station. Contractors are advised to develop a protection plan for the preserved buildings and minimize disturbance. The report's findings aim to balance heritage preservation with the need to build the station, which is set to open in 2032.

site_title: Woman who claimed to be deity accused of cheating, causing hurt
summary: Woo May Hoe, a 52-year-old woman who claimed to be a deity, faces 50 charges of cheating, causing grievous hurt, and other offenses. She allegedly deceived at least 14 devotees, including forcing one to donate $3.5 million and others to swallow human faeces. Woo also conspired with followers to obtain bank loans, totaling over $5 million, and to settle unlicensed loans. She is expected to be back in court on November 17, with potential penalties including up to 10 years in jail and fines.

site_title: Thumb drive inventor gets jail for accounting fraud
summary: Henn Tan, founder of Trek 2000 International, a company that invented the thumb drive, was sentenced to one year and four months' jail for committing accounting fraud. Tan, 66, pleaded guilty to five charges of falsifying accounts, forging documents, and cheating external auditors between 2006 and 2011. He conspired to inflate revenue and pre-tax operating profit by $3.2 million, using false supporting documents. Tan's crimes were uncovered by auditors Ernst & Young, leading to a disclaimer of opinion for Trek 2000's financial statements for 2015.

site_title: 33 men caught smoking illegal cigarettes in Customs sting
summary: Singapore Customs has caught 33 men smoking duty-unpaid cigarettes in an operation across Chinatown and Geylang. Nine were Singaporeans, while 25 were issued composition sums ranging from $500 to $1,300. Two were issued advisories, and six are under investigation. The operation resulted in the seizure of 380 duty-unpaid cigarettes. Those caught may face fines up to 40 times the amount of duty and GST evaded, or imprisonment for up to six years. The incident highlights the risks of buying duty-unpaid cigarettes, with offenders potentially facing significant financial penalties.

site_title: Experts gather for conference on chemical, biological, radiological threats
summary: More than 100 international experts are attending a two-day conference in Singapore to discuss chemical, biological and radiological (CBR) threats. The inaugural Asean Defence Ministers' Meeting-Plus (ADMM-Plus) CBR Conference aims to strengthen the region's capacity to address non-state actor threats. Senior Minister of State for Defence Heng Chee How emphasized the need for cooperation and joint exercises to prevent major CBR terrorist attacks, citing examples of past threats, including Indonesia's foiled 2019 plot to use abrin-filled explosives.

site_title: Good reasons for Singapore's tough stance on drugs: Shanmugam
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam cited the mass shooting in Thailand, where at least 38 people, including 22 children, were killed, to justify Singapore's tough stance on drugs. The incident occurred three months after Thailand decriminalised cannabis, and the Thai Prime Minister has ordered a crackdown on drugs. Shanmugam also referenced a series of stabbings in Canada, where a perpetrator with a history of drug abuse and gang ties was involved. He emphasized that Singapore's stance on drugs is justified due to the link between substance abuse and violent crimes.

site_title: Musk alleges Twitter whistle-blower ordered to burn evidence
summary: Elon Musk alleges that Twitter officials ordered a whistle-blower, Peiter Zatko, to destroy evidence of the company's missteps as part of a $7.8 million severance package. Zatko, Twitter's former head of security, burned 10 notebooks and deleted 100 files at the company's request. Musk claims this prevents him from corroborating evidence in a lawsuit over a $44 billion buyout. Twitter's lawyers are accused of silencing Zatko, and Musk's lawyers are seeking sanctions. The case is set to resume on October 28.

site_title: Over 1,000 Singaporean Mandarin terms in online database
summary: Singapore's Promote Mandarin Council launched an online database in 2019 featuring over 1,000 unique Singaporean Mandarin terms. The database highlights the cultural significance of these terms, which reflect the unique identity of Chinese Singaporeans and Singapore's multicultural society. Keynote speakers, including National Institute of Education associate professor Tan Chee Lay, will discuss the importance of preserving Singaporean Mandarin at a free public seminar in October. The database has been used in schools and academic conferences, and a bilingual book set is planned for publication in 2023.

site_title: Dispute involving Ong Teng Cheong's elder son settled
summary: A legal dispute between Ong Teng Cheong's elder son and his former sister-in-law, Madam Wang Yi Yi, has been settled. The settlement does not address the ownership of an award-winning Art Deco bungalow in the Dalvey Estate, which remains a point of contention. Details of the settlement are not disclosed.

site_title: Chipmaker stock rout engulfs TSMC, Samsung with $346b wiped out in sector
summary: The US administration announced export curbs on China's access to US semiconductor technology, sparking a sell-off in chip-related stocks globally. The sector's market value has been wiped out by over $240 billion, with TSMC, Samsung Electronics, and Tokyo Electron experiencing significant declines. Analysts predict a knock-on impact across the supply chain and growing challenges for technology shares, including the Federal Reserve and tensions in the Taiwan Strait. The curbs are seen as a setback to China's localization efforts and may force companies to lose Chinese customers in the future.

site_title: IMF cuts Asia's growth forecasts amid uncertainty over recovery
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut Asia's economic growth forecasts, citing rising inflation and slowing growth in trade partners. The downgrade expects emerging Asian economies to grow 4.4% in 2022 and 4.9% in 2023, down from previous projections. China's growth is expected to slow to 3.2% in 2022 and rebound to 4.4% in 2023, while the US dollar is expected to strengthen, worsening debt woes for emerging economies. Global growth is forecast to slow further in 2023, with over a third of the global economy at risk of contraction.

site_title: Top buyers of US bonds all bailing out at once
