summary: Major buyers of US Treasury bonds, including Japanese pensions and life insurers, foreign governments, and American commercial banks, are suddenly pulling back, raising concerns over the market's stability. This exodus of demand, combined with the US Federal Reserve's decision to sell $60 billion in Treasuries monthly, has led to a surge in yields, with 30-year US bonds reaching their highest level since 2014. Experts warn that more pain may be in store until new sources of demand emerge, ultimately affecting US taxpayers and increasing borrowing costs.

site_title: Condo resales up amid tight new home supply, rising launch prices
summary: Condominium resale volumes increased in September, rising 1.1% from August and 22.8% from the same period last year, driven by limited new private home stock and rising launch prices. Condo resale prices gained 1.7% for the 26th consecutive month, with prices up 11.1% from September 2021. HDB upgraders accounted for 60.9% of total sales volume, with resale prices in the suburbs or outside central region rising 12.9% for the year. However, the introduction of cooling measures may impact the market, with some analysts predicting a temporary pullback or slowdown.

site_title: Company briefs: Glencore HSBC BYD
summary: Glencore faces class-action-style lawsuits from British investment and pension funds over market manipulation and bribery, linked to a US$1 billion fine. HSBC Global Private Banking expands into Chinese cities, targeting wealth growth uncertainties. BYD enters India's mainstream car market with its first electric SUV, the Atto 3, after investing US$200 million.

site_title: 'Boring' Max to bring out his best
summary: Maximilian Maeder, a 16-year-old kitefoiler, recently secured his title at the Formula Kite European Championships in Greece with a hard-fought win. He qualified straight for the finals and won the championship with just one race, showcasing his skills. This triumph boosts his confidence ahead of the crucial World Meet, where he will face stiff competition. Maeder's victory demonstrates his capabilities as a kitefoiler, and he is now poised to take on the best in the world.

site_title: S'pore stocks fall for fourth day as key Asian markets tumble
summary: Singapore stocks fell for the fourth consecutive day, tracking a decline in most Asian markets following a negative session on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index dropped 0.1% to 3,105.00, with tech firms and semiconductor stocks among the biggest losers. Shares of Venture Corp and Jardine C&C fell 2.1% and 3.4%, respectively. Key indexes in Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea also declined, with semiconductor stocks feeling the impact of US curbs on China's access to US technology.

site_title: A space where vulnerable youngsters learn not to be afraid | The Straits Times
summary: A non-profit arts organization called 3Pumpkins has been running a club called Tak Takut, which means "not afraid" in Malay, since 2019. The club aims to build trust in children and provide a sense of belonging by offering various arts, sports, and free play programs. Founded by Ms. Lin Shiyun, the club welcomes children aged 7-14 and has hosted over 200 members, with around 40 attending daily. All activities are free, and the club is partially funded by the Quantedge Foundation and the Singapore Together Movement.

site_title: In-principle MAS nod for crypto exchange Coinbase
summary: Coinbase, the largest US-based cryptocurrency exchange, has received an in-principle approval from Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to offer digital asset payment services. This approval comes as the firm continues to expand its presence in the region, with a significant tech hub in Singapore and plans to hire and train professionals on Web3 technologies. The move aligns with Singapore's efforts to establish itself as a crypto hub, despite recent market volatility and regulatory proposals aimed at stabilizing the industry.

site_title: Global PC shipments suffer worst drop amid slowdown, inventory glut
summary: The global PC market experienced its steepest decline on record, with shipments falling 19.5% in the third quarter of 2022 compared to the previous year. This drop echoes similar declines seen by Canalys and is attributed to economic uncertainty and inventory glut. The market slowdown is also linked to restrictions on chip and technology exports to China. Despite robust hiring numbers, economic headwinds are expected to impact IT spending, with the market likely to recover by the second half of 2023, according to analysts. Lenovo remained the top PC maker, but HP saw the largest decline.

site_title: Big Hearted hit-out
summary: Trainer Michael Clements' horse Big Hearted, a 2020 Singapore Gold Cup winner, is considered a contender for the Group 1 QEII Cup with its impressive 600m Polytrack run. Clements has four horses in the race, including Prosperous Return and Tangible. Big Hearted's previous performances, including a second-place finish in the 2021 Singapore Derby, suggest it has the ability to compete in the 1,800m QEII Cup. Other strong contenders include Hard Too Think, a consistent performer in big races, and Senor Don, who is gunning for four consecutive wins.

site_title: New energy sources not ready yet to meet rising demand: Oil exec
summary: A top Saudi Aramco executive, Mohammed Al Qahtani, states that alternative energy sources are not yet ready to meet the rising global energy demand, particularly in high-growth regions like Asia. He emphasizes the need for continued investment in oil and gas, as well as new energy solutions, to ensure a sustainable and affordable energy transition. This investment will be crucial for an orderly energy transition.

site_title: Simeone hoping for a turnaround
summary: Atletico Madrid faces a crucial match against Group B leaders Club Brugge, with the Belgian side seeking a point to book their place in the Champions League knockout stage. The match is a must-win for Atletico, who are bottom in the group and need a result to revive their chances. Coach Diego Simeone is hopeful of a turnaround, citing their solid home record, and will be without key players Sergio Reguilon, Felipe, and Marcos Llorente due to injury. Ferran Jutgla, Brugge's top scorer, is expected to pose a threat to Atletico's defense.

site_title: Ronaldo to face FA hearing over improper conduct
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo will face an English Football Association hearing to settle a charge of improper conduct over an incident at Everton in April. Ronaldo was caught on camera knocking a mobile phone out of an underage Everton fan's hand, causing the phone to be smashed. His mother, Sarah Kelly, has expressed frustration and disappointment with Ronaldo's actions, calling for him to be held accountable. A possible outcome could include a fine and/or ban if Ronaldo is found guilty.

site_title: World champ v World No. 1
summary: Singapore's top athletes, including badminton star Loh Kean Yew and former world No. 1 pool player Aloysius Yapp, have been shortlisted for the Sportsman of the Year award. Meanwhile, bowler Shayna Ng is in the running for a hat-trick of Sportswoman of the Year successes. The Singapore Sports Awards will take place on Nov 10 to honour national athletes and coaches for their achievements in 2021, with other finalists including Amita Berthier and Yu Mengyu.

site_title: Tuesday's gallops by horses engaged at Kranji on Saturday
summary: Racing results from Kranji on Tuesday and Monday show various horses emerging victorious in their respective races. In the Queen Elizabeth II Cup Group 1, Sacred Croix won with a time of 39.4 seconds, followed by Mr Malek and Senor Don. In the Class 3 and Class 4 races, winners included In All His Glory, Prosperous Return, and Lim's Craft, among others. The results will be crucial in determining the top performers in the racing circuit.

site_title: Kane looking to break his scoring duck in Europe
summary: Tottenham is set to face Eintracht Frankfurt in the Champions League, with the momentum of their solid start to the season potentially helping them overcome the fixture crunch. The team is third in the Premier League, four points behind leaders Arsenal, and second in Group D of the Champions League. Harry Kane, who has scored eight goals in the league but none in the Champions League, is eager to break his scoring duck in Europe, and victory against Frankfurt could move Tottenham closer to the knockout stage.

site_title: Rafeef's Choice is worth following
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

South Africa's form analysis focuses on upcoming races, with several horses showing promising performances. Rafeef's Choice is expected to open her account in Race 3, while Academic Gold and Official Secret are threats in Race 1. In Race 4, Future Turn and Run Rudolph Run are closely matched, and Galactic Path and Shavout are likely to compete in Race 5. Other notable horses include Swift Action in Race 6 and Bright Green in Race 7, who are expected to improve and contest the outcome. The analysis provides insights into the horses' strengths and potential performances.

site_title: Bullying 'serious issue' in football
summary: A survey of 843 football players in the Premier League and English Football League found nearly 10% had suffered bullying, with almost 5% experiencing suicidal thoughts. The Professional Footballers' Association (PFA) released the data to coincide with World Mental Health Day, highlighting the social and mental health challenges faced by current and former players. The PFA is adapting its well-being workshops to address bullying, and offers counselling and support services to its members, with 520 players using these services in the 2021-22 season.

site_title: Circuit Elite on the up and up
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

At Happy Valley, top trainers and jockeys are set to dominate the racing scene. Trainer Benno Yung and jockey Zac Purton combined for a treble on Sunday and are expected to win the first two races. Other trainers, such as Jamie Richards and Pierre Ng, are also fielding strong contenders. Favorites like Everyone's Delight, Shenron, and Smiling Face are expected to take the top spots in their respective races. The Hong Kong Jockey Club's top riders and trainers are expected to make a strong showing, with several horses looking to improve their form.

site_title: Bronny James signs Nike deal for 'family legacy'
summary: Bronny James, the 18-year-old son of NBA superstar LeBron James, has signed a Nike deal as part of the company's marketing for its newest sneaker, the Nike LeBron 20. Bronny is the eldest of five amateur basketball players to sign endorsement deals with Nike, alongside his father, who has a lifetime deal worth over $1 billion. Bronny, a Sierra Canyon High School guard, aims to play college basketball before entering the NBA draft. The deal marks the beginning of Bronny's family legacy with Nike, as his father has been with the brand since his youth.

site_title: Sports World: Atcher axed from Rugby World Cup job
summary: Chief executive Claude Atcher of the 2023 Rugby World Cup was sacked after a probe found evidence of a "deep social malaise" within the organization. Atcher was suspended by France's sports minister in August due to "alarming managerial practices."

site_title: Lewandowski's supply chain out of sorts
summary: Barcelona coach Xavi Hernandez is seeking answers as the team's form dips ahead of a crucial home match against Inter Milan. The team's struggles coincide with Robert Lewandowski's goal drought, having netted only one goal in the last three matches. Lewandowski has created chances for himself but his teammates have failed to capitalize. A win against Inter would be crucial for Barcelona's La Liga title hopes and avoiding the Europa League, but Inter's suffocating defense may hinder Lewandowski's chances.

site_title: Call for 'open' category for rowers
summary: The chair of British Rowing, Mark Davies, has called for World Rowing to create an "open" category for transgender athletes, similar to swimming's governing body Fina. Currently, World Rowing allows athletes to compete in the female category after reducing testosterone levels for 12 months. Davies suggests this policy may be too lenient, citing concerns about a potential unfair advantage. The move follows similar changes in other sports, such as triathlon and football's Fifa, which are reviewing their guidelines on transgender athlete participation.

site_title: Konate eyes Liverpool reset in Champs League
summary: Liverpool faces a crucial Champions League match against Rangers on Wednesday, with a win needed to secure qualification for the knockout stage. The Reds, led by Jurgen Klopp, will travel to Scotland without Luis Diaz, Joel Matip, and Trent Alexander-Arnold due to injuries. A victory would leave Liverpool on nine points with two games remaining, putting them on the cusp of advancing to the last 16 for the sixth straight time. French defender Ibrahima Konate is aware of the team's frustration and the importance of the match in boosting morale.

site_title: Orlando Pride coaches sacked for 'retaliatory conduct'
summary: The National Women's Soccer League (NWSL) terminated the contracts of Orlando Pride coaches Amanda Cromwell and Sam Greene due to retaliatory conduct against players. The decision comes after a joint investigation found the coaches violated the league's policy on discrimination, harassment, and bullying. Cromwell and Greene were on administrative leave since June 6. The league also stated that Cromwell and Greene are ineligible to work in the NWSL until approved by the commissioner. The move aims to protect and advocate for players and find a new head coach who embodies the organization's values.

site_title: Over 1,300 fans cannot travel to World Cup
summary: The British Home Office has announced measures to prevent over 1,300 fans from England and Wales with banning orders from traveling to Qatar for the 2022 World Cup. Those subject to football banning orders must hand in their passports, and those who want to travel elsewhere will need permission to keep their passports and face checks at ports of exit. Those caught trying to go to Qatar will face a banning-order court hearing within 24 hours, with penalties including six months in prison and an unlimited fine. The measures aim to prevent violence and disorder at the tournament.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Upcoming sports and tennis events include UEFA Champions League Group A matches (Napoli vs Ajax and Barcelona vs Inter), UEFA Conference League Group B matches (West Ham vs Anderlecht and Betis vs Roma), ATP Tour Gijon Open, and WTA Tour San Diego Open. Track World Championships will take place on Friday, while the DP World Tour Andalucia Masters golf tournament begins on Thursday.

site_title: Matsuyama shuns LIV, Woods now at new low
summary: Hideki Matsuyama has reaffirmed his commitment to the PGA Tour, denying rumors that he was considering joining the breakaway LIV Invitational Golf Series. Matsuyama, the 2021 Masters winner, will defend his title at the Zozo Championship in Japan, facing a stacked field. Meanwhile, Tiger Woods has reached a career-low 1,206th in the world golf rankings and will not compete in the tournament due to his ongoing hiatus from the sport.

site_title: Why a career break means you should start thinking about your retirement plan
summary: A recent Prudential Singapore survey found that 1 in 5 residents who have resigned or intend to leave their jobs since the pandemic expect a 6-year delay in retirement, pushing back the average retirement age from 58 to 64. The survey also revealed that nearly half of respondents are unprepared for retirement, with many relying on Central Provident Fund (CPF) and bank savings as their primary source of retirement income. Experts emphasize the importance of early retirement planning and investing in various financial instruments to ensure a secure retirement.

site_title: Proposals to strengthen gig worker protections on track to be finalised by year end
summary: Singapore's Advisory Committee on Platform Workers is set to finalize proposals to strengthen gig worker protections by the end of the year. The committee, established in 2021, aims to improve retirement and housing adequacy, work injury compensation, and bargaining power for platform workers such as cabbies, private-hire car drivers, and deliverymen. The recommendations, expected to be released in the second half of 2022, will be followed by further engagement with workers and platform companies to operationalize the proposals, potentially leading to legislation to enforce the changes.

site_title: Grab the chance to see S'pore Sail GP up close
summary: Organisers of the Singapore Sail Grand Prix have released ticket details for the event on January 14-15 at East Coast Park. Tickets range from $18 for children to $28 for adults and $388 for the "Bring Your Own Boat" category. The event will feature nine international teams competing in six fleet races and one top-three shoot-out. Spectators can access waterfront areas, watch live broadcasts, and explore the race village with exclusive behind-the-scenes tours and private hospitality options available. The event is the eighth leg of the 11-stop global Sail GP championship.

site_title: Money woes cut short W Series
summary: The W Series, an all-female motor racing series, has cancelled its remaining three races due to financial struggles, citing a cash crunch and the devaluation of the British pound. Despite this, founder Catherine Bond Muir remains confident that the series will return next year. Jamie Chadwick has been declared the champion for the third season in a row, with a 50-point lead over Dutch rival Beitske Visser. The series' financial woes highlight the challenges faced by women in sports, with Bond Muir citing a broader disparity between women's and men's sports.

site_title: Football: Liverpool's problems mount as Matip, Alexander-Arnold join injury list
summary: Liverpool defenders Joel Matip and Trent Alexander-Arnold will be sidelined for at least two weeks due to injuries sustained during their 3-2 loss to Arsenal. Matip has a calf injury and Alexander-Arnold has an ankle problem. This is the latest setback for Jurgen Klopp's team, which already lost Luis Diaz until December with a knee injury. Ibrahima Konate is set to start alongside Virgil van Dijk at Rangers, while Joe Gomez and James Milner may fill in at right-back. Klopp's team is struggling in the Premier League, 14 points off the top, with several key players out of action.

site_title: Football: Pep Guardiola admits 10-man City are 'so tired' after Copenhagen draw
summary: Manchester City, managed by Pep Guardiola, drew 0-0 against FC Copenhagen in the Champions League, despite playing with 10 men for an hour after Sergio Gomez was sent off. The 0-0 result allowed City to advance to the knockout stages with two games to spare. City forward Riyad Mahrez missed a penalty, and the team struggled to score without Erling Haaland, who was rested ahead of their next match against Liverpool. Guardiola praised his team's effort, saying they gave "absolutely everything" despite being "so tired."

site_title: A smart district that fosters collaboration and partnerships among innovators
summary: Singapore's Punggol Digital District, the country's first tech-enabled and sustainable smart district, is set to open in phases from 2024. The district will feature an Open Digital Platform (ODP) that enables communication and integration among different operating systems. Partnering with local firms, the district aims to foster collaboration and innovation. Key partners include the Singapore Institute of Technology, dConstruct, Group-IB, and Delta Electronics, which will utilize the ODP to enhance their projects. The district will also feature smart and sustainable amenities, such as electric autonomous buses and smart parking systems.

site_title: Social enterprises and corporates win awards for training youth, social sector staff
summary: President Halimah Yacob presented awards to 11 winners of the President's Volunteerism and Philanthropy Awards for their efforts to train young people and social sector staff. The awards recognized initiatives such as Campus PSY's mental health training for youth and social enterprises like Empact and Agape Connecting People, which partnered with corporations to provide training and job placement services to vulnerable groups. The awards aim to encourage more corporates to step up their philanthropic efforts, with President Halimah praising the 112 companies recognized as Champions of Good.

site_title: AI to help detect glaucoma early among research projects to be funded under $25m programme
summary: Singapore has launched a $25 million research programme to diagnose and treat glaucoma early, aiming to significantly reduce blindness caused by the disease over the next 10 years. The programme, led by the Singapore National Eye Centre, will focus on identifying glaucoma risk factors, improving diagnosis, and innovating new treatments. It will also use artificial intelligence to screen for undiagnosed glaucoma in communities, with the goal of improving patient care and cost savings for healthcare systems. The programme is expected to benefit approximately 10% of Singapore's population, who are at risk of undiagnosed glaucoma.

site_title: More than 5,000 phishing e-mails impersonating Case officers sent after cyber attack
summary: Cyber attackers impersonated Singapore's Consumer Association of Singapore (Case) officers, sending over 5,095 phishing e-mails to more than 5,000 consumers. The emails, sent from hacked mailboxes, requested payment transactions for monetary compensation. Case confirmed the unauthorized access was limited to email addresses, and all personal information remained secure. The association has suspended affected mailboxes, strengthened its cybersecurity systems, and reported the incident to the police and Personal Data Protection Commission. Consumers are advised not to click on links or disclose personal details, and to report any suspicious transactions to the authorities.

site_title: 11,732 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore; spike driven by XBB variant but severe cases remain low
summary: Singapore reported 11,732 new Covid-19 cases, more than doubling from the previous day, driven by the XBB variant. Despite the spike, severe cases remain low, likely due to vaccination and previous waves of infection. The majority of patients exhibit mild symptoms, with 11 ICU cases and 50 requiring oxygen supplementation. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is taking action against online falsehoods circulating on WhatsApp, and the number of severe cases is "just slightly higher" than past levels.

site_title: More FPDA exercises to resume as Covid-19 situation improves: Military chiefs
summary: Singapore's military chiefs have announced plans to resume more exercises and exchanges with the Five Power Defence Arrangements (FPDA) nations, including Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, and the UK, following improvements in the Covid-19 situation. The 21st FPDA Defence Chiefs' Conference, held in person for the first time since the pandemic, concluded with a joint statement allowing nations to gradually resume exercises and activities. The updated exercises will focus on conventional and non-conventional security challenges, and will include humanitarian assistance and disaster relief drills.

site_title: There are good reasons why S'pore is tough on drugs, says Shanmugam in comments on Thai shooting
summary: Singapore's tough stance on drugs was reinforced by Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam, who cited the mass shooting in a Thai childcare centre as an example. At least 38 people, including 22 children, were killed by a former police officer who had been facing a drug charge. Shanmugam criticized activists who have been critical of Singapore's stance, saying they have been silent following the incident. He also noted that Thailand has ordered a clampdown on drugs, three months after decriminalizing cannabis, and questioned the effectiveness of this measure.

site_title: Bank of England intervenes again in bond market, warns of 'material risk' to financial stability
summary: The Bank of England has intervened again in the UK bond market, warning of a "material risk" to financial stability. The central bank will buy up to £5 billion of index-linked debt per day until the end of the week to stem a sharp sell-off in the £2.1 trillion government bond market. This move comes amid concerns about the impact of unfunded tax cuts and pension fund emergency collateral. The Bank of England cited "self-reinforcing 'fire sale' dynamics" and the need to prevent a market collapse, as investors worry about the future of the market after emergency support measures end on Friday.

site_title: Golf: Tiger hits new ranking low but excites fans at par-three course
summary: Former world No. 1 Tiger Woods has sunk to a career-low ranking of 1,206th in the world golf rankings after numerous back and leg injuries. The 46-year-old golfer, a 15-time Major winner, had spent 683 weeks atop the rankings but tumbled after a 2021 car crash and subsequent injuries. Woods made a limited comeback, returning to competition in April's Masters but withdrawing from the PGA Championship and British Open. Despite his current low ranking, Woods delighted fans with recent social media posts showcasing his skills at a par-three course.

site_title: Ex-security supervisor jailed for a year after molesting girl, 16, in guardhouse
summary: A 58-year-old security supervisor in Singapore was sentenced to 12 months' jail for molesting a 16-year-old girl while she worked as a temporary security guard at a condominium in February 2022. The victim told the supervisor to stop multiple times, but he continued the assault for 30 minutes, and later offered her $100 to perform a sex act. The supervisor pleaded guilty to two charges of sexual exploitation of a young person and was found to have been remorseless and intended to cover up the incident.

site_title: $22m to develop maritime decarbonisation and digitalisation projects over next five years
summary: Singapore has allocated $22 million over the next five years to develop maritime decarbonisation and digitalisation projects. The Singapore Maritime Institute will collaborate with two local universities, Nanyang Technological University and National University of Singapore, on research initiatives focusing on alternative energy sources, decarbonisation, and operational efficiency. The projects align with Singapore's energy strategy to switch to low-carbon alternatives, and are part of a broader effort to reduce emissions and improve maritime operations.

site_title: 'I saw the man's face covered with blood': Neighbour recalls scene of Yishun murder
summary: A 47-year-old businessman, Mr Eddie Seah Wee Teck, was found dead in his Yishun apartment after a 19-year-old man, his son, was arrested for murder. The victim was discovered motionless on the floor with blood covering his face and clothes. The suspect, believed to be the youngest child, was seen holding a metallic object before the victim collapsed. Police received a call for help at 7:05pm on Monday and pronounced the victim dead at the scene. The suspect is expected to be charged with murder on Wednesday.

site_title: Beamless flats, smart crane systems to be piloted in Tengah BTO flats in productivity push
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) is set to pilot beamless flats and smart crane systems in two Build-To-Order projects in Tengah, aiming to boost building productivity by 25% by 2030. The beamless design allows for greater flexibility in unit layout, while the smart crane systems use AI and sensors to optimize hoisting routes and reduce waste. HDB will also test sustainable construction methods, including virtual models and fibre-glass reinforced concrete materials, to achieve a 40% increase in construction productivity.

site_title: Condo resales up as more HDB upgraders priced out by new launch prices
summary: Condominium resale volumes rose 1.1% in September, driven by limited new private home stock and high new launch prices, which priced out Housing Board upgraders. The highest resale price reached $17.6 million for a unit at Reflections at Keppel Bay. Condo resale prices maintained a 1.7% gain for the 26th consecutive month, with suburban private homes accounting for 60.9% of total sales. The resale market may face a slowdown due to the recent cooling measures, but tight new home supply and private home owners switching to the resale market could mitigate the impact.

site_title: New spanner in the works for election at Singapore's biggest motor trade body
summary: A new twist has emerged in the Singapore Vehicle Traders Association (SVTA) election saga. The election, initially set for Sept 23, was halted in the High Court after Mr Arthur Ong, a contender for president, protested the inclusion of Mr Neo Tiam Ting as a running candidate, claiming it was unconstitutional. Ong sent an email to association members on Oct 5 expressing his concerns, potentially threatening legal action. The outcome of the election remains uncertain, leaving the association's future leadership uncertain.

site_title: Contagious nature of Omicron variant helped societies transition to living with Covid-19: Study
summary: A study by Duke-NUS Medical School and the National Centre for Infectious Diseases found that the contagious nature of the Omicron variant helped highly vaccinated populations transition to living with Covid-19. The Omicron variant conferred "mucosal immunity" and resulted in more people acquiring hybrid immunity, better protecting against reinfection. It also led to milder infections and lower rates of lung infections in vaccinated and boosted patients. The findings suggest that future vaccines should aim to provide broader protection against emerging variants.

site_title: Sailing: Tickets for Singapore Sail Grand Prix on sale now
summary: Tickets for the Singapore Sail Grand Prix are now available, with prices starting at $28 for waterfront access and $18 for children aged 7 and up. The event, taking place on January 14-15, will feature nine international teams competing in six fleet races and one top-three shootout. Spectators can also opt for a Team Base Tour ($28) or Bring Your Own Boat ($388) for a closer experience. Private hospitality Platinum Suites are also available, offering premium food and beverage options. The event is part of the 11-stop global Sail GP championship.

site_title: Woman convinced followers she was deity and got them to give her millions, eat faeces
summary: A 52-year-old woman, Woo May Hoe, faces 50 charges for deceiving and harming her devotees in a nine-year period. She convinced followers to donate millions, eat human faeces, and undergo physical harm, including a follower's tooth extraction and assault. Woo also obtained bank loans using false income claims and misled followers about loan repayments. She faces up to 10 years in jail if convicted, with charges including cheating, grievous hurt, and causing harm by means of a substance.

site_title: Experts discuss chemical, biological, radiological threats at S’pore conference
summary: Singapore hosts a two-day conference to discuss chemical, biological, and radiological (CBR) threats, attended by over 100 delegates from 20 countries and international organizations. Senior Minister of State for Defence Heng Chee How emphasized the real threat posed by non-state actors, citing Indonesia's 2019 foiled plot to use abrin-filled explosives. Experts stress the need for close cooperation and joint exercises to address CBR incidents, as these threats are transborder and transnational, and can cause mass casualties. The conference aims to strengthen the region's capacity to counter CBR threats.

site_title: SPH Media Group announces leadership changes at The Straits Times and The Business Times
summary: SPH Media Group announced leadership changes at The Straits Times and The Business Times, effective October 26. Warren Fernandez, current editor-in-chief of English/Malay/Tamil Media group, will leave to pursue other opportunities. Wong Wei Kong, current editor of BT, will succeed Fernandez as EMTM editor-in-chief, while Jaime Ho, former chief editor of CNA Digital, will become ST editor. Chen Huifen, BT's current executive editor, will be BT editor. The changes aim to transform the newsrooms into multimedia operations to meet changing audience needs.

site_title: Kite boarding: European C'ships win a confidence boost for Max Maeder ahead of World C'ships
summary: Maximilian Maeder, a 16-year-old kiteboarder, won the Formula Kite European Championships, securing his first-place title with a dominant performance in the final race. He qualified straight for the finals and only needed one race to retain his title, but struggled in the second final, finishing behind other competitors due to a bad start. This victory provides a confidence boost for Maeder ahead of the upcoming World Championships.

site_title: Ex-president Ong Teng Cheong's family settles dispute, but Dalvey Estate bungalow's fate unclear
summary: Former Singapore president Ong Teng Cheong's family has settled a legal dispute between his elder son and his former sister-in-law, Madam Wang Yi Yi. The dispute resolution does not affect the ownership or fate of the family's award-winning Art Deco bungalow in the Dalvey Estate, which remains unclear.

site_title: Global PC shipments suffer worst drop as China chip curbs loom
summary: Global PC shipments declined 19.5% in the third quarter of 2022, the largest drop on record, due to economic uncertainty and inventory gluts. Lenovo remained the top PC maker, with a 15% drop in shipments. Chip curbs imposed by the US on China have led to a market slowdown, with major chipmakers like Taiwan Semiconductor and AMD facing significant declines. The market is expected to recover by the second half of 2023, but economic headwinds may impact IT spending for both business and personal use.

site_title: Hong Kong property market tumbling as unsold homes pile up
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a downturn, with unsold homes piling up after sales failed to meet expectations. Luxury projects are being priced lower than second-hand homes, yet still struggling to attract buyers. Experts predict a 30% decline in home prices in 2023 and a potential economic contraction this year. The city's shrinking labor force, diminished appeal to mainland buyers, and tightening monetary environment are contributing to the decline.

site_title: Badminton's Loh, pool player Yapp up for top award at returning Singapore Sports Awards
summary: Badminton star Loh Kean Yew and former world No.1 pool player Aloysius Yapp have been shortlisted for the Sportsman of the Year award at the Singapore Sports Awards. Loh achieved a milestone in 2021 by becoming the first Singaporean to win the BWF World Championship, while Yapp rose to the top of his game's ranking. Other finalists include bowler Shayna Ng, who won the gold medal in the women's singles at the International Bowling Federation Super World Championships, and table tennis players Yu Mengyu and Feng Tianwei.

site_title: Doctor charged with causing death of patient after aesthetic treatment
summary: A 34-year-old Singaporean doctor, Chan Bingyi, has been charged with causing the death of 31-year-old patient Ms Lau Li Ting after allegedly administering ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) during an aesthetic treatment in 2019. Chan is accused of administering the substance at too high a concentration and too quickly, leading to EDTA toxicity, cardiac arrest, and her eventual death. He is out on $5,000 bail and faces up to two years in jail if convicted. The incident occurred at Revival Medical and Aesthetics Centre in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals grow for 8th straight month in September to 752,305
summary: Singapore reported a record 778,141 international visitor arrivals in September, extending the country's growth streak for the eighth consecutive month. Indonesia remained the top source of arrivals with 115,433 visitors, followed by India with 83,265 and Malaysia with 79,692. However, China, Singapore's largest inbound market from 2017-2019, saw a significant decline in visitors, sending just 13,601 in September. The year-to-date total of 3.7 million international visitor arrivals falls short of the STB's expectation of 4-6 million visitors for the year.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase gets in-principle nod from Singapore authorities
summary: Coinbase, the largest US-based cryptocurrency exchange, has received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to offer digital asset payment services. This nod follows the firm's efforts to build its presence in Singapore, with nearly 100 employees and plans to hire more. The move aligns with the firm's Singapore plans, which include establishing the city as its Asia-Pacific tech hub. The approval is seen as a key institutional market for Coinbase in Asia, given Singapore's talent pool and regulatory leadership.

site_title: 2 more Mie Sedaap instant noodles recalled due to pesticide, a total of 6 products affected
summary: Singapore's Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has recalled six Mie Sedaap instant noodle products due to contamination with ethylene oxide, a pesticide not authorized for use in food. The products, including Kari Spesial and Korean Spicy Chicken flavors, were found to have chilli powder contaminated with the chemical. The manufacturer, PT Wings Surya, will withdraw the products from the market and reformulate them. Consumers are advised not to consume the products, and those who have consumed them are encouraged to seek medical advice. The recall is part of efforts to ensure food safety in Singapore.

site_title: Thumb drive inventor and Trek 2000 founder Henn Tan jailed for accounting fraud
summary: Henn Tan, founder of Trek 2000 and inventor of the thumb drive, was sentenced to one year and four months in jail for accounting fraud. Tan pleaded guilty to five charges of conspiring to falsify accounts, forge documents, and cheat external auditors. He conspired with former CFO Gurcharan Singh to inflate revenue and pre-tax operating profit by $3.2 million, and falsified financial statements for Trek 2000's 2015 financial year. Tan's crimes undermined the integrity of the financial and securities market, and he was also fined $80,000 for a previous offense.

site_title: Australia to avoid recession even as world slows, treasurer says
summary: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the country is well-positioned to avoid recession due to low unemployment and high commodity prices. Chalmers expects the Australian economy to weather a global downturn, citing the country's strong domestic conditions. He will deliver his first budget in two weeks to tackle spiralling inflation and provide relief to households, while also investing in supply chains and skills training. The Reserve Bank of Australia has slowed its policy tightening, contrasting with the US Federal Reserve, which has delivered consecutive 75 basis-point hikes.

site_title: Roll-out of Moderna Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine brought forward to Oct 14
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Health has announced that the Moderna Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine will be rolled out three days earlier than scheduled, starting October 14. The vaccine targets the original Sars-CoV-2 strain and the Omicron BA.1 variant, and has shown effectiveness against other variants. Eligible individuals aged 50 and above, or those below 50 with medical vulnerabilities, can walk-in for the vaccine at nine joint testing and vaccination centers. The move comes as Singapore reports a rising number of Covid-19 infections, with the XBB sub-variant currently making up 55% of cases.

site_title: askST: What you need to know about Singapore's new Covid-19 vaccination strategy
summary: Singapore has shifted its Covid-19 vaccination strategy to focus on being up-to-date, rather than counting the number of doses received. The new approach requires individuals to have received at least the minimum protection, which includes three doses of mRNA vaccines or the Novavax/Nuvaxovid vaccine, or four shots of Sinovac-Coronvac or Sinopharm vaccines. The government has also lifted all remaining vaccination-differentiated measures, including requirements for vaccination for events and dining in. Booster doses are recommended for those aged 50 and above, and specific guidelines are provided for different age groups.

site_title: Football: More than 1,300 British fans banned from attending World Cup by UK Home Office
summary: The UK Home Office has banned over 1,300 British football fans from attending the World Cup in Qatar due to a history of football-related violence. The ban, which takes effect from Friday, prevents supporters deemed likely to cause trouble from traveling. Those who flout the rules could face six months in prison and unlimited fines. Home Secretary Suella Braverman stated that the measures aim to prevent "the behaviour of a minority of lawbreakers" from tarnishing the tournament.

site_title: Alternative energy sources not yet keeping pace with demand, says top Saudi Aramco exec
summary: Saudi Aramco's senior vice-president, Mohammed Al Qahtani, states that alternative energy sources are not yet ready to meet rising global energy demand, particularly in Asia. The ongoing energy crisis highlights the need for continued investment in the oil and gas sector and conventional energy solutions to ensure a smooth energy transition. Al Qahtani emphasizes the importance of growing Saudi Aramco's business in Asia, despite this challenge.

site_title: Basketball: LeBron James' 18-year-old son Bronny signs Nike endorsement deal
summary: Bronny James, the 18-year-old son of NBA superstar LeBron James, has signed a Nike endorsement deal. He is one of five amateur basketball players, including three women, to join the company's marketing efforts. The deal includes Bronny's involvement in Nike's newest sneaker, the Nike LeBron 20. No financial terms were disclosed. This signing follows in LeBron James' footsteps, who signed a lifetime Nike deal in 2015. The move marks a potential step towards Bronny playing in the NBA alongside his father.

site_title: Special treats await travellers at Changi Airport T2 to mark terminal's reopening
summary: Changi Airport's revamped Terminal 2 departure hall reopened on Tuesday with special treats for travelers, including free coffee and snacks. The move marks the final piece of Singapore's reopening strategy, with all four terminals now open and handling capacity restored to around 70 million passengers per year. The first day saw a total of 17 Singapore Airlines flights depart, with more flights expected to begin from October 13. The terminal's renovation is expected to boost its handling capacity to 28 million passengers annually by 2024.

site_title: Glencore faces flood of investor lawsuits following bribery charges
summary: Glencore faces a wave of class-action-style lawsuits from investment and pension funds in Britain, following its admission of bribery and market manipulation spanning over a decade. More than a dozen funds, including Mubadala Investment Company and International Petroleum Investment Company, have filed claims at a London court, linked to the US$1 billion fine paid by Glencore in May. The company pleaded guilty to charges in the US, Britain, and Brazil, and has agreed to pay approximately US$1.1 billion to authorities.

site_title: Most powerful buyers in US bonds all bailing at once
summary: The US Treasury market is experiencing a significant withdrawal from major buyers, including Japanese pensions and life insurers, foreign governments, and US commercial banks, amid rising hedging costs and a strong US dollar. The Federal Reserve's plan to sell $60 billion in Treasuries per month has also contributed to the market's decline. With yields on 30-year US bonds reaching a 9-year high, investors warn of potential pain in store until new demand emerges, affecting US taxpayers and potentially triggering value-at-risk shocks.

site_title: Football: Lionel Messi to headline tribute to Diego Maradona on Nov 14
summary: Lionel Messi will headline a star-studded lineup for the "match for peace" in tribute to Diego Maradona on November 14 in Rome. The event, organized by Pope Francis's Foundation, features other notable players like Ronaldinho, Gianluigi Buffon, and Jose Mourinho. The match honors Maradona's legacy, who passed away in 2020 at the age of 60 due to heart failure. The event will take place at the Olympic Stadium in Rome, just days before the start of the World Cup in Qatar.

site_title: Chipmaker rout engulfs TSMC, Samsung with $345.7 billion wiped out in sector
summary: US export curbs on China's access to US semiconductor technology sparked a sell-off in chip-related stocks globally, wiping out $345.7 billion from the sector's market value. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, Samsung Electronics, and Tokyo Electron plummeted over 7%, 5.8%, and 5.8% respectively. The curbs are expected to fuel a knock-on impact across the supply chain and add to challenges for technology shares. Analysts predict China's localisation efforts may be at risk, and the US move is a "big setback" for global semiconductors.

site_title: Rowing: British Rowing calls for creation of 'open' category for transgender athletes
summary: British Rowing chair Mark Davies is calling for the creation of an "open" category for transgender athletes, following World Swimming's lead in restricting participation in elite women's competitions. Currently, World Rowing allows athletes who were male at birth to compete in the female category if they reduce their testosterone to below 5 nanomoles per litre for 12 months. British Rowing plans to publish an updated policy aligning with World Rowing's approach. This move comes as governing bodies review their guidelines on transgender athletes amid concerns over fairness and inclusivity in women's sports.

site_title: India's new rich fuel brand expansion for Tata's jewellery arm
summary: India's luxury jeweller Titan plans to triple its Zoya-branded stores to 15 by 2027, driven by the country's growing rich consumers. The company expects this expansion to cost around $5.2 million per boutique. With India being the world's second-largest market for gold used in jewellery, Titan anticipates "aggressive pace" of growth for its Zoya brand, which has seen revenues climb five times from pre-pandemic sales figures. The company aims to build a global luxury brand through overseas expansion, leveraging its experience in the Middle East and US with its Tanishq brand.

site_title: Nasdaq registers lowest close since July 2020; chips stocks fall
summary: The Nasdaq Composite dropped 110.30 points, or 1.04%, to 10,542.10, marking its lowest close since July 2020. Investors worried about the impact of higher interest rates and restrictions on China's semiconductor industry, leading to declines in chipmakers' stocks. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also fell, with the Dow dropping 93.91 points and the S&P 500 losing 27.27 points. Analysts expect lower third-quarter earnings, with some predicting a 4.1% year-over-year increase in S&P 500 companies.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon warns of recession in 6 to 9 months
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon warned that the US and global economies could tip into a recession within 6-9 months due to runaway inflation, high interest rates, and the unknown effects of the Federal Reserve's quantitative tightening policy. Dimon cited the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine and the European recession as additional indicators. The S&P 500 index has already lost 24% this year, and Dimon predicted it could fall by another 20% from current levels, with a potential second 20% decline being more painful.

site_title: Malaysia lifts export ban on live broiler chicken: What types of chicken are imported into S'pore?
summary: Malaysia has lifted its export ban on live broiler chicken to Singapore, effective October 11, 2022. About 34% of Singapore's chicken supply comes from Malaysia. The country imports the following types of chicken: broiler chickens (40 days old), kampung chickens (smaller, more expensive), and black chickens (premium, higher protein content). Singapore also imports chilled, frozen, and processed chicken from over 20 countries, including live chickens from Indonesia and potential new farms in Batam.

site_title: Elon Musk claims Twitter ordered whistle-blower to destroy evidence
summary: Elon Musk alleges that Twitter ordered whistle-blower Mr. Peiter Zatko to destroy evidence, including 10 handwritten notebooks and 100 computer files, as part of a $7.8 million severance package. The evidence contained notes of meetings with company counterparts during Zatko's year-long tenure as security chief. Twitter's lawyers claim that the destruction of evidence was an attempt to silence Zatko and prevent corroborating evidence from coming to light, contradicting Musk's claims of operational problems at the company. The case is set to resume on October 28.

site_title: IMF, World Bank see rising risks of global recession
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Kristalina Georgieva and World Bank president David Malpass warned of a growing risk of global recession due to slowing growth in advanced economies, currency depreciation, and ongoing inflation concerns. The IMF is expected to downgrade its forecast for 2.9% global growth in 2023, citing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and climate disasters. The leaders called for concerted action to help emerging markets and urged central banks to continue efforts to contain inflation.

site_title: Football: Forest stem tide of defeats with 1-1 draw against Villa
summary: Nottingham Forest secured a 1-1 draw against Aston Villa, halting a run of five consecutive defeats and moving off the bottom of the table. Emmanuel Dennis scored for Forest in the 15th minute, while Ashley Young equalized for Villa in the 22nd minute. The draw saw Forest move to 19th place on five points from nine games, while Villa remained 16th on nine points. Forest manager Steve Cooper, who was handed a new three-year contract despite the team's poor form, praised the team's hard work and relief at earning their first point in six matches.

site_title: Man found dead in Yishun: Police arrest teenage son
summary: A 47-year-old man was found dead outside his residential unit in Yishun Avenue 4, Singapore. His 19-year-old son was arrested at the scene and is expected to be charged with murder on Wednesday. The police investigation is ongoing. The suspect faces the death penalty if convicted of murder.

site_title: Jail, driving ban for driver of delivery van that fatally hit pedestrian
summary: A 46-year-old delivery van driver, Romzi Abdul Wahab, was sentenced to 14 weeks in jail for fatally hitting a 72-year-old pedestrian in 2021. He pleaded guilty to driving without reasonable consideration for others on the road. Romzi shifted his attention from the road to check his GPS, failing to notice the pedestrian, and was unable to stop in time. He will also be banned from driving for eight years after his release from prison. The court found no mechanical failure in the vehicle contributing to the accident.

site_title: 15 in 100 Covid-19 cases are reinfected; new wave possible
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung warned that a new wave of Covid-19 cases is possible due to a 15% reinfection rate, where 15 out of 100 infected individuals have previously been infected. With over 4,000 cases reported on Sunday, the number could double to 9,000-10,000 on Tuesday, straining hospitals and healthcare workers. The government will need to balance support for healthcare workers with measures to control the spread of the virus, as the situation is being closely monitored for signs of another big wave.

site_title: Free vaccine shots may continue under Healthier SG
summary: Singapore will continue to offer free Covid-19 vaccine shots under the Healthier SG initiative, Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced. The country is shifting towards a new vaccination strategy of up-to-date vaccination, replacing the previous system of counting shots and boosters. This change aims to align with periodic vaccinations against influenza, and free Covid-19 jabs will remain available under the initiative. The Healthier SG program will provide additional benefits, including free vaccinations, to its beneficiaries.

site_title: Docs to assess man accused of giving false evidence in maid's case
summary: Karl Liew Kai Lung, 45, is set to undergo neuropsychological assessments after being charged with giving false evidence in a maid's case. Liew, son of former Changi Airport Group chairman, was accused of falsely telling police he found 119 items of clothing belonging to him in boxes packed by former maid Ms Parti Liyani. Ms Parti, an Indonesian, was initially convicted of stealing $34,000 but was acquitted after the High Court overturned her conviction. Liew's case was adjourned for the assessments, expected to be completed in late October and early November, with a report due in December.

site_title: 17 weeks in prison for man who hit cabby, verbally abused cop
summary: A 31-year-old man, Muhammad Taleb Kishen, was sentenced to 17 weeks in prison for assaulting a taxi driver, Muhammad K. Koh Liang Cai, who punched the driver on New Year's Day in 2020 after the driver refused to take Taleb's wife home. Taleb also verbally abused a police officer, Senior Staff Sergeant Adrian Tung, in a separate incident in 2019. Both men pleaded guilty to their crimes and made restitution to the taxi driver.

site_title: Healthier SG to include mental health in future
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG initiative will include mental health in its future care protocols, but not initially. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung said mental health requires a more comprehensive response and will be addressed through measures such as expanding clinical capacity, outreach sessions, and counseling. A national strategy on mental health will be developed after a public consultation, which aims to improve access to services, support youth mental health, and address workplace mental health. The health minister emphasized the importance of addressing mental health issues in seniors, citing loneliness as a significant concern.

site_title: Public seminar on Singaporean Mandarin as 1,000 terms selected for online database
summary: The Promote Mandarin Council launched the Singaporean Mandarin Database in 2019, featuring over 1,000 unique terms that reflect Singapore's culture and identity. A public seminar, Selat to Singapore: A Conversation on Singaporean Mandarin, will be held on October 29, featuring keynote speakers Associate Professor Tan Chee Lay and others. The database highlights the cultural significance of Singaporean Mandarin and aims to strengthen understanding of local Chinese culture, building confidence and capability among Singaporean Chinese to use Mandarin.

site_title: Family trapped in lift for 3½ hours while on dinner outing
summary: A 74-year-old man, Mr Chia, and his family were trapped in a lift at UOB Plaza 1 in Raffles Place for 3½ hours after it malfunctioned and stopped on the fourth floor. The family was left in the dark, with the air conditioning cut off, and was told multiple mechanics couldn't fix the issue. The Singapore Civil Defence Force eventually rescued them by guiding them to an adjacent working lift. The family was finally freed at 10pm and was offered a light meal by the restaurant's manager. The building has halted the affected lift's operation.

site_title: Woman who stabbed former boyfriend during fight jailed
summary: A 38-year-old woman, Jeya Jayaram, was sentenced to 7 months and 4 weeks in jail for stabbing her former boyfriend and neglecting her pet chihuahua, which died of dehydration. She pleaded guilty to one count each of voluntarily causing hurt with a knife and behaving in a disorderly manner. Jeya was also fined $5,800 and banned from owning pets for a year. The neglect of the dog occurred after she moved out of their shared flat in March 2020, leaving the dog without food or water for two months.

site_title: Two firms told to stop work, fined after safety lapses
summary: Two firms, Soon Bee Huat Trading, a tile distributor, and DA Engineering, a waste recycling firm, were ordered to stop work and fined for multiple safety breaches. Soon Bee Huat Trading was fined $15,000 and DA Engineering was fined $8,000 after inspections found workers operating equipment without proper training and storing goods beyond load capacity. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) also highlighted other safety concerns, including exposed machine parts, frayed cables, and incorrect clamp usage, emphasizing the need for company leaders to take greater ownership of workplace safety.

site_title: Local importers expect live broiler chickens later this week
summary: Malaysia has lifted its export ban on live broiler chickens for Singapore, but local importers expect the shipment to arrive later this week due to paperwork. The ban was initially imposed in June due to a local supply shortage, but was eased in October with restrictions, including halving the export number of live commercial broiler chickens to 1.8 million per month. Importers must still apply for permits and adhere to export quantity limits to avoid suspension of export permits.

site_title: S'pore looking at more measures to address income inequality: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that Singapore will refresh its measures to address income inequality, focusing on lower-income groups, seniors, and young families. The government plans to reduce fee caps at government-supported pre-schools, review leave measures, and develop better living options for seniors in housing estates. Wong emphasized the need to shift attitudes and mindsets to value the contributions of every individual, and to integrate various services across the government to better support vulnerable groups. The government is open to new ideas to empower lower-income families and will study how to achieve financial assurance in old age.

site_title: Social service practitioners moot ideas to help children from low-income families
summary: Social service practitioners are discussing ways to support children from low-income families, citing low morale and lack of motivation due to performance disparities. They suggest promoting a culture of mentoring and encouraging employers to offer family-friendly policies, such as paternity leave. The goal is to provide upstream support for lower-income families, including stable employment and stress management, to help them overcome challenges and achieve success. This is part of the Forward Singapore dialogue, which aims to culminate in a report in mid-2023.

site_title: She grappled with dad's suicide for over a decade
summary: A 42-year-old woman, Jacqueline Pak, is part of a study by the Institute of Mental Health (IMH) on suicide factors, along with 24 others who lost loved ones to suicide. Pak's father took his own life 25 years ago, and she struggled with the trauma for over a decade, initially blaming herself. The study aims to identify the main factors that led to her father's suicide, with the goal of preventing future suicides. Researchers have found that financial stress, relationship breakdowns, chronic pain, and mental illness are common contributing factors, and the study is extending its recruitment period to find more participants.

site_title: Death of bus driver in crash outside depot is 39th workplace death
summary: A 54-year-old Singaporean bus driver, Mr. Liu Shan Liung, died in a workplace accident outside the bus depot on Sunday. He was the 39th workplace fatality in 2022, surpassing the 37 fatalities in 2021. The bus crashed into a tree at around 2:40am, with Mr. Liu trapped in his seat. He was pronounced dead at the scene. The police are investigating the accident, and the bus driver's family, including his wife and three children, are receiving support from the union. A funeral is expected to be held on Tuesday.

site_title: 2 start-ups win contest to help Sats manage food, plastic waste
summary: Two US-based start-ups, Enexor BioEnergy and Tria, have won an OCBC Bank sustainability competition to help in-flight caterer and ground handler Sats manage food and packaging waste. Enexor's Bio-CHP system converts organic waste into electricity, while Tria produces plant-based containers that can be composted or turned into biofuel. Both companies will receive up to $80,000 in funding and pilot their solutions with Sats, with potential plans for Enexor to set up a Bio-CHP system at Changi Airport by 2023.

site_title: Weekly dengue cases down by 70% from peak in May
summary: Weekly dengue cases in Singapore have dropped by 70% from their peak in May, with 95% of clusters closed. As of Oct 7, there were 28,500 reported cases, with 427 cases reported last week. Nine people have died of dengue so far in 2022, compared to five in 2021. The National Environment Agency (NEA) has launched the National Dengue Prevention Campaign, releasing male Wolbachia-Aedes mosquitoes to control Aedes aegypti mosquito populations.

site_title: Free Covid-19 jabs may continue to be offered as part of Healthier SG initiative
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that free Covid-19 jabs may continue as part of the Healthier SG initiative, which also provides benefits for influenza jabs. The country is transitioning to an up-to-date vaccination strategy, focusing on booster shots every 5-12 months. As of October 17, eligible individuals can receive the bivalent Moderna vaccine at joint testing and vaccination centers. Pfizer's Comirnaty bivalent vaccine is expected to be available by the end of the year. The government encourages people to get vaccinated ahead of the winter season when new Covid-19 strains are expected to emerge.

site_title: S'pore banks fight for market share in fixed deposits, savings accounts
summary: Singapore banks are intensifying their competition for market share in fixed deposits and savings accounts, offering promotional rates above 3% in response to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat inflation. This trend has been observed over the past few months, with banks seeking to attract depositors' wallets amidst rising interest rates.

site_title: Company Briefs: Yangzijiang Financial OpenSea H&M
summary: Yangzijiang Financial appointed Ms Wu Menglin as its new head of funds, bringing her 10-year experience at GIC's private equity funds. OpenSea's CFO, Brian Roberts, left the company after less than a year, citing a desire to be an adviser. H&M is testing charging fees for online returns in Norway, part of an effort to reduce costs.

site_title: Job prospects in China at record low as economy slows
summary: Chinese residents face record-low job prospects amid a slowdown in the economy, with the central bank's Employment Sentiment Index declining to 35.4 in the third quarter, the lowest since 2010. 45.2% of households said finding a job was "tough" or "hard to judge", and only 9.7% said it was easy. The economy is being dragged down by repeated Covid-19 flare-ups and a property market slump, with economists predicting a 3.3% GDP growth rate this year, below the official goal of 5.5%.

site_title: What is a technical recession and how does it differ from a full-blown one?
summary: Singapore may be in a technical recession as its GDP growth is estimated to have contracted in the third quarter, but the official word will be confirmed on Friday. A technical recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth in GDP. Unlike a full-blown recession, a technical recession does not necessarily imply a significant rise in unemployment rates. Singapore's manufacturing output and export-driven economy make it vulnerable to global demand fluctuations, and a technical recession may not necessarily indicate a deeper economic downturn. The outcome will depend on the official GDP growth estimates.

site_title: Supply chains may return to normal in 2023, with shipping profits easing
summary: Supply chains may return to normal in 2023, with shipping profits easing, according to the latest logistics managers' index. Despite ongoing shortages and fragile supply chains, international transportation capacity has improved, with about half of shipping congestion resolved. Analysts predict a full reversal to normality by March 2023, barring disruptions. Weekly traffic figures at the busiest US port in Los Angeles indicate a gradual decline in shipping slowdown, and cargo owners are benefiting from falling rates, but the industry's earnings are expected to peak in 2022 as supply and demand rebalance.

site_title: Most singles in S'pore want to get married, have kids
summary: In Singapore, eight in 10 young singles (77%) want to have children, with most (92%) of married respondents desiring two or more kids. However, financial concerns and stress of raising children are major deterrents, with half of married respondents having one child or no children. The 2021 survey found that marriage and parenthood aspirations have remained relatively stable, but with shifts in views on caregiving responsibility and openness to dating apps. Paid paternity leave and flexible work arrangements are key factors in encouraging couples to have children.

site_title: More couples meeting through online dating sites or apps, survey shows
summary: A National Population and Talent Division survey found that the proportion of singles who met their partners through online dating sites or apps increased from 7% in 2012 to 29% in 2021. The top ways couples meet include social activities, friends, school, and work. Online dating sites and apps became more popular, with 58% of respondents comfortable meeting through them in 2020, up from 19% in 2012. The survey also revealed that 50% of single respondents were not currently dating, with limited social circles and a preference for chance meeting being top reasons.

site_title: STI tracks regional decline as hopes dim for Fed policy pivot
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% to 3,107.47, mirroring regional declines, after a strong US jobs report reduced hopes for a US Federal Reserve policy pivot. ThaiBev led decliners, with three local banks (DBS, OCBC, and UOB) also falling. Sats and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding were the only index counters in positive territory. Markets in Australia, Shanghai, and Hong Kong also declined, with key indexes falling between 1.4% and 3%. Investors await Thursday's US CPI data, which may impact inflation sentiment.

site_title: Gold heading east as tumbling price draws Asian buyers
summary: Global gold prices have tumbled 18% since peaking in March due to the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes, prompting Western investors to dump bullion and Asian buyers to snap up cheap gold jewellery and bars. Large volumes of metal are being drawn out of vaults in New York and London, with over 527 tonnes pouring out since April. However, logistical issues and market quirks are making it difficult to meet demand, resulting in unusually large premiums over the global benchmark price in some Asian markets, with gold selling at multi-year highs in Dubai, Istanbul, and Shanghai.

site_title: MAS bans ex-banker for 10 years over role in 1MDB scandal
summary: A former senior official at a Swiss private bank, Raj Sriram, has been banned from providing financial advisory services for 10 years due to his role in the 1MDB scandal. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) took action after a 24-month conditional warning, following an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) that found Sriram's neglect contributed to the bank's failure to file suspicious transaction reports. The MAS concluded that Sriram's conduct warranted a 10-year prohibition order, citing his senior position at the bank and the key conduit for tainted funds in the scandal.

site_title: OCBC Bank to get new chief financial officer in November
summary: OCBC Bank announced that current CFO Darren Tan will step down in November after 11 years in the role, opting for early retirement. He will be succeeded by Ms Goh Chin Yee, current head of group audit, effective November 1. Ms Goh, 57, joined the bank in 1988 and has held various roles, including head of group audit, where she introduced data analytics and automation to improve risk insights. CEO Helen Wong praised Ms Goh's contributions, citing her deep institutional knowledge and broad exposure across disciplines.

site_title: Sing$ policy decision in Oct hinges on employment, growth risks
summary: Singapore's central bank is expected to keep pushing up the currency against trading partners in October, despite risks of a global downturn and potential technical recession. High inflation may force the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to tighten monetary policy, but analysts warn that an excessively strong Sing dollar could harm export competitiveness and economic growth. A decline in exports could hit employment and overall expansion, with some predicting a 0.6% decline in GDP growth in the third quarter.

site_title: Adani in talks with investors to raise $14.4b for expansion: Report
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani and his family are in talks with investors like Singapore's Temasek and GIC to raise at least $10 billion to fund the expansion of Adani Group's clean energy, ports, and cement businesses. The conglomerate aims to invest over $100 billion in the next decade, with most funds allocated to energy transition. Adani family members and executives met with potential investors in Singapore, exploring multiple tranches of capital through the sale of stakes in group companies. The exact details of the capital raise remain unclear, with Temasek and Adani Group declining to comment.

site_title: SailGP: More teams, more dynamic
summary: The third season of SailGP has kicked off with more teams, events, and dynamic racing, showcasing world-class sailing. With 11 events across four continents, including two new teams from Canada and Switzerland, the competition has become increasingly close, with a single mistake potentially leading to a significant deficit. The expanded schedule has also raised concerns about fatigue among drivers and crews, but SailGP's CEO Russell Coutts believes regularity is key to building a fan base and improving racing quality. The series continues with the next event in Dubai on November 12.

site_title: Klopp confronts ref on 'soft' penalty
summary: Jurgen Klopp was furious over a "soft" penalty decision that cost Liverpool a 3-2 Premier League defeat to Arsenal. Thiago Alcantara was awarded a penalty for minimal contact with Gabriel Jesus, which Bukayo Saka converted. Klopp confronted referee Michael Oliver, stating the penalty was "very soft" and not worthy of a spot-kick. The loss left Liverpool in 10th spot, 14 points behind leaders Arsenal, but Klopp remains optimistic, believing his team can turn their season around with hard work and coaching.

site_title: Iskandar back on track with Lucky Double
summary: Malaysian apprentice jockey Iskandar Rosman snapped a 44-ride losing streak with a double on Saturday, including a win on Luxury Brand. The timely brace boosts his season record to 14 wins, seven behind leader Yusoff Fadzli. Iskandar attributed his slump to focusing too much on the title fight and his 2kg claim. With seven meetings left, he faces a tough task to catch up, but expressed gratitude for the win, calling Luxury Brand "an amazing horse."

site_title: Chinese chip stocks fall amid fresh US curbs on tech access
summary: Chinese semiconductor stocks plummeted amid US curbs on China's access to American technology, with Bellwether Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp dropping 5.2% in Hong Kong. The US measures restrict chip exports for AI and supercomputing, and tighten rules on semiconductor equipment sales to Chinese companies. The curbs, set to take effect this month, are seen as a blow to global industrial and supply chains, and hurt US companies. The chip industry is already facing a slowdown, with Samsung Electronics and Advanced Micro Devices reporting disappointing results, fueling concerns the downturn is far from over.

site_title: Making sense of the confusing affair
summary: Max Verstappen has won his second consecutive Formula 1 world championship. A first-lap accident involving Ferrari's Carlos Sainz led to a Safety Car, allowing Pierre Gasly of AlphaTauri to chase a field of animals on the track in the dark. The unusual scene occurred on October 9, 2022, amidst the chaos of the race, raising questions about how the championship was not recognized earlier.

site_title: Sias to probe firms' green claims to protect investors
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (Sias) plans to probe companies' green claims to protect investors. The watchdog will review sustainability reports and disclosures, asking more questions to ensure accountability. This aims to combat greenwashing, where companies mislead consumers about their environmental practices. Sias also plans to organize investor education programs and review ESG investment products to protect investors' interests. The move follows concerns from Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat about the impact of greenwashing on global financial systems, which can erode confidence in ESG products and affect financial stability.

site_title: Emulating tiger is 'an honour'
summary: South Korea's Kim Joo-hyung, 20, won the Shriners Children's Open, becoming the first player since Tiger Woods to secure a second PGA Tour win before turning 21. Kim outlasted world No. 4 Patrick Cantlay with a three-shot victory, firing a flawless 66 to finish 24-under 260. This win marks Kim's second Tour victory in four starts, solidifying his rapid rise to prominence in the golf world.

site_title: Tomori wants to redress dreadful display at Chelsea
summary: Fikayo Tomori hopes to redeem himself after a poor display in a 3-0 loss to Chelsea in their previous match. Tomori, who played for Chelsea's academy before joining AC Milan, wants to put on a better show against his former club. Milan and Chelsea are tied in Group E of the Champions League, and a win for Milan would reaffirm their chances of qualifying for the knockout stage. Tomori has settled well at Milan and is looking to lead his team to a victory against Chelsea.

site_title: Premier League talking points
summary: Leicester City's struggles continue, with a 2-1 loss to Bournemouth marking their fifth consecutive away defeat. The Foxes have only four points from nine games, sparking chants about manager Brendan Rodgers' future. Newcastle United, meanwhile, has moved into the top six with a 5-1 win over Brentford, thanks in part to the sharpness of their attack. Brighton and Hove Albion midfielder Enock Mwepu has retired at 24 due to a hereditary heart condition, while Patson Daka's goal for Leicester was a positive sign for the team.

site_title: S'pore hit by late goal
summary: Singapore's Lionesses suffered a 2-1 defeat to Indonesia in a friendly match at the Jalan Besar Stadium. Nur Farhanah Ruhaizat, who returned from a cartilage injury, scored the equalizing goal in the 86th minute, but Indonesia won 2-1 with an injury-time winner. The Lionesses had a strong second half, but goalkeeper errors cost them the match. Despite the loss, coach Stephen Ng emphasized the importance of developing the team's squad for future games.

site_title: Allegri wants juve to raise their game
summary: Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri urged his team to raise their game as they face Maccabi Haifa in the Champions League, needing a win to keep alive last-16 hopes. Despite a recent win against Bologna, Juve have picked up just one win from their first three group games and face a tough test in Israel. Allegri warned his players to minimize errors and give everything on the pitch, as a loss could lead to a Europa League spot. The team must also overcome Paris Saint-Germain and Benfica's lead in the group standings.

site_title: Shadoff clinches 'surreal' first title on her 246th try
summary: England's Jodi Ewart Shadoff clinched her first LPGA Tour title on Sunday at the LPGA Mediheal Championship, holding off rivals for a wire-to-wire triumph. Shadoff, 34, finished 15-under 273 after a one-under 71 on the final round, her 246th career start. Shadoff overcame a four-stroke lead to secure the win, saying the feeling was "surreal" after a long wait. Japan's Yuka Saso finished second, with Georgia Hall and Paula Reto sharing third.

site_title: Chepngetich 14sec off world record
summary: Ruth Chepngetich of Kenya won the women's title at the Chicago Marathon, finishing in 2:14:18, 14 seconds off the world record set in 2019. Fellow Kenyan Benson Kipruto took the men's title, capturing the crown in 2:04:24. Chepngetich's time is the second-fastest in history, while Kipruto matched the 2013 record. Over 40,000 runners competed in the 44th edition of the marathon, with Chepngetich defending her title for the second consecutive year.

site_title: Hope for Swiatek's rivals in WTA finals
summary: Iga Swiatek, the World No. 1, lost her first final in the season-ending WTA Finals to Barbora Krejcikova in the Ostrava final. Krejcikova's 5-7, 7-6 (7-4), 6-3 win ended Swiatek's 10-match winning streak. Despite the loss, Swiatek plans to donate her $71,960 finalist's cheque to mental health charities in Poland, a move she hopes will spread awareness and help those in need. The loss gives Krejcikova a glimmer of hope for the WTA Finals in Fort Worth, Texas, which begin on October 31.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Key events and conclusions for the next 48 hours include UEFA Champions League matches on Wednesday, October 12, 2022, at 12:40am and 2:55am, featuring teams such as Manchester City, Juventus, Milan, and PSG. Additionally, tennis tournaments on the ATP and WTA tours continue with Day 2 of the Gijon Open and Day 2 of the San Diego Open on Wednesday.

site_title: All about chasing the same dream
summary: A four-year-old horse named Dream Alliance, trained by Tim Fitzsimmons, made a winning debut in a $20,000 Open Maiden race at Kranji, setting a new class record with a 13/4-length victory. The horse, owned by Legacy Power Racing Stable, was ridden by Manoel Nunes and had previously finished second and eighth in two previous starts. Nunes, a two-time champion jockey, has returned to his prolific form, taking a 22-win lead in the premiership title with 63 wins so far this season.

site_title: Kellady, Beasley suspended
summary: Jockey Matthew Kellady was suspended from Oct 16 to 22 for careless riding on Italian Revolution, after permitting his mount to shift in and check with Supreme One.
