site_title: Finding Nemo for only $5,620
summary: Flying Nemo, a 3-year-old horse, made a surprise debut win in Saturday's $75,000 Restricted Maiden race at the Polytrack 1,000m, taking the lead at the 300m mark and crossing the finish line in 59.31 seconds. The horse, trained by Desmond Koh and ridden by Simon Kok, paid just NZ$7,000 (S$5,620) as a yearling and has earned its first-time owners NZ$40,163. This win marks a significant return on investment for the new owners, who took a chance on the horse despite its lack of racing experience.

site_title: Yapp not at ease despite title lift
summary: Singaporean 9-ball player Aloysius Yapp clinched his second consecutive title by winning the Sandcastle 9-Ball Open in New Jersey, defeating Chang Jung-lin 7-6. Despite struggling in the past two tournaments, Yapp expressed relief and hopes the victory will prepare him for the upcoming US Open, where he finished as a runner-up in 2021. Yapp plans to work on staying calm during matches and is focusing on his breathing and reducing distractions. His goal is to play his best game and see where it takes him, rather than specifically targeting a win.

site_title: This one is 'more beautiful'
summary: Max Verstappen retained his Formula One championship title at the Suzuka Grand Prix, securing his second title with four races to spare. The 25-year-old Dutch driver won the rain-interrupted race by 27 seconds, with a five-second penalty being handed to Charles Leclerc, allowing Verstappen to maintain his unassailable lead. Verstappen's dominant season has seen him win 12 of 18 races, with Red Bull Racing claiming their 14th victory of 2022.

site_title: Outrage in paddock after tractor appears on track
summary: French driver Pierre Gasly narrowly avoided being killed after passing a tractor on the track at the 2022 Japanese Grand Prix, where a similar incident involving Jules Bianchi led to his fatal accident in 2014. Gasly, who was 2 meters away from the crane, said he would have died if he had been 1 meter to the left. The incident has sparked outrage among drivers and teams, with many calling for a full investigation. The FIA will look into the incident, which has raised concerns about safety in heavy rain conditions.

site_title: Djokovic captures 90th title, seals ATP Finals spot
summary: Novak Djokovic claimed his 90th career title and fourth of 2022, defeating Stefanos Tsitsipas 6-3, 6-4 in the ATP final. Djokovic's victory secured his spot at the ATP Finals and narrowed the gap to Rafael Nadal's 92 tournament wins. The 35-year-old Serb attributed his success to his experience and mental approach, saying 35 is "not 25." Meanwhile, Taylor Fritz won the Japan Open, and Barbora Krejcikova stunned world No. 1 Iga Swiatek in the Ostrava Open final.

site_title: Comeback kings save best for final
summary: Defending champions RSG SG won the Mobile Legends: Bang Bang Professional League Singapore (MPL SG) Season 4 grand final 4-3 against rivals Slate Esports, maintaining their perfect record. After trailing 3-2, RSG SG fought back to win the next game and dominate the final game, securing their second consecutive MPL SG crown and a spot at the US$800,000 M4 World Championship. Captain Yeo "Diablo" Wee Lun credited his team's focus and determination for the comeback victory.

site_title: Promoters of Super League stay defiant
summary: Real Madrid president Florentino Perez, Juventus president Andrea Agnelli, and Barcelona president Joan Laporta have reaffirmed their commitment to the Super League project, despite ongoing litigation and pressure from authorities and fans. The project, which aims to create a direct competition for the Champions League, has been revived after a court decision in 2023 is expected to determine its future. Perez defended the project, calling it an "improved Champions League," while Laporta expressed support for the idea but emphasized the need for an open format with meritocracy. The judicial process continues.

site_title: Thematic investing: Why investors are rethinking their investment route
summary: Allianz Global Investors has identified seven disruptive themes, including artificial intelligence, health tech, cyber security, and digital life, that can generate potential income and growth for investors. The themes have been accelerated by the Covid-19 pandemic, with health tech and digital life experiencing significant growth. Pet ownership has also become increasingly popular, with many people viewing their pets as "fur babies" and spending more money on premium food, medical attention, and other services. Thematic investing aims to identify "macro-level" trends disrupting the global economy and capitalize on them for better returns, offering a long-term view to adapt to current and anticipated challenges.

site_title: College dropout to millionaire
summary: Eugenio Chacarra, a 22-year-old Spanish golfer, won the individual and team titles at the LIV Golf Invitational Bangkok, earning $6.8 million. Chacarra, a college dropout, joined LIV Golf six months ago and has since earned $5.643 million. He credited LIV Golf for giving him the financial freedom to play without worrying about costs, saying it's "amazing" to be able to play with the best players in the world. Chacarra's win marked a significant milestone in his career, with his family and best friend in attendance.

site_title: LIV put a defibrillator on the game of golf: Norman
summary: LIV Golf, led by Greg Norman, is seeking to amplify its presence in golf with a dramatic and attention-grabbing move. Norman envisions the 2023 season starting with a high-profile, record-breaking event in space, featuring a LIV logo on a spaceship carrying prominent backers like Jeff Bezos or Richard Branson. The move aims to showcase LIV Golf's massive investment from Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, currently valued at $255 million. This bold strategy is part of the series' efforts to challenge the PGA and DP World Tours, sparking further controversy amidst the golfing world.

site_title: Sports World: Bezecourt's late goal earns Eagles a point
summary: Geylang International earned a 3-3 draw with Tanjong Pagar in the Singapore Premier League, thanks to Vincent Bezecourt's late goal in the 93rd minute. The Eagles were down to 10 men after Huzaifah Aziz's red card, but Bezecourt's goal secured a point. In golf, Patrick Cantlay matched the course record with an 11-under 60 to share the lead with Kim Joo-hyung at the PGA Shriners Children's Open. Meanwhile, Jodi Ewart Shadoff maintained a four-stroke lead at the LPGA Mediheal Championship after a three-under 69 on Saturday.

site_title: Football: Eze fires Palace to comeback victory over Leeds
summary: Crystal Palace secured a 2-1 comeback victory over Leeds United in the Premier League. Leeds took an early lead through Pascal Struijk, but Palace leveled through Odsonne Edouard's header. Eberechi Eze scored the winning goal in the 76th minute, giving Palace a much-needed win. The victory moves Palace out of the relegation zone and into 15th place, level on nine points with Leeds.

site_title: E-sports: RSG SG retain Mobile Legends: Bang Bang Professional League S'pore title
summary: Defending champions RSG SG won their second consecutive Mobile Legends: Bang Bang Professional League Singapore (MPL SG) title, defeating Slate Esports 4-3 in the best-of-seven series. The team, led by captain Yeo "Diablo" Wee Lun, overcame a 3-2 deficit to force a decider and ultimately won the final game. With the victory, RSG SG secured a spot at the US$800,000 M4 World Championship in Jakarta in January 2023.

site_title: 5th batch of combat engineer officer cadets celebrate 50 years of friendship
summary: The 5th batch of combat engineer officer cadets celebrated 50 years of friendship at the Chinese Swimming Club in Katong, Singapore. In 1973, 45 young men from diverse backgrounds reported to Gillman Barracks to train as combat engineers. Despite their differences, they overcame physical and mental limits to become leaders in various units across the Singapore Armed Forces' combat engineer formation, marking a remarkable achievement in their 50-year friendship.

site_title: SBS Transit driver dies after bus crashes into tree in Hougang
summary: A 54-year-old SBS Transit bus driver died in a traffic accident in Hougang, Singapore, after losing control of the bus and crashing into a tree outside the bus depot at 2:40am on Sunday. The driver, who was driving an empty employees' bus, was pronounced dead at the scene. Police investigations are ongoing, and the bus operator has extended condolences to the driver's family.

site_title: Football: Ronaldo nets 700th club goal of his career
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo scored his 700th club goal in a 2-1 win for Manchester United over Everton. The Portuguese forward netted his first Premier League goal of the season in just 14 minutes, coming off the bench to replace injured Anthony Martial. Ronaldo's goal took his career total to 144 in two spells with United, surpassing his previous tally of 130. Manager Erik ten Hag credited Ronaldo with needing goals to regain confidence, saying they often come in a flow, making games easier for the player.

site_title: Japanese GP drama shows even F1 teams have not figured out regulations
summary: Max Verstappen won the Japanese Grand Prix for the second year in a row, solidifying his position as world champion. However, the victory was overshadowed by a dramatic incident involving Sebastian Vettel, who crashed out of the race. A tractor appeared on the track during the Safety Car period, causing a distraction for drivers, including Pierre Gasly, who was chasing a field of running animals. Despite the unusual events, Verstappen secured the win, further cementing his championship title.

site_title: Staircase in Upper Thomson Road painted with landmarks from the past
summary: A 20m-long staircase mural in Singapore's Upper Thomson Road has been unveiled, titled "Hidden Gem". The mural features past landmarks such as the Imperial open-air theatre and was designed and painted by artist Muhammad Izdi and residents of Yew Lian Park. The project, part of a community art initiative, took two months to complete and costs $25,000, fully funded by the Urban Redevelopment Authority and National Arts Council. The mural was unveiled by Senior Minister Chee Hong Tat and MP for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC, and aims to preserve memories of old landmarks in the area.

site_title: Football: 'We are not done', says Klopp despite Liverpool losing 3-2 to Arsenal
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp expressed optimism despite the team's 3-2 loss to Arsenal, saying "we're not done" after trailing 14 points behind the Premier League leaders. Klopp's side has struggled with their worst start in his seven-year reign, with two losses and four draws. He acknowledged the team's slow start but emphasized that they are working on getting back to basics ahead of crucial matches against Rangers in the Champions League and Manchester City next weekend.

site_title: Golf: Rookie Chacarra earns $6.8 million with win at LIV event in Bangkok
summary: Eugenio Chacarra, a 22-year-old golfer, won the LIV Golf Invitational Bangkok with a 19-under 197 total, earning $6.8 million. Chacarra, who was once No. 2 in the World Amateur Golf Ranking, claimed the individual and team title with his Fireballs teammates, including Sergio Garcia. The win marked Chacarra's biggest payday and took his earnings on the LIV Golf series to $5.643 million.

site_title: Football: West Ham come from behind to beat Fulham 3-1
summary: West Ham United came from behind to beat Fulham 3-1 in a London derby at home. Fulham took an early lead with Andreas Pereira's goal, but West Ham equalized through a penalty from Jarrod Bowen after Pereira's foul. Gianluca Scamacca gave West Ham the lead just after the hour mark, and Michail Antonio sealed the win in stoppage time. The victory marked West Ham's back-to-back Premier League wins for the season and moved them up to 13th place in the standings, a point behind ninth-placed Fulham.

site_title: Supply chain 'normal' appears on horizon; with shipping lines' earnings moderating
summary: Global supply chains are showing signs of normalcy, with shipping lines' earnings moderating, according to logistics managers' index and analysts. Despite ongoing shortages of parts and workers, international transportation capacity has improved, and congestion is decreasing. Analysts predict a full reversal to normality by March 2023, barring disruptions. Shipping slowdowns and lower demand are contributing to the easing of supply chain stress, with cargo rates plummeting 60% in 2022. However, Moody's Investors Service has cut its outlook for the industry to negative, citing supply-demand imbalances that will likely persist into 2023.

site_title: Football: Real Madrid, Juventus and Barca not giving up on controversial Super League
summary: Real Madrid, Juventus, and Barcelona are refusing to give up on the Super League project, despite its initial collapse due to fan and authority pressure. The project's future is now being decided by a court case in 2023, which may determine its fate. Despite criticism from UEFA President Aleksander Ceferin, the three clubs remain committed to the project, with Juventus' Andrea Agnelli and Barcelona's Joan Laporta expressing support and proposing changes to the format. A judicial process is ongoing, with the final decision expected near the start of 2023.

site_title: Study finds that teens who attempt suicide face more stress, perceive parents as hostile
summary: A recent study in Singapore found that teenagers who have attempted suicide perceive their parents as more aggressive, neglectful, and cold, despite having a more negative perception of themselves. In contrast, parents were less likely to perceive themselves as neglectful. The study compared 60 teenagers who attempted suicide with their parents or main caregivers, highlighting the complex relationship between family dynamics and mental well-being in youth. The findings emphasize the importance of addressing family stress and improving parental-child relationships to prevent suicidal behaviors.

site_title: Basketball: Draymond Green calls practice incident a 'huge embarrassment'
summary: Golden State Warriors forward Draymond Green apologized for punching teammate Jordan Poole during practice, calling it a "huge embarrassment" and stating he failed as a leader. Green, who did not know how Poole felt about the situation, said he was in a "very bad space mentally" but had no excuse for his actions. The team is internally investigating the incident and Green has not practiced with the team for several days, with coach Steve Kerr saying there's no set date for his return.

site_title: Malaysia to allow export of live broiler chicken from Oct 11
summary: Singapore will be able to import live broiler chickens from Malaysia starting October 11, after a ban imposed since June 1. The ban was lifted following a Malaysian Cabinet decision, allowing the export of live chickens to Singapore. Before the ban, Malaysia supplied about a third of Singapore's chicken, with 3.6 million chickens exported monthly. The move is seen as a relief for chicken importers and households, who have faced disruptions in their food supply due to the ban. The Singapore Food Agency is seeking clarification on the details of the lifted ban.

site_title: Cue sports: Yapp claims Sandcastle 9-Ball Open title for second straight win ahead of US Open
summary: World No. 6 Aloysius Yapp won the Sandcastle 9-Ball Open in New Jersey, claiming his second consecutive title ahead of the US Open. Yapp defeated 10th-ranked Chang Jung-Lin 7-6 in the race-to-seven final. Despite struggling in his past two tournaments, Yapp expressed relief and optimism about his chances at the US Open, where he finished as a runner-up in 2021. He aims to improve his composure during matches and work on his breathing techniques to reduce distractions.

site_title: Golf: S'pore amateur Brandon Han wins first overseas event at Bangchak C'ship
summary: Brandon Han, a 20-year-old Singaporean golfer, won his first overseas event at the Bangchak Championship in Khao Yai, Thailand. Han finished one-under 215, 14 strokes ahead of the field, and expressed pride in his performance, despite feeling he could have done better. The victory marks a significant milestone in his amateur career, and he plans to continue competing in upcoming events, including the Thailand Amateur Open and the Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship, before enlisting for national service in 2023.

site_title: Formula One: 'It's a crazy feeling" as Verstappen retains world title after dramatic Japan GP win
summary: Max Verstappen retained the Formula One world title after winning the rain-shortened Japanese Grand Prix, securing an unassailable 113-point lead with four races to spare. Verstappen crossed the line first, and a five-second penalty on Charles Leclerc dropped him to third, awarding Verstappen the championship. The race was marred by a chaotic start, safety car periods, and a near-miss involving Pierre Gasly, who was investigating after passing a tractor on the track.

site_title: 196-year-old Jamae Chulia Mosque in Chinatown to get $3m restoration from end-2022
summary: Singapore's 196-year-old Jamae Chulia Mosque in Chinatown will undergo a $3 million restoration project starting from the end of 2022, with the goal of increasing its capacity to 1,700 worshippers. The mosque, built in 1826, will remain open during the restoration period and will feature expanded classroom space, ramps, and a new community plaza. The project aims to preserve the mosque for future generations and is expected to be completed by 2025.

site_title: Making your kids go cold turkey without devices during the exam period may backfire
summary: Singapore parents considering confiscating their kids' devices during the exam period may inadvertently hinder their child's learning. The move could lead to frustration, making children more likely to avoid studying altogether. Instead, parents are advised to set limits and boundaries, encouraging kids to use devices for revision and educational purposes. By striking a balance between device usage and study time, parents can help their children prepare effectively for the exams. This approach may lead to better academic outcomes and a healthier relationship with technology.

images.alt_text: Confiscate your kid's device until the exams are over? Your well-intentioned move may backfire instead.

site_title: Significant improvement in recidivism rate among Malay offenders
summary: Singapore has seen a significant improvement in recidivism rates among Malay offenders, with 26% of Malay offenders released in 2019 being detained or sentenced within two years. This marks the lowest recidivism rate in 30 years. The recidivism rate among Malay offenders has decreased by 7.5% compared to the 2015 release cohort. Additionally, the number of Malay drug abusers arrested has fallen from 1,618 in 2017 to 1,282 in 2021. The government attributes the progress to community support and the Dadah Itu Haram campaign, which aims to combat drug abuse among Malays.

site_title: SPH Reit posts 2.2% rise in 12-month distribution per unit on retail recovery
summary: SPH Reit reported a 2.2% increase in its 12-month distribution per unit (DPU) to 5.52 cents, driven by a 16.4% rise in footfall at its Singapore assets, including Paragon and The Clementi Mall. Gross revenue rose 1.7% and net property income grew 3.5%. The Reit's performance was weaker in Australia, where footfall dropped 3.6%. CEO Susan Leng attributed the return to normalcy in Singapore and Australia to better footfall and tenant sales, particularly at its Singapore assets.

site_title: Binance blockchain hit by $817.5m hack, exposing crypto vulnerabilities
summary: A $817.5 million hack on Binance's blockchain network exposed vulnerabilities in decentralized finance. The attack, which targeted a cross-chain bridge, highlighted weaknesses in decentralized systems controlled by code. Despite no user losses, Binance emphasized the need for improved security measures. The incident follows a series of cross-chain bridge attacks, resulting in $2 billion in stolen cryptocurrency. A community vote will determine next steps, including freezing stolen funds and offering a bounty for hackers. The attack underscores the limitations of decentralization in resolving issues quickly.

site_title: American entrepreneur came for S'pore F1, leaves with potentially $180k of deals
summary: American entrepreneur Rembrandt Flores spent a week in Singapore during the F1 event, meeting with potential clients and sealing potentially $180,000 worth of deals. Flores, founder of 8Commas, a Los Angeles-based Web3 consultancy, networked and attended lavish parties, but also prioritized early morning meetings. His Singapore Grand Prix experience was highly successful, resulting in lucrative business opportunities.

site_title: Refreshed river boat services by 2024 may provide commuting option to Sports Hub
summary: Singaporeans will enjoy at least 25% off standard ticket prices for sightseeing cruises and guided tours along the waterfront by 2024. The Urban Redevelopment Authority aims to refresh river boat services to provide a commuting option to the Sports Hub in Kallang. Boat and tour operators must offer the discount to encourage local ridership. The new services will target Marina Reservoir, offering innovative water-based experiences such as leisure and recreational activities, and may broaden activities for tourists and locals in the Bay.

site_title: Chinese crypto mogul Leon Li sells stake in exchange firm Huobi
summary: Chinese crypto mogul Leon Li sold his entire stake in Huobi Global, the once-most active Bitcoin trading platform, to a buyout firm managed by About Capital Management (HK). This move comes after Huobi retreated from China, its largest user base and revenue source, following Beijing's declaration of crypto transactions as illegal last year. Huobi has since expanded into overseas markets, but faces competition from bigger rivals like Binance and FTX. Li, the exchange's co-founder, will cease involvement in its operations, citing a need for a new shareholding structure with a global vision and international resources.

site_title: Tampines, Punggol BTO projects win HDB award for construction, design features
summary: Singapore's Kay Lim Construction & Trading won the HDB Construction Award for its innovative approach to building Tampines GreenVerge, a 2,022-unit BTO project completed within four years with minimal delays. The project incorporated drone monitoring, automated systems, and a smart silt stopper to speed up construction. The award also recognized Northshore StraitsView in Punggol for its strong design identity and architectural features, which drew inspiration from Chinese landscape paintings. The HDB Design, Construction and Engineering Awards aim to provide well-designed and quality homes to Singaporeans.

site_title: Backup power generator failure at Woodlands caused outage, delayed immigration clearance: ICA
summary: A backup power generator failure at Woodlands Checkpoint in Singapore caused a power outage, disrupting immigration clearance for several hours. The generator failed during scheduled maintenance at 12:20am, leading to a 4-hour delay in immigration clearance. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) diverted traffic and used alternative checkpoints, and power was restored at 4am. The ICA apologized for the inconvenience and thanked travelers for their patience and cooperation.

site_title: Those above 50 urged to keep up with vaccine shots as vaccination-differentiated measures are lifted
summary: Singapore is set to lift its vaccination-differentiated measures (VDS) on Monday, allowing fully vaccinated individuals to move freely without restrictions. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung urged those above 50 to stay up to date with their Covid-19 vaccine shots, citing lower infection risks with full vaccination. The government has recommended switching to the bivalent vaccine, which has the same safety profile as the original vaccine, and will step up measures if needed to protect the unvaccinated and prevent severe cases.

site_title: I love Japan but I also love S'pore: Don Don Donki founder Takao Yasuda, whose younger son did NS
summary: Don Don Donki, a Japanese retailer, opened its 13th store in Singapore last Thursday. Founder Takao Yasuda, a Singapore-based entrepreneur, is known for challenging the norm. Born with a strong sense of adventure, Yasuda grew up memorizing the world map and dreamed of being an explorer. His unconventional approach has led to the success of Don Don Donki, which offers a unique shopping experience blending Japanese culture with local flair.

site_title: Football: Militao takes Real Madrid top of La Liga, Atletico scrape win
summary: Real Madrid secured a 1-0 win over Getafe, moving them to the top of La Liga with a three-point lead over Barcelona. Eder Militao scored in the 4th minute, and despite several scoring opportunities, Getafe couldn't equalize. Meanwhile, Atletico Madrid edged a 2-1 win over Girona, with Angel Correa scoring a brace. Sevilla drew 1-1 with Athletic Bilbao under new coach Jorge Sampaoli, who is hoping to improve the team's position in the table.

site_title: Cycling: Italy's Ganna powers to cycling world one-hour record
summary: Italian cyclist Filippo Ganna set a new track one-hour record with a distance of 56.792km at the Grenchen velodrome in Switzerland. Ganna, 26, surpassed the previous record of 55.548km set by British rider Daniel Bigham in August 2022. This achievement erases the mark of Chris Boardman from 1996, and marks the first Italian to set the hour record since 1984. Ganna's performance comes after a disappointing season, but he is now set to compete in the world track championships outside Paris between Oct 12-16.

site_title: Football: Dortmund deliver late Klassiker magic to steal 2-2 draw against Bayern
summary: Borussia Dortmund secured a 2-2 draw against Bayern Munich in a thrilling Der Klassiker match, with the match ending in a dramatic late equalizer by Youssoufa Moukoko. The match saw 11 yellow cards and a red card, with Bayern's Kingsley Coman sent off in the 90th minute. Dortmund's Anthony Modeste scored the equalizing goal in the 95th minute, sending the crowd into delirium. The draw leaves Bayern in third place, trailing surprise packages Union Berlin and Freiburg by a point, while Dortmund moves up to fourth with 16 points from nine matches.

site_title: Close to 1,000 ITE students deployed over the Formula 1 weekend
summary: Around 1,000 ITE students participated in a work attachment program at the Formula One Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix 2022. The students, from event management and business courses, were deployed as circuit park guides, service ambassadors, and information booth staff. Despite challenges such as heavy rain and rowdy patrons, the students demonstrated professionalism and provided excellent service. The program aimed to provide real-world training and work experience for the students, and many reported it as an eye-opening and valuable experience, with some even gaining a new appreciation for the sport.

site_title: An inclusive Singapore: Employment of people with disabilities is not just about numbers, but dignity
summary: Singapore aims to be a more inclusive society for people with disabilities by 2030. The government has released a roadmap with recommendations for employment, education, caregiver support, and public space inclusion. Consultant Ms. Chia Yong Yong, who has peroneal muscular atrophy, notes that the employment landscape has improved, but she faces barriers in inaccessible infrastructure. The Enabling Masterplan 2030 seeks to address these issues, promoting dignity and opportunities for individuals with disabilities, and aims to create a more welcoming environment for all.

site_title: An inclusive Singapore should have all-day audible traffic signals for visually impaired
summary: Singapore aims to become a more inclusive city by 2030 with a roadmap that includes recommendations for employment, education, caregiver support, and public spaces. The Enabling Masterplan 2030, released in August, includes all-day audible traffic signals to aid visually impaired pedestrians in traveling independently and safely. The initiative is expected to enhance accessibility and independence for people with disabilities, allowing them to navigate the city safely and confidently. The plan is part of Singapore's efforts to become a more welcoming place for people with disabilities.

site_title: More support needed for families and caregivers of people with disabilites, says parent of autistic boy
summary: A parent of a 19-year-old autistic boy expressed support for Singapore's disability inclusion roadmap, released in August. He suggested creating activities to engage those unable to work and addressing employment issues for those able to work. The parent emphasized the need for more support for families and caregivers of people with disabilities, particularly in caregiver support and inclusion in public spaces. The Enabling Masterplan 2030 aims to make Singapore a more welcoming place for people with disabilities by 2030. The parent's comments highlighted the importance of addressing the needs of individuals with high-needs autism.

site_title: Entrepreneur came for F1, leaves with potentially $180k of deals
summary: American entrepreneur Rembrandt Flores attended the Singapore Grand Prix, capitalizing on the event to network and secure deals. During his week-long visit, he hosted lavish parties and met with potential clients, including celebrities. Flores, founder of 8Commas, a Los Angeles-based Web3 consultancy, reportedly secured potentially $180,000 worth of deals, leveraging the event to expand his business. His activities were described as a whirlwind of networking, play, and repeat, showcasing his efforts to make the most of his time in Singapore.

site_title: Nearly 1,000 ITE students get real-world training at GP
summary: Nearly 1,000 ITE students participated in a work attachment program at the 2022 Formula One Singapore Grand Prix, gaining real-world training and experience in event management and customer service. The three-day event drew a record crowd of 302,000 fans despite heavy rain and challenging conditions. Students reported overcoming obstacles such as uncooperative guests and bad weather, and praised the opportunity to apply their skills in a professional setting. The program, which began in 2009, aims to provide students with hands-on experience at major international events.

site_title: Japan foreign minister calls on PM Lee; both reaffirm longstanding relations
summary: Japanese Foreign Minister Yoshimasa Hayashi visited Singapore, calling on Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong as part of his first official visit. Both leaders reaffirmed their longstanding relations and cooperation, including Japan's increased engagement with Asean. They discussed regional and global developments, and looked forward to deepening collaboration in areas such as digitalization, sustainability, and energy. The visit marked the 55th anniversary of Singapore-Japan diplomatic ties and came ahead of the 50th anniversary of Asean-Japan dialogue relations in 2023.

site_title: Looking forward to even more inclusive public spaces
summary: Singapore aims to become a more inclusive society by 2030 with a new roadmap released in August. The plan includes recommendations on employment, education, caregiver support, and accessible public spaces. A group of experts shared their thoughts on the plans, highlighting the need for inclusivity in public spaces. The government's goal is to create a welcoming environment for people with disabilities, with a focus on employment, education, and accessibility.

site_title: Singapore and Brunei conclude six-day bilateral naval exercise
summary: Singapore and Brunei concluded a six-day bilateral naval exercise, Exercise Pelican, which included the Republic of Singapore Air Force's (RSAF) F-16 fighter jets for the first time. The 40th edition of the exercise, held from Monday to Saturday, focused on mutual cooperation, understanding, and interoperability between the navies. The exercise involved various training activities, including gunnery firing, air defence, and communication drills. The event underscores the close and longstanding defence ties between the countries, with both navies praising the exercise's significance in their bilateral relations.

site_title: Impact of cooling measures on smaller resale flats being tracked
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Desmond Lee says the recent cooling measures on private property owners may inadvertently drive up demand for smaller Housing Board resale flats. The 15-month waiting period for non-subsidized HDB resale flats, which affects private property owners aged 55 and above, may lead to increased sales of four-room and smaller flats. The government will monitor the market response to the measures, aiming to moderate demand in the HDB resale market and ensure buyers borrow prudently.

site_title: Looking forward to even more inclusive public spaces in Singapore
summary: Singapore has released a roadmap for disability inclusion, known as the Enabling Masterplan (EMP) 2030, which includes recommendations for employment, education, caregiver support, and public spaces. The plan aims to make the city-state a more welcoming place for people with disabilities by 2030. Experts, including those with disabilities, have praised the plan, with one manager with cerebral palsy stating that inclusive public spaces would enable people with disabilities to participate in workplace activities and interact with colleagues. The plan's focus on inclusive public spaces is seen as a significant step forward in promoting disability inclusion.

site_title: Should drivers buy a new car or revalidate COE of an existing one?
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) revealed that as of August, 11,143 vehicles were nearing the end of their 10-year COE lifespan. Drivers have two options: revalidate their existing COE or purchase a new car. The decision depends on factors such as the vehicle's age, condition, and market value. Revalidating a COE may be more cost-effective, while buying a new car may provide better fuel efficiency and safety features, ultimately affecting the driver's choice and financial situation.

site_title: Extra leave days to build unity among ideas at Forward Singapore dialogue
summary: Singaporeans attending a Forward Singapore dialogue proposed an additional two days of paid leave to visit the country's heritage and cultural sites, aiming to deepen a shared identity and build unity. The suggestion came under the "unite" pillar, with participants suggesting that such visits could foster a sense of solidarity and appreciation for national symbols. The dialogue, part of a nationwide engagement exercise, is set to conclude with the release of a roadmap by the middle of 2023.

site_title: River boats may offer commuting service to Sports Hub by 2024
summary: Singapore River boats may launch a commuting service to the Sports Hub by 2024, offering 25% off standard ticket prices for sightseeing cruises and guided tours in Marina Reservoir. The tender aims to refresh cruise offerings and attract locals and international visitors to the area. Current river cruise service providers, such as Singapore River Cruise and Water B, are studying the tender as ridership recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic. The new plans may broaden activities for tourists and locals, but the success of previous attempts to launch river taxis in 2013 and 2017 remains uncertain.

site_title: UK's accession to set benchmark
summary: The UK has become the ninth member to ratify the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a trade bloc. This accession sets a benchmark for assessing other applicants, signaling the UK's commitment to free trade. The CPTPP, comprising 11 countries, aims to promote economic growth, innovation, and fair competition. With the UK's membership, the bloc now has a more diverse range of economies, paving the way for increased trade and investment opportunities among its members.

site_title: Me & My Money: Sticking to investing in what she knows best
summary: Caecilia Chu, co-founder of multicurrency payments platform YouTrip, focuses on long-term investments and thorough research. She invested in a reputable US-based hedge fund with a 15-year profitable track record after meeting its manager. This approach has served her well, and she continues to prioritize her knowledge and research in her investment decisions.

site_title: Smaller flats' resale prices tracked
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced that the resale prices of four-room and smaller Housing Board flats are being monitored. This move comes as the latest cooling measures aim to moderate demand for bigger flats. The tracking of smaller flat resale prices may indicate a potential rise in demand for these units.

site_title: When a $143m public company is based on a small deli
summary: Three men, James Patten, Peter Coker Sr, and Peter Coker Jr, face charges of securities fraud and market manipulation for allegedly inflating the price of two companies, Hometown Deli and E-Waste Corp, to over $100 million. The companies were created around a single deli in New Jersey, with the trio manipulating trading to create the appearance of active trading. The men could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted, with Patten also charged with wire fraud and money laundering. The SEC previously filed a civil suit against the trio.

site_title: Ukraine conflict holds lessons on how war could be avoided: SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasizes that the Russia-Ukraine conflict holds lessons on how war can be avoided, particularly in addressing the situation over Taiwan. Unlike parallels drawn between the two conflicts, Teo notes significant differences in structural and strategic levels. He urges leaders to analyze the situation and take steps to prevent war, citing the need for strategic thinking and conceptual ideas. Teo believes that both sides in the US-China relationship and the US and China's stance on Taiwan do not want war, but there must be a will and wisdom on all sides to maintain peace and cooperation.

site_title: Nine receive Muis awards for contributions to Muslim community
summary: Nine individuals received Muis awards for their contributions to the Muslim community, with Dr Abdul Razak Chanbasha receiving the highest accolade, the Jasa Cemerlang (Outstanding) Award, for his four decades of service in education and community development. Dr Razak, a Justice of the Peace and member of Warees Investments' board, was recognized for his work with the Association of Muslim Professionals. Eight others received the Jasa Bakti (Service) Award for their long service to the community, including Ustaz Fadlon Osman, who has served as a religious counsellor for over 20 years.

site_title: Woman gives birth in private-hire car as driver rushes couple to hospital
summary: A woman, Ms Jasmine Teo, 32, gave birth to a 3kg girl in a private-hire car after her husband called a ride-sharing service to rush her to the hospital due to intense labor pains. Driver Victor Albert, 60, broke traffic rules to get them to the hospital quickly, but they were stuck in a traffic jam. When Ms Teo's water broke, Albert drove in the bus lane and arrived at the hospital just in time. The baby was born in the back seat of the car, and Albert was praised for his heroic actions.

site_title: Singapore's 4G leaders have their hearts in the right place: Minister
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean expressed confidence in Singapore's fourth-generation (4G) leaders, stating they have the ability and capability to foster leadership and community bonding among Singaporeans. He attributed their success to their ability to work together and build trust, qualities he learned from his own experience in politics. Teo emphasized the importance of continuity and stability, citing the need for a good succession plan, and stated he will continue to serve Singapore regardless of his position or role after the next general election.

site_title: Businessman lost $18m over 8 years as he didn't read investment documents
summary: Entrepreneur FM Wang, chairman of a Chinese manufacturing company, lost approximately $18 million over 8 years due to his lack of financial literacy. He signed documents in both English and Chinese eight times, but failed to read them. Wang relied on bank relationship managers, rather than reading the documents himself, leading to significant financial losses. This incident highlights the importance of financial literacy and thoroughness in managing one's finances.

site_title: S'poreans' hopes for a more welcoming society for persons with disabilities
summary: Singaporeans are optimistic about the country's plans to become more inclusive for people with disabilities by 2030. The Enabling Masterplan (EMP) 2030 includes recommendations on employment, education, caregiver support, and public spaces. Experts, including those with disabilities, praise initiatives such as all-day audible traffic signals for visually impaired pedestrians and employment goals, but also highlight the need for more support for families and caregivers, particularly those with high-needs individuals. The masterplan aims to increase disability employment to 40% by 2030, but some advocate for faster implementation of interventions.

site_title: ST photojournalists tell their side of Covid-19 story
summary: ST photojournalists share their experiences covering the COVID-19 pandemic and the nation's reopening. They recall the early days of the pandemic, when they wore personal protective equipment and took precautions to avoid transmission. The journalists described the challenges of working during the pandemic, including the risk of infecting loved ones, and the shift to sanitizing themselves and their equipment. They also highlighted the human side of the pandemic, documenting the struggles of migrant workers and the joy of reunions as borders reopened. Their stories are part of the Through The Lens exhibition at the National Museum of Singapore.

site_title: What investors should know before investing in retail corporate bonds
summary: Fixed-income investments have gained popularity this year, with yields rising after the pandemic years of 2020 and 2021. Central banks are raising interest rates to control inflation, causing Treasury yields to spike globally. Retail corporate bonds offer higher coupon rates than government securities but come with added risks, making them a consideration for investors.

site_title: Sticking to investing in what she knows best

site_title: When a $143m public company is based on a small deli
summary: A $143 million public company, based on a single restaurant in New Jersey, is under scrutiny for alleged securities fraud and market manipulation. This case serves as a cautionary tale for investors who may not fully understand a company's business before investing. site_title: Businessman lost $18m over 8 years as he didn't read investment documents
summary: A Singapore businessman, FM Wang, lost approximately $18 million over 8 years due to his lack of reading investment documents. site_title: Capital protection reigns supreme in risky market
summary: Wealthy investors are prioritizing capital protection in volatile markets, adjusting their portfolios in response to rising interest rates. site_title: Fine jewellery as a 'refuge' for rich investors in turbulent times
summary: Hong Kong-based entrepreneur Calvin Lo notes that the coronavirus pandemic has made wealthy businessmen cautious about transferring power to their successors. Due to this, fine jewellery has become a refuge for these investors, allowing them to maintain control and value of their wealth. The pandemic has made them more conservative, hindering the ability to hand over the reins to their heirs, instead opting for jewellery as a secure asset.

site_title: 3 lasting impacts of WFH on work cultures
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted work cultures, with a drastic shift towards remote work. Prior to the pandemic, only 8% of professionals in the knowledge industry worked from home. By the second quarter of 2020, this number increased to 17.4%. The prolonged remote work period, now over 700 days, has led to a reevaluation of what constitutes productive work. This change is expected to have lasting impacts on work cultures, necessitating a radical revision of the definition of productive work post-pandemic.

site_title: Fine jewellery as a 'refuge' for rich investors in turbulent times
summary: Hong Kong-based entrepreneur Calvin Lo, CEO of R.E. Lee International, notes that the COVID-19 pandemic has made wealthy businessmen cautious about handing over their companies to successors. summary: Central banks worldwide are raising interest rates to combat inflation, causing Treasury yields to spike globally. As a result, fixed-income investments, such as retail corporate bonds, have gained attention this year, with yields increasing after the pandemic years of 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Save 50% of salary to retire by 50
summary: Millennials are redefining retirement goals, with many aiming to save 50% of their salary by age 50 to achieve financial independence. This trend marks a generational shift, as millennials prefer to retire earlier than their parents, who typically aim for the mid-to-late 60s.

site_title: UK's accession process to CPTPP trade bloc to be benchmark for others
summary: The UK's accession process to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade bloc will serve as a benchmark for future applications. site_title: 4 tips to help you avoid big losses

site_title: Lord Justice lays down the law in JRA Trophy
summary: Lord Justice, a 8-year-old bleeder, won the $70,000 Japan Racing Association Trophy, marking a significant turnaround in his racing career. Trainer David Kok has successfully handled the horse, which has only run five times since joining him in 2021, winning four times. The horse's recent win, its fourth in a row, has boosted Kok's chances for 2023, despite the trainer's modest acknowledgment of the achievement. Kok attributes the horse's success to its fitness and the claim of apprentice jockey Jerlyn Seow, which helped with the weight advantage.

site_title: Mickelson the S'pore fan
summary: Phil Mickelson, the world's second-ranked golfer, is set to return to Sentosa, Singapore, when LIV Golf debuts in the city-state in 2023. The 2023 season will feature 14 events with a $405 million prize purse, with the Singapore event topping the US$6 million Barclays Singapore Open. Mickelson, a fan of Singapore's former prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, expressed his excitement to play at Sentosa, praising the country's development and golf course. The event is expected to draw a massive crowd and provide opportunities for local golfers to qualify for the LIV events.

site_title: City hail 'incredible weapon'
summary: Manchester City's Erling Haaland has scored his 15th Premier League goal in just nine games, matching Kevin de Bruyne's total from the 2021-2022 season. Haaland's goal helped City win 4-0 at home to Southampton, moving the team to the top of the table. De Bruyne also became the club's overall assist leader in the league with his 95th assist. City's win was their fourth consecutive home league victory, and they are now on a 9-game streak of scoring at least three goals at home, a feat last achieved by Wolverhampton Wanderers in 1959.

site_title: 4 tips to help you avoid big investment losses
summary: A recent article offers four tips to help investors avoid significant losses. Key takeaways include being aware of statements sent by the investment company, especially those that can impact holdings due to market volatility. Investors should also be cautious of blaming others when losses occur, as this can hinder their ability to learn from mistakes. In contrast, when profits are made, investors tend to attribute success to their own investment genius rather than acknowledging the role of luck. By adopting a more realistic and humble approach, investors can make more informed decisions and minimize potential losses.

site_title: Pereira aims for elusive first PGA win
summary: Chilean golfer Mito Pereira shot an 8-under 63 to take the lead after two rounds of the Shriners Children's Open, sitting at 12-under 130. Pereira has a one-shot edge over American Robby Shelton, who also scored a 63. Pereira is seeking his first PGA Tour win, having previously led at the end of a round in the 2022 PGA Championship. He is focused on getting his first win, putting past disappointments aside.

site_title: Playing smart the key as Chacarra turns up the heat
summary: Eugenio Chacarra, a 22-year-old golfer, leads the LIV Golf Invitational Bangkok with a 16-under 128 total after two rounds. He posted a nine-under 63 on Saturday, five strokes ahead of a four-way tie for second. Chacarra, who turned pro in June, credits playing with experienced teammates and learning from them as key to his success. He will face a 48-strong field in the final round on Sunday, where individual winners earn $4 million and the top team will receive $3 million.

site_title: Believe you can win: Arteta
summary: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta is urging his team to show a fearless mentality ahead of their match against Liverpool, citing their recent North London derby win as a confidence booster. The Gunners, who have 21 points after eight matches, face a tough test against the Reds, who have won only twice in seven league games. Arteta believes a statement win could give Arsenal a psychological boost and increase their chances of a top-four finish, while also potentially ending their exile from the Champions League since 2016-17.

site_title: Save 50% of salary to retire by 50
summary: Millennial workers are redefining retirement goals, with many aiming to leave their jobs by 50 and achieve financial independence earlier than their parents. A significant generational shift is underway, with many seeking to work for themselves or take a lower-paying role that aligns with their interests. However, experts warn that saving 50% of salary to retire by 50 is challenging, especially considering living costs and desired lifestyles. Many millennials are taking a more flexible approach, focusing on saving and investing to enjoy life before retirement, rather than solely relying on saving for financial independence.

site_title: China dedicate dominant win to supporters
summary: China won their 22nd consecutive women's team title at the World Team Table Tennis Championships, defeating Japan 3-0 in front of their home fans. The Chinese team, led by world No. 1 Sun Yingsha, Olympic champion Chen Meng, and reigning world champion Wang Manyu, dominated the competition. China's victory extends their record-extending 22nd title and sets them up for a potential double celebration in the men's final on Sunday. Japan's 51-year wait to reclaim the Corbillon Cup continues.

site_title: Be nasty but also smart, says ten Hag
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag emphasized the need for his team to adopt a ruthless, aggressive edge while also becoming "streetwise" and savvy to challenge for honors. The team has collected 23 yellow cards, prompting ten Hag to remind players to play both smart and nasty. Ten Hag warned that developing the required urgency, intensity, and mindset will take months, not weeks or a month. Manchester United face Everton on Sunday, looking to bounce back from a 6-3 loss to Manchester City. Ten Hag will assess the fitness of Raphael Varane, who will face a late test.

site_title: Pogacar thanks team for 'almost perfect' season
summary: Tadej Pogacar retained his Giro di Lombardia title, winning the 253km race from Bergamo to Como. Pogacar, a two-time Tour de France winner, beat Enric Mas in a two-man sprint, with Mikel Landa third. Pogacar praised his UAE Team Emirates teammates, calling the season "almost perfect." The victory marked his third win in a "Monument" classic race. The season concluded with notable retirements of Vincenzo Nibali and Alejandro Valverde, who will participate in the inaugural Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium.

site_title: Come rain or shine, Max is on cloud nine
summary: Max Verstappen secured pole position at the Japanese Grand Prix, beating Charles Leclerc by 0.010 seconds. Verstappen's 18th pole of his career sets him up to potentially win his second consecutive Formula One title. With a 104-point lead, Verstappen needs to score eight more points than Leclerc to secure the championship. The weather may pose a challenge, but Verstappen is confident in his car's performance.

site_title: Ricciardo to sit out 2023 after driver merry-go-round
summary: Daniel Ricciardo has announced he won't be racing in Formula One in 2023 due to limited options, with only two teams, Haas and Williams, offering him a seat. Ricciardo, who has won eight F1 races, is setting his sights on a return to the grid in 2024. The move comes after a series of driver changes, including Pierre Gasly's signing with Alpine and Nyck de Vries' promotion to AlphaTauri. Ricciardo will take a break from F1 to recharge and considers a reserve driver role at Mercedes.

site_title: Klopp faces many bumps in the road to a Reds rebuild
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp faces a challenging path to rebuilding his team after a decline in form. The Reds, like Premier League leaders Arsenal and Manchester City, are playing exciting football with new arrivals and veteran players performing well. However, this resurgence is a stark contrast to Liverpool's recent struggles, raising concerns about their ability to sustain success. Klopp's team is now in a similar position to Arsenal, highlighting the difficulties in replicating past glory. A significant road back to their dominant era appears to be ahead of the Reds.

site_title: Mbappe, 23, tops list of best-paid footballers
summary: French striker Kylian Mbappe tops the list of the world's highest-paid football players with an estimated annual earnings of $128 million, surpassing Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo. Mbappe, 23, achieved this milestone after signing a three-year contract extension with Paris Saint-Germain in May. The top-10 highest-earning players will collect $652 million this season, with Mbappe, Messi, and Ronaldo accounting for more than half of the total.

site_title: Sports World: S'pore U-19 cricket team win in Oman
summary: Singapore's U-19 cricket team won the Asia Division 2 qualifiers in Oman, defeating Hong Kong by 5 wickets. The team will join other teams in the final round of the qualifiers in 2023, securing a spot at the 2024 U-19 World Cup. Meanwhile, Tampines Rovers secured third spot in the Singapore Premier League, while Jodi Ewart Shadoff leads the LPGA Mediheal Championship with a 4-stroke lead.

site_title: Tennis: Swiatek into Ostrava final with 60th win of 2022
summary: Iga Swiatek reached the Ostrava WTA final with a three-set victory over Ekaterina Alexandrova, her 60th win of the 2022 season. The 21-year-old Pole equalled Caroline Wozniacki's record, and advanced to her 10th final of the year. Swiatek will face Barbora Krejcikova in the final, who also won in three sets to reach the championship. Both players are seeking their first title of the year.

site_title: Football: Man City move top, Chelsea and Newcastle continue to rise, Spurs respond
summary: Manchester City moved to the top of the Premier League with a 4-0 win over Southampton, while Chelsea and Newcastle continued their rise with victories over Wolves and Brentford, respectively. Tottenham Hotspur responded to a difficult week with a 1-0 win over Brighton & Hove Albion. The wins put pressure on early title rivals Arsenal and Leicester City, with City now 23 points from nine matches and Chelsea moving to fourth with 16 points.

site_title: Investing in sustainability without compromising returns during volatile times
summary: The BlackRock ESG Multi-Asset Fund offers investors a chance to score well on both returns and sustainability, leveraging BlackRock's global expertise in asset management and sustainable investing. The fund has outperformed its peers, achieving better risk-adjusted returns over the past three years and consistently ranking in the first quartile by Morningstar. It adopts a "best-in-class" approach and uses exclusionary screens aligned with global regulatory requirements. The fund aims to capture opportunities in energy and food security, as well as technological innovation, making it an attractive option for investors seeking sustainable returns.

site_title: Table tennis: China claim fifth straight women's title at world meet
summary: China won their fifth consecutive women's team title at the World Team Table Tennis Championships in Chengdu, China, sweeping past Japan 3-0. The Chinese team, led by top players Chen Meng, Wang Manyu, and Sun Yingsha, dominated the competition, with Sun Yingsha closing out the title with a 3-0 victory over Miyu Nagasaki. This marks China's 22nd victory in the women's team event, while Japan's 51-year wait to reclaim the Corbillon Cup continues.

site_title: As home loan rates rise in Singapore, how can home owners find ways to save?
summary: Singapore's fixed home loan rates hit a new high of 3.85% as interest rates offered by private financial institutions continue to rise. To help homeowners and buyers save, DBS Bank has launched two schemes: DBS HomeSaver, which allows customers to earn higher interest on their savings, and a POSB HDB home loan package pegged at 2.6%. Experts advise borrowers to reassess their consumption and spending habits, find a loan that suits their needs, and understand the terms and costs involved. Building an emergency fund with at least six months' worth of expenses is also crucial to mitigate the impact of interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Housing Board flats in Singapore

site_title: 'Aggressive' Tsitsipas awaits Djokovic
summary: Stefanos Tsitsipas defeated Russia's Andrey Rublev 4-6, 6-4, 6-3 to reach the Astana Open final. He will face 21-time Grand Slam champion Novak Djokovic on Sunday. Djokovic, who beat Daniil Medvedev in the semi-finals, expressed his get-well wishes for Medvedev, who pulled an adductor muscle in his leg. Tsitsipas credited his aggressive game style for the comeback victory, and Djokovic acknowledged that Medvedev was the better player in the match. The final is scheduled for 6:30pm local time on Sunday.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic into Astana final after surprise Medvedev retirement
summary: Novak Djokovic reached the final of the ATP tournament in Astana after Daniil Medvedev unexpectedly retired at the end of the second set, trailing 4-6, 7-6 (8/6). Djokovic, 21-time Grand Slam champion, will face Stefanos Tsitsipas in Sunday's final. Tsitsipas, the third seed, beat Andrey Rublev in the other semifinal, winning 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. Djokovic has won seven of his nine meetings with Tsitsipas, including in last year's French Open final, and aims for his 90th ATP title.

site_title: Extra leave days to build unity among suggestions at Forward Singapore dialogue
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has suggested an additional two days of paid leave for all Singaporeans to explore the country's heritage and cultural sites, aiming to build unity and appreciation for the Singapore identity. The idea was proposed during a Forward Singapore dialogue held at Yew Tee Community Club, where 136 participants shared their views on refreshing Singapore's social compact. The event, part of a nationwide engagement exercise, aims to engage all Singaporeans in the national conversation and chart a new way forward for the country.

site_title: Football: Bournemouth heap more misery on Leicester with comeback win
summary: Bournemouth came from behind to defeat Leicester City 2-1 at the Vitality Stadium, moving to eighth in the Premier League. Leicester, who have lost all five of their away games this season, fell to their seventh loss of the season. Bournemouth's second-half comeback, sparked by a levelling goal in the 68th minute, was completed when Ryan Christie scored in the 72nd minute. The result leaves Leicester in 19th place in the relegation zone.

site_title: Football: 'Good men’ helped Spurs win after sudden death of fitness coach – Conte
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte credited his team's victory over Brighton & Hove Albion as a testament to the "good men" on his squad, following the sudden death of their fitness coach Gian Piero Ventrone. Ventrone died on Tuesday after being diagnosed with leukemia, leaving the team devastated. Spurs won 1-0, with Harry Kane scoring his eighth league goal of the season, and Conte praised his team's resilience in the face of tragedy. Conte will attend Ventrone's funeral on Monday.

site_title: On The Ball: Roadblocks in Klopp's path to rebuild Liverpool
summary: Liverpool coach Jurgen Klopp is facing roadblocks in his attempt to rebuild the team, with rumors of buyer's remorse surrounding striker Darwin Nunez. The team, once in contention with Arsenal and Manchester City for the Premier League lead, is struggling to regain its footing. Klopp has publicly defended Nunez to quell behind-the-scenes concerns, but it appears Liverpool's path to recovery is becoming increasingly difficult. The team's recent performance is reminiscent of a significant setback, leaving Klopp to navigate a challenging landscape.

site_title: Football: Haaland scores in 10th straight game as City cruise to 4-0 win over Saints
summary: Manchester City cruised to a 4-0 win over Southampton, moving to the top of the Premier League with 23 points from nine matches. Erling Haaland scored his 10th consecutive goal in all club competitions, netting his 15th league goal of the season in the 65th minute. The Norwegian striker had a difficult afternoon, narrowly missing chances earlier, but City's victory took them to the top of the standings ahead of Arsenal, who can reclaim the lead if they beat Liverpool on Sunday.

site_title: Football: Guimaraes double helps resurgent Newcastle win 5-1 over Brentford
summary: Newcastle United secured a 5-1 win over Brentford, moving up to fifth in the Premier League with 14 points. Bruno Guimaraes scored twice, including a solo goal, and Jacob Murphy, Miguel Almiron, and Ethan Pinnock also found the net. The win marked a significant turnaround for the resurgent team, just a year after the Saudi Arabia-backed takeover. Newcastle coach Eddie Howe praised his team's intensity and pressing, while Brentford boss Thomas Frank expressed disappointment with his side's sloppy display.

site_title: Singapore Hospice Council raises $472,000 for palliative care awareness, training
summary: The Singapore Hospice Council raised approximately $472,000 from a charity concert to increase awareness and improve palliative care services in Singapore. The funds will support advocacy work and caregiver training in areas such as pain management and bereavement support. The event aimed to promote early consideration of palliative care, which can improve patients' quality of life and reduce unnecessary hospitalization. The money will also be used to train caregivers in administering medication and proper nutrition for patients with advanced illnesses.

site_title: Football: England in 'good place' but not the world's best team, says Wiegman
summary: England women's coach Sarina Wiegman described her team as "in a good place" after a 2-1 win over the US in a friendly match at Wembley Stadium. The match, ahead of the 2023 World Cup, saw Lauren Hemp score an early goal and Georgia Stanway secure a penalty for England. Wiegman played down suggestions England are the world's best team, stating that winning the World Cup is the ultimate measure of greatness. US coach Vlatko Andonovski praised England's squad and performance, calling them title contenders for the 2023 World Cup.

site_title: Football: Chelsea stroll past Wolves to continue winning run under Potter
summary: Chelsea secured a 3-0 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers at Stamford Bridge, handing new manager Graham Potter his first Premier League home win. Goals from Kai Havertz, Christian Pulisic, and Armando Broja helped the team continue their winning run under Potter. The victory took Chelsea to fourth in the standings with 16 points from eight games, while Wolves remain 18th with six points after three straight defeats. Potter made seven changes to his lineup, but Chelsea's strength in depth and dominance ultimately outclassed the struggling Wolves side.

site_title: Golf: LIV Tour has 'put a defibrillator on the game', says CEO Greg Norman
summary: LIV Golf CEO Greg Norman calls his tour a game-changer, stating it has "put a defibrillator on the game". The series, backed by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, has sparked controversy with its $255 million investment luring players away from the PGA and DP World Tours. Norman envisions a more extravagant and attention-grabbing approach, including high-profile partnerships and out-of-this-world promotional stunts.

site_title: Golf: Millionaire rookie Chacarra on top after 2nd round of LIV event in Bangkok
summary: Eugenio Chacarra, a 22-year-old rookie golfer, leads the leaderboard after 36 holes at the LIV Golf Invitational Bangkok, posting a 16-under 128 total with a 9-under 63 in the second round. Chacarra holds a five-stroke lead over a four-way tie for second, with Richard Bland, Sihwan Kim, Harold Varner III, and Patrick Reed trailing. Chacarra's impressive performance earns him a potential $4 million individual prize and a spot in contention for the LIV Golf Invitational Bangkok title.

site_title: 9 individuals recognised for contributions towards Muslim community at annual Muis Awards
summary: Nine individuals were recognized for their contributions to the Muslim community at the annual Muis Awards, with Dr Abdul Razak Chanbasha receiving the Jasa Cemerlang Award for his four decades of service in education and community development. Other recipients include Madam Norlizah Yusof, who advocates for women's empowerment, and Ustaz Fadlon Osman, who has served as a religious counsellor to inmates and their families. The awards aim to recognize those who have made significant contributions to the socio-religious life of the local Muslim community, with over 150 individuals having received the awards since 1991.

site_title: Rugby: New Zealand survive early scare to open home World Cup with a win
summary: New Zealand women's rugby team overcame a strong early start from Australia to win 41-17 in their World Cup opener at Eden Park in Auckland. Hosts and reigning champions New Zealand scored seven unanswered tries after Australia was reduced to 13 women in the second half. Prolific winger Portia Woodman scored a hat-trick, while Ruby Tui grabbed a late double. England also dominated their match against Fiji, scoring 84-19 and extending their unbeaten run to 26 matches, while France won 40-5 against South Africa.

site_title: Basketball: Celtics coach Ime Udoka rose fast and fell hard
summary: Boston Celtics coach Ime Udoka has been suspended for a year after a mysterious incident involving a female subordinate, according to two people familiar with the situation. The Celtics cited "violations of team policies" without providing further details. Udoka, a former player and assistant coach, had a reputation for his strong work ethic and tenacity on the court, but his personal life has been shrouded in mystery. The suspension has left the team in turmoil, with an interim coach taking over, and fans and former teammates struggling to understand the circumstances surrounding Udoka's departure.

site_title: Singapore, Brunei conclude 6-day bilateral naval exercise
summary: Singapore and Brunei navies concluded their 6-day bilateral naval exercise, Exercise Pelican, which marked the 40th edition of the annual exercise. The exercise, held from Monday to Saturday, involved a range of training activities, including air defence drills with Republic of Singapore Air Force's F-16 fighter jets for the first time. The exercise aimed to enhance mutual cooperation, understanding, and interoperability between the navies of the two countries, underscoring their close and long-standing defence ties.

site_title: HDB monitoring if cooling moves impact prices of 4-room and smaller resale flats: Desmond Lee
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee has announced that prices of four-room and smaller Housing Board (HDB) resale flats are being monitored for any increase resulting from recent cooling measures. The measures, implemented on September 30, restrict private property owners from buying non-subsidized HDB flats for 15 months after selling their current home. Lee aims to moderate demand in the HDB resale market and ensure buyers borrow prudently, while providing options for seniors to downgrade or right-size their living arrangements. The government will closely monitor market responses to the measures.

site_title: Motor racing: Verstappen on the verge of title success with Suzuka pole
summary: Max Verstappen secured pole position at the Japanese Grand Prix, edging Charles Leclerc by 0.010 seconds. Verstappen's Red Bull teammate Carlos Sainz took third. Verstappen's pole position puts him on course to win a second consecutive Formula One title, but the weather forecast for Sunday's race is uncertain. With rain affecting practice sessions, Verstappen leads Leclerc by 104 points and needs to score eight more points than Leclerc to secure the title.

site_title: Football: Rooney urges out-of-favour Man United forward Ronaldo to stay patient
summary: Former Manchester United player Wayne Rooney advised Cristiano Ronaldo to remain patient and make the most of opportunities as he works to regain his place in the team. Ronaldo has started only one league game this season, amid rumors of a potential move away. Rooney, who played with Ronaldo at United between 2004-2009, acknowledged that time catches up with players and that Ronaldo will find it hard to sit on the bench. Rooney believes Ronaldo will get his chance if he stays patient, but ultimately it's up to Ronaldo to take those chances and force his way back into the team.

site_title: UK accession process to be benchmark for other CPTPP trade pact applicants: Gan Kim Yong
summary: The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has agreed to use the UK's accession process as a benchmark for assessing other countries' applications to join the trade bloc. CPTPP members support the expansion of the agreement with countries committed to its objectives. Discussions on Britain's accession are ongoing, and other applications, including from China, Taiwan, and South Korea, are also under consideration. The agreement has already started to deliver trade benefits to member states, with trade in goods increasing by 15% among CPTPP members.

site_title: askST: Should I get a new car or revalidate the COE on my existing one?
summary: COE prices have been rising, increasing car prices. According to the Land Transport Authority, 11,143 cars in Singapore are nearing the end of their 10-year COE lifespan. To continue owning a vehicle, drivers can either revalidate their COE or purchase a new car, as options are limited due to the impending COE expiration. This decision may impact car buyers, especially those who want to keep their existing vehicle.

site_title: Japan's Foreign Minister Hayashi calls on PM Lee, Singapore ministers
summary: Japanese Foreign Minister Yoshimasa Hayashi visited Singapore, calling on Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and reaffirming the strong cooperation between the two countries. The visit comes ahead of the 50th anniversary of Asean-Japan dialogue relations in 2023. Both leaders discussed regional and international issues, as well as opportunities for collaboration in areas like digitalization, sustainability, and energy. They also welcomed Japan's increased engagement with Asean, and looked forward to deepening bilateral cooperation.

site_title: 17 arrested over the sale of illegal streaming devices
summary: Singapore authorities arrested 17 individuals, aged 24-61, suspected of selling illegal streaming devices valued at $500,000. Over 2,500 devices were seized during simultaneous raids at Sim Lim Square retail shops. The devices enabled access to unauthorized content from online sources. The English Premier League (EPL) collaborated with police on the raid, welcoming the Copyright Act amendments that make piracy illegal. This crackdown follows the blocking of 99 web addresses and a previous court victory against unauthorized sellers in 2019, demonstrating authorities' commitment to tackling piracy.

site_title: Woman gives birth on way to hospital; second taxi birth for Tada
summary: A Singaporean woman, Ms Jasmine Teo, gave birth to a 3kg girl in the back seat of a taxi driven by Victor Albert, who broke traffic rules to rush to the hospital. The baby was born at 8:35am after Ms Teo's water bag broke while stuck in a traffic jam. Mr Albert alerted the doctors upon arrival, and the medical team delivered the baby. This is the second birth in a year for taxi company Tada, and the driver has been rewarded with a hamper of wellness items and fuel vouchers.

site_title: Vaccination-differentiated measures for Covid-19 to be lifted from Oct 10
summary: Singapore will lift vaccination-differentiated measures (VDS) from October 10, marking a new phase of living with Covid-19. The measures, which included restrictions on events and dining, will no longer be required for groups over 500, nightlife establishments, and hawker centers. The government will instead focus on up-to-date vaccination, with individuals needing three doses for those 5 and above, and a booster dose for those 50 and above.

site_title: Dow ends 2.1% lower as rate hike fears weigh on US stocks
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.1% on Friday, led by the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as investors feared further interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. A strong jobs report showed a steady slowdown in the economy, boosting expectations for another rate hike in November. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell sharply, with the unemployment rate dipping to 3.5%. Investors are concerned that the Fed's aggressive measures will continue to impact the equity markets, despite recent gains.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore to end vaccination-differentiated safe management measures on October 10, marking a new phase of living with Covid-19. The country will rely on vaccination as its primary defense against the virus. Meanwhile, six people face criminal charges over a football stadium disaster in Indonesia that killed 131 people, and a new retail industry strategy was announced to help Singaporean retail brands grow and diversify overseas. Additionally, domestic workers in Singapore will receive a mandatory day off per month starting January 1, 2023.

site_title: Two more Mie Sedaap instant noodle products recalled due to pesticide: SFA
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has recalled two more Mie Sedaap instant noodle products due to ethylene oxide contamination, a pesticide not authorised for use in food. The affected products, Mie Sedaap Soto and Curry flavour instant noodles, were imported from Indonesia and have expiry dates of Dec 11, 2022 and Feb 22, 2023. SFA is investigating the cause of contamination and will continue to test other products from the brand. Consumers who have bought the affected products are advised to seek medical advice if they have health concerns.

site_title: ST photojournalists share challenges, stories of covering Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Singaporean photojournalists from The Straits Times shared their experiences and challenges covering the COVID-19 pandemic during a talk at the National Museum of Singapore. Chief photojournalist Kevin Lim described the initial scenes of people in full personal protective equipment, which prepared him for the days to come. Senior executive photojournalist Kua Chee Siong discussed the risks of transmitting the virus and sanitizing himself after assignments. Other journalists, including Jason Quah and Feline Lim, shared their experiences documenting the reopening of the Causeway, border restrictions, and the impact on Filipino workers.

site_title: Maids to get one mandatory rest day a month from Jan 1
summary: From Jan 1, 2023, all employers in Singapore must provide domestic workers with at least one mandatory rest day each month, which cannot be compensated with cash. The rest day can be taken on any day of the week and can be taken as one full day or over two half-days. This move aims to support the well-being of domestic workers, allowing them to rest and recharge, and potentially improve their performance and relationship with employers.

site_title: Projects to future-proof healthcare highlighted at SGH event
summary: The Singapore General Hospital (SGH) has showcased research projects aimed at future-proofing the healthcare system. A mobile app, Audioflow, can detect abnormal urinary flows and predict patient loads at the emergency department, while a predictive model forecasts patient attendances and lengths of stay. The projects are part of the SGH Annual Scientific Meeting awards and aim to strengthen the healthcare system against future shocks in a rapidly ageing Singapore. The projects utilize technology to improve healthcare services, following the trend of increased comfort with digital healthcare during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Keep region open and inclusive amid uncertainties: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for countries to steer the region towards peace and stability amidst geopolitical disputes and economic fragmentation. He encouraged countries to build stakes in the region, foster economic interdependence, and integration, citing Singapore and Asean's open and inclusive approach as a model. Wong highlighted the importance of multilateralism, strengthening international law, and cooperation, while also supporting China's "reform and opening up" and promoting people-to-people links between nations.

site_title: Two scholarships, one professorship set up in O&G department in NUS Medicine
summary: The National University of Singapore Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine has unveiled two scholarships and a professorship in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (O&G) to celebrate its centennial. The Kuldip Singh Visiting Professorship, funded by $1 million, supports research collaborations and mentors promising academics. Two scholarships, the Sabaratnam Arulkumaran Scholarship and the Obstetrics and Gynaecology Centennial Bursary, also launched, providing financial support for research and medical students, respectively.
