site_title: Resilient corporate earnings may give global stocks a year-end bounce
summary: Global stocks may experience a year-end bounce due to resilient corporate earnings, which could help offset a brutal quarter. The MSCI All-Country World Index declined 7% for the third straight quarter, but analysts believe this sets a lower bar for companies to clear. Past stock performance suggests a potential recovery, with the S&P 500 gaining 4.1% in the final quarter of the past 20 years. Despite ongoing challenges, including higher costs, tighter monetary policy, and global economic uncertainty, some strategists expect a short-term bounce, citing contrarian indicators and favorable sector performance.

site_title: Digital banks should focus on innovative products: Expert
summary: Digital banks should focus on offering innovative products that differentiate them from traditional banks rather than competing on interest rates, according to WeLab Digital's founder and CEO Simon Loong. This approach will ensure long-term profitability, rather than a short-term battle for customers. By carefully selecting their customer base, digital banks can establish a competitive edge and achieve sustained success.

site_title: Keppel trust eyes trebling of portfolio to $18b in next 10 years
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) aims to triple its portfolio to $18 billion within the next 10 years. Under CEO Jopy Chiang, the trust has expanded its reach beyond existing markets, securing interests in wind assets in Europe and venturing into Saudi Arabia and South Korea. KIT has also reshaped its strategy to tap new opportunities, with renewable energy investments expected to make up 25% of its equity-adjusted assets under management. The trust reported a 2.7% year-on-year increase in its distribution per unit for the first half of FY2022, despite lower distributable income.

site_title: China's market rout opens up a historic gap with Indian stocks
summary: China's stock market has experienced a historic decline, with the MSCI China Index plummeting 23% in the last quarter, while the MSCI India Index rallied almost 10%. This divergence has made India an attractive alternative, driven by its economic growth forecast to be the fastest in Asia and its ability to weather a looming global recession. India's domestic market expansion and structural barriers to investing in China have contributed to the shift, with major companies like Apple and Citigroup expanding their presence in the country.

site_title: EC World Reit proposes asset sale for loan repayment
summary: EC World Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is proposing to sell its indirect interests in two Chinese logistics properties, Bei Gang Logistics and Chongxian Port Logistics, for 1.2 billion yuan and 820 million yuan respectively. The proceeds will mainly be used to repay existing loans, with 450.9 million yuan also paid to unit holders through a special distribution. The divestment aims to reduce the Reit's debt by at least 25% and is expected to generate 1.3 billion yuan in net proceeds.

site_title: Asia's factory activity slows on global slump
summary: Asia's factory activity slowed in September due to declining demand in China and advanced economies, exacerbated by rising raw material costs and global economic uncertainty. Surveys showed Japan's PMI at 50.8, down from 51.5, while Taiwan's, Vietnam's, and Malaysia's PMIs also declined. China's factory activity data also pointed to cooling, with its official PMI at 50.1 and Caixin/Markit manufacturing PMI at 48.1. The slowdown clouds Asia's economic recovery prospects, with many analysts expecting China's economy to grow by just 3% this year.

site_title: Hughes' 'super special' victory
summary: Canadian golfer Mackenzie Hughes won the PGA Tour's Sanderson Farms Championship after defeating Austria's Sepp Straka in a two-hole play-off. Hughes, 31, secured his second career PGA title, finishing at 17-under 271, after sinking an eight-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole. Hughes credited his perseverance and grit for the victory, saying it felt "super special" and was a relief after a close finish.

site_title: Iras can share info on taxpayers with govt agencies even without consent
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) will be able to share taxpayer information with government agencies without consent, but only for company-related data. This change, made to the Income Tax Act, will apply to company sales revenue and other business-related information. Safeguards will be in place to protect data confidentiality, including sharing information in ranges rather than exact values. The move aims to strengthen the performance of official duties and is expected to bring in $170 million in additional revenue annually.

site_title: S'pore factory activity contracts for first time since 2020, raising risk of technical recession
summary: Singapore's manufacturing activity contracted for the first time in over two years in September, with the Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 49.9 points, down 0.1 from August. This contraction, coupled with a second month of decline in the electronics sector, raises the risk of a technical recession, defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth. Analysts attribute the decline to soaring inflation, interest rate hikes, and slumping global demand, particularly in the electronics sector, which accounts for 40% of Singapore's industrial output.

site_title: MS Holdings chairman offers 7 cents a share to privatise firm
summary: MS Holdings' chairman Ng Chui Hwa's company, Kingswin Investment, has made a voluntary unconditional cash offer to privatize the crane rental company at 7 cents per share, representing a 16.7% premium over the last trading price. The offer is aimed at shareholders who struggle to exit their investments due to low trading liquidity. Kingswin Investment plans to compulsorily acquire remaining shares if it receives 90% valid acceptances. The offer is seen as an opportunity for shareholders to exit their investments.

site_title: Pound gains after British govt U-turn on cut to top tax rate
summary: The British pound gained 1% against the US dollar on news that the government would reverse plans to cut the highest rate of income tax, a move that sent sterling and government bonds into meltdown last month. The reversal, which saves £2 billion, is expected to support the pound but may not be enough to restore confidence. Analysts warn further government action may be needed to stabilize the currency, which had slumped to a record low of $1.03270 last week. The yen fell to 145.4 against the US dollar, its lowest level since September 22.

site_title: Private home prices continue to climb, led by 7% surge for suburban condos
summary: Private home prices in Singapore rose 3.4% in the third quarter of 2022, with suburban condos experiencing a 7% surge. The non-landed segment saw a 4.1% increase, driven by strong demand for new condominium units. Prices for new non-landed homes reached a record $2,093 per sq ft, while landed home prices rose 1.2%. Analysts attribute the growth to healthy demand, low interest rates, and pandemic recovery, despite looming economic slowdown and expected interest rate hikes.

site_title: 'extra motivation' serves Djokovic well
summary: Novak Djokovic claimed his third title of 2022 with a straight-set victory over Marin Cilic in the Tel Aviv final. The 35-year-old Serb won 6-3, 6-4, his 19th win over Cilic in 21 meetings. Djokovic, who hadn't played a tournament in three months, credited the absence with "extra motivation." The win strengthens his claim for a place at the ATP Finals, where he just needs to finish in the top 20.

site_title: 'Amazing experience' in Japan for Warriors
summary: The Golden State Warriors, led by Stephen Curry, completed a productive pre-season trip to Japan with a 104-95 win over the Washington Wizards in their second exhibition game. Curry scored 17 points in almost 17 minutes, while rookie Patrick Baldwin Jr. contributed to the Warriors' comeback in the final quarter. The team will fine-tune their skills in three remaining pre-season games before the season opener on October 18. Curry described the trip as an "amazing experience" both on and off the court, praising Japan and Tokyo.

site_title: 'Bottle Claus' key to Kipchoge's mark
summary: Eliud Kipchoge broke his own world record in the Berlin Marathon, finishing with a time of 2:01:09. Key to his success was Claus-Henning Schulke, a volunteer known as "Bottle Claus," who expertly passed Kipchoge 13 bottles during the 42km race. Schulke's precise hand-offs, which he has honed over 25 years, ensured Kipchoge's nutrition plan was executed flawlessly, allowing him to set a new world record. Kipchoge praised Schulke's role in his victory, writing "Thank you for helping me today" on the back of his race bib.

site_title: Singapore stocks start week with losses as weak sentiment lingers
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.7% on Monday, with 24 of 30 STI counters down, led by Wilmar International's 3.4% drop to a 52-week low. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,107.09. The decline follows a weak Wall Street trend and US equity futures weakness, with 337 losers outweighing 175 gainers. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also fell 0.83% to its lowest point since 2011.

site_title: It should pay to Call Me Master in the last race
summary: South Africa's Vaal racing saw several notable performances across eight races. Call Me Master, a top contender, is in form and could make it four wins in his last five starts in the 8th race. Raiseahallelujah is looking for a fourth consecutive win in the 5th race, while several horses, including Imperial Ruby and Duke of Sussex, are expected to contend in their respective races. The outcomes of the events will be determined by the horses' tactics and performances.

site_title: Reports on costs of Optus data hack speculative, says Singtel
summary: Singtel has dismissed media reports citing potential fines or costs from the Optus data hack, saying they are "speculative" and will disclose material developments on a timely basis. The breach, which affected nearly 10 million Optus accounts, may result in costs of up to A$661 million for document replacement and up to US$560 million for Singtel. A class action is reportedly being investigated, with lawyers engaged to advise Optus. An independent review by Deloitte is underway to assess the cyber attack and Optus' security systems.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary: Today's sports schedule includes UEFA Champions League matches: Bayern vs Plzen (12:40am), Liverpool vs Rangers (2:55am), and Marseille vs Sporting (2:55am). Additionally, table tennis tournaments continue with the World Team Championships (10am, 1pm, 4pm, 7pm) and tennis events: Japan Open (10am), Astana Open (2pm, 8pm), and Ostrava Open (10pm). View the full schedule on Singtel or StarHub TV guides for updates.

site_title: Qatar's brief respite at home
summary: Qatar's World Cup football team trained at home for the first time in four months, addressing "nervy displays" in preparatory matches. The team, which faces tough Group A opponents, is working to correct errors and boost body fitness. Despite losses to Croatia's Under-23 team and Canada, players expressed optimism, citing the benefits of the isolation period and home crowd support. Coach Felix Sanchez plans to return to Spain for more training, but players are ready for the World Cup, which begins on November 20.

site_title: Cricket Australia sorry for child abuse
summary: Cricket Australia has apologized to child sex abuse survivors, joining the National Redress Scheme to support victims. Chairman Lachlan Henderson urged state organizations to sign up, acknowledging the "appalling issue" in the sport. The apology comes after a former junior cricketer took legal action against Cricket Australia over alleged abuse in 1985. The National Redress Scheme aims to compensate and support victims of historical child sexual abuse in institutions, with other major sporting bodies already signed up. Cricket Australia is exploring additional ways to help victims of abuse.

site_title: English mare Alpinista wins Arc for 74-year-old trainer Prescott
summary: English raider Alpinista, ridden by Luke Morris, won the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe, Europe's most prestigious horse race, for 74-year-old trainer Mark Prescott. Alpinista, a 7-2 favourite, repelled French Derby winner Vadeni and reduced Prescott to tears with her sixth successive Group 1 victory. The win marked a rare foreign trip for Prescott, who was overcome with emotion upon crossing the finish line. Alpinista's victory was also a long-time goal achieved by owner Kirsten Rausing, who has been breeding from this family for 40 years.

site_title: Joe Singh's new horse streets ahead
summary: Street Of Dreams, a four-year-old gelding by Dundeel, won a $20,000 Maiden race at Kranji, Singapore, with a stunning 61.4-length margin and a class record time of 1min 10.77sec. Trainer Steven Burridge credited two surgeries and gelding for revitalizing the horse's potential, which had been stunted by respiratory issues. The win marked Bernardo Pinheiro's first victory for Burridge and caps a race-to-race double. Pinheiro's licence was prematurely ended due to a two-month suspension for stewards' dissatisfaction with his riding style.

site_title: Indian thrower suspended for doping
summary: Indian javelin thrower Shivpal Singh has been suspended for four years after testing positive for the banned steroid methandienone in September 2021. Singh, 27, was India's second-best javelin thrower after Olympic champion Neeraj Chopra. The suspension, effective from October 2021, ends in October 2025. Singh had claimed he was not involved in doping, but a contaminated supplement purchase was cited as the cause of the positive test. This is the second doping suspension for an Indian athlete in 2022, following discus thrower Kamalpreet Kaur.

site_title: Gold cup bidder back in the black
summary: Mr. Black Back, a Singapore-based horse trained by Tim Fitzsimmons, won a convincing 1,400m turf race, increasing his rating by six points and making him a potential contender for the upcoming Singapore Gold Cup. The horse had previously finished third in a Polytrack race over 1,200m and had shown stamina in his Australian debut. Fitzsimmons plans to take Mr. Black Back to 1,800m next and believes the horse has the potential to make a long shot for the Gold Cup, which is set to take place in six weeks.

site_title: Premier League talking points
summary: Manchester City dominated Manchester United with a 6-3 win, showcasing the significant gap between the two teams. Liverpool struggled with a slow start, conceding a two-goal lead in a 3-3 draw against Brighton. Arsenal secured their first win over a "Big Six" team, beating Tottenham 3-1 at home. Chelsea's new manager Graham Potter enjoyed a winning start with a 2-1 comeback win at Crystal Palace, but issues persist, including defensive errors and limited clear-cut chances.

site_title: Sunday's Singapore Stipendiary Stewards' report highlights
summary: In Sunday's Singapore Stipendiary Stewards' report, several horses were penalized for poor performances. Eastiger was 6th and Happy Friday was 4th, both of which jockeys attributed to their mounts weakening in the straight. Briggs, a gelding, was 10th and bled after racing keenly. Glory Shine finished last and High Limit led, but trainer Jerome Tan plans to ride the gelding forward in future races. The JUN and Legacy Fortune returned lame, and Illustrous was left without a finishing effort after jockey Wong Chin Chuen was unable to settle his mount.

site_title: Kyrgios aims to keep up momentum
summary: Nick Kyrgios is set to focus on this week's Japan Open despite a court hearing in Australia for alleged common assault. The 27-year-old Wimbledon finalist said he's been dealing with the case "for months" and is taking it "day by day." Kyrgios aims to keep his momentum going after a "heartbreaking" US Open loss and feels motivated to win his first Grand Slam at the Australian Open in January. He's seeded fifth in Tokyo and will play Chinese Taipei's Tseng Chun-hsin in the first round.

site_title: Inter facing Barca at the worst time
summary: Inter Milan is facing a crisis as they prepare to host Barcelona in the Champions League, with coach Simone Inzaghi under increasing pressure. A 2-1 loss to Roma on Saturday has left Inter eight points off the Serie A title pace and wondering about their season. The upcoming double-header will likely decide their European adventure, with defeat potentially ending their Champions League hopes. Inzaghi's job is not at risk, but dissenting voices around him have grown, and Inter faces a tough task to turn their season around, with Barcelona's star striker Robert Lewandowski in form.

site_title: Sports World
summary: Maximilian Maeder, a 16-year-old Singaporean kitefoiler, won the Formula Kite European Championships for the second year in a row. In sports news, Real Madrid dropped their first points this season with a 1-1 draw against Osasuna, while Tyler Herro signed a four-year contract extension worth $43 million with the Miami Heat. Ryan Fox won the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship, paying tribute to the late cricket great Shane Warne, who was a close friend and teammate.

site_title: Horner a raging bull over claims but cheered by Perez
summary: Red Bull team principal Christian Horner was visibly frustrated during an FIA press conference in Singapore, where he was questioned about alleged improprieties in the team's 2021 spending. Horner's team, Red Bull, denies any wrongdoing. Horner's reaction, described as "stony-faced," was seen as a sign of his frustration. However, teammate Max Verstappen's manager, Pierre Gasly, later expressed support for Horner, suggesting that the team is not guilty of any wrongdoing.

site_title: Football: Barcelona will take the game to Inter in Milan, Xavi says
summary: Barcelona manager Xavi Hernandez says the team will be aggressive and impose their style on Inter Milan in their Champions League Group C match. Despite facing a tough group with Inter and Bayern Munich, Xavi is upbeat about Barcelona's start to the season, led by new signing Robert Lewandowski, who has scored 12 goals in nine games. However, Xavi will face a headache in selecting his squad due to injuries, including several key players, and acknowledges that Inter will be a tough opponent despite their injuries, with a strong core.

site_title: Digital banks should not compete on rates but focus on products, customer base: Expert
summary: Digital banks in Singapore should focus on offering unique products rather than competing on interest rates, according to WeLab CEO Simon Loong. This approach will help them select a customer base and ensure long-term profitability. By differentiating themselves from traditional banks, digital banks can differentiate themselves and attract customers who value their specific offerings, rather than trying to match rates that may not be sustainable in the long term. This strategy will enable digital banks to thrive in the market.

site_title: 'we're in this together'
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has urged his team to pull together and be defensively compact to improve their patchy form, after admitting they are low on confidence. The team has won just four of their opening 10 Premier League matches and is 11 points off the pace. Klopp, who has praised Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi for overcoming similar struggles, believes individual confidence is not the solution, but rather a collective effort. The Reds will face Rangers in the Champions League on Tuesday, looking to clinch a second straight win and boost their chances of advancing to the knockout stage.

site_title: Move on quickly from loss in derby, Conte tells Spurs
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte has urged his team to "move on" from their 3-1 loss to Arsenal, emphasizing the need to focus on their upcoming Champions League match against Eintracht Frankfurt. Spurs, tied on points with Frankfurt, face a crucial game on Tuesday, and Conte plans to draw positivity from their performance against Arsenal. Frankfurt, meanwhile, seeks to extend their four-match winning streak, having beaten Union Berlin 2-0 over the weekend. The match will be played at Frankfurt's home stadium, where they have struggled this season.

site_title: Hull 'very proud' hard work pays off for 2nd LPGA title
summary: Charley Hull secured her second LPGA title at the Volunteers of America Classic, holding off Lin Xiyu and Lydia Ko by one and two strokes respectively. Hull fired a 7-under 64 to finish 18-under 266, ending a drought since her 2016 Tour Championship win. Hull attributed her success to good work and confidence, feeling in control of her round, especially in the final stages. Lin finished second, while Ko took third, with Thailand's Atthaya Thitikul placing fourth.

site_title: Gerrard questions wasteful attackers
summary: Aston Villa manager Steven Gerrard expressed frustration after a 0-0 draw against Leeds United, despite outshooting them 19-1 from open play. Gerrard questioned his team's attacking players for lacking quality and ruthlessness, despite creating numerous scoring opportunities. Leeds, who played with 10 men for most of the second half, earned a point and moved to 12th place, while Villa's first away point moved them up to 14th. Gerrard vowed to address his team's attacking issues to secure more wins.

site_title: Football: Davies back for Spurs at Frankfurt but Kulusevski still out
summary: Tottenham Hotspur defender Ben Davies has recovered from a hairline fracture and will be on the bench for the Champions League Group D game against Eintracht Frankfurt. However, winger Dejan Kulusevski remains out due to a hamstring injury with no timeline for his return. Conte expressed pessimism about Kulusevski's recovery and considers 21-year-old Bryan Gil a first option for the attack. Young player Djed Spence may also get a chance, but Conte emphasized that his decisions are based on the team's best interests, not fan pressure.

site_title: ST Explains: Credit Suisse stuck in spotlight ahead of strategy shift
summary: Credit Suisse faces intense scrutiny ahead of a strategic shift, with its market capitalization dropping to around 9.5 billion Swiss francs. The bank has faced a string of losses, risk management failures, and leadership changes, including a spying scandal and the resignation of CEO Thomas Gottstein. Analysts estimate Credit Suisse may face a capital shortfall of 4-6 billion Swiss francs, with options including asset sales, a capital raise, or state aid. As the second-biggest lender in Switzerland, the bank's failure could cause significant harm to the Swiss economy and financial system.

site_title: 2 women who help needy children with education get top honours from Her World
summary: Two women, Ng Gim Choo and Amanda Chong, received top honors from Her World magazine for their contributions to education and literacy. Ng, 70, was named Woman of the Year for her charity's pre-school and enrichment programs, while Chong, 33, was named Young Woman Achiever of the Year for co-founding a literacy charity and her writing and advocacy work. Both women emphasized the importance of education and overcoming obstacles to achieve their goals.

site_title: S'porean father and son duo jailed for corruption involving former chief of Malaysian cargo airline
summary: A Singaporean father and son duo, Peter Tan Chin Hock and Kenneth Tan Kwang Leng, were jailed for corruption involving the former chief of Malaysian cargo airline Raya Airways. They pleaded guilty to corruption charges and were sentenced to 7 months and 2 months of jail respectively. The duo conspired with another director to give bribes to Raya Airways' former CEO, Mr Lee Shashitheren, totaling RM504,698, avoiding a payment of US$139,037.27 to the airline.

site_title: Companies nurture local talent and tap innovation to grow despite challenges
summary: Singaporean companies Micron and Commonwealth Concepts are thriving despite economic challenges by embracing digitalization and upskilling efforts. Micron leverages technologies and supports staff talent development, resulting in increased productivity and efficiency. The company has partnered with the Government and encourages a growth mindset among employees, with initiatives such as AI-enabled defect inspection and automated manufacturing processes. Commonwealth Concepts has also adopted flexible workflows, job redesign, and employee training programs to build resilience. These measures have enabled the companies to navigate global supply chain shocks and future-proof themselves for emerging challenges.

images.alt_text: Micron employees get the opportunity to upskill and train themselves
CCPL is working on

site_title: Taxman will be allowed to share certain tax information on firms without getting consent
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) will be allowed to share certain tax information on firms without consent for official purposes. Changes to the Income Tax Act, passed by Parliament, will enable government agencies to access company data, but safeguards will protect data confidentiality, such as sharing sales revenue in ranges rather than exact values. The new rules apply only to company data, not individual taxpayers, and will not be shared with non-public sector individuals.

site_title: S'pore factory activity contracts for first time since 2020, raising risk of technical recession
summary: Singapore's manufacturing activity contracted for the first time in over two years in September, with the Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 49.9 points, down 0.1 point from August. The electronics sector, which accounts for 40% of industrial output, also contracted for the second month in a row. The decline raises concerns of a technical recession, with economists predicting a 0.6% quarter-on-quarter contraction in the third quarter, potentially leading to a technical recession.

site_title: Football: As he plots Liverpool revival, Klopp says even Ronaldo has confidence dips
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has admitted his team is low on confidence but urged them to fight through it ahead of a crucial Champions League match against Rangers. Despite struggling in the Premier League, Klopp believes his team can clinch a second straight Champions League win if they beat Rangers. He likened Cristiano Ronaldo's current form to his team's lack of confidence, saying they need to be patient and take a step in the right direction. Klopp also emphasized the importance of defensive solidity, saying they need to be more compact and go back to the basics.

site_title: Man arrested after $11,200 is lost in refund scam involving mobile phones and tablets
summary: A 28-year-old man in Singapore has been arrested for allegedly carrying out a refund scam involving mobile phones and tablets. He purchased devices using fake particulars and then returned them to receive full refunds, causing losses of over $11,200. Investigations revealed dummy sets of mobile phones, sticker seals, and a laptop among other case exhibits. The suspect faces up to 10 years in jail and a fine if found guilty of cheating. The case is ongoing, and the public is advised to report any scam information to the authorities.

site_title: Tennis: Swiatek to skip Billie Jean King Cup finals, complains about scheduling
summary: Iga Swiatek, the world No. 1 tennis player, will not play for Poland in the upcoming Billie Jean King Cup finals in Glasgow due to scheduling conflicts. The tournament, scheduled from November 8-13, conflicts with the season-ending WTA Finals in Fort Worth, Texas, which will be held just one day after. Swiatek expressed disappointment and concerns over the governing bodies' handling of the tournament calendar, citing potential health risks and injuries. She plans to discuss the issue with the WTA and ITF to change the schedule.

site_title: NCMP Leong Mun Wai's allegations against Govt's public expenditure 'without basis': Indranee
summary: Minister Indranee Rajah has dismissed Non-Constituency MP Leong Mun Wai's allegations that the Government's management of public expenditure is deficient, calling them "completely without basis". Leong had objected to the Sports Hub and SPH Media Trust transactions, claiming the Government was being overly generous. Indranee rejected these claims, stating that the Government had explained the reasoning behind the decisions in detail and that Leong's assertions were a "deliberate and cynical attempt" to stoke anxiety and damage the Government.

site_title: Inspections on slopes may be more frequent during intense wet weather
summary: Singapore's local agencies may conduct more frequent slope inspections during intense wet weather, following a landslide at a construction site in September 2022. Minister for National Development Desmond Lee stated that agencies carry out regular inspections on slopes that pose a risk to public safety and implement mitigation measures as needed. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) requires qualified persons to assess slopes for risk of failure and recommend protection measures, such as earth retaining walls and stabilising structures. This comes after an average of four landslide incidents were reported per year between 2017 and 2019, with a higher number in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Football: Spurs have to take some positivity from defeat by Arsenal, says Conte
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte has urged his players to "move on" from their 3-1 defeat to Arsenal, emphasizing the need to take positivity from the game and focus on their upcoming Champions League match against Eintracht Frankfurt. Spurs face a crucial game against an in-form Frankfurt side, who have won four of their last five league games and are seeking their fourth straight victory in all competitions. Despite injuries to key players, Conte believes his team can draw on determination to overcome the challenge.

site_title: Weekly Money FM Podcasts: Start-up ecosystem remains resilient amid macro-related issues
summary: The Singapore start-up ecosystem remains resilient despite macro-related issues, according to an interview with Tech in Asia's COO, Maria Li. Meanwhile, new home loan limits were introduced, affecting homebuyers, while the Singapore Grand Prix gears up. Experts also shared tips on tackling high blood cholesterol levels and the future of housing needs. Additionally, recommendations for aspiring leaders and corporate practitioners were offered by an author. These topics were discussed on Money FM's weekly podcasts.

site_title: Scammers target PM Lee in fake e-mail scam
summary: Scammers in Singapore have been targeting government leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, with fake e-mails purportedly from the Prime Minister's Office. The scammers have created various e-mails with different content, including one thanking recipients for their contributions to Singapore. PM Lee warned that people should ignore such e-mails and stay vigilant, advising to check first before proceeding. This is part of a broader effort to combat fake online articles and scams, with the Anti-Scam Hotline and Scam Alert website available for more information.

site_title: Maid gets 17 months' jail for stealing cash, jewellery and Rolex watches from employer's mother
summary: A 44-year-old maid, Rogelyn Nermal Nemaria, was sentenced to 17 months' jail for stealing cash, jewelry, and Rolex watches from her employer's mother, Madam Ang Yien. Nemaria stole approximately $64,000 worth of items, including 20 pieces of jewelry and three Rolex watches, over several occasions between May 2021 and March 2022. She pawned some items and sent others to her family in the Philippines, but two of the Rolex watches were later recovered. Nemaria pleaded guilty to two theft-in-dwelling charges and showed remorse during sentencing.

site_title: Tennis: 'Excited' Kyrgios focused on Japan Open on eve of court case
summary: Nick Kyrgios, a Wimbledon finalist, is set to appear in a court hearing in Australia on Tuesday for alleged common assault. Despite this, he expressed focus on the Japan Open, saying it's "not difficult at all" to balance both commitments. Kyrgios, who lost in the US Open quarter-finals last month, is "super excited" to play in Tokyo and is motivated to win his first Grand Slam at the Australian Open next year. He believes his recent form and training have prepared him to compete at the highest level.

site_title: Drug trafficker gets death penalty after court rejects claim that most of heroin found was girlfriend's
summary: A 49-year-old Singaporean man, Mohamed Ansari Mohamed Abdul Aziz, has been sentenced to death for heroin trafficking after a High Court rejected his claim that his girlfriend, Bella Fadila, was responsible for most of the heroin found in their apartment. The couple was arrested in 2016 after a search of their apartment yielded 77 packets containing over 760g of heroin, with 30.23g of pure heroin found. Ansari initially claimed Bella was not involved, but later incriminated her, and the court accepted her testimony that she only helped pack the drugs.

site_title: Football: Middlesbrough sack manager Chris Wilder
summary: Middlesbrough Football Club has sacked manager Chris Wilder after less than a year in the role, citing the team's poor performance. The club is third from bottom of the Championship, having won only two of 11 league games this season. Wilder, who previously won promotion to the Premier League with Sheffield United in 2019, leaves the team following a 1-0 away defeat by Coventry. The club has appointed interim manager Leo Percovich, assisted by Craig Liddle, Mark Tinkler, and Lee Cattermole, to take over first-team affairs.

site_title: Cricket: Australian body sorry for historical child sex abuse
summary: Cricket Australia chairman Lachlan Henderson apologized to child sex abuse survivors in the sport, acknowledging the "appalling issue" of historical child sex abuse. The organization has joined the National Redress Scheme, but urged state-based organizations to also sign up. Henderson called for more action to support victims and encouraged states and territories to join the scheme. This comes after a former junior cricketer took legal action against Cricket Australia over alleged abuse on an Under-19 tour in 1985, and a former state cricketer was jailed for abusing schoolboy players in the 1980s and 1990s.

site_title: BT Money Hacks Podcast: Toasting fine wine's resilience
summary: A wine investment expert, Anthony Zhang, co-founder and CEO of Vinovest, suggests that fine wine can be a hedge against inflation due to its low correlation to general market performance. Wine prices have outpaced inflation and its outperformance in 2021 may be attributed to its clear capital preservation during the pandemic. Zhang notes that collecting for passion versus profits can impact investment decisions, but overall, the outlook for wine investing remains positive.

site_title: WealthBT Podcast: Impact investing: Making a difference with your capital
summary: WealthBT Podcast discusses impact investing with Evelyn Yeo, head of Asia Investments from Pictet Wealth Management Asia. Impact investing differs from ESG investing in its focus on creating positive social or environmental outcomes alongside financial returns. A framework to measure impact is essential, and private clients are drawn to impact investments due to their alignment with values. The conversation also covers sustainable real estate, risk and return expectations, and the potential for philanthropic capital to drive positive change.

site_title: Green Pulse Podcast: How much more renewable energy can South-east Asia tap?
summary: South-east Asia, a region with high energy demand, has over 66% of installed power capacity from fossil fuels. The International Renewable Energy Agency (Irena) report highlights the need for a green transition. In a podcast discussion, Mr. Mark Hutchinson, chair of the South-east Asian Task Force at the Global Wind Energy Council, emphasizes that renewable energy options, such as wind and solar power, have yet to reach their full potential in the region. Funding and grid flexibility are key challenges to scaling up renewable energy, but Hutchinson suggests that changes to traditional grids can facilitate a smoother transition.

site_title: Basketball: Heat sign Herro to four-year contract extension
summary: Miami Heat guard Tyler Herro has signed a four-year contract extension worth an average of $30 million per season, with potential performance incentives that could increase the total value to $130 million. Herro, the 2019 NBA Draft pick, was last season's NBA Sixth Man of the Year, averaging 20.7 points and 5.0 rebounds per game. Heat president Pat Riley expressed excitement about Herro's continued improvement, citing his growth since being drafted 13th overall in 2019. The deal will keep Herro with the Heat through the 2027-2028 season.

site_title: Seating for MPs in Parliament revised as Covid-19 measures eased
summary: Singapore's Parliament has eased Covid-19 measures, allowing MPs to no longer sit in a split-team arrangement in the Chamber. The revised seating plan allows MPs to take breaks together in one room, with measures still in place to safeguard members' health. The Speaker of Parliament emphasized the need for vigilance and adherence to self-administered antigen rapid tests. The changes follow Singapore's streamlined safe distancing measures, which have progressively eased since early 2020.

site_title: Rich kids' boot camps return as private banks woo next-gen clients
summary: Private banks in Singapore and globally are resuming invite-only events for the children of wealthy clients, known as "next-gen" clients, as the region's elders transfer their fortunes. The events, which include workshops on entrepreneurship and crypto art, aim to build loyalty and prove value to these affluent young individuals. With 72 of Asia's 141 richest people over 60 and $1.1 trillion in combined wealth, banks must attract these clients to maintain lucrative accounts and access to deals, as they are likely to become independently wealthy.

site_title: Vaccination still key to reducing excess deaths resulting from Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that vaccination remains crucial in reducing excess deaths from Covid-19. According to the Ministry of Health, 2,490 excess deaths occurred in Singapore between January 2020 and June 2022, with the unvaccinated disproportionately contributing to Covid-19 deaths. Ong noted that vaccination significantly reduces the risk of severe illness and death, and that pandemic restrictions helped slow down the rate of infection. He also announced plans to make Covid-19 vaccinations similar to flu jabs, taken seasonally, in the future.

site_title: Credit Suisse shares hit record low as CEO fails to calm markets
summary: Credit Suisse shares hit a record low of 3.52 Swiss francs, dropping 12% in Zurich trading, amid turmoil over the bank's financial stability. CEO Ulrich Koerner attempted to reassure markets, but the bank's market capitalization has dropped 60% this year, and it's on track for its biggest annual drop in history. The cost of insuring against default has climbed 15% to levels not seen since 2009, and analysts estimate the firm may need to raise 4 billion Swiss francs to fund restructuring.

site_title: Covid-19 panel that decides on relief for firms, individuals to wind down
summary: A panel that provided Covid-19 relief to businesses and individuals in Singapore will wind down, with its registry set to close. The Panel of Assessors for Covid-19 (Temporary Relief) was established in April 2020 to help those affected by the pandemic, and has issued around 1,070 determinations. The relief, which applied to firms with construction, supply, event, and tourism-related contracts, ended on February 28. Remaining applications will be deemed withdrawn, and the Government is working to bring amendments to other laws into force, including updates to the Extradition Act and Protection from Harassment Act.

site_title: Forward SG feedback may be addressed midway, before exercise ends: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said the Forward Singapore team will review and study suitable platforms to publish gathered feedback, potentially addressing it midway through the exercise. The exercise aims to refresh the social compact, culminating in a roadmap to be released in mid-2023. Midterm milestones, such as Budget 2023, may also be used to respond to feedback earlier. The team will hold more engagements and partnerships with Singaporeans to gather views and co-develop policies, and will consider feedback on topics like employability, living environment, and environmental sustainability.

site_title: Golf: Fox pays tribute to 'great mate' Warne after Alfred Dunhill win
summary: New Zealand golfer Ryan Fox won the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship at St. Andrews with a four-under 68 in the final round. The victory came one shot ahead of Callum Shinkwin and Alex Noren. Fox paid tribute to late Australian cricket great Shane Warne, with whom he partnered last year, describing him as a "great mate." Fox credited Warne's presence with influencing his performance, saying he felt "some luck" and "helping out." The win marks Fox's third European DP World Tour title.

site_title: Job growth for locals shows bringing in global talent not a zero-sum game: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's job growth for locals in PMET roles has risen by 34,400 from 2016 to 2021, despite bringing in global talent. Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng said this growth is a result of complementary global talent complementing the local workforce, creating more job opportunities for locals. The number of EP holders in the ICT sector increased from one-sixth to one-fifth, while the number of locals in PMET roles also rose. The Ministry of Manpower's approach, including the Complementarity Assessment Framework, aims to bring in quality talent and ensure fair consideration for local workers.

site_title: Football: Real president Perez says fans are drifting away from football
summary: Real Madrid president Florentino Perez stated that European football is "sick" and that changes are needed to retain younger fans. Perez, a key architect of the European Super League, believes the current competitions do not attract spectators' interest except in the final stages. He called for more matches between top teams and the best players, citing the infrequent matchups between top teams. Perez's comments come as the Super League faces court proceedings against UEFA's monopoly in European football. Perez remains committed to the Super League, which faces a ruling from the EU Court of Justice next year.

site_title: 130 people received wrong dose of Covid-19 vaccine, out of 16 million doses administered so far
summary: Singapore's vaccination exercise has resulted in 130 people receiving incorrect doses of Covid-19 vaccines, with 11 experiencing overdoses and 119 receiving lower doses. Out of these incidents, seven were children with no adverse reactions. The Ministry of Health is investigating the Sept 15 incident where two adults were given a full vial of undiluted vaccine, and will take enforcement actions if regulatory breaches are found. The Ministry requires clinics to report errors within three hours and inform patients immediately.

site_title: In The Driver's Seat: Allegations turn Horner into Red Bull's raging bull
summary: Red Bull team principal Christian Horner was questioned by media about alleged improprieties in the team's 2021 spending during an FIA press conference in Singapore. Horner left the conference stony-faced, but later expressed excitement about his driver Sergio Perez's fourth grand prix victory, calling it the "best drive of his career."

site_title: Pound gains after UK government U-turns on cut to top tax rate
summary: The pound surged nearly 1% to its highest level in 10 days after the UK government announced a U-turn on plans to cut the top income tax rate. The decision reverses £2 billion out of £45 billion of planned tax cuts, which had triggered a crisis of investor confidence and led to a £65 billion bond-buying program by the Bank of England. Analysts say the move will support the pound, but further government action may be needed to restore confidence.

site_title: Formula 1: 6 memorable things about the 2022 Singapore Grand Prix
summary: The 2022 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix marked a return to normalcy for the country post-Covid, with the event attracting a record 302,000 fans. Despite heavy rain on both Saturday and Sunday, the event went ahead, with fans enjoying a range of food and entertainment options. The F1 weekend featured performances by various artists, including TLC, Suede, The Black Eyed Peas, and Green Day. Max Verstappen's hopes of claiming his second world championship were dashed after he was forced to abandon his final fastest lap due to low fuel and finished seventh. The event was a commercial success, with trackside hotels and average daily rates exceeding historical rates.

site_title: Airlines' flight plans show Changi Airport volume should reach 80% of 2019 levels by year end
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister S. Iswaran said that Changi Airport's flight plans show the airport's volume should reach 80% of 2019 levels by the end of the year. The recent reopening of Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Japan is expected to further increase year-end flights. China's opening strategy is seen as a major uncertainty, with the country accounting for 20% of Singapore's pre-Covid-19 tourists. Airlines have filed for over 80% of pre-Covid-19 flights, with recruitment efforts on track to restore manpower to 90% of 2019 levels.

site_title: Singapore signs open skies agreement with Palau
summary: Singapore has signed an open skies agreement with Palau, allowing airlines from both countries to fly between each other and beyond to any third country without restrictions on capacity, frequency, or routing schedules. The agreement was signed on October 3, 2022, by Singapore's Minister of Transport S. Iswaran and Palau's President Surangel Whipps Jr. The move is expected to enhance connectivity and trade between the two countries, with potential links to New Caledonia also being explored. This brings Singapore's total air services agreements to over 130.

site_title: Bird Paradise to open in Mandai in Q2 of 2023 and will have eight walk-in aviaries
summary: Bird Paradise, a new 17-hectare wildlife park in Mandai Wildlife Reserve, is set to open in the second quarter of 2023. The park will feature eight walk-in aviaries, showcasing a variety of bird species from around the world, including threatened species and the world's largest living genetic reserve of hornbills. With over 3,500 birds from 400 species, the park aims to promote animal welfare and conservation, offering immersive experiences and educational spaces, including a 2,000-seater amphitheatre and play areas for children.

site_title: Man cheated victims of over $17k with claims of access to Louis Vuitton discounts
summary: A Singaporean man, Soon Yong Jie, was sentenced to 16 months' jail for cheating at least six individuals out of $17,901 between September 2019 and September 2020. He claimed to have access to Louis Vuitton discounts by representing he worked at the fashion brand or had connections. Soon's scheme involved deceiving victims into transferring money, which he used to pay debts and cover personal expenses. He had a history of similar offences, including a 17-month sentence in 2017, and was also granted a seven-week deferment for treatment of depression and gambling disorder.

site_title: Caltex cancels price increase to be back in line with competition
summary: Caltex has cancelled its planned price increase, reverting to its previous rates, after competitors failed to follow suit. The move makes 92-octane petrol uniform at $2.71 across three of the five major players in Singapore. The change comes as oil industry consultant Ong Eng Tong notes that pump operators are increasingly reacting quickly to price movements, particularly following recent parliamentary discussions on the issue.

site_title: Social media firms face fines, blocking in S'pore under new Bill to tackle online harm
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Bill to regulate online communication services, requiring social media firms with significant reach to limit local users' exposure to harmful content and provide accountability. Failure to comply may result in fines of up to $1 million or service blocking. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will issue orders to block or take down egregious content, including posts advocating suicide, self-harm, and child exploitation. Platforms must establish measures to prevent users, especially children, from accessing harmful content and report on their safety measures.

site_title: Asia’s factory activity weakens on global slowdown, cost pressures
summary: Asia's factory activity weakened in September due to slowing demand in China and advanced economies, alongside persistent cost pressures. Key indicators showed a decline in manufacturing activity in Taiwan and Malaysia, and a slower pace in Japan and Vietnam. China's factory and services activity data also pointed to further cooling, with strict lockdowns disrupting production and sales. The region's economic recovery prospects are clouded, with many analysts expecting China's economy to grow by just 3% this year, the slowest since 1976.

site_title: 87% of households have claimed May 2022 CDC vouchers
summary: About 97% and 87% of Singaporean households have claimed their December 2021 and May 2022 Community Development Council vouchers, respectively, utilizing $180 million, or 80% of total vouchers. The Government has disbursed two sets of $100 CDC vouchers in December 2021 and May 2022, with additional vouchers to be disbursed in 2023 and 2024. The Government is monitoring inflation rates and considers providing more assistance, including issuing $100 CDC vouchers to every Singaporean aged over 21, if necessary.

site_title: EC World Reit proposes asset sale for loan repayment; to make special distribution
summary: EC World Reit is proposing to divest its indirect interests in two Chinese logistics properties, Bei Gang Logistics and Chongxian Port Logistics, at values of $242 million and $242 million respectively. The proceeds will be used to repay existing loans and fund a special distribution to unit holders, expected to be $90.2 million. The divestment aims to reduce the Reit's debt by at least 25% by December 31, 2022, meeting a lender condition. The proposal is set to be approved by unit holders at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: MS Holdings chairman offers to privatise company at 7 cents per share
summary: MS Holdings chairman Ng Chui Hwa made a voluntary unconditional cash offer to privatise the company at 7 cents per share, a 16.7% premium over its last trading price of 6 cents. The offer is seen as an opportunity for shareholders to exit their investment due to low trading liquidity. The company, which leases mobile and lorry cranes, has seen low trading volumes, averaging around 7,147 shares per day. The offeror, Kingswin Investment, plans to compulsorily acquire remaining shares if 90% of issued shares are accepted.

site_title: US home prices now posting biggest monthly drops since 2009
summary: US home prices have posted the largest monthly declines since 2009, with median home prices falling 0.98% in August from the previous month, according to Black Knight. This marks two straight months of significant declines after over two years of record-breaking growth. Skyrocketing mortgage rates are driving affordability to the lowest level since the 1980s, with prices still up 12.1% from a year earlier. The sharpest correction was in San Jose, California, with a 13% drop from its 2022 peak.

site_title: Golf: England's Charley Hull holds off Lydia Ko, Lin Xiyu to win The Ascendant LPGA title
summary: England's Charley Hull won The Ascendant LPGA title with a 7-under 64, edging out China's Lin Xiyu and New Zealand's Lydia Ko by one and two strokes, respectively. Hull's second LPGA Tour title snapped a six-year win drought, as she finished 18-under 266 at Old American Golf Club. Hull credited her improved confidence and game, saying "my game is there" after her breakthrough victory.

site_title: Teenagers have wider network of friends in schools with mixed form classes: NIE study
summary: A study by the National Institute of Education (NIE) found that Singaporean secondary school students in mixed-form classes formed a wider network of friends, with nearly 40% of their school friends coming from different academic streams. This suggests that integrating students with different abilities can foster stronger social bonds and friendships. The study aimed to explore the effects of mixed-form classes on student relationships and social interactions.

site_title: Private home prices rise 3.4% in Q3, led by 7% jump for suburban condos: Flash data
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 3.4% in Q3, driven by a 7% increase in suburban condos, the largest quarterly jump since 2009. Median prices of new non-landed homes in the suburbs surged 18% to a record $2,093 per sq ft, while new sales in the suburbs leaped to 1,238 units. Despite recent cooling measures, analysts expect prices to remain unaffected for the rest of the year, citing low interest rates and strong demand.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 2.4% in Q3; may dip in coming months after cooling measures
summary: HDB resale prices rose 2.4% in Q3, marking the 10th consecutive quarter of growth, but are expected to dip in coming months due to new cooling measures. The measures, which include tighter borrowing limits and stricter debt servicing ratios, aim to cool the public housing market. Analysts predict a temporary pullback in demand for large flats, leading to a price correction, and expect the overall HDB resale price gain for 2022 to be no more than 10%. The upcoming BTO launch in November is also expected to draw demand away from the resale market.

site_title: Singtel says media reports on potential hefty costs from Optus cyber attack 'speculative'
summary: Singtel disputes media reports on potential hefty costs from Optus cyber attack, calling them "speculative". The breach, which affected up to 9.8 million Australians, may cost Optus up to A$661 million to replace affected documents. Bloomberg estimates Singtel could face a loss of over a quarter of its annual profit. Deloitte has been appointed to conduct an independent review of the breach and Optus' security systems. The Australian government has criticized Optus, urging the company to notify affected customers and take precautions to protect themselves from financial crime.

site_title: Golf: Mackenzie Hughes wins Sanderson Farms Championship in playoff
summary: Mackenzie Hughes won the Sanderson Farms Championship in a playoff, claiming his second PGA Tour title and first since 2016. Hughes birdied the second playoff hole to defeat Sepp Straka, who also saved par on the 18th hole. Hughes finished with a final-round 69 to take the title at 17-under 271. Hughes' win came after a strong performance, including four birdies and one bogey, and he credited his experience in scrambling and saving pars as key to his victory.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust targets trebling of portfolio to $18b over next decade
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) aims to triple its portfolio to $18 billion over the next decade under the leadership of CEO Jopy Chiang. The trust has secured wind assets in Europe, expanded into Saudi Arabia and South Korea, and reorganized its strategy to focus on energy transition, environmental services, and distribution and storage. With a goal of 25% of its equity-adjusted assets under management coming from renewable energy investments, KIT's assets under management are expected to rise 36% to $6.1 billion.

site_title: What F1 can teach us about investing
summary: Formula One racing can teach investors about managing risk. F1 cars rely on over 100 sensors monitoring 10,000 components to optimize performance and minimize risk. Similarly, investors must balance risk and potential rewards. Effective risk management is crucial in investing, and F1's emphasis on precision and control can be applied to financial decision-making. By analyzing data and making informed decisions, investors can mitigate potential losses and increase their chances of success. This mindset can be applied to various investment strategies.

site_title: Work Talk Podcast: South-east Asia businesses in crosshairs of geopolitics
summary: Singapore businesses are navigating geopolitical uncertainties, including the Russian-Ukraine war, US-China rivalry, and tensions over Taiwan. A survey by Milieu Insight found that 62% of businesses across Southeast Asia are concerned about the impact of geopolitics on their operations. Local firms are advised to diversify their supply chains, invest in new markets, and prepare for potential trade protectionism. Businesses are also being urged to play a role in soothing geopolitical tensions through responsible investments and practices.

site_title: Market volatility continues as inflation persists, but stay invested for the long term
summary: The Dow Jones fell 500 points last Friday, closing at 28,725.51 points, a 2.9% loss for the week. Global investment markets have seen significant changes in the past two years due to economic and political uncertainties. The worst September since 2002 has left investors with a new normal, prompting caution and emphasizing the importance of long-term investment strategies amidst persistent inflation.

site_title: Personalised heat advisory an aim of study to help people cope as S'pore heats up
summary: Researchers in Singapore are developing a personalised heat advisory to help vulnerable groups cope with the rising temperatures. The study, led by Associate Professor Jason Lee, aims to establish thresholds for groups such as primary school pupils, adults not acclimatised to the hot weather, and those aged 65 and above. Participants will undergo exercises in a lab setting to gather data on their body temperature, gait, and cognitive functions, and the data will be used to create a personalised heat-health index. The advisory will provide individuals with tailored advice on how to regulate their time spent outdoors and avoid heat-related risks, such as heat stroke.

site_title: Cooling Singapore studies to look at rising temperatures on health, natural ecosystems
summary: Scientists in Singapore will conduct a series of studies to understand the impact of rising temperatures on human health and natural ecosystems. The Cooling Singapore project, funded by the National Research Foundation, will examine various urban climate risks, including heat vulnerability, urban development, and green spaces. The studies will focus on vulnerable groups, such as the elderly and young children, and assess the resilience of trees and vegetation in the face of rising temperatures. The research will inform policymakers and help develop targeted heat advisories and mitigation measures to reduce urban heat and improve thermal comfort.

site_title: Science Talk: It's time to pass on the salt
summary: Singaporeans consume an average of 8.8g of salt per day, according to the Health Promotion Board. This excessive salt intake can lead to health issues such as high blood pressure and cardiovascular disease. Experts advise reducing salt consumption, but many struggle to give up salty foods like aromatic crisps. Efforts to lower salt intake are necessary to improve public health, and individuals can start by making small changes to their daily diet.

site_title: Football: Champions Real Madrid held by Osasuna
summary: Real Madrid was held to a 1-1 draw at home by Osasuna in La Liga, their first point of the season. Karim Benzema missed a late penalty after being fouled inside the area, allowing Osasuna to equalize. Vinicius Jr gave Real Madrid the lead before halftime, but Kike Garcia scored the equalizer with a brilliant header. The draw lifted Osasuna to sixth in the standings, while Real Madrid remains level with Barcelona at the top, ahead on goal difference.

site_title: I have never stopped missing her but I have learnt to live with it: Widower
summary: A widower, Edmund Foo, has spoken about living with grief after his wife's death from end-stage breast cancer. He quit his banking job to care for her and their two young daughters, aged 5 and 6, after the diagnosis. Foo has now addressed his suppressed emotions, acknowledging the pain of missing his wife. He has learned to cope with his grief, allowing him to move forward and potentially rebuild his life. Foo's story highlights the emotional challenges faced by those dealing with the loss of a loved one.

site_title: Some major pre-school players to raise fees in 2023
summary: Major pre-school chains in Singapore will raise fees in 2023, with increases ranging from 7% to 11%. MindChamps will raise fees by 7%, while Cherie Hearts will increase by 11%. However, pre-schools receiving government subsidies, such as PCF Sparkletots and Star Learners, will keep fees affordable, with caps of $720 and $760 before GST, respectively. The median fees in the pre-school sector have decreased from $800 in 2016 to $760 in 2021 before subsidies.

site_title: Seeing beyond what meets the eye in wildlife conservation
summary: National Parks Board staff in Singapore conducted a nocturnal wildlife survey at the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, using red torches to minimize disturbance to the animals. Photojournalist Mark Cheong and Audrey Tan accompanied the staff on the evening mission, observing a lesser mousedeer grazing from a distance. The use of red light, which is less disturbing to nocturnal animals, allowed for a closer observation of the wildlife without disrupting its natural behavior.

site_title: Circularity as a solution to inflation challenges
summary: The global cost-of-living crisis has reached a tipping point, with consumer prices soaring and millions at risk of dire energy shortages. The crisis highlights the impact of resource scarcity on lives and economic growth. To address this, experts suggest transforming the linear economy into a circular one, focusing on "repurpose and reuse" to reduce waste and promote sustainability. This shift could mitigate the burden of resource scarcity and support economic growth in the face of a growing, urban, and affluent population. A circular economy could provide a solution to the challenges posed by inflation.

site_title: Grief over loss of a wife: Why few widowers seek help
summary: A Singapore-based grief support service, Viriya Grief Support Services, aims to start a support group for widowers in August. Counsellors note that men tend to grieve privately, unlike women who often seek support from friends and family. This lack of public expression of grief among men can make it difficult for them to cope with their emotions. The support group seeks to provide a safe space for widowers to share their experiences and discuss topics relevant to them, addressing the unique needs of men grieving the loss of a spouse.

site_title: Corals blossom from artificial reef structures sunk in 2018 on seabed off Sisters' Islands
summary: Eight artificial reef structures sunk in 2018 off Singapore's Sisters' Islands Marine Park have begun to show signs of life, with coral colonies growing on the structures. Over 1,961 live coral colonies from 43 hard coral genera have settled on the structures, with some areas showing a wide variety of fish species. The artificial reefs, designed to enhance Singapore's marine habitats, are expected to contribute 1,000 sq m of additional reef substrate to the marine park, supporting biodiversity and potentially repopulating coral populations.

site_title: Reminders to 'hold on to the handrail' in Chinese dialects at some MRT stations
summary: Singapore's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system has begun broadcasting reminders to elderly commuters in Hokkien and Cantonese dialects to hold onto the handrail while using escalators. The move aims to assist the elderly, particularly those who may not be familiar with English. Retiree Martin Gregory, 73, is one such commuter who has taken it upon himself to always hold on to the handrail, citing the recent broadcasts as a welcome addition to the system's safety measures.

site_title: Oil prices jump over 3% as Opec+ mulls biggest production cut since pandemic
summary: Oil prices surged 3.2% to $82 a barrel as Opec+ delegates considered a potential output cut of over 1 million barrels a day to stabilize prices. This would be the largest since the pandemic. The move comes as global demand slows due to economic concerns, with some analysts predicting oil prices will reach $100 a barrel by the end of the year. The decision is expected to be made at Opec+'s meeting in Vienna on Wednesday.

site_title: More adults with autism to be hired in healthcare sector under new MOU
summary: A new three-year agreement between IHH Healthcare Singapore and the Autism Resource Centre (ARC) aims to train and equip more individuals with autism for healthcare roles. The collaboration, since 2019, has already placed 15 adults with autism in jobs within IHH SG's hospitals and clinics, with roles including data sorting and resolving discrepancies. The partnership seeks to expand job opportunities for individuals with autism in the healthcare sector, leveraging their attention to detail and precision. The goal is to increase the number of hospital staff with autism and contribute to Singapore's target of 40% of working-age people with disabilities employed by 2030.

site_title: askST Jobs: I have a co-worker who is not interested in his work. How should I motivate him?
summary: A coworker's lack of interest in work can lead to poor performance and extra workload. Before involving a supervisor or HR, have a conversation with the coworker to identify areas for improvement and provide constructive feedback. Write down specific points beforehand to avoid emotional discussions. If issues persist, involve a manager or HR with a plan, providing evidence from previous conversations to support the case. Staying professional, open-minded, and sincere in the process is key to finding a fair resolution.

site_title: Singapore re-elected to council of UN civil aviation agency
summary: Singapore has been re-elected to the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) council, a United Nations agency's governing body, for the fourth time. Minister for Transport S. Iswaran led the Singapore delegation, committing to supporting ICAO's efforts for a sustainable aviation future. As a member of the 36-member council, Singapore contributes to shaping international standards in areas such as aviation safety and security. The re-election recognizes Singapore's contribution to international aviation and provides an opportunity for the country to learn from fellow council members.

site_title: Sunset Way community rents surveillance set-up to fight illegal parking
summary: Grassroots volunteers in Sunset Way, Singapore, have successfully reduced traffic delays and safety concerns by setting up a mobile camera surveillance system to combat illegal parking. The community-led initiative, which began in August 2022, has seen a significant decrease in traffic violations, from three reports a week in May and June to none in three consecutive weeks in August. The project has been supported by the Land Transport Authority and has raised questions about the effectiveness of official enforcement resources, with Senior Minister Sim Ann suggesting that community-led initiatives can supplement LTA's efforts.

site_title: Reconsider the kind of salt to use
summary: Scientists have questioned the conventional advice to reduce salt intake, suggesting that not all salt is created equal. Research suggests that certain types of salt, such as Himalayan pink salt, may have a lower sodium content and different chemical composition than regular table salt, potentially making them a healthier option for some individuals. However, more studies are needed to confirm these findings and establish the health benefits of using alternative salts.

site_title: Home-based baker loses customers after Instagram account gets stolen
summary: A home-based baker in Singapore lost access to his Instagram account after a scammer hijacked it, using his 5,000 followers to advertise fake investment schemes and contests. The scammers demanded to verify his identity as a genuine seller, then locked him out of his account after he sent a screenshot of a password reset link. The baker, Mr Faisel Mohamed, has tried to reclaim his account but has been unsuccessful, and many of his followers have unfollowed him. The police have confirmed a report has been lodged, and Meta, Instagram's parent company, is working to recover the account.

site_title: How NParks is using tech to help S'pore's biodiversity
summary: The National Parks Board (NParks) is utilizing technology to aid Singapore's biodiversity. Dr. Adrian Loo, group director of NParks' wildlife management division, has spotted the critically endangered Sunda pangolin only twice in over 30 years due to its nocturnal nature. NParks is leveraging tools such as night vision equipment and an app that may identify birds via their calls to enhance conservation efforts and monitor wildlife in Singapore's forests.

site_title: Some major pre-school chains to raise monthly fees in 2023
summary: Major pre-school chains in Singapore will raise monthly fees in 2023, with some increasing by up to 11%. Kiddiwinkie Schoolhouse, Cherie Hearts, and MindChamps will raise fees for their full-day programs, while others, such as PCF Sparkletots and My First Skool, are in discussions with the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) over the issue. The ECDA-appointed pre-schools with fee caps of $720-$760 will continue to keep fees affordable for lower-income families, but the increases will add to the burden for parents already facing rising costs due to inflation.

site_title: Local stargazers catch closest view of Jupiter in nearly 60 years
summary: A group of 15 members of The Astronomical Society of Singapore observed Jupiter on September 23, catching its closest view in nearly 60 years. Data scientist Koh Wee Ming witnessed the planet's sharp features through his telescope, four days before its closest approach to Earth. This rare event, known as Jupiter's Opposition, occurs when the planet sits directly opposite the Sun and is closer to Earth than at any other time of the year. The Opposition period will last until early February 2023, with Jupiter visible in the eastern direction until late October.

site_title: Tiny mousedeer holds its own against S'pore's larger hoofed mammals
summary: A tiny mousedeer has been found to be a formidable competitor in Singapore's forests, rivaling larger hoofed mammals like the sambar deer and wild boar. With large carnivores extinct, these three species - the mousedeer, sambar deer, and wild boar - are the largest mammals left on the mainland. Despite the mousedeer's smaller size, it shares similar dietary preferences with the other two species, competing for seeds and plants in the forest ecosystem.

site_title: Photojournalism talks, guided tours for ST's Through The Lens exhibition return on Oct 7 after 2-year break
summary: The Straits Times' Through The Lens exhibition returns on Oct 7 after a two-year hiatus at the National Museum of Singapore. The exhibition features photographs from ST photojournalists and winning images from the 2022 World Press Photo Contest, exploring the impact of climate change and the COVID-19 pandemic. Guided tours and talks on photojournalism, including discussions on covering the pandemic and the Ukraine war, will also be held. Admission to the exhibition is free, and pre-registration is required for talks.

site_title: Public education key to mitigating online threats: Edwin Tong
summary: Singapore's Second Minister for Law Edwin Tong emphasized the importance of public education in mitigating online threats, including scams, phishing, and cyber attacks. The country saw 14,349 scam cases from January to June, with online threats posing significant risks to social cohesion. Tong noted that while law enforcement efforts are crucial, upstream education is equally important to empower individuals with knowledge and tools to protect themselves. The government and various organizations are launching a series of cyber safety webinars and a community law centre to address these issues.

site_title: 14.5km of cycling paths completed in Ang Mo Kio, Bishan, Toa Payoh
summary: Singapore has completed 14.5km of cycling paths in Ang Mo Kio, Bishan, and Toa Payoh, enhancing inter-town connectivity and safety. The 7km in Ang Mo Kio, 4km in Bishan, and 3.5km in Toa Payoh are part of the LTA's 1,300km cycling network by 2030. The new paths will provide better access to MRT stations and parks, with more 25km of paths and connectors to be added by 2026. Minister for Defence Ng Eng Hen launched the new paths, emphasizing the importance of reducing carbon footprint and promoting active mobility.

site_title: Safety broadcasts in dialect for elderly at selected MRT stations
summary: Singapore's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system has started broadcasting safety messages in Hokkien and Cantonese dialects specifically targeting the elderly. Retiree Martin Gregory, 73, noticed the new broadcasts and expressed relief, often relying on handrails when using escalators. The move aims to cater to the growing number of elderly commuters in Singapore, promoting their safety and well-being in the public transportation system. The broadcasts are part of efforts to enhance accessibility and inclusivity for all commuters, regardless of language or cultural background.

site_title: I have a co-worker who is not interested in his work. How should I motivate him?
summary: A coworker's lack of interest in their work can lead to subpar performance and impact team productivity. To address the issue, maintain a professional demeanor and approach the conversation with empathy. Discuss the specific areas for improvement and gather evidence of the coworker's struggles. If the issue persists, involve a supervisor or HR with a plan, ensuring to remain sincere and professional throughout the process, and keeping an open mind to finding a fair resolution.

site_title: What F1 can teach us about investing
summary: Formula One racing can teach investors about managing risk, as winning or losing is largely about balancing performance with risk management. Like in racing, investors must weigh the potential rewards against potential losses. Effective risk management involves anticipating and preparing for various scenarios, much like F1 drivers adapt to changing track conditions. By adopting a similar mindset, investors can make more informed decisions and minimize potential losses, ultimately increasing their chances of success. This strategy can be applied to various investment types, including high-risk or high-reward opportunities.

site_title: Global visionaries honoured at Time100 Impact Awards
summary: Microbiologist Pardis Sabeti was honored at the Time100 Impact Awards for her work in using data to contain and treat deadly infectious diseases like Ebola and Covid-19. Sabeti, who previously won Time's Person of the Year Award in 2014 for her Ebola work, continues to develop technologies to detect pathogens and is focusing on education to prepare the world for future pandemics. Other award winners include actress Alia Bhatt, former James Webb Space Telescope director Gregory L. Robinson, and singer Lea Salonga, who all use their work to drive positive change in their respective fields.

site_title: StanChart hikes savings rate
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has increased the maximum interest rate on its Bonus$aver savings account to 4.88% per annum, its highest ever for the account. The rate is up from 2.38% and is the latest move by lenders to boost terms on current and savings accounts.

site_title: Market volatility continues as inflation persists, but stay invested for the long term
summary: Market volatility persists due to ongoing inflation, marking a new reality for investors. The global investment landscape has seen significant changes in the past two years, with unprecedented economic and political uncertainties. Volatile markets, having reached their worst September since 2002, reflect this uncertainty, emphasizing the need for long-term investment strategies amidst ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: New mobile app helps make parking in Tiong Bahru easier
summary: A new mobile app, Breeze Drive & Park, launched in Tiong Bahru to help motorists find empty and cheaper parking spaces. The app, developed by NCS, provides real-time information on parking availability and rates, powered by AI, video analytics, and navigation technology. Initially focusing on Tiong Bahru for six months, the app aims to alleviate parking difficulties in the area, where plans to make the neighborhood more pedestrian-friendly have reduced parking spaces. The app also offers traffic data, popular eateries, and walking trails, and is the first transport app to provide parking information in Singapore.

site_title: Circularity as a solution to inflation challenges
summary: The global cost-of-living crisis has reached a tipping point, with consumer prices soaring in the US and millions facing energy shortages as winter approaches. Resource scarcity is exacerbating the issue, particularly as the world becomes more populated, urban, and affluent. This burden is expected to worsen in the coming decades, highlighting the need for solutions to address the challenges posed by inflation.

site_title: Surge in phishing scams involving Singpass
summary: Singapore authorities warn of a surge in phishing scams targeting victims through SMSes to obtain Singpass log-in credentials. The scammers send unsolicited SMSes with spoofed Singpass IDs, claiming account deactivation and requiring login credentials. Victims are led to fake log-in webpages and prompted for OTPs, resulting in unauthorized transactions. Authorities have taken down phishing sites, urging users to be vigilant and take precautions such as verifying website domains, updating contact details, and resetting passwords immediately if suspicious activity is detected.

site_title: World economy roiled by simultaneous shocks echoing 2007 anxiety
summary: The world economy is experiencing a rapid downshift due to simultaneous shocks, including the fallout from aggressive interest rate hikes, which are increasing the likelihood of another global recession.
