Former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers warns of a "period of elevated risk" echoing the 2007 anxiety, as inflation data shows a need for cautious rate tightening. The global economic gloom is sowing fear in financial markets, driven by a rapidly appreciating dollar and weakening other currencies, with the potential for financial turmoil and joint action to address challenges in question.

site_title: Albirex gain point as Sailors slump after leading 2-0
summary: Albirex Niigata secured a crucial 1-1 draw against Hougang United, gaining a point instead of two and bolstering their lead in the Singapore Premier League (SPL) title race. The Japanese side trailed Hougang, who lost 5-3 to Balestier, by four points with three games remaining. Albirex's advantage has grown, and a top-two showdown on Friday will be crucial for the title. Hougang coach Clement Teo expressed disappointment despite a strong display, while Albirex forward Ilhan Fandi credited his team's composure for the point.

site_title: Aussie FA promises action over Nazi salute
summary: Football Australia vows to take swift action against fans who made Nazi salutes and disrupted an indigenous welcoming ceremony at the Australia Cup final between Macarthur FC and Sydney United 58. Eight people were evicted from the stadium, and the governing body is assessing footage and images of the incident. The Australian Jewish community and players have condemned the behavior, calling for immediate action against the perpetrators. Football Australia is working with police and the stadium to determine strong and swift action, with the incident being described as a small minority of the 16,461 spectators.

site_title: Hamilton allowed to wear nose stud
summary: Mercedes driver Lewis Hamilton was allowed to keep wearing his nose stud during the Singapore Grand Prix due to medical reasons. Despite this, his team was fined €25,000 (S$35,210) by the FIA for failing to notify stewards about the jewellery. The team had submitted a self-scrutineering form stating Hamilton had removed all his jewellery, but he had actually removed the piercing before the competition and was advised by doctors to keep it in due to an infection. The FIA accepted the team's error and deemed it not intentional.

site_title: Boston race's non-binary category triggers a trend
summary: The Boston Marathon has introduced a non-binary category for its 2023 event, following a trend set by other major marathons such as the London and Berlin Marathons. The move, driven by conversations with non-binary athletes, allows runners to register without having to choose a male or female division. This shift is seen as a significant step towards inclusivity in the running community, with other marathons, including the New York City and Chicago Marathons, also adding non-binary divisions. The Boston Marathon's approach, which includes qualifying standards, sets a precedent for the sport.

site_title: StanChart joins other banks here in raising savings interest rate
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has increased the interest rate on its Bonus$aver account to 4.88% per annum, its highest for the savings account, in response to rising inflation. This move follows other banks, such as UOB and OCBC, in raising interest rates for current and savings accounts. The bank's customers can now earn interest on balances of up to $100,000 and bonus interest of up to 1.2% per annum for certain spending and investment activities. The rate increase is part of a broader trend in the banking sector amid a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Birthday to forget for Verstappen
summary: Max Verstappen's five-win streak ended at the 2022 Singapore Grand Prix, where he finished 7th, two days after his 25th birthday. Verstappen, who led the championship race by 116 points, blamed a "messy" showing after a poor start and struggles with his car. Despite a late charge, he secured six points and now leads the championship by 104 points with five races remaining.

site_title: China's Lin getting more 'comfortable' with title tilts
summary: China's Lin Xiyu shares the lead at the LPGA Volunteers of America Classic after a 2-under 69 in the third round, matching England's Charley Hull on 11-under 202. Lin, 26, is getting more comfortable with challenging for titles, citing her experience in previous tournaments as a factor. She finished the round with a lone bogey, but remains optimistic about her chances, saying "definitely have a chance" and "getting more comfortable about it." The tournament continues on Sunday.

site_title: Double treble in derby win
summary: Manchester City thrashed Manchester United 6-3 in the English Premier League, with Erling Haaland and Phil Foden scoring hat-tricks. The team's performance was criticized by manager Erik ten Hag, who cited a lack of fight and spirit. The defeat marked the first time City have scored two hat-tricks in a top-flight match since 1930. City moved to within a point of Arsenal at the top of the standings, while United remained in sixth spot.

site_title: Liverpool need to defend better: Klopp
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has expressed concern over his team's defensive performance, calling for them to "fight through" their struggling start to the season. The Reds have conceded first in nine of their last 11 league games, including a 3-3 draw with Brighton & Hove Albion that left them 11 points behind Premier League leaders Arsenal. Klopp attributed the defeat to poor passing and defending, stating that his team needs to work on controlling the game and increasing confidence.

site_title: Maiden wins for duo in London
summary: Kenyan Amos Kipruto won the men's London Marathon in his debut, crossing the line in 2:04:39. Ethiopian Yalemzerf Yehualaw, 23, won the women's race in her second marathon, completing it in 2:17:26. Yehualaw overcame a fall at the 33km mark to surge clear with 4 miles to go, winning the women's title. Kipruto, a world bronze medallist, broke away late to secure his victory.

site_title: King Arthur reigns supreme at Kranji again
summary: King Arthur, a 5-year-old I Am Invincible gelding, won the $100,000 Kranji Stakes A by 1/2-length over Sky Eye in a thrilling 1,200m speed dash. King Arthur, ridden by Yusoff Fadzli, showed his true worth after being a $12 favourite, overcoming a slow start to claim the win in a class record time of 1min 08.51sec. The win was a significant boost for trainer Donna Logan, who now leads the trainers' log with 52 wins, one ahead of rival Jason Fitzsimmons.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Upcoming sports events include English Premier League's Leicester v Nottingham, World Team Championships in table tennis, and Japan Open in tennis. The UEFA Champions League will feature Group C matches between Bayern and Plzen, and Group A matches between Liverpool and Rangers. The ATP Tour also has matches in Japan and Astana. In women's tennis, the WTA Tour's Ostrava Open continues with its second day.

site_title: Hubbard's dad fires him up for cool run
summary: Mark Hubbard took a one-stroke lead at the Sanderson Farms Championship with a seven-under 65 in the third round. The 33-year-old American, chasing his first PGA Tour title, birdied five consecutive holes on the back nine to stand on 15-under 201. Hubbard's father's advice to avoid Saturdays as his worst scoring days paid off, and he remained patient throughout the round. Canada's Mackenzie Hughes finished second with a 68, while South African Garrick Higgo and American Scott Stallings shared third on 204. Hubbard aims to improve on his best Tour showing and secure his first PGA title.

site_title: 'Best drive of my career'
summary: Sergio Perez claimed his second F1 win of the season at the Singapore Grand Prix, overtaking pole sitter Charles Leclerc just seconds after the start and holding off the Ferrari driver by 7.5 seconds. Perez's victory was his first in Singapore and made him the fifth F1 winner at the circuit. Red Bull teammate Max Verstappen finished seventh, while Leclerc and Ferrari teammate Carlos Sainz secured second and third respectively. Perez described the win as the "best drive of my career."

site_title: Perez claims night race; Singapore clocks record attendance
summary: Red Bull's Sergio Perez won the Formula One Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix with a record attendance of 302,000 spectators over three days, exceeding the previous high of 300,000 in 2008. The event marked a significant recovery for Singapore after two years of pandemic uncertainty, with tourism receipts reaching $1.9 billion in 2021 and visitor arrivals steadily increasing. The Singapore Tourism Board attributes the success to the unique elements surrounding the event, citing its strength as a global attraction and the Republic's appeal as a major tourist destination.

site_title: Sports World: Lewy stretches scoring run for Barca
summary: Robert Lewandowski scored in Barcelona's 1-0 win over Mallorca in La Liga, extending his scoring streak to six games. The Pole has nine goals this term, including eight in the league, and Barcelona's win lifts them to the top of the table with 19 points. Meanwhile, Cameron Norrie's hopes of qualifying for the ATP Finals were hit after a positive Covid-19 test forced him to withdraw from the Japan Open. Shohei Ohtani signed a record-breaking $43 million contract with the Los Angeles Angels for the 2023 season.

site_title: Nishioka delighted with his mentality, attitude
summary: Yoshihito Nishioka won the Korea Open, defeating fourth seed Denis Shapovalov 6-4, 7-6 (7-5) for his second ATP title. The Japanese player credited his focused mentality and attitude for the victory, rising to a career-high 41st in the world. Nishioka also beat fifth seed Dan Evans in the opening round, while Mayar Sherif became the first Egyptian woman to win a WTA Tour title, defeating top seed Maria Sakkari in the Parma final.

site_title: Euro Super League 'has never been closed off'
summary: Real Madrid president Florentino Perez reiterated the idea of a European Super League, stating it has "never been closed off" despite a 2021 collapse. Perez argued the Super League aims to modernize football, offering fans high-quality games, and compared it to tennis, where top players frequently face each other. He criticized UEFA for altering the Champions League, which he believes deprives fans of big games. Perez also took aim at Paris Saint-Germain president Nasser Al-Khelaifi, who he claims mistakenly attributed Real Madrid's Super League launch to fear of competition.

site_title: Super Wealthy storms into HK Sprint contention
summary: Super Wealthy, a 7-year-old Epaulette gelding, created history at Sha Tin by becoming the first horse to win the Group 3 National Day Cup Handicap twice in successive years. Carrying 130lb, he clocked 56.05 seconds to beat Cordyceps Six by a neck, securing his third win for trainer David Hayes. Hayes plans to target the Group 2 BOCHK Private Banking Jockey Club Sprint on November 20 as a lead-up to the Group 1 Longines Hong Kong Sprint on December 11.

site_title: Football: Dogged 10-man Leeds secure 0-0 home draw with Aston Villa
summary: Leeds United secured a 0-0 home draw against Aston Villa in the Premier League, despite playing with 10 men after midfielder Luis Sinisterra was sent off in the second half. The match saw few decent attacking opportunities, with Villa's best chance coming from Philippe Coutinho's volley that was headed just wide. The draw moved Leeds to 12th place with nine points from seven games, while Villa improved to 14th with eight points from eight games. Both teams expressed frustration over the result, with Villa boss Steven Gerrard citing missed chances and Leeds coach Jesse Marsch praising his team's resilience.

site_title: Football: Wolves fire coach Lage - reports
summary: Wolverhampton Wanderers have sacked manager Bruno Lage following a disappointing start to the season, with the team languishing in the relegation zone. Lage, 46, took over last season but led the team to only 6 points from 8 games. Wolves have struggled in front of goal, scoring only 3 strikes this season, the lowest in the top flight. Lage's departure marks the fourth defeat of the campaign, with the team sitting 18th place.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic wins Tel Aviv final for 89th career title
summary: Novak Djokovic won the Tel Aviv final, claiming his 89th career title with a straight-sets victory over Marin Cilic, 6-3, 6-4. This was Djokovic's third title of 2022 and his 19th win over Cilic in 21 meetings. Djokovic, 35, broke Cilic in the second game of the final and won the first set after 47 minutes. He only faced one break point in the final, clinching it in 94 minutes. This win follows his victories in Rome and Wimbledon this season.

site_title: Gallagher nets winner but earns Palace fans' respect
summary: Chelsea midfielder Conor Gallagher scored a late winner in a 2-1 comeback win against Crystal Palace, his first goal for the club. Gallagher, who played for Palace on loan last season, said it was "written in the stars" that he would score against his former club. The goal earned Chelsea three points and impressed new manager Graham Potter, who praised Gallagher for his strike. However, Palace manager Patrick Vieira expressed frustration with the result, citing missed chances and a disputed VAR decision.

site_title: 'I feared for our lives'
summary: Former Indonesian football player Noh Alam Shah recounts his playing experience, describing the intense fanaticism of Indonesian club football as a intimidating force. Shah, a former national striker, shares his fear for his life during his time playing in the country. His account highlights the extreme passion and aggression of Indonesian football fans, a stark contrast to the more controlled atmosphere in Singapore. Shah's story sheds light on the darker side of Indonesian football culture.

site_title: Formula 1: Red Bull's Sergio Perez wins 2022 Singapore Grand Prix
summary: Sergio Perez won the 2022 Singapore Grand Prix, his first victory in the city after nine years. Perez controlled the rain-hit and chaotic race, overtaking pole sitter Charles Leclerc early on and maintaining the lead. Ferrari's Leclerc and Carlos Sainz finished second and third, respectively. Perez's win marked his fourth of the season and made him the fifth F1 winner in Singapore.

site_title: Formula 1: Birthday to forget for Red Bull's Verstappen as he finishes seventh in S'pore
summary: Max Verstappen finished 7th in the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix, missing out on a chance to clinch his second world title. The Dutch driver, who led the championship by 116 points, struggled with his car's fuel levels during qualifying and a poor start. Despite a late charge, Verstappen's 6 points secured his position as the championship leader with 5 races to go. He is now 104 points clear of Charles Leclerc and 106 ahead of teammate Sergio Perez.

site_title: Football: SPL Team of the Week (Matchweek 25)
summary: SPL Team of the Week for Matchweek 25 features Takahiro Koga (Albirex Niigata) for his four crucial saves in a draw, Raihan Rahman (Tanjong Pagar United) for two assists, and Ryoya Taniguchi (Balestier Khalsa) for a hat-trick. Other notable players include Joshua Pereira (Geylang International), Nazhiim Harman (Hougang United), and Reo Nishiguchi (Tanjong Pagar United) for his five goals, as the title race heats up.

site_title: Football: Haaland, Foden hat-tricks help Man City thrash Man United 6-3
summary: Manchester City thrashed Manchester United 6-3 in the English Premier League, with Erling Haaland scoring his 17th goal of the season and Phil Foden securing his first Premier League hat-trick. City dominated the game, taking a 4-0 lead at halftime, before United made some late efforts to reduce the deficit. Haaland and Foden both scored in the second half to seal City's win, while United's Christian Eriksen and Anthony Martial scored two goals each. The defeat was a disappointing one for United, who had been on a four-game winning streak in the league.

site_title: Football: Albirex draw 1-1 with Hougang but gain edge in title race as Sailors lose to Balestier
summary: Albirex Niigata drew 1-1 with Hougang United, maintaining their edge in the Singapore Premier League (SPL) title race as the Lion City Sailors suffered their third straight defeat, losing 5-3 to Balestier. The draw keeps Albirex four points ahead of the Sailors with three games remaining, and the Japanese side is now set to face off against the Sailors in the top-two showdown on Friday.

site_title: Marathon: Kipruto takes maiden London title, Yehualaw storms to victory
summary: Kenyan Amos Kipruto won his first London Marathon title with a time of 2:04:39, edging out Leul Gebresilase in second. Ethiopian Yalemzerf Yehualaw dominated the women's race, crossing the line in 2:17:26 and setting a new Ethiopian record. The absence of top runners, including Eliud Kipchoge and Mo Farah, contributed to their withdrawals, allowing Kipruto and Yehualaw to claim their victories.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO seeks to calm as default swaps near level seen in 2009
summary: Credit Suisse Group CEO Ulrich Koerner reassured staff that the bank has a "strong capital base and liquidity position" amid turbulent markets, where the cost of insuring the firm's bonds against default climbed 15% last week to levels not seen since 2009. Koerner will send regular updates until a new strategic plan is announced on October 27, amid speculation about sweeping changes to its investment bank and potential job cuts. Analysts estimate the bank may need to raise 4 billion Swiss francs in capital to fund restructuring and growth efforts.

site_title: StanChart the latest lender to up terms of account as interest rates rise; offers up to 4.88% on Bonus$aver
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has raised the interest rate on its Bonus$aver account to 4.88% per annum, its highest for a savings account. The bank increased rates by up to 1.2 percentage points across categories, with customers earning bonus interest of up to 1.6% for spending at least $2,000 and 1% for investments and insurance. The move follows other lenders, including UOB, OCBC, and DBS Bank, which have also raised interest rates amid a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: 4 global trailblazers receive Time100 Impact Awards in ceremony held in S'pore for first time
summary: Four global trailblazers received Time100 Impact Awards in a ceremony held in Singapore for the first time. The recipients include microbiologist Pardis Sabeti for her work in containing and treating infectious diseases, actress Alia Bhatt for mental health advocacy, former James Webb Space Telescope Programme director Gregory L. Robinson for space exploration, and singer Lea Salonga for her work with the United Nations. The awards recognize visionaries who have made an impact and moved their industries forward, with Sabeti dedicating her award to young Iranians fighting for their freedom and calling for humanity to uplift and empower the most vulnerable.

site_title: Public education, ground-up efforts key to fighting online threats: Edwin Tong
summary: Singapore Minister Edwin Tong emphasizes the importance of public education in combating online threats such as scams, phishing, and cyber attacks. Online threats involve anonymous adversaries who are not bound by geography, posing significant risks to individuals and social cohesion. The country saw 14,349 scam cases from January to June, with the most common types including job, phishing, e-commerce, and investment scams. Tong highlights the need for both law enforcement and upstream efforts, including public education, to mitigate these threats.

site_title: Police issue warning on surge in phishing scams involving Singpass
summary: Singapore police warn of a surge in phishing scams targeting victims with Singpass log-in credentials via SMSes. Unsolicited SMSes claim Singpass accounts will be deactivated, requiring facial verification, and direct users to a spoofed log-in webpage. Authorities have taken down phishing websites, but user vigilance is crucial. To avoid scams, users should verify claims by calling the Singpass hotline, ensure the website domain is singpass.gov.sg, and reset passwords immediately if suspicious activity is detected.

site_title: Football: Real chief likens Super League to tennis, where 'top players face each other multiple times'
summary: Real Madrid president Florentino Perez reiterated his support for a European Super League, likening it to tennis where top players face each other multiple times a year. He argued that fans deserve to see high-quality games, citing examples of tennis players Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic's frequent matches. Perez criticized UEFA and Paris Saint-Germain president Nasser Al-Khelaifi, accusing the latter of misrepresenting Real Madrid's motivations for launching the Super League. Perez's comments were met with criticism, including from La Liga president Javier Tebas, who warned that his statements could harm other clubs, including Real Madrid.

site_title: Formula 1: Rain delays start of Singapore Grand Prix; train services extended by 30 minutes
summary: The Formula One Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix was delayed by an hour due to heavy rain, with the 61-lap race starting at 9:05pm instead of 8pm. The delay allowed train services to be extended by 30 minutes, with the last train departing City Hall Station at 1:15am. The rain also affected the qualifying session on Saturday, but Red Bull's Sergio Perez won the race, finishing ahead of Ferrari's Charles Leclerc and Carlos Sainz.

site_title: Global stocks pin hopes of year-end rally on earnings resilience
summary: Investors are optimistic about a year-end rally in global stocks, driven by a resilient corporate earnings season. The S&P 500 gained an average 4.1% in the final quarter of the past 20 years, a period marked by previous fourth-quarter declines. Analysts expect earnings to hold up, with Bloomberg Intelligence forecasting a 2.9% rise in S&P 500 earnings, and some strategists predicting a short-term bounce despite the negative investor mood. However, the ongoing challenges of high inflation, interest rate hikes, and global economic uncertainty remain.

site_title: New mobile app aims to make parking in Tiong Bahru a breeze for motorists
summary: A new mobile app, The Breeze Drive & Park, has launched in Singapore to help motorists find parking spaces in Tiong Bahru. The app, developed by tech firm NCS, provides real-time information on parking space availability and rates, using artificial intelligence and video analytics. Initially focusing on Tiong Bahru for six months, the app aims to ease parking woes in the popular neighborhood, where some parking lots have been removed to make way for pedestrian-friendly areas. The app also offers traffic data, walking trails, and local attractions.

site_title: Motorcycling: KTM's Oliveira wins rain-affected Thailand GP as title race hots up
summary: KTM rider Miguel Oliveira won the Thailand Grand Prix in a rain-affected event, crossing the line 0.730 seconds ahead of Jack Miller and Francesco Bagnaia. Oliveira showcased his wet-weather skills, while Bagnaia made up ground on world championship leader Fabio Quartararo, reducing his lead from 18 points to just two. Oliveira's victory helped Oliveira move up the title race, while Quartararo suffered a disastrous start, dropping from fourth to 17th.

site_title: Football: Australian federation vows to punish Nazi salutes at cup final
summary: Australian football federation Football Australia vowed to take swift action against fans who made Nazi salutes and chanted far-right Croatian songs during the Australia Cup final between Macarthur FC and Sydney United 58. Eight people were evicted from the stadium, and the governing body is assessing footage to determine "strong and swift action" against offenders. Jewish community representatives and players condemned the behavior, calling for immediate action against the perpetrators, who are accused of disrupting an indigenous welcoming ceremony and violating crowd noise laws. The incident has sparked outrage and calls for greater accountability.

site_title: Formula 1: Hamilton allowed to wear nose stud, but Mercedes cop $35k fine
summary: Formula 1 driver Lewis Hamilton was allowed to wear a nose stud during the Singapore Grand Prix due to medical reasons, despite his Mercedes team being fined $35,210 for failing to notify stewards about the jewelry. Hamilton had removed the stud due to an infection, but his doctors advised him to keep it in. The FIA, Formula One's governing body, ruled that the team's mistake was not intentional and fined them $25,000 for not following the rules.

site_title: Golf: China's Lin, England's Hull share lead at LPGA Volunteers Classic
summary: China's Lin Xiyu and England's Charley Hull shared the lead at the LPGA Volunteers Classic after the third round, both scoring 11-under 202. Lin, 26, fired a two-under 69 to match Hull's 71, while New Zealand's Lydia Ko and France's Celine Boutier shared third on 203. Lin is chasing her first LPGA title and remains optimistic about her chances, saying she's "getting more comfortable" with the pressure of playing in the weekend final groups.

site_title: Tennis: Britain's Norrie out of Japan Open with Covid as ATP Finals hopes take hit
summary: Britain's tennis player Cameron Norrie withdrew from the Japan Open due to a positive Covid-19 test, forcing a hit to his hopes of qualifying for the ATP Finals. Norrie also pulled out of the Korea Open, citing a positive test without symptoms. The season-ending ATP Finals will take place from November 13-20, and Norrie's withdrawal may impact his qualification chances.

site_title: More adults with autism to be employed in healthcare sector under new agreement
summary: A new agreement between Autism Resource Centre (ARC) and IHH Healthcare Singapore aims to increase employment of adults with autism in the healthcare sector. The collaboration, since 2019, has led to 15 employees with autism working in various roles, including pharmacies, radiology, and medical records departments. The three-year partnership will train and equip more individuals with autism for healthcare roles, expanding job opportunities. This move supports Singapore's goal to have 40% of working-age people with disabilities employed by 2030.

site_title: Tennis: Japan's Nishioka beats Shapovalov to win Korea Open
summary: Japan's Yoshihito Nishioka won the Korea Open, defeating fourth seed Denis Shapovalov 6-4, 7-6 (7-5) to claim his second ATP title. Nishioka, who defeated world No. 2 Casper Ruud in the semifinals, rose to a career-high ranking of 41. This victory follows his 2018 Shenzhen Open title. Nishioka will next participate in the Tokyo tournament from October 3-9.

site_title: Football: Spanish football clubs to observe minute's silence after Indonesian stadium crush
summary: Spanish football clubs will observe a minute's silence before matches on Sunday to pay respects for the 125+ people killed and 180 injured in a stampede at an Indonesian game. The stampede occurred after tear gas was released by police following a pitch invasion by fans after Arema FC's 3-2 defeat by Persebaya Surabaya. Indonesian President Joko Widodo has ordered a safety review of the country's football matches, and the Football Association of Indonesia has suspended all games in the top league until an investigation is completed.

site_title: Football: Strict regulations, enforcement to keep fans safe in Singapore stadiums
summary: Singapore Premier League clubs are responsible for maintaining security and safety at their home grounds. Bag checks, regulations to ban dangerous items, and security personnel are in place to ensure order at professional football matches. The national agency Sport Singapore operates the stadiums, but clubs are accountable for implementing safety measures under SPL regulations.

site_title: I feared for our lives: Alam Shah recounts Indonesia football stint following stadium stampede
summary: Former Singapore national footballer Noh Alam Shah shared a harrowing experience of playing for an Indonesian club, where he witnessed a stadium stampede that left him fearing for his life. Shah, known for his volatile personality on the field, described the situation as inevitable and tragic. He recalled the intense fan culture in Indonesian football, which made him feel uneasy and vulnerable. Shah's account highlights the dangers of extreme fan behavior in sports.

site_title: Showtime: Giant planet Jupiter just came closest to Earth in nearly 60 years
summary: Jupiter, the largest planet in the solar system, made its closest approach to Earth in nearly 60 years, occurring on Sept 27, 2022. The planet appeared brighter and clearer than usual, with its features such as the Great Red Spot and four largest moons visible through a telescope. This rare event, known as Jupiter's Opposition, happens every 13 months and allows for a sharper view of the planet's bands and swirls. Jupiter will remain visible in the night sky until early February 2023.

site_title: Singapore re-elected to ICAO council, commits to supporting sustainable aviation
summary: Singapore has been re-elected to the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) council for a third term, committing to support sustainable aviation. The move, which was first made in 2003, reflects Singapore's strong international collaboration and commitment to building a resilient, inclusive, and sustainable future for aviation. As a member of ICAO, Singapore will continue to shape international standards in areas such as safety, security, and environmental protection, and will focus on initiatives like sustainable fuel and "green lanes" to reduce aviation's carbon footprint.

site_title: Formula 1: Singapore Grand Prix sees record crowd of 302,000 after 2-year hiatus
summary: The Formula 1 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix 2022 has set a new record with 302,000 fans attending the three-day event, surpassing the previous high of 300,000 in 2008. The event, which was cancelled in 2020 and 2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, drew strong interest and support from the local economy, with hotel occupancy rates and room rates exceeding historical highs. The event generated significant tourism receipts and supported over 30,000 jobs at the circuit each weekend.

site_title: World economy roiled by simultaneous shocks echoing 2007 anxiety
summary: The world economy is facing a rapid downshift due to a series of shocks, including interest rate hikes, inflation, and the Russian invasion of Ukraine, increasing the likelihood of another global recession. The US Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes are causing concern, with evidence mounting of the impact on consumers and businesses, including Nike's stockpile of unsold product and FedEx's warning on delivery volumes. The rapidly appreciating dollar is also driving up inflation elsewhere, putting pressure on authorities to restrain their own economies.

site_title: Charity aims to make mental healthcare more accessible to children, youth
summary: A charity in Singapore, Impart, aims to make mental healthcare more accessible to children and youth through its Project Cope and crisis response initiative Imna. Since its launch, over 150 children and youth have been served, with a record 112 suicides among young people aged 10-29 in Singapore in 2021. The charity provides crisis intervention, peer supporters, and community workers to address mental health issues at the primary care level, but faces challenges of long waiting times and burnout among clinicians.

site_title: The pitfalls of 'investing' in gold jewellery
summary: Gold prices have dropped 20% from their pandemic high due to the stronger US dollar. However, investing in gold jewellery is not the same as trading in the bullion market. Goldsmiths sell jewellery at a premium, typically 20% above international trading rates, making it less of an investment opportunity. This premium is equivalent to buying the gold at a higher price, rather than the actual market value, making it less attractive for investors.

site_title: Football: Barca edge Mallorca to top league, Atletico dominate sorry Sevilla
summary: Barcelona edged Mallorca 1-0 to move one point clear of Real Madrid in La Liga, thanks to Robert Lewandowski's 20th-minute strike. Meanwhile, Atletico Madrid dominated a 2-0 win over Sevilla, increasing the pressure on coach Julen Lopetegui. Lewandowski leads the scoring charts in Spain with nine goals from seven games, and Barcelona's coach Xavi Hernandez earned a new domestic record of 18 consecutive league matches without defeat.

site_title: China's market rout creates historic gap with Indian stocks
summary: China's stock market has plummeted by 23% in the last year, while India's MSCI index has risen 10% in the same period, creating a historic gap between the two emerging markets. The divergence is attributed to China's Covid-19 restrictions, regulatory crackdowns, and tensions with the West. India's economy is forecast to grow 7% in the fiscal year, more than twice China's 2022 growth, making it an attractive alternative for global investors. India's expanding domestic market and rising market clout are expected to boost its presence worldwide.

site_title: Things to note when trading in gold
summary: When trading in gold, buyers of smaller bars may face high "workmanship" charges, significantly increasing the overall cost. A one-gram bar on the UOB website was listed at $107, despite its gold value being around $76, a 40% markup. This disparity may deter potential buyers from purchasing smaller gold bars, highlighting the need for transparency in pricing.

site_title: Generational shift in S'pore on cannabis use overseas: Survey
summary: A survey of 1,000 Singaporeans and permanent residents found a generational shift in attitudes towards cannabis consumption overseas, with younger people (16-44) more accepting of the practice. 40% of respondents in this age group believed it should not be an offence to consume cannabis abroad, while 44% of those aged 45-54 and 55+ believed it should be illegal. Experts attribute the shift to media portrayals, online information, and peer pressure, and call for more interactive mediums and in-depth conversations to engage young people on the harsh realities of drugs.

site_title: ACS (I) looks to tap artificial intelligence for exam invigilation
summary: Anglo-Chinese School (Independent) is exploring the use of artificial intelligence (AI) for exam invigilation to detect irregular behavior among students and reduce manpower needs. The school launched a tender to develop and operate an AI system that analyzes and identifies anomalous actions, such as frequent head movements or dropping objects. The system has been successfully tested in trials, resulting in a 30% manpower savings. The Ministry of Education has expressed support for the trial, citing the need for robust protocols in school-based examination invigilation.

site_title: Football: Arsenal beat Spurs to stay top, Liverpool held by Brighton
summary: Arsenal secured a 3-1 victory over Tottenham Hotspur, staying atop the Premier League with 21 points. Liverpool drew 3-3 with Brighton & Hove Albion, while Chelsea won 2-1 against Crystal Palace under new manager Graham Potter. Newcastle United thumped 10-man Fulham 4-1, and West Ham United beat Wolverhampton Wanderers 2-0 to move out of the bottom three. The results leave Manchester City four points behind Arsenal, with their match against Manchester United on Sunday.

site_title: 53% want S'pore to explore legalising cannabis for medical use: Survey
summary: A survey of 1,000 Singaporeans and permanent residents found 53% in favor of exploring the legalization of cannabis for medical use, with 59% of those aged 16-34 supporting the idea. However, the majority, 35%, are opposed to any legalization, and 44% believe cannabis is harmful for recreational use. The government's stance is based on evidence and science, which show cannabis use to be harmful, and they allow controlled access to cannabis-derived medication for medical purposes.

site_title: Volunteering opportunities for youth as part of Forward SG
summary: Singapore is launching nearly 3,000 new volunteering opportunities for youth between October and December as part of the Forward Singapore exercise. The initiatives, led by the National Youth Council, focus on environmental conservation, helping seniors, and promoting inclusivity through discussions on sensitive issues like race and religion. A toolkit and digital campaign will also be launched to equip young people with civic discourse skills and encourage conversations on difficult topics. Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong emphasized the importance of building a cohesive, inclusive, and united Singapore.

site_title: Thundery showers expected on most days in first half of October
summary: Thundery showers are expected on most days in Singapore during the first half of October, with daily temperatures ranging between 24-33°C. The Meteorological Service Singapore (MSS) forecasts above-average rainfall over most parts of the island, with the highest anomaly recorded at Lower Peirce Reservoir in September. The rainy south-west monsoon is currently affecting the country, and strong winds in the Strait of Malacca may cause thundery showers and gusty winds in the second week of October.

site_title: Will property cooling measures affect August BTO applicants?
summary: New property cooling measures were introduced to cool the housing markets, including a 15-month wait for private home owners to buy resale flats and tightening of the loan-to-value limit for HDB loans to 80% from 85%. However, successful applicants in August and earlier BTO launches will not be affected, as the LTV limit for HDB loans will remain at 85%. The measures aim to moderate demand and will be reviewed based on market changes.

site_title: Science on harmful effects of cannabis use remains clear
summary: Multiple studies have found that cannabis use is linked to impaired memory, decision-making, and development of psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia, depression, and bipolar disorder. Research by Singaporean researchers and others has shown that early, chronic, and frequent cannabis consumption can lead to deleterious effects on cognitive performance, executive function, and mental health. The findings have informed the continued regulation of cannabis as a controlled drug in Singapore, citing increased risk of fatal accidents, addiction, and mental health problems associated with THC use.

site_title: Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital opens new nursing home in Potong Pasir
summary: Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital (KWSH) opened its second nursing home in Potong Pasir, catering to the high concentration of seniors in the area. The 438-bed facility offers nursing, daycare, and traditional Chinese medicine services, as well as dementia care. The home's opening coincides with KWSH's 112th anniversary, bringing the total number of beds across its six eldercare facilities to 1,200. The facility aims to support up to 75 seniors daily through activities and social work, and is part of a goal to develop the centre as an active ageing care hub.

site_title: Singaporeans sneaking in fresh chicken from Johor
summary: Singaporeans are smuggling fresh chicken from Johor by wrapping it in newspaper and hiding it among vegetables in a grocery bag placed near their feet inside a car. This prohibited act is allegedly done by sellers in Johor to bring back the chicken to Singapore. The method involves placing the bag near the feet to avoid detection by authorities.

site_title: More should be done to support seniors as aspirations change: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need to support seniors in Singapore as they age, citing the rapid aging of the population. The People's Action Party Seniors Group (PAPSG) will work to ensure seniors have good opportunities in the economy, including remaining in the workforce longer and having access to anti-discrimination laws. The group will also provide better end-of-life care and explore assisted living options to address the growing need for senior-friendly communities. With one in four citizens expected to be above 65 by 2030, PAPSG aims to combat negativity surrounding aging and empower seniors to remain active and engaged.

site_title: Over nine in 10 junior doctors hired annually are locals: MOH Holdings
summary: MOH Holdings reported that over 90% of junior doctors recruited annually are locals, with most being graduates from Singapore's three local medical schools or returning Singaporeans. The statement comes amid an ongoing tender for a recruitment agency to hire doctors in India, sparking concerns about efforts to hire local doctors and alleged incidents of widespread fraud among Indian medical students and doctors. MOH Holdings recruits about 700 junior doctors annually and has increased its local pipeline, with combined intakes of Singapore's medical schools increasing by 45% between 2012 and 2019.

site_title: 53% want S'pore to explore legalising it for medical use
summary: A survey of 1,000 Singaporeans and permanent residents found that 53% support legalizing cannabis for medical purposes, while 35% oppose any legalization. The majority believe cannabis is harmful, but some acknowledge its potential benefits for medical use. Experts, including former addicts and lawyers, express differing opinions on the issue, with some arguing that laws should be amended to allow controlled access to cannabis-derived medication. The government maintains its zero-tolerance approach to drug use, citing evidence that shows cannabis use is harmful.

site_title: A slice of southern Spain at Gardens by the Bay
summary: The Flower Dome at Gardens by the Bay in Singapore has launched an exhibition, A Spanish Serenade With Sunflowers, recreating the Patio de las Doncellas of the Real Alcazar in Seville, Spain. The display features sunflowers, pelargoniums, petunias, roses, and camellias, inspired by Andalusian cities in southern Spain. The collaboration marks the first time Gardens by the Bay has worked with the Embassy of Spain and the Spain Tourism Board, highlighting Spanish culture, art, and heritage through a floral display and cultural exhibition until October 30.

site_title: MOM company's dorm operations expected to be financially sustainable
summary: Nest Singapore, a corporate entity set up by the Ministry of Manpower, is expected to be financially sustainable in operating two dormitories for migrant workers. The first dorm, in Jurong, will house 2,400 workers and the second, in Sengkang West, will have a capacity of 7,200 when it begins operations in 2028. Funding details are still in the works, but existing regulations will apply to Nest's dorms. The company will partner with private sector players to tap industry expertise, and the launch follows the extension of the Foreign Employees Dormitories Act to cover smaller dorms.

site_title: Science is clear on harmful effects
summary: Multiple studies have linked cannabis use to impaired memory and decision-making, as well as the development of major psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia, depression, and bipolar disorder. Research by Singaporean researchers found that early, chronic, and recreational cannabis consumption can exert deleterious effects on cognitive performance, including learning abilities and memory. The studies also showed that cannabis use can lead to dependence and mental health problems, with a sevenfold increased risk of fatal accidents on the road due to impaired psychomotor performance.

site_title: Malaysian farmers to boost output only when there is clarity on lifting ban
summary: Malaysian chicken farmers are hesitant to increase production for export to Singapore until there is clarity on when the existing export ban will be lifted. The ban, imposed in June, has left farmers with a surplus of chickens and monetary losses. With a 30-day growth period for chickens, Singapore may only receive a full supply of fresh chickens about a month after the ban is lifted. Farmers are worried about losing market share to Indonesia, which is setting up farms in Batam to export fresh chickens to Singapore, and are calling for the government to provide a definite date for exports to resume.

site_title: Five taken to hospital after fire breaks out in Yishun flat
summary: A fire broke out at a Housing Board flat in Yishun, Singapore, on Saturday, affecting five people. The fire was extinguished with a water jet, and five individuals, including two with minor burn injuries, were taken to hospital for smoke inhalation. The cause of the fire is believed to be a battery pack from a power-assisted bicycle in the living room. Authorities have emphasized the importance of following safety guidelines for these devices to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Opportunities for Singapore to attract more investments
summary: Singapore's existing semiconductor ecosystem is poised to attract more investment as semiconductor companies seek to diversify manufacturing and supply sources due to heightened geopolitical tensions and supply chain disruptions. This trend presents opportunities for the city-state to expand its presence in the industry, potentially leading to increased economic growth and development.

site_title: Covid-19 antibody treatment no longer recommended for use
summary: Singapore's National Centre for Infectious Diseases no longer recommends the use of casirivimab-imdevimab, a Covid-19 treatment authorized in 2021, due to its poor activity against Omicron variants. The World Health Organisation and US FDA previously advised against its use. The centre now recommends a higher dose of sotrovimab for treatment, or alternative treatments like antiviral drugs. The Sars-CoV-2 virus continues to evolve, with the BA.4 and BA.5 variants now predominant, and the Covid-19 therapeutic work group will review its recommendations with evolving data.

site_title: Malay Muslims have made great progress but must now aim higher: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Malay/Muslim community has made significant progress in education, with 99% of Malay students completing at least 10 years of education and over 90% completing post-secondary studies. However, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for the community to aim higher and support early childhood education, resolving family issues, and promoting lifelong education among workers. The government has pledged to support Mendaki's plans to raise $40 million, matching funds raised dollar for dollar, up to $20 million, to improve existing programs and implement new schemes.

site_title: Should I get a credit card for a free travel bag?
summary: A sales promoter at a mall offered a free Rimowa luggage item to customers who sign up for a new credit card. The promotion likely includes cashback, air miles, or shopping discounts, but choosing the most beneficial rewards can be difficult. The offer may be tempting for travelers in need of a new luggage set, but the decision depends on individual needs and preferences.

site_title: Generational shift in S'pore on cannabis use overseas
summary: A survey of 1,000 Singaporeans and permanent residents found that younger people (16-24 years old) are more accepting of cannabis consumption abroad, with 40% believing it should not be an offense. In contrast, older respondents (45-54 and 55+) were more likely to think it should be illegal, with 44% and 27% respectively holding this view. The survey attributed the shift in attitudes to media portrayals, online information, and peer pressure, and experts warned that the liberalization of attitudes towards cannabis could lead to desensitization to its harms.

site_title: MOM setting up company to run two new foreign worker dorms
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) is setting up a company called Nest Singapore to manage two new purpose-built dormitories for foreign workers. The dorms, built and owned by MOM, will feature innovations to improve foreign worker housing, including more spacious rooms, better ventilation, and en-suite toilets. The first dormitory, Tukang, will open in 2025 with 2,400 beds, and the second, Sengkang, will open in 2028 with 7,200 beds. The goal is to transform dormitory living and management, with a focus on public health resilience and liveability.

site_title: What history tells us about Fed hikes
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates again is aimed at curbing inflation, which is at 8.3% in the US, near its highest rate in 40 years. The Fed chair, Jerome Powell, acknowledged the hikes will raise unemployment and slow the economy. The Fed's approach is being studied in the context of the 1979-1983 era under Paul Volcker, who successfully brought inflation below 4% despite two recessions and high unemployment. The Volcker era shows the Fed can make a "big" psychological statement to curb inflation, and a similar pivot is needed to bring the economy back on track.

site_title: 'This is my biggest regret': Home-based baker recounts losing Instagram account to scammer
summary: A Singapore-based home-based baker, Mr Faisel Mohamed, 45, had his Instagram account hijacked by a scammer who used his account to advertise fake investment schemes to his 5,000 followers. After receiving an order with a verification request, the scammer tricked Mr Faisel into sending a screenshot containing a link to reset his password, which the scammer used to lock him out. The scammer has since advertised fake investment schemes and contests, causing many followers to unfollow Mr Faisel. The police have confirmed a report has been lodged and Meta, Instagram's parent company, is in the process of recovering Mr Faisel's account.

site_title: Opera to digital to sustainability - Tom Reichert's consulting journey
summary: Tom Reichert, a prominent consultant, left Boston Consulting Group's digital practice in February to become the head of ERM, a leading environmental consultancy. Reichert's departure was unexpected, as he was a key figure at BCG. At ERM, he now oversees the firm's sustainability efforts, helping clients and individuals find more environmentally friendly ways to work and live. Reichert's move signals a shift in focus towards sustainability in the consulting industry.

site_title: Old-school investing works even at the cutting edge
summary: Singaporean fintech executive Deepak Khanna, head of wealth and trading at Revolut, adheres to an old-school investment strategy despite working in the cutting-edge financial tech sector. He allocates less than 50% of his income towards expenses, directing the rest towards property payments and investments. This approach allows Khanna to grow his investment portfolio over the long term, reflecting his belief in the value of property as a stable investment.

site_title: Aspiring HDB resale flat buyers scramble to adjust to changes
summary: Subscribers to the Housing and Development Board (HDB) resale flat market must wait 15 months after selling their private homes before buying a non-subsidized flat. This temporary measure aims to cool the market, prompting some buyers to abandon their plans or rent instead. Property agents are scrambling to adjust housing plans for anxious clients, as the government reviews the measure based on demand and market changes. The new rule, introduced on Friday, is expected to impact the resale flat market significantly, with some buyers opting to downsize or delay their purchases.

images.alt_text: Since Friday, private home owners must wait 15 months after the sale of their current home before they can buy a non-subsidised HDB resale flat. The authorities said it is a temporary measure that will be reviewed depending on overall demand and mark

site_title: Opera to digital to sustainability - Tom Reichert's consulting journey
summary: Tom Reichert, a prominent environmental consultant, has taken the helm at ERM, the largest pure-play environmental consultancy. Reichert, who previously led Boston Consulting Group's digital practice, shifted focus to sustainability, stating it has become a central concept. His move signals a significant shift in the industry, with sustainability no longer an afterthought but a core priority. Reichert's leadership at ERM aims to help firms and individuals adopt more sustainable practices, marking a significant evolution in the consulting landscape.

site_title: When workers are put on 'quiet firing'
summary: "Quiet firing" refers to a phenomenon where employers intentionally make working conditions unbearable, forcing employees to resign without being directly fired. This can be achieved through neglecting resources, opportunities, or time, effectively "constructively discharging" employees. The practice is a flip side to "quiet quitting," where employees contentedly fulfill their job descriptions. Experts warn that this tactic can be detrimental to employees' mental health and well-being, while also being a form of subtle harassment.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary: Key events and matches are scheduled for the next 24 hours, including football matches like Balestier vs Lion City Sailors and Man City vs Man United, as well as golf tournaments like the Alfred Dunhill Links C'ship and the UFC Fight Night featuring Dern vs Yan. Other notable events include MotoGP's Thailand Grand Prix, Formula One's race day, and tennis finals for the Korea Open, Tel Aviv Open, and Sofia Open, among others.

site_title: Pitfalls of investing in gold jewellery
summary: Investing in gold jewellery is not a lucrative option, with prices often 20% higher than international trading rates. The current gold price drop of 20% from its pandemic high makes it challenging to profit from jewellery purchases. To break even, the gold price must increase by more than 20%. Investors may face significant losses, making it a less desirable investment choice.

site_title: Things to note when trading in gold
summary: When trading in gold, buying larger bars can be more cost-effective due to lower "workmanship" charges. A one-gram gold bar costs $107, but its actual gold value is around $76, representing a 40% markup. This significant difference highlights the importance of comparing prices and considering the weight and purity of gold when making a purchase.

site_title: Chess body to probe Carlsen's cheating claims
summary: The International Chess Federation (Fide) will convene a three-person panel to investigate allegations of cheating by American teenager Hans Niemann, who was accused of cheating by world champion Magnus Carlsen after a surprise defeat in a tournament. Niemann has a history of online cheating and was previously banned from chess.com, but denies any wrongdoing in over-the-board games. Fide aims to ensure a fair ruling, protecting the rights of both parties during the investigation.

site_title: Cashing in on chips
summary: Singapore has established itself as a significant node in the global semiconductor supply chain over 50 years. Despite the current slowdown in demand, long-term prospects remain robust due to the integral role of semiconductor chips in technology products. Key players, including major chipmakers, have contributed to the sector's growth, and its upward trend is expected to continue as technology advancements drive demand. The sector's resilience is attributed to its widespread use in various products, including smartphones, laptops, and cars.

site_title: When workers are put on 'quiet firing'
summary: Quiet firing, a phenomenon where employers intentionally or unintentionally discourage employees from staying by creating unfulfilling work conditions, has been identified as a growing issue. Examples include denying raises, blocking opportunities for growth, and neglecting feedback. Experts say this tactic can lead to employees feeling unappreciated and uninvested, ultimately causing them to quit. Research suggests that lack of career development and uncaring leaders are top reasons people leave their jobs, with women being disproportionately affected. Employers must invest in developing new managers and clear expectations to prevent quiet firing and support employee growth.

site_title: 'Warrior' to lead derby battle
summary: Manchester United's Lisandro Martinez will face a test in the derby against Manchester City's Erling Haaland, who has scored 14 goals in nine games for City. Martinez, known for his tenacious tackling, is Manchester United's best defense against Haaland, but the 22-year-old striker is considered the best in the world. Martinez's height difference with Haaland is notable, but his aggressive style may be key to stopping the Norwegian. United manager Erik ten Hag believes his team can beat City if they act as a unit, but Haaland's form suggests he will be a major challenge.

site_title: What history tells us about Fed hikes
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates again is aimed at curbing inflation, now at 8.3% annually in the US, near its highest rate in 40 years. Following the example of Fed chair Jerome Powell, who acknowledged the hikes would raise unemployment and slow the economy, the Fed is pivoting from its focus on controlling the money supply to targeting interest rates. This approach, seen in the 1982 Volcker era, has led to significant financial market improvements, including a 40-year bull market, but also comes with the risk of economic downturns.

site_title: Young & Savvy: Should I get a credit card for a free luggage bag?
summary: A Singaporean woman was offered a free Rimowa luggage bag by a credit card sales promoter at a shopping mall. She was tempted by the offer, considering her worn-out previous luggage. The article suggests that credit cards can be used prudently for benefits like free items, but the woman is still deciding whether to sign up for the card. The decision depends on her individual financial situation and needs.

site_title: Leclerc clinches pole at Singapore Grand Prix
summary: Ferrari driver Charles Leclerc secured pole position at the Singapore Grand Prix, beating Red Bull's Sergio Perez and Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton. The qualifying session took place in wet conditions, which often favors drivers starting from pole. Eight of the last 12 Singapore GP winners have started from the front, highlighting the challenges of overtaking at the Marina Bay Street Circuit. Leclerc will look to capitalize on his pole position in the upcoming race.

site_title: Arteta hails team's 'great energy'
summary: Arsenal maintained their top spot in the Premier League with a 3-1 win over Tottenham Hotspur at the Emirates Stadium. Goals from Granit Xhaka, Thomas Partey, and Gabriel Jesus sealed the victory, with Harry Kane's penalty for Tottenham equalizing in the first half. The Gunners' win marked their 12th consecutive unbeaten match against their local rivals and moved them four points clear of second-placed Manchester City.

site_title: 'Silly season' heats up for drivers
summary: The 2022 Formula One season's "silly season" has begun, shifting focus from the championship to the drivers' market. Max Verstappen's dominance has sealed his championship win, with 116-point lead. The attention now turns to three available seats and potential reshuffles at AlphaTauri, with six races remaining.

site_title: The Great British race off
summary: Lando Norris, a Formula One driver from the UK, is racing to claim his first F1 win, having debuted in 2019. Despite being 76 grands prix into his career, he has yet to secure a chequered flag. Norris faces stiff competition from George Russell, who is seen as the potential successor to Norris as Britain's next F1 hope. A victory for Norris would solidify his position as the country's top F1 driver, but Russell's recent performances suggest a close battle for the title.

site_title: Will the one that got away haunt United on Sunday?
summary: Manchester City have been the dominant force in Manchester football for the last decade, collecting five Premier League titles. By next summer, Manchester United will have gone 10 years without a title, a record that may haunt the club. Despite a slow start to the current season, City are favored to win a sixth title, solidifying their position as the top team in Manchester.

site_title: Wilson stars as US claim fourth straight World Cup easily
summary: The US women's basketball team, led by A'ja Wilson, won their fourth straight Women's Basketball World Cup and 11th overall, defeating China 83-61 in Sydney. The US dominated the game, led by Wilson's 19 points, and stretched their unbeaten streak to 30 games. This victory follows a record-breaking semi-final win against Canada and a previous win against China. The US has now beaten China in all seven previous World Cup clashes by an average of 22 points, solidifying their position as the top team in the competition.

site_title: Horner slams his rivals
summary: Red Bull team principal Christian Horner has slammed rival teams for claiming his team breached the Formula One budget cap, calling the comments "unacceptable" and "hugely defamatory." Horner is considering legal action against those making the claims, which could include Aston Martin. The FIA will issue certificates of compliance with the 2021 financial regulations on Wednesday, marking a crucial test for the cost cap. If a breach is found, teams could face penalties including point deductions, suspension, and a reduction in the cost cap.

site_title: Have faith in Charminton
summary: Charminton, a four-year-old Kiwi-bred gelding trained by Logan, has the best credentials to win Sunday's $50,000 Class 4 Division 2 event over the Polytrack 1,200m. Consistent in his performances, Charminton has won two and placed second twice from four starts, displaying top qualities of a thoroughbred. With a recent trial win and a gallop with his regular rider, Charminton is set to face off against Cash Cove, War Warrior, Teardrops, and Harry Dream, with many experts tipping him to emerge victorious.

site_title: Old-school investing works even at the cutting edge
summary: Singaporean fintech executive Deepak Khanna, head of wealth and trading at Revolut, believes in old-school investing, particularly in property, as a long-term investment strategy. He prioritizes saving money to meet his family's needs and pursue his passions, allocating less than 50% of his income towards expenses. The rest is directed towards property payments and other investments, showcasing his conservative yet effective approach to managing finances.

site_title: Fuming over narrow defeat
summary: Angela Lee fell short in her bid to capture the One Championship strawweight world title, losing to China's Xiong Jingnan via unanimous decision. Lee, the current atomweight champion, had a strong fight but was unable to deliver a decisive blow, with Xiong retaining her title after five rounds. Lee and One CEO Chatri Sityodtong expressed their disappointment with the decision, with Chatri stating that Lee "stood toe to toe" with Xiong and did well in the fight.

site_title: Hull's 'boringest' putting work pays off
summary: Charley Hull fired a seven-under 64 to take a two-stroke lead at the Volunteers of America Classic in Texas, with 11-under 131. Hull credited her hot putting, which she worked on extensively during a recent two-week break from the tour. Thailand's Atthaya Thitikul and China's Lin Xiyu trailed by two strokes, while Mackenzie Hughes shot the low round of the day, a nine-under 63, to tie for the lead at the Sanderson Farms Championship in Mississippi.

site_title: Green trade finance goes digital to help SMEs run efficiently and sustainably
summary: A Singaporean construction company, Kimly, has partnered with fintech company Doxa and bank UOB to digitalize their trade finance processes, making green trade financing more accessible to smaller suppliers and contractors. The partnership uses Doxa's online procurement-to-pay platform to automate complex workflows, reducing paperwork and increasing efficiency. With the platform, Kimly can access green and sustainable trade financing from UOB without additional paper documents, and suppliers can validate their invoices on the platform. The partnership aims to simplify green financing for SMEs and lower-tier contractors, making it easier for them to access green financing options.

site_title: Sports World: Good start for women but woe for the men
summary: The Singapore women's table tennis team secured a 3-0 win over Luxembourg, maintaining their lead in Group 4 at the World Team Championships. Meanwhile, the men's team suffered a 3-2 defeat to Croatia, and face Belgium on Sunday. In motorsports, Yuey Tan finished 14th in the Thailand Super Series, while Jamie Chadwick qualified 8th for the W Series. Tanjong Pagar United moved into fourth spot in the Singapore Premier League, beating Young Lions 8-1. The IOC is considering allowing Russian athletes who do not support Ukraine's invasion to compete.

site_title: Trossard's hat-trick rescues a draw for Brighton
summary: Brighton & Hove Albion drew 3-3 with Liverpool in the Premier League at Anfield, with Leandro Trossard scoring a hat-trick for the visitors. Trossard's goals, including a brace within 17 minutes, threatened Liverpool's unbeaten run at home. The match ended in a draw after Liverpool came back from a two-goal deficit, with Trossard's late equalizer securing the point for Brighton. The result marked a promising debut for Brighton's new manager Roberto de Zerbi.

site_title: Haaland, the man United tried in vain to get, may haunt them on Sunday
summary: Manchester City's Erling Haaland has scored 14 goals in his first 10 games, impressing in his debut season. The team has dominated Manchester football for the last decade, collecting five Premier League titles, while Manchester United has gone 10 years without a title. City are now favored to win a sixth title this season, despite a slight start, and are expected to surpass United's title drought by next summer. Haaland's impressive form may prove costly for Manchester United, who had attempted to sign him.

site_title: Night of contrasting fortunes at S'pore GP
summary: Charles Leclerc secured pole position at the Singapore Grand Prix, his ninth time leading the starting grid this season, with a lap time of 1min 49.412sec. Max Verstappen, the championship leader, was left frustrated after abandoning his final flying lap due to fuel woes, settling for eighth place. Sergio Perez will join Leclerc in the front row, with Lewis Hamilton third fastest. Leclerc is now looking to make the most of his pole position, while Verstappen faces an uphill task to win and secure his second world title.

site_title: Football: Klopp issues 'do better' rallying cry after Brighton draw
summary: Liverpool coach Juergen Klopp urged his players to "fight through" their disappointing start to the season after a 3-3 draw with Brighton & Hove Albion. The draw leaves Liverpool trailing Premier League leaders Arsenal by 11 points and has sparked concerns about the team's performance, particularly in the opening exchanges. Klopp called for improvement in passing and defending, and emphasized the need to regain confidence to make up for the lost ground in the busy October schedule.

site_title: Football: Chalobah sees red as Newcastle thrash 10-man Fulham 4-1
summary: Newcastle United secured their first away win of the season with a 4-1 thrashing of 10-man Fulham at Craven Cottage. Nathaniel Chalobah was sent off in the 8th minute for a dangerous challenge, allowing Newcastle to capitalize and take a 3-0 lead at halftime. Callum Wilson, Miguel Almiron, and Sean Longstaff scored for Newcastle, while Aleksandar Mitrovic's injury and Bobby Decordova-Reid's late goal were not enough to stop the defeat. Newcastle move into 7th spot with 11 points, while Fulham remain just below them on goal difference.

site_title: Tennis: 'Quite emotional' Djokovic into fourth final of season in Tel Aviv
summary: Novak Djokovic reached his fourth final of the season with a straight-sets win over Roman Safiullin in the Tel Aviv semi-finals, 6-1, 7-6 (7/3). Djokovic, 35, will face either Marin Cilic or Constant Lestienne in the final. The victory marked Djokovic's 127th final appearance, and he is seeking his third title of the season and 89th of his career.

site_title: Formula One: Norris or Russell, who will win the great British race-off?
summary: Lando Norris and George Russell are considered heir apparents to Lewis Hamilton due to their British nationality and abilities. Norris, a patient driver, has yet to claim a Formula One win despite 76 grands prix. He faces a "great British race-off" against Russell, who has also shown promise. The winner will likely succeed Hamilton as a top F1 driver, but no conclusion is reached in the article as it appears to be an introductory piece.

site_title: Football: Trossard hat-trick gives Brighton hard-earned draw at Liverpool
summary: Belgian forward Leandro Trossard scored a hat-trick, including three goals in the second half, to help Brighton & Hove Albion draw 3-3 with Liverpool at Anfield. Trossard's goals came after Liverpool had taken a 2-0 lead, but he equalized in the 54th minute and sealed the draw with a seventh-minute goal in the second half. The draw keeps Brighton fourth in the standings, four points ahead of Liverpool in ninth. Coach Roberto de Zerbi praised Trossard, calling him a "great, great player" who can do even better.

summary: Singapore is launching nearly 3,000 volunteering opportunities for youth to engage in environmental conservation, helping the elderly, and addressing sensitive issues such as race and religion. A toolkit will be made available to support youth discussions on these topics, with a digital campaign promoting inclusivity and civic discourse skills. The initiatives are part of the Forward Singapore exercise, aiming to refresh the country's social compact and build a cohesive, inclusive, and united Singapore.

site_title: Football: Jesus says he left City over Guardiola's style of play
summary: Manchester City striker Gabriel Jesus revealed in an interview that he left the club due to Pep Guardiola's style of play, which he felt was not suited to his preferred centre forward role. Jesus, 25, was unhappy with limited playing time on the flank, and after joining Arsenal, he expressed gratitude for Arteta's understanding and the team's different style of play. Jesus has made a successful start at Arsenal, scoring four goals and three assists in his first seven Premier League matches.

site_title: Aspiring HDB resale flat buyers scramble to make new plans after property cooling measures introduced
summary: Aspiring Housing Board (HDB) resale flat buyers in Singapore are scrambling to adjust their plans after the government introduced new property cooling measures. The measures, which kicked in on Friday, aim to curb the public housing market. Some buyers who were previously planning to downsize from private properties to HDB flats are now abandoning their plans altogether, citing uncertainty and changes in the market. The measures are expected to impact the resale flat market, causing buyers to reassess their options and make new plans. The cooling measures are part of the government's efforts to control housing prices.

site_title: Formula 1: Leclerc savours pole position as Verstappen fumes after fuel woes in Singapore GP qualifying
summary: Charles Leclerc secured pole position for the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix, edging out Max Verstappen by 0.054 seconds. Leclerc's teammate Carlos Sainz qualified fourth, while Verstappen's Red Bull teammate Sergio Perez took third. Verstappen's poor qualifying session was marred by fuel woes, leaving him eighth. Leclerc's ninth pole of the season will give him a strong starting position, but Verstappen must win to maintain his championship lead.

summary: Singapore has completed 14.5km of new cycling paths in Ang Mo Kio, Bishan, and Toa Payoh, expanding its Islandwide Cycling Network programme. The 7km paths in Ang Mo Kio, 4km in Bishan, and 3.5km in Toa Payoh will provide residents with better connectivity to nearby MRT stations and parks. The LTA aims to expand the network to 1,300km by 2030, with at least 25km of additional paths slated for completion by 2026.

summary: The People's Action Party Seniors Group (PAPSG) aims to support seniors in Singapore with work opportunities and quality end-of-life care. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a positive perception of seniors, who are increasingly seeking to stay active and engaged in the community. PAPSG will help seniors remain in the workforce, provide better end-of-life care, and explore assisted living options. The group will also advocate for seniors through Forward Singapore conversations, addressing concerns such as cost of living and workplace discrimination.

summary: Chelsea secured a 2-1 win over Crystal Palace in Graham Potter's first Premier League game as coach. Conor Gallagher scored the winning goal in the 93rd minute with a curling shot, following Pierre Emerick-Aubameyang's equalizer in the 38th minute. The match saw several controversy-filled incidents, including a disputed yellow card for Thiago Silva and a yellow card for manager Patrick Vieira. The result keeps Chelsea eight points behind league leaders Arsenal but gives them a game in hand, highlighting the challenge Potter faces in his new role.

site_title: Formula One: Ferrari's Charles Leclerc on pole for Singapore Grand Prix again
summary: Ferrari's Charles Leclerc secured pole position for the Singapore Grand Prix, his ninth from 17 races this season, with a time of 1min 49.412sec. Red Bull's Sergio Perez was second, and Lewis Hamilton took third. Max Verstappen, the championship leader, struggled to find pace and ended up eighth. Leclerc expressed confidence in Ferrari's chances, saying he believed they could win if they executed the perfect race. The pole position marks a promising start for Ferrari in the final race of the season.

site_title: MOM dorm operations expected to be financially sustainable
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) is launching Nest Singapore, a company limited by guarantee, to run two purpose-built dorms for foreign workers. The first dorm, in Jurong, is expected to open in 2025 and house 2,400 workers, while the second, in Sengkang West, is set to open in 2028 and accommodate 7,200 workers. The company is expected to be financially sustainable, but MOM will need to work through the details of government funding. Existing regulations, including the Foreign Employee Dormitories Act, will apply to Nest's dorms.

site_title: Formula 1: With an eye on 2023, 'silly season' for drivers heats up again
summary: The Formula 1 "silly season" has begun with six races left in the 2022 season. Max Verstappen's dominant performance has ended discussion on the world championship, shifting focus to the drivers' market. With three seats available and potential reshuffles at AlphaTauri, teams are scrambling to secure top talent, setting the stage for a busy driver transfer period ahead of the 2023 season.

site_title: #PopVultures Podcast: Avril-is-dead, Larry Stylinson and all the fandom conspiracies in between
summary: The Straits Times' #PopVultures podcast explores bizarre fandom conspiracy theories, including the death of Canadian pop star Avril Lavigne, secret relationships between One Direction members Harry Styles and Louis Tomlinson, and the alleged replacement of Chinese actor Zhang Zhehan with a body double. Host Jan Lee examines the theories and their ties to social media and para-social relationships, highlighting the spread of misinformation and distrust.

summary: A fire broke out in a fifth-floor unit in Block 451 Yishun Ring Road, Singapore, on Saturday, affecting five people who were rescued and taken to hospital. The fire is believed to have originated from a power-assisted bicycle battery in the living room. Two people sustained minor burn injuries, while five were assessed for smoke inhalation. The incident highlights the importance of following safety guidelines for power-assisted bicycles.

site_title: MMA: Controversy as Angela Lee loses bid for strawweight title in disputed decision
summary: Angela Lee lost her bid for the One Championship strawweight title to Xiong Jingnan in a disputed unanimous decision. The Chinese fighter defended her title after the five-round bout, which saw Lee show heart and grit but ultimately fall short. Lee expressed her disappointment and frustration with the decision, feeling she was more consistently pushing forward and that her defense was not scored highly by the judges. The loss marks Lee's second unsuccessful bid for the title, following a technical knockout loss in 2019.

site_title: How S’poreans illegally bring in fresh chickens from Johor, according to sellers
summary: Singaporeans are secretly buying fresh chickens from Johor, Malaysia, to bring back home, despite it being a prohibited act. Sellers in Kampung Pandan's wet markets reported that "quite a few" Singaporeans purchase the chickens, often wrapping them in newspapers and hiding them in grocery bags with vegetables. This practice is not only against the law but also poses health risks to consumers. Authorities have not taken action against these individuals, but the practice remains a concern for public health and safety.

site_title: Chicken farmers in Malaysia not raising output until end of export ban is confirmed
summary: Malaysian chicken farmers are waiting for clarity on when the export ban to Singapore will be lifted before ramping up production. The ban, which was initially set to end in July, has been delayed multiple times and now has no clear end date. Farmers are concerned about monetary losses and are considering moving their operations to Indonesia. A surplus of chickens in Malaysia means Singapore may not receive a full supply of fresh chickens immediately when the ban is lifted, potentially leading to a shortage in the market.

site_title: Child abuse video campaign launched to help pre-school teachers spot, handle cases
summary: A new video campaign launched by charity Casa Raudha aims to help pre-school teachers spot and handle cases of child abuse. The campaign addresses common concerns and provides signs to look out for, such as non-responsive or withdrawn children. Neglect cases made up the bulk of 2,141 child abuse investigations in 2021, a 63% increase from 2020. The video will be distributed to over 1,000 pre-schools, with the goal of helping to prevent the inter-generational cycle of violence and providing timely intervention to address trauma.

site_title: CCTV surveillance paid by community committees combats illegal parking in Sunset Way
summary: A community-led initiative in Sunset Way, Singapore, has successfully combated illegal parking through mobile camera surveillance. After a successful trial period, the project has been extended for another four months. The setup, which costs $1,500 a month, has reduced traffic delays and safety concerns for over 1,000 households. The grassroots volunteers, with the support of the Land Transport Authority (LTA), have seen a significant decrease in traffic violations, from three weekly reports in May and June to zero for three consecutive weeks in August.

site_title: Hackers targeted 8 Shangri-La hotels between May and July, guests' data potentially leaked
summary: Hackers breached Shangri-La hotels' databases between May and July 2022, potentially exposing guest data. The breach occurred undetected and targeted 8 hotels in Singapore, Hong Kong, and other locations. Although the exact data stolen is unknown, guest data including names, email addresses, and reservation details are likely compromised. Shangri-La is offering a complimentary identity monitoring service to affected guests and has strengthened its network security. The breach occurred during the Shangri-La Dialogue security summit, but there's no evidence it was specifically targeted.

summary: Singapore's Malay/Muslim community has made significant progress, with 99% of Malay students completing at least 10 years of education and over 90% pursuing post-secondary studies. However, a segment still faces difficulties, prompting Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to urge self-help group Yayasan Mendaki to focus on early childhood support, resolving family issues, and promoting lifelong education. The government will support Mendaki's plans to raise $40 million, matching funds raised dollar for dollar, up to $20 million.

site_title: MOM to set up new corporate entity to run 2 foreign worker dorms
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) will set up a new corporate entity called Nest Singapore to manage two purpose-built dormitories for foreign workers. The dorms, slated to begin operating in 2025 and 2028, will be built to improved standards with features such as spacious rooms, en-suite toilets, and modular space. The goal is to drive innovation and transform practices in migrant worker housing, and to foster a sense of hope and community among residents. The ministry aims to reduce the risk of infectious disease transmission and enhance liveability, while also introducing new technologies and solutions to support migrant workers.

site_title: Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital opens second nursing home to cater to Potong Pasir's seniors
summary: Kwong Wai Shiu Hospital (KWSH) opened its second nursing home in Potong Pasir, catering to the high concentration of seniors in the area. The home, which has 438 beds, will provide nursing, daycare, and traditional Chinese medicine services, as well as dementia care and social activities like dancing and taiji. The facility is part of KWSH's efforts to develop an active ageing care hub, which aims to engage seniors in the community through social and recreational activities, and is expected to reach out to at least 350 seniors in its first year.
